HEADLINE: JAPAN TELLS U.S. IT WILL NOT JOIN EMBARGO ON IRAN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
In a sharp rebuff to the Clinton Administration, the Japanese Government has told Washington that Tokyo will refuse to join its embargo on trade with Iran, undercutting the American effort to isolate Teheran economically for its sponsorship of terrorism and its suspected pursuit of nuclear weapons.
Britain, France and Germany have already told the White House that they will not join in the embargo. But because Japan is such a large customer -- it purchases 400,000 barrels of oil a day from Teheran -- its participation was crucial if the trade embargo was to have anything more than symbolic effect. 
 Statistics compiled by Tokyo indicate that Japan bought about 10 percent of its total crude oil imports from Iran last year. That makes Japan one of Iran's largest customers: Japanese companies purchase about 17 percent of all of Iran's oil production, but some of that is sold to third countries.
White House officials said they were not surprised by the decision and said they doubted that it was a direct retaliation for the American threat to impose 100 percent tariffs on Japanese luxury cars starting later this month.
"They probably would have snubbed us on this anyway," one of Mr. Clinton's senior economic advisers said today. "But clearly they are not in any mood to do us favors."
But the decision adds significantly to the strain between the two countries as President Clinton prepares to meet on Thursday with Japan's Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, before the start of the economic summit conference in Halifax, Nova Scotia.
For years Japan has differed sharply with the United States on how to deal with the Iran. Tokyo argues that efforts to isolate Iran economically or diplomatically will only worsen the country's behavior. The Administration has responded that isolation, rather than engagement, is the only way to send a forceful message.
The Administration last month expanded the longstanding embargo on direct oil imports from Iran. Under the new rules, American companies and their subsidiaries can no longer buy Iranian oil and sell it in third markets, including Japan's.
The United States first imposed comprehensive sanctions on Iran during the hostage crisis that began in 1979, but lifted them in 1981. The Reagan Administration reimposed some sanctions in the mid-1980's and banned direct imports of oil in 1987.
Oil analysts doubt that Iran's overall sales will be affected very much by the expanded embargo. As American companies are dropping their contracts, others are picking up the slack. China, engaged in its own disputes with the Administration, has said it will dramatically expand its imports of Iranian oil.
While the State Department and White House officials have tried over the last month to convince United States allies to join the embargo, officials conceded from the start that it was nearly a lost cause.
At a White House briefing today, the deputy national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said, "We will continue to urge our trading partners and the other leaders of the international economy to exercise the greatest possible restraint with respect to their trade with Iran."
Other officials, however, said they doubted that the subject would be a major topic of discussion next week when the summit meeting takes place with Japan and the largest Western industrial powers among Washington's allies -- Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Canada.
Mr. Berger said the Administration would press "specifically with respect to concessional trade programs with Iran that gives them actual export credits or other kinds of financing they could not otherwise get."
Last month, under intense American pressure, Japanese officials agreed to suspend one such program, involving hundreds of millions of dollars in aid for a dam project in Iran. But the program has not been killed; Japanese officials say only that the next installment of the aid will be "suspended" for an indefinite period.
The question of whether Japan is defying the Iranian embargo to retaliate for American trade pressure is a crucial one. It goes to the heart of American assertions that the automobile dispute is containable and will not infect other parts of the relationship with Tokyo.
Both Japanese and American officials have been at pains in recent weeks to insist that the trade issues have been "walled off" from the political and security relations between the two countries.
The reality is more muddied. Oil-purchase policy in Japan is commanded by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which is also in charge of the trade talks. As a result, it is inevitable that the decision on Iran will be interpreted by many as a warning from Tokyo.
The White House insisted today that the trade dispute has not spilled over into other aspects of Japanese-American relations. "We still believe that we can deal with these trade issues and economic issues and keep them from affecting the balance of the relationship," said Michael D. McCurry, the President's press secretary. He said the meeting next week between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Murayama "will make clear that there are remaining a range of issues upon which we cooperate closely and we will continue to cooperate closely."
In private, however, Administration officials continue to tell their Japanese counterparts that unless the trade issues are resolved, the rest of the relationship will eventually suffer. And they say the stress on other issues at Halifax next week is largely a reflection of the widely held assessment that Mr. Murayama is on his way out of office and is powerless to broker a trade deal even if he was inclined to do so.

HEADLINE: Dole and Democrat in Talks On Regulatory Overhaul

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
Eager to curb Federal regulatory powers, Senator Bob Dole is close to agreement with an influential Democratic ally on a bill that Mr. Dole may bring to the Senate floor next week, Senate aides said.
Mr. Dole, a Kansas Republicanwho, as majority leader, is the bill's most powerful sponsor, has been negotiating all week with Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Louisiana Democrat who is a longtime proponent of regulatory changes and who Mr. Dole has said might draw enough support from other Democrats to head off a filibuster. 
 Today, the negotiators circulated a draft of two central provisions from a Dole-Johnston compromise, sending other Democrats scrambling to muster opposition. The provisions, which slightly soften Mr. Dole's original version of the bill, spell out the extent to which the measure would alter existing environmental laws, and set guidelines for judicial review of regulations.
The legislation on regulations addresses one of the most intensely debated environmental changes before the Congress this year: requiring proof that major regulations would reduce the risks of pollution and that the presumed benefits are worth the cost. That would block many strict environmental rules from being issued.
The House has passed similar legislation as part of a broad package of anti-regulatory measures in the Republicans' Contract With America. The Clinton Administration and its environmental allies oppose them.
Mr. Dole, along with Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, has been meeting daily with Mr. Johnston to revise the bill, which is the next item Mr. Dole wants the Senate to debate after it completes work on a telecommunications bill, probably next week.
Mr. Roth is chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee, which unanimously approved a version of the legislation that is much milder than the version Mr. Dole sponsored.
But while the latest draft moves Mr. Dole slightly closer to Mr. Roth's version, many elements of the complex legislation remained unresolved, and its opponents today voiced doubts that the new provisions went far enough to address the concerns of the White House and environmentalists.
The White House has already begun to assemble "talking points" for Democratic senators to use next week, an effort to raise opposition to the measure even before formal debate begins. The measure could come to the floor as early as midweek but might be delayed if Mr. Dole doubts that he has enough votes to prevail.
The bill's proponents argue that too many costly environmental rules are imposed on businesses without adequate proof that the rules would reduce the risks posed by pollution, and without considering the presumed benefits versus the cost.
Opponents counter that many environmental rules are intended to provide a margin of safety to the public, and that health concerns outweigh economic considerations. They say the bill will roll back many of the environmental gains of the past 25 years.
For months, competing versions of the bill have been moving haltingly through the Senate, leaving Mr. Dole with a familiar conundrum as the legislative leader who is also running for President: whether to accept a moderate version that could pass easily, like Mr. Roth's proposal, or to fight a protracted battle for his own version, which is enthusiastically supported by business groups who could provide him important political support.
Although Mr. Dole doubtless could get enough Republican support for a simple majority in favor of his version, Democrats had threatened a filibuster, so he needs 60 senators to cut off debate and force a vote.
The version of the bill sponsored by Mr. Dole was approved by the Judiciary Committee despite strong opposition from the committee's Democrats and the Administration.
Rather than accepting the version passed by the Governmental Affairs Committee, which many business lobbyists do not think goes far enough, Mr. Dole has been seeking to draw a few Democrats his way.
But it remains to be seen whether Mr. Johnston can bring along many moderate Democrats, let alone liberals who are itching for a fight on the environmental front.
The compromise version that circulated today was not embraced by environmentalists.
"We are extremely troubled by it," said Greg Wetstone, legislative director of the Natural Resources Defense Council.
The compromise said that the bill's cost-benefit tests for environmental and health regulations "shall supplement, and not supersede" provisions of bills like the Clean Air Act and the Clean Water Act.
But it also contained detailed instructions for Federal agencies to take costs and benefits into account in setting rules, adding a new ingredient to decisions that are now made principally on the basis of protecting the public's health.

HEADLINE: Business Digest

 BODY:

Treasury Market Slumps For Third Day in a Row
Prices of Treasuries took their worst beating since September amid speculation that the Japanese might curtail future purchases of United States Government securities. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.72, up from 6.61 percent on Thursday and 6.53 percent at the beginning of the week.
Some analysts said the rumor might have served as an excuse for investors to sell in a market that has run too far, too fast on anticipation that the economy will continue to slow. No one saw the trading as a sign of a major new direction in the market. [Page 36.]
 
The stock market turned sour, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 34.58 points to 4,423.99, as traders saw further evidence of an economic slowdown but without the prospects of a cut in interest rates that would help lift sagging corporate earnings. The traders were so troubled by the outlook that they ignored surprisingly good news on the inflation front. For the week the Dow was down 20.4 points. [37.]
 
Share prices plunged in Tokyo to the lowest level in nearly three years, amid discouragement over the economic outlook and the Government's rescue plan for the banking industry. The Nikkei fell 398.12 points, or 2.6 percent, to 15,044.18, its lowest close since Aug. 19, 1992. The latest development to pull down stocks was the release of the central bank's quarterly survey of Japanese business sentiment, which found that businesses had become more optimistic, despite the strong yen. That seemed to depress the market, analysts said, because it would deter the central bank from cutting interest rates to stimulate the economy. [34.]
 
The dollar dropped sharply on a rumor that large Japanese investors were selling United States securities. It recovered much of the loss as traders concluded the rumor was groundless. [42.]
 
Producer Prices Flat, With No Sign of Inflation
Inflation at the producer level disappeared again in May, reflecting the slowing economy, as price declines for food and energy products offset increases for other types of finished goods, Government figures showed. [36.]
 
Tokyo Rejects Iran Embargo
The Japanese Government has told Washington it will refuse to join the embargo on trade with Iran, undercutting the Administration's effort to isolate Teheran economically for its sponsorship of terrorism and its pursuit of nuclear weapons. [1.]
 
Lotus's Employees Cautioned
Lotus Development has directed employees not to buy or sell shares in the company until the board has announced its position on I.B.M.'s takeover offer. [35.]
 
Microsoft Damns the Torpedoes
Despite a Justice Department investigation, Microsoft said it had no intention of altering its plans for entering the computer on-line services business in August. [35.]

A Rockefeller Center Roadblock
A Federal bankruptcy judge blocked an attempt by Rockefeller Center Properties, the real estate investment trust that holds a $1.3 billion mortgage on Rockefeller Center, to wrest control of the property from its bankrupt owners. [46.]
 
ITT Completes Sale of Units
ITT said it had agreed to sell the remaining portions of its ITT Financial subsidiary for about $5.5 billion, completing a process it announced in September. [35.]
 
Steinway Agent Raided in Japan
Raiders from Japan's Fair Trade Commission confiscated documents at the Tokyo offices of the local sales agent of Steinway & Sons, on suspicion that the agent had prevented rivals from importing pianos made by the New York company. [34.]
 
Books From Rock and Roll
Brian Roylance and his Genesis Publications are turning from facsimiles of classic novels and historic documents to rock and roll, preparing to sell limited editions of books by George Harrison and Eric Clapton and about the Rolling Stones and Jimi Hendrix. The books sell for hundreds of dollars each. [11.]

HEADLINE: 2 Nutrition Programs Win Crucial Backing in Senate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 9

 BODY:
The chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee broke with fellow Republicans in the House today and rejected the notion of giving the states responsibility for the school lunch program.
The chairman, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, also turned down pleas from some Republican governors who want Washington to replace food stamps with direct cash payments to the states. 
 The opposition of so influential a figure on both issues doomed whatever chance the governors might have had of winning control of the food stamp program. And it significantly reduced the chances that the Federal Government would relinquish the school lunch program.
After weeks of negotiations with members of his committee, which has jurisdiction over both programs, Senator Lugar said he had concluded that there was little support for turning them into block grants to the states.
Republicans in the House have already won its approval for replacing the school lunch program with block grants. But they concede that they have lost the battle for public opinion under withering fire from Democrats, who have attacked the House majority as cruel to children.
If any senators ever supported the idea, Mr. Lugar said in a talk with reporters today, "their ardor was dulled" by the spectacle of the ferocious House debate over the issue. Mr. Lugar said some Senate Republicans strongly supported the school lunch program and had told him, "Tamper with that at your peril."
But Mr. Lugar, a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, said he supported giving the states new flexibility to run nutrition programs, and he proposed food stamp cutbacks intended to save $16.5 billion, or 11 percent of projected spending, over five years. A welfare bill passed by the House in March would make deeper cuts, slicing projected spending on food stamps by $20.3 billion, or 14 percent, over five years.
The Clinton Administration welcomed Mr. Lugar's proposals, saying they were more reasonable than those approved by the House. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said, "I've always known that Senator Lugar was a strong supporter of basic nutrition programs that insure needy people are fed."
Mr. Lugar's proposals come as farm lobbyists and advocates of child nutrition programs square off in a fight over how to apportion cuts in the budget of the Agriculture Department, which runs both crop subsidy programs and feeding programs.
Senator Lugar proposes to cut child nutrition programs by $2 billion over the next five years, in addition to his $16.5 billion in food stamp savings. He said he expected farm lobbyists and some Republican senators to seek deeper cuts in those programs as a way to avoid big cuts in subsidies for crops like cotton, wheat, rice and corn.
The Senator said he expected his proposals to win a formal endorsement from the Agriculture Committee next week. He will then offer them as an amendment to a sweeping welfare bill due to reach the Senate floor later this month.
For the last 10 months, Republicans have extolled the virtues of block grants, lump-sum payments of Federal money to the states for loosely defined purposes like nutrition assistance or child care.
Mr. Lugar said he was inclined a few months ago to support a block grant for food stamps. But today he said, "I changed my mind." He said he now believed that food stamps provided states invaluable assistance in responding to recessions and population growth caused by the migration of people from one region to another.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, ranking Democrat on the Agriculture Committee, praised Mr. Lugar for protecting nutrition programs within the fiscal constraints imposed by the Republican Congressional leadership. But Mr. Leahy said the proposed cuts in food stamps were too deep.
Mr. Leahy also said he was distressed at the rivalry between farmer and anti-hunger groups, which have for decades worked together, supporting each other's programs. "I see that coalition breaking down, becoming almost jungle warfare," he said.
Robert J. Fersh, president of the Food Research and Action Center, an anti-hunger group, said, "Senator Lugar has moved to preserve the current structure of the food stamp and child nutrition programs, and that is extremely good news for anyone concerned about hungry people."
The budget blueprint approved by the Senate last month calls on the Agriculture Committee to cut $28 billion from its programs over five years and suggests that no more than 20 percent of the savings should come from commodity programs. That implies that at least $22.4 billion of the savings will come from food stamps and nutrition programs -- $4 billion more than Mr. Lugar proposed.
Mr. Lugar said senators were free to propose deeper cuts in nutrition programs when the committee takes up a comprehensive bill to reauthorize farm programs later this year.
Mr. Lugar proposed these changes to save money in the food stamp program:
*Beneficiaries 18 to 50 years old with no dependents would generally be required to work or participate in job training at least 20 hours a week.
*The formula for calculating monthly food stamp allotments would be revised to cut benefits about 3 percent from the amounts prescribed under current law.
*The standard deduction used in calculating a household's eligibility for food stamps, now $134 a month, would be reduced to $124 and frozen at that level for five years.
*Federal and state payments to help families with home heating costs would be counted as income in determining eligibility for food stamps.
In addition, Mr. Lugar proposed small reductions in Federal subsidies paid to schools serving lunch or breakfast to schoolchildren. Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research and advocacy group, said these cuts were "very modest, ranging from a fraction of a cent to a couple of pennies per meal."

HEADLINE: Getting on a Transplant List Is the First of Many Hurdles

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
Mickey Mantle's swift progression from deathly ill patient to liver recipient made the organ transplant process look easy.
But for the 4,659 Americans waiting for livers and the thousands more waiting for hearts, lungs, kidneys, intestines and pancreases, the hurdles they must leap are so many and, often, so onerous, that the wonder is that many get organs at all. 
 Ethicists and transplant surgeons said they were not questioning whether it was appropriate for Mr. Mantle to have gotten a new liver so quickly -- he was the sickest person in his geographic area with blood type O and so was first in line when a liver from a donor with his blood type became available. But, they said, the real trick is to get on the transplant list in the first place.
These experts said that whether a patient gets on a list for an organ depends very much on the person's social circumstances and psychological profile, how rich he or she is and how well he or she is able to manipulate the organ transplant system.
Mr. Mantle checked into his local hospital, Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas, on May 28, complaining that his stomach hurt. On June 6, after diagnosing liver cancer in addition to his pre-existing hepatitis and cirrhosis, his gastroenterologist put him on a waiting list for a liver transplant. A donor materialized late in the day on June 7. At 4:30 A.M. on June 8, Dr. Robert Goldstein, a transplant surgeon at Baylor, began operating to give Mr. Mantle a new liver.
But for most people the process, which can take days to months, is more prolonged.
The first requirement for getting a transplant is simply having a doctor. "A lot of folks don't have any contact with the medical system," said Dr. Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Bioethics at the University of Pennsylvania, who is writing a book about liver transplants.
Once a patient sees a doctor, it is up to that doctor to decide whether to refer the patient to a medical center for a transplant. Doctors weigh factors that could determine compliance with medical care after a transplant, like whether the patients have friends and family to support them and whether they are substance abusers or are mentally ill or mentally retarded.
Dr. James L. Levenson, a professor of psychiatry, medicine and surgery at the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, said that although private doctors are the first gatekeepers, the criteria they use have never been systematically studied.
If the patient's doctor decides to refer the patient to a transplant center, the next hurdle is demonstrating an ability to pay. "You have to pass the critical wallet biopsy," Dr. Caplan said. "Let's say I find out I need a liver transplant. I go to the medical center and before I get any tests done, the business office talks to me. These transplants are very expensive. It costs $10,000 to $20,000 for them even to evaluate you, and you may have to travel to get to one of these places."
It costs an average of $300,000 for the transplant and the first year of care, including anti-rejection drugs, and patients must show that their insurance will pay or that they can somehow come up with this money.
Joel Newman, who is a spokesman for the United Network for Organ Sharing, a Richmond nonprofit group that, under a Federal contract, allocates organs nationally, said that if patients cannot assure a transplant center that their insurance will take care of their costs, they are often required to put down a deposit before their evaluation can begin.
Another factor is the ability to pay for anti-rejection drugs. Many insurance companies will not pay, or will not pay the full amount for these medications, which can cost $1,000 or more a month and must be taken for the rest of a patient's life. Medicare, which, by law, must pay for kidney transplants, is phasing in a new policy that will extend the period it pays for anti-rejection drugs for kidneys from one year to three years. But, after that, patients are on their own.
Dr. Jimmy Light, director of transplantation at the Washington Medical Center, said that the center tries to find creative ways to help patients come up with money to pay for anti-rejection drugs, but that if the patients cannot show they can purchase the drugs, they cannot have transplants.
John Mitchell, treasurer of the Transplant Foundation in Richmond, said his tiny organization tries to help those in dire need of money to pay for anti-rejection drugs. "It's a problem, I'll tell you," he said.
The group raised $15,000 last year through such fund-raisers as art auctions and bowling marathons, he said, but it was nowhere near enough money to meet the demand. Mr. Mitchell said he knows of many transplant doctors who dip into their own pockets to help patients pay for the drugs. But he also knows of at least one woman who died after having a heart transplant because she did not have enough money to pay for her medications.
Even if patients have enough money to qualify for a transplant, the transplant center must also deem them good candidates psychologically and socially. The criteria vary widely. In a survey he conducted in the late 1980's, Dr. Levenson found that the criteria used vary according to organs. Heart-transplant programs are the strictest, he said, kidney programs the most lenient, and liver programs are in between.
Among the factors that transplant centers said they weighed as contraindications are not having a spouse or relative or close friend for support, having suffered a recent death or loss of someone close to you, being a felon, having a history of criminal behavior, having a family history of mental illness, having schizophrenia, suffering from depression, having attempted suicide, being demented, having a personality disorder and being mentally retarded.
But a patient rejected by one program might be accepted by another. For example, 54 percent of liver programs said they always exclude demented patients, 23 percent said that dementia weighed against a patient, but nearly 20 percent said it was irrelevant.
Dr. Levenson also found variations in the listing of alcoholics and drug addicts. For liver transplants, most centers require that the person demonstrate abstinence for some period of time, usually from six months to a year, before the transplant. Mr. Mantle had undergone treatment for alcoholism a year and a half earlier, and had been off alcohol since then, according to a Baylor surgeon.
But insurance programs often impose their own criteria, with some refusing to pay altogether for a person with alcoholic liver disease and others imposing longer periods of abstinence than the medical center requires.
Dr. Levenson said that "justice would seem to call for the same criteria everywhere" in excluding patients from transplant lists. But, he added, "the countervailing argument is that we don't have enough experience and enough data to know exactly what the right answer is."
Savvy patients can choose the centers most likely to accept them, Dr. Caplan said. They also look for centers that have short waiting times. Organs are allocated within local regions, and median waiting times for livers, for example, range from 18 days to 443 days, depending on the organ procurement organization and where it is located.
Mr. Mantle, who was in Region 4, was in an area with some of the shortest waiting times for livers. New York, Region 9, has the longest waiting time. Mr. Newman said that some affluent patients, who can afford to go through the evaluation process more than once, get listed at several different centers simultaneously, increasing their chances of getting an organ.
The option of picking and choosing a transplant center is not available to everyone, however. Patients who belong to health maintenance organizations are often restricted to a short list of centers.
A very few patients gain yet another advantage in seeking an organ. A donor's family can designate them as the recipient. Mr. Newman said a woman in Washington donated her heart to her minister, who was on a waiting list, but not at the top. The minister got the heart. Last year, a family in Tennessee donated their daughter's heart to her father, who lived in Michigan. The family of a man in Tampa, Fla, who was a Ku Klux Klan sympathizer, instructed that his organs not be given to blacks and the local organ procurement agency agreed to the condition, arguing that to do otherwise would be to deprive needy patients.
With all its variables -- subjective, economic and regional -- coming into play, it is hard to argue that the transplant system is fair, Dr. Caplan said. But, he added, that should be no surprise. "Those who tell me they are surprised to hear that maybe someone with money or celebrity or high political office may have an easier time getting on the transplant list must have slept through the past year," he said, alluding to the nation's health care debates.

HEADLINE: Block that Raid, Mr. McCall

 BODY:
While passing its budget this year, the New York State Legislature came up with some exotic fiscal gimmicks to pay for expenses. Few were more brazen than the lawmakers' raid on a $360 million pool of money called the Supplemental Reserve Fund. The State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, has the authority to try to block the raid in court. He should do so.
The case bears scrutiny because New York City may be tempted to try something similar to reduce its own budget deficit. The state and city have many contingency funds on their books, set aside for emergencies or expenses that accrue over time, like pension costs. These funds should always be restricted to their original purposes and not raided to balance the general budget. The Supplemental Reserve Fund was established more than two decades ago to pay for future extra benefits for people already retired whose pensions have eroded over the years because of inflation. 
 Earlier this year, the Legislature approved a bill using the fund for that purpose for state retirees. It also directed New York City to make the same kind of payments for its retirees, even though the city had no comparable fund. Gov. George Pataki vetoed it at the urging of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani.
This week, the Legislature moved again to draw from the state reserve to supplement pension benefits, but only a part of the state reserve. Most of the reserve, it decreed, would be used to meet regular costs in the budget. This time Mr. Giuliani muted his protests because the law did not require New York City to come up with its own money for pension supplements until 1997, and because the Mayor feared that more state budget cuts would cost the city more state aid.
Now Mr. McCall is faced with a dilemma. He is the sole trustee of the fund. If he goes to court to block its use for the state budget, he will not only throw the state into deficit, he will kill the pension supplement for retirees, many of whom deserve help. But a lawsuit to prevent the raid will also send a signal that the state must not resort to gimmicks even for worthy objectives. The choice is clear. Mr. McCall should sue.

HEADLINE: Save the Job Corps

 BODY:
The Federal Government finances a dizzying array of education and training programs. Chairman Nancy Kassebaum of the Senate Labor Committee will propose a bill next week to combine 70 or so training programs into a block grant, giving the money to the states to help low-skilled or unemployed workers. Dismantling may make sense for marginally effective programs, but it makes no sense for the Job Corps, a uniquely successful program for disadvantaged youths. The Kassebaum bill is expected to preserve the Job Corps, but risk its future by turning it over to the states to run.
The Job Corps serves more than 60,000 youths between the ages of 16 and 24 at 110 centers around the country. The program is expensive, about $1 billion a year, or about $20,000 per participant. That is much higher than other programs, but consider the reasons. The Job Corps is a residential program, providing enrollees room, board, counseling, social skills instruction, education, vocational training and job placement services. Getting youths out of destructive home environments is the key. Over 80 percent of Job Corps enrollees are high school dropouts. Nearly half are on welfare and less than half read at better than an eighth-grade level. 
 The results justify the expense. A study from the 1980's showed that those who completed the Job Corps program boosted their earnings by 15 percent, and were much more likely to complete high school and attend college. Graduates worked longer, received less welfare and committed fewer crimes. Seventy percent of Job Corps graduates got jobs, joined the military or enrolled in educational programs. The study estimated that for every dollar the Federal Government spent on the Job Corps, society got back almost $1.50 in benefits such as additional output or lower prison expenditures. These numbers need to be updated, but there is no evidence they no longer hold.
The Job Corps cannot be run well by the states. It trains and places students for a national, not local, job market. As a Federal program it gives enrollees the chance to enter the center that best matches their career plans. Besides, one Federal bureaucracy makes more sense than 50 state bureaucracies. The Job Corps runs on a competitive model; private corporations compete to operate training centers, and Washington has not been loath to replace lax managers.
Critics point to centers with high costs, dropout rates and crime. There are problems. But the critics overlook the crime-prone population the program serves, and the enviable record of steering these kids into careers. High dropout rates reflect in part the program's demanding standards and swift exit for those who breach the rules.
States will not spend lavishly to aid their poorest residents. Nor do they have a good track record running training programs for the disadvantaged. The Republicans who took over Congress preaching cost-effective government should not disable the one Federal training program that works.

HEADLINE: Taiwan's President Tiptoes Around Politics at Cornell

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: ITHACA, N.Y., June 9

 BODY:
His countrymen wanted to hear him talk about the symbolism of his landmark visit to the United States, the significance of the trip for Taiwan's international image, the effect of it all on American-Chinese relations.
But President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan, while sounding a few familiar themes about Taiwan's rapid economic expansion and steady democratization, preferred to talk about the things one might expect to hear at a class reunion: How he missed his days as a doctoral student in agricultural economics at Cornell University here. What he had been doing since his graduation in 1968. And how he appreciated the chance to come back. 
 "It has been a long and challenging journey, with many bumps in the road, yet my wife and I are indeed very happy to return to this beloved campus," he told an overflow crowd of 5,000 today, speaking in English with a heavy Taiwanese accent.
"The long, exhausting evening in the libraries, the soothing and reflective hours at church, the hurried shuttling between classrooms, the evening strolls, hand in hand" -- he recalled them all. "So many memories of the past have come to mind, filling my heart with joy and gratitude."
He did not need to say much more to get his point across. For all the buildup surrounding the first Taiwan leader to visit the United States since diplomatic ties ended in 1979, Mr. Lee would have probably been content just to stand at the lectern and smile. It was his mere presence that meant a thousand words, a diplomatic breakthrough culminating years of lobbying and foreshadowing what Taiwan hopes will be a bigger international role.
Mr. Lee emphasized that his was a private trip, but its importance was not lost on the more than 300 journalists who traveled here from Taiwan. They analyzed his every word and gesture in a reporting free-for-all befitting a papal visit.
Nor was its importance lost on several American officials, who either heralded Mr. Lee with a red-carpet arrival at the Syracuse airport on Thursday or ventured up to this rolling, beautiful campus today. On Thursday, it was Senators Alfonse D'Amato of New York, Jesse Helms of North Carolina and Frank Murkowski of Alaska; today, it was Representative Gary Ackerman of Queens.
Even so, caution and restraint were the watchwords today as every detail of Mr. Lee's visit -- from the canceled afternoon news conference to his wife's garden photo session on the campus -- seemed tightly scripted to insure that an already-controversial trip would not become more so.
China has been livid that Mr. Lee has been treated like, well, a president, of what they consider a renegade province. It has retaliated against the United States by canceling several official delegations and postponing talks on technology sales.
Today, Beijing issued its strongest condemnation yet of the trip. The official New China News Agency said: "The issue of Taiwan is as explosive as a barrel of gunpowder. It is extremely dangerous to warm it up, no matter whether the warming is done by the United States or by Lee Teng-hui. This wanton wound inflicted upon China will help the Chinese people more clearly realize what kind of a country the United States is."
The controversy did not escape the Cornell campus. Outside the Newman basketball arena where Mr. Lee spoke today, more than 200 pro-Taiwan independence and pro-Beijing demonstrators lined opposite sides of the street, forming a phalanx through which bewildered and bemused alumni had to pass to attend the lecture.
Mr. Lee's talk was interrupted almost two dozen times by thunderous applause, in marked contrast to the international reception Taiwan has normally gotten since its expulsion from the United Nations in 1971.
He hinted at how frustrating Taiwan's lack of international standing has sometimes been.
"We sincerely hope that all nations can treat us fairly and reasonably, and not overlook the significance, value and functions we represent," he said. "Some say that it is impossible for us to break out of the diplomatic isolation we face, but we will do our utmost to demand the impossible."
Taiwan, officially known as the Republic of China, and China, or the People's Republic of China, each claim to be the legitimate government of China and insist that all countries pick a side. In 1979, the United States switched from Taipei to Beijing. Since then, Taiwan has become increasingly isolated from the international community; now, only 29 countries have official ties with Taiwan.
But Taiwan has lobbied its unofficial friends tirelessly with its big bank account and smooth diplomacy, resulting in several visits by Mr. Lee to Southeast Asia and the Middle East.
Last fall, Cornell invited Mr. Lee to come deliver a lecture, but the State Department refused to issue a visa. This year, Cornell asked again -- with the help of a Republican Congress that passed a nearly unanimous resolution supporting Mr. Lee's visa application. The Clinton Administration yielded to the request.
Mindful of souring relations with China, American officials asked Mr. Lee -- and the hundreds of Taiwanese-Americans who flocked here from hundreds of miles away to catch a glimpse of him -- to keep things as low-key as possible. But the feeling here was that no matter what China might do, Taiwan has done wonders for its image, as has Mr. Lee.
There has been some speculation in the Taiwan press, for instance, that Mr. Lee timed his visit to increase his popularity in anticipation of next year's presidential elections, the first time the President will be directly elected by the people.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 12, 1995, Monday

HEADLINE: Russia and Ukraine Settle Dispute Over Black Sea Fleet

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 9

 BODY:
The leaders of Russia and Ukraine signed an agreement today that should conclude their bitter dispute over the Black Sea Fleet, improving relations between the two most important countries of the former Soviet Union.
The issue of the old Soviet fleet and naval base at Sevastopol, Crimea, has done much to fan nationalist tensions between Moscow and Kiev since the Soviet Union died in 1991. 
 It is a measure of how much the world has changed that the two Presidents, Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Leonid D. Kuchma of Ukraine, had their meeting at an American-run hotel, the Radisson-Lazurnaya, in the Russian Black Sea resort of Sochi.
An obviously pleased Mr. Yeltsin told reporters that the signing was an important one that "finally put a period on this question once and for all."
Mr. Kuchma was more careful, as is his nature, adding, "Although some detailed issues remain, I consider this question solved in general." The main thing, he said, "is that Ukraine and Russia really agreed on strategic partnership."
But the fleet, which is both small and old, with the newest of the 635 vessels built 17 years ago, was always more of a political issue than a strategic one. A newly independent Ukraine has been reluctant to sacrifice its sovereign rights to a Russia that has generally patronized it.
For a time, the vessels flew the flags of both countries, but since Moscow paid the bills, commanders nearly always obeyed Moscow's orders, creating a dangerous series of mutinies and fistfights.
The matter was further complicated by the weird history of Crimea, an area with a large ethnic Russian population, resorts and a naval base, that was handed to Ukraine as a meaningless gesture of friendship in 1954 by the Soviet leader Nikita S. Khrushchev. The new border lost its meaninglessness after the breakup of the Soviet Union, and Russian nationalists regularly demand that Crimea be returned to Russia, along with the fleet and the base.
Many previous agreements on the issue have fallen apart, but today the two countries agreed in principle to split the fleet; Russia is then to"purchase" most of the Ukrainian share, ending up with 82 percent of the vessels.
Russia will continue to use the base at Sevastopol, paying rent to Ukraine, mostly in the form of energy supplies and debt forgiveness. But Ukraine will also be able to use other parts of the large base in Sevastopol for its small fleet, which has become Ukraine's navy. Exactly where Ukraine's main base will be is to be announced, as the two countries had decided to leave it out of the final document.
Mr. Kuchma, an ethnic Russian from eastern Ukraine, defeated Ukraine's first President, Leonid D. Kravchuk, in a bitter election campaign that centered on Ukraine's economy and relations with Russia. Since taking office, Mr. Kuchma has strengthened himself by standing up for Ukrainian sovereignty while nearby countries, like Belarus, have tried to move closer to Moscow.
Mr. Kuchma has also introduced real economic reform and budget discipline, earning a loan agreement from the International Monetary Fund and praise from Washington. He has pushed through the ratification of an important arms control treaty, has gotten Moscow to reschedule much of Ukraine's $3 billion debt for gas supplies and, most important perhaps, has forced his own legislature to grant him broader powers to appoint the Government, issue decrees and pursue economic change.
Recently, he used the example of Russia's crushing of a secessionist region, Chechnya, to disband a secessionist legislature that had its own president in Crimea. While sensitive, Mr. Kuchma's strong action to keep Ukrainian sovereignty over Crimea is regarded as an important backdrop to the signing of today's deal.
For Russia, the gains are also considerable. Moscow intends to reassert its power in the Black Sea as a counterpoint to Turkey, which has its own ambitions in Central Asia. Russia is also pushing oil companies to build a new oil terminal at Novo rossisk, a Russian port on the Black Sea, rather than building new pipelines through Turkey. Even a small, decaying fleet will give Russia a presence.
Dmitry Neverov, writing in the newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets, noted that in 1990, in the Black Sea, there were only two large naval exercises, by Bulgaria and Turkey. In 1994, however, there were seven: four by Turkey and three NATO joint exercises.
"One could interpret these figures as testimony of increased mutual trust in the Black Sea, if one wished," Mr. Neverov wrote. "But speaking the truth, one should speak of the increased presence of NATO forces in an area of Russia's vital interests."

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's Choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
COLD SNAP: Stories, by Thom Jones. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) A collection that turns a merciless, ironic gaze on the organic trap called life, in which spiritual beings -- humans -- are forever in jeopardy of mere chemical accidents or biological insults.
 
COMRADE CRIMINAL: Russia's New Mafiya, by Stephen Handelman. (Yale University, $27.50.) A reporter's account of post-cold-war Russia as a lawless land at the mercy of organized crime.
 
DEEP RIVER, by Shusaku Endo. (New Directions, $19.95.) Mr. Endo's novel follows soulless modern Japanese travelers to the Ganges, where they encounter the humanity and suffering of a few who have found faith.
 
THE HAUNTED LAND: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism, by Tina Rosenberg. (Random House, $25.) A moral, political and psychological investigation, by a wise journalist, of four post-Soviet societies struggling with their conduct under the old regimes.
 
THE INFORMATION, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $24.) Mr. Amis's cool and brilliant novel is sustained throughout by the corroding, corrupting envy of an unsuccessful novelist for a successful novelist who is also his best friend.
 
IN THE TIME OF THE AMERICANS: FDR, Truman, Eisenhower, Marshall, MacArthur -- The Generation That Changed America's Role in the World, by David Fromkin. (Knopf, $30.) F.D.R. stars in a historian's incisive account of the men who made the 20th century what it is.
 
THE LOVE LETTER, by Cathleen Schine. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Helen is 42, capable and loves Edith Wharton. Johnny is 20, acne-spotted and -- like, excellent! -- a big Tom Robbins fan. In this comic novel they fall in love.
 
THE MAN WITHOUT QUALITIES, by Robert Musil. Translated by Sophie Wilkins and Burton Pike. (Knopf, two volumes, boxed, $60.) A magnificent new version of the unfinished and unfinishable novel by an Austrian contemporary of Proust and Joyce whose acknowledged greatness has always exceeded his acknowledged readership.
 
RETHINKING AMERICA, by Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $25.) An examination of America's economy and prescriptions for repairing it to accord with a changed world order, by a journalist who does not fear big subjects.
 
THE ROMANTIC GENERATION, by Charles Rosen. (Harvard University, $39.95.) A professor and pianist offers a fond, accessible analysis of the works of Schumann, Mendelssohn, Chopin and others during the period from 1827 to 1849. Mr. Rosen furnishes musical illustrations on the accompanying compact disk.
 
WHISTLER AND MONTESQUIOU: The Butterfly and the Bat, by Edgar Munhall. (Frick Collection/Flammarion/Abbeville, $45.) A profusely illustrated biographical account of the encounter between the eccentric American painter and the foppish French nobleman that resulted in one of Whistler's masterpieces.

HEADLINE: GARDENING

BYLINE: By ALLEN LACY; Allen Lacy writes and publishes Homeground, a quarterly gardening newsletter, and is the author of "The Gardener's Eye" and "The Garden in Autumn."

 BODY:
MANY American publishers feel that the time is right for gardening books. The demographics are encouraging -- the baby boomers who enriched the authors and publishers of volumes on jogging a decade ago have moved farther into maturity. With leisure, comfortable incomes and settled ways, the theory goes, they should be ripe to take up gardening. Thus, hardly a day goes by that some new book on the subject doesn't appear in my mailbox.
Sadly, many -- perhaps the majority -- of them are early candidates for a garage sale, especially those dominated by the alphabet, following a formula that says start with abelia, end with zinnia and along the way throw in some information about the height and spread of plants, the colors of their flowers and how tolerant they are of nasty weather. 
 But it would be a grand mistake to generalize from what is merely typical, because every season seems to produce a small but choice crop to read and reread with pleasure. Joe Eck and Wayne Winterrowd's book A YEAR AT NORTH HILL: Four Seasons in a Vermont Garden (Little, Brown, $29.95) is a prime example. It is toothsome -- passionate, reflective, inspiring, endlessly quotable and filled with good humor and humanity.
Mr. Eck and Mr. Winterrowd, partners in North Hill Garden Design Associates, have been tending their five-acre jewel in southern Vermont since 1977. It is in a climate best described as challenging: Zone 4 -- only 100 frost-free days a year. I have not (yet) visited North Hill, but I have friends who have and who, when it comes to gardens, are on the picky side. The consensus is that North Hill is one of the best private gardens in North America.
"A Year at North Hill" is a book to match the garden. It joins that tiny handful of fine texts that are also literature -- Canon Ellacombe's "In a Gloucestershire Garden," Vita Sackville-West's "Joy of Gardening" and almost anything by Elizabeth Lawrence, but especially her "Gardens in Winter."
This volume delivers precisely what its title promises, a month-by-month account of a year (April to March) in the life of a garden and of the people who dreamed it into being and tend it obsessively. "It has been many years since -- if ever -- we thought of gardening as a pastime," they say. "We are actually writing about our life, or at least the hugest chunk of it." The authors have such contagious passion that I suspect a nongardener who picks up the book and starts reading could end up longing to grow Myosotidium hortensia, the spectacular but difficult Chatham Islands forget-me-not they grow in their lower greenhouse, or perhaps the Rosa pimpinellifolia. A reader would want to see it "pretty and clean, but laced with frost" in the autumn, as it is in Mr. Eck's photograph.
North Hill, like most wonderful gardens, is a retreat, a private place set apart from the public sphere, but the authors understand that within its confines the entire world is also present. History may not obviously intrude, but it is an educational and always tempting inference, because every plant has its story, whether it is known or not. This applies to everything from the onions and other vegetables that were domesticated in preliterate times to exotica discovered within the last decade -- for example, that strange and wondrous biennial Angelica gigas, a rangy plant, all knobs and knees, with half-domed flower clusters of the richest purple, first brought from South Korea, the authors say, in 1985. Mr. Winterrowd and Mr. Eck are devoted plantsmen, and it shows on every page of their book as they celebrate the rare and the uncommon. But they also know how to value and praise commoner plants, like lilacs and daffodils.
One thing puzzles me: Who wrote what? Both of the authors contribute to Horticulture magazine, and Mr. Winterrowd is the author of "Annuals for Connoisseurs," yet I can't find seams in this text; it is written in a single voice.
A writer's mind and a photographer's eye seldom inhabit the same body. I know, because I stood next to Cynthia Woodyard, one of America's very best garden photographers, as we took pictures of the same scene in a garden in Maryland. We used the same camera, same lens and same film. The difference when our slides came back was obvious. As one of my sons put it on comparing them, "You know, Dad, you can always tell a pro."
That said, I must also confess that the British writer, film maker and photographer Vivian Russell wears all of these hats successfully, judging by MONET'S GARDEN: Through the Seasons at Giverny (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, $32.50). It is the handsomest book yet on the celebrated Impressionist's restored gardens at Giverny. The photos are as sumptuous and blowsy as the garden itself, with its wild profusion of plants, its wide gravel walks spilling over with nasturtiums beneath turquoise arches luxuriant with climbing roses in pink, buff, yellow and crimson. Everything seems chockablock at Giverny, as Nicotiana sylvestris fights orange cosmos, black-eyed susans and rose campions to struggle up to its aerial mastery.
Someone once may have used the word "subtle" to describe this garden, but if so, he didn't have his goggles on right. There's no more sophisticated color theory in practice here than in a kindergartener's crayon box. In an amiable democracy of color, magenta asserts its right to raise its voice alongside those of orange, bright yellow and scarlet. Ms. Russell's camera gets right into the fray, showing us what is, in fact, something of a glorious, jumbled mess. (The eye of the painter and of the garden designer may also turn out not to inhabit the same body.)
This book gives us something its rivals do not: a verbal and pictorial account of what's behind the scenes when the gardens are closed to the public. We are told, for example, that the soil here is pretty punk. At the end of each October, the garden shuts down for five months. All of its annuals and many of its perennials are ripped out and carted off for composting, and then work on the soil begins, with massive infusions of compost, manure and sulphate of potash to feed the explosion of growth in the year ahead. Judging from Ms. Russell's photographs of this work in progress, one thing is clear: by no stretch of the imagination could Giverny be called a low-maintenance garden.
THE relations between gardeners and landscape architects can sometimes be a bit testy. Gardeners thrive on plants, the more the better. Landscape architects tend more to love "bones" and permanent structures -- staircases, paths, pools. James van Sweden and Wolfgang Oehme are landscape architects known for their use of ornamental grasses and sturdy, fairly carefree, tough perennials, things like Sedum telephium (Autumn Joy) and Rudbeckia maxima (Goldsturm). Some have called their style "the new American garden," though it owes a hefty debt to the German plantsman Karl Foerster, who worked much earlier in the century. Mr. van Sweden and Mr. Oehme have designed quite a number of private residential gardens for well-heeled clients, but some of their best works have been public commissions, including the German-American Friendship Garden in Washington and Hudson River Park in Manhattan's Battery Park City.
These influential designers have probably made some gardens without water features, but the number must be small, as Mr. van Sweden's GARDENING WITH WATER (Random House, $40) shows clearly. A compendium of his work in collaboration with Mr. Oehme, it presents a convincing case for the proposition that no garden is quite a garden unless there is water in it -- from a little terra-cotta birdbath in a small city garden to an elaborate concoction of effervescent fountains, swelling waterfalls and still ponds, made to work on a grand scale by plumbing and electricity.
Gardeners with water in mind and ready to take the plunge, as it were, would do well to spend some time with this book, both for inspiration and for practical advice about what to plant, the needs of fish and how to keep the water clean and free of algae.
Among America's cities, Charleston, S.C., Boston and Philadelphia vie for first place as having the longest and richest horticultural history. It could be argued that Charleston takes the prize, thanks to its mild winters, which make it possible for such subtropical plants as hibiscus, oleanders and gardenias (named for Alexander Garden, an 18th-century Charleston physician) to grow outdoors year-round. Today the small, enclosed gardens of the city's historic district delight the tourists essential to the economy of the region, and also provide inspiration to gardeners like me, who are not of the lawn persuasion and believe that something there is that loves a wall.
Garden lovers who haven't yet gone on pilgrimage may be persuaded by GARDENS OF HISTORIC CHARLESTON (University of South Carolina, $39.95), by James R. Cothran, to plan a visit. A South Carolina native and a landscape architect and city planner in Atlanta, Mr. Cothran pleasantly surveys Charleston's long horticultural traditions. He discusses many of the most common plants that are characteristic in its gardens, like banana shrub, creeping fig and cassia. He also describes several small private gardens in such a way that readers will long for invitations from their owners to come calling. Mr. Cothran's book is appealingly illustrated with botanical prints, drawings and color photographs.
As we move west, the landscape changes dramatically. After a very cursory introduction to the history of gardening in the Golden State -- by the fourth paragraph the gold rush has arrived -- Nancy Goslee Power, a West Coast garden designer, gets down to her main business in THE GARDENS OF CALIFORNIA: Four Centuries of Design From Mission to Modern (Clarkson Potter, $50), written with Susan Heeger. She describes 30 gardens established from the Spanish colonial era to the present, and the result can only make gardeners with plots in less favored climates, like mine in southern New Jersey, long to travel, if not to move. In addition to such magnificently extravagant (and now open to the public) gardens as Filoli and the Huntington Botanical Gardens, Ms. Power explores much more personal and intimate ones up and down the state. Her own, a charmer on a lot in Santa Monica just 50 by 160 feet, was designed over a 10-year period. For a book of this kind, photographs are of course essential, and Mick Hales's are sumptuous.
Five acres in southern Vermont that add up to a gardener's Eden; Monet's Giverny, a point of pilgrimage for American tourists in France every summer; water gardens sometimes on a scale to impress a Renaissance pope; lush gardens in California -- all partake of the heroic, aspiring far beyond what most of us dream of, much less find practical to contemplate or feasible to accomplish.
Judith Moffett's HOMESTEAD YEAR: Back to the Land in Suburbia (Lyons & Burford, $22.95) is cut from different cloth entirely, for it is gentle in tone and modest in aim. Like "A Year at North Hill," it is an account of the events within a single year, but the garden is a suburban backyard near Philadelphia. Influenced by the idea of "homesteading," Ms. Moffett, a part-time college teacher and science-fiction writer, limited her teaching in the spring of 1992 and took a sabbatical for the fall with the intention of doing what she could to make the household self-sufficient. She and her husband cleared out the one-acre backyard and built raised vegetable beds. They enlarged the patch, kept hives of bees and raised ducks to eat.
It was a year's experiment only; indeed, Ms. Moffett and her husband now live in Salt Lake City. There is no elaborate dream here, and certainly no grand theory, but there is an appealing, plain honesty and some food for thought. The students I teach seem to think increasingly that food comes from the grocery store and that meat is born in polyfoam trays covered in transparent plastic film. Our poultry comes to us courtesy of Mr. Purdue or Mr. Tyson, and if I have any students who have ever killed, plucked and drawn a chicken they have kept quiet in class.
We need modest books that suggest what might happen if we turned our backs on the supermarket and tried as far as possible, for a time at least, to raise our own food with our own hands. "Homestead Year" does a nice job with these homespun realities.
 
 
 
DIRT UNDER HER NAILS
 In her new book, DEEP IN THE GREEN: An Exploration of Country Pleasures (Knopf, $24), Anne Raver may be writing most winningly about inoculating peas, or how to hear the squeak-squeak when digging clams, or about the ridiculously gregarious kitten Mr. Grey, alleged mouser. Or about the stuff in her parents' attic at the farm in Maryland, the old family place that none of the children want to keep. Or about trees in Manhattan. Or how to recognize a bufflehead duck simply by the way he flies out of the water. But at heart she isn't writing about these things. She is writing about herself. Nothing wrong with that. She comes across as an attractive person, not unlike us -- terrified to go up on a ladder to take off the storm windows and put on the screens, finding it hard to come to terms with our fathers, struck by the dissonance between rural Vermont and suburban New York, where we get the finger for going slow in a go-slow zone on Long Island. Ms. Raver writes about gardening for The New York Times, and this collection of 58 columns, all of which appeared in this paper or in her previous venue, Newsday, makes up an agreeable and varied garden of essays. They are nicely written. Fun to read. Sad. Heartwarming. Sometimes even useful. But make no mistake. Even though she is disguised as a garden columnist, this is only episodically a book about gardening. It's about life as seen by Anne Raver. Gardening is only the principal preoccupation, or maybe the organizing principle, of her life. I have no doubt that were she not interested in gardening but, say, in radio-controlled model airplanes, she could (and probably would) write a book fundamentally like this one. CHRISTOPER REED

HEADLINE: The Paradox of NPR

BYLINE: By David K. Shipler; David K. Shipler, a former correspondent for The New York Times, won a Pulitzer Prize in 1987 for "Arab and Jew: Wounded Spirits in a Promised Land."

 BODY:

LISTENING TO AMERICA
Twenty-five Years in the Life of a Nation,
as Heard on National Public Radio.
Edited by Linda Wertheimer.
Illustrated. 438 pp. Boston:
Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.95.
 
THE SOUND AND THE STORY
NPR and the Art of Radio.
By Thomas Looker.
421 pp. Boston:
A Richard Todd Book/
Houghton Mifflin Company.
$24.95. 
 IN theory, National Public Radio shouldn't work. Financed mostly by private donations, it also relies on Federal subsidies that ought to subject its news coverage to the nefarious influence of Washington politicians. As every schoolchild must know, a free press -- which means a press free of government -- is essential to a democratic system; certainly there have been plenty of examples around the world of censored, biased, government-controlled media. Soviet radio, television and newspapers were cheerleaders for a decaying system, burying economic failures, environmental catastrophes and ill-fated foreign adventures like Afghanistan. If a Soviet leader had made the equivalent of President Boris Yeltsin's absurd declaration last month that no military action was taking place in Chechnya, Moscow television would have reported it dutifully, without showing pictures to the contrary.
Even in the democracy of Israel, Government television has at times contributed to widespread ignorance by toning down news of Palestinian suffering under Israeli occupation. When the right-wing Likud bloc was in power, anguished Palestinian voices rarely got on the air.
By contrast, NPR has avoided biases that government might appreciate and reward. Its two news-and-feature programs, "Morning Edition" and "All Things Considered," shame the commercial networks with more intelligent and less editorial reporting than private broadcasters provide. This anomaly persists even as Republicans threaten to eliminate funding for public broadcasting, a move that heightens the value of three recent books that display NPR's virtues.
Linda Wertheimer and Robert Siegel, two of the hosts of "All Things Considered," have each edited an impressive volume of transcripts of various touching, analytical, whimsical, historic, gripping interviews and reports. Ms. Wertheimer's "Listening to America: Twenty-five Years in the Life of a Nation, as Heard on National Public Radio" covers NPR's entire existence, from antiwar demonstrations to the Republican victory last November; Mr. Siegel collected "The NPR Interviews: 1994," which appeared last fall and includes the best of 1993 from Richard Avedon to Archbishop Desmond Tutu. And in "The Sound and the Story: NPR and the Art of Radio," Thomas Looker, a producer who has worked as a writer and reporter for NPR, goes into the studios for a meticulous examination of the personalities and processes that have revived radio's artistry, once lost beneath the gloss of television.
The most telling message of all three books is not addressed explicitly, but for anyone with the patience to read attentively, it reverberates throughout the texts of the broadcasts. It is this: The liberal political bias that some conservatives imagine simply isn't there. Nor is there any accommodation to the White House or to Congress, no matter what the party in power.
"Listening to America" includes a prescient and devastating report by Mara Liasson on the candidate Bill Clinton's tendency to shift positions -- an early indication of his inability to stand by difficult decisions. There are transcripts of stories that fainter hearts, dependent on government funding, might have shunned: Nina Totenberg's scoop (along with Newsday) on Anita Hill's charges against Clarence Thomas, Daniel Zwerdling's vivid account of the dissembling that led to the space shuttle Challenger's explosion, Brenda Wilson's caustic description of the opulence of the Reagan inaugural celebrations. "The poor, if they attended, were in disguise," she remarked.
In a foreword to "Listening to America," Bill Buzenberg, vice president for news at the network, rebuts the myth that NPR's audience consists of mostly well-to-do liberals. Polling, he says, shows that just over half of NPR listeners hold only a high school diploma and almost a third have college degrees. Nearly half have household incomes of less than $40,000. Just over one-third describe themselves as conservatives, just under one-third as liberals, and the rest are middle-of-the-road.
Perceived distortions by NPR are not political, Mr. Looker writes in "The Sound and the Story." They are created by the mechanics of technology and news gathering. "Experts" who are chosen for interviews are those with "particular verbal skills," Mr. Looker observes. "A whole range of ideas and opinions -- a vast region of experience and understanding -- eludes articulation in a two- or three-minute exchange, in the case of television, or a four- or five-minute presentation, in the case of NPR. Typically, discussions that add historical perspective or that argue more than two or three alternatives to a question will not fit into such shortened frameworks."
THE real struggle at NPR, Mr. Looker notes, is between journalism and art -- between the growing trend toward harder news and the more reflective use of sound to conjure up a sense of scene. Here, fine radio can be as rewarding as literature, for the listener must work with his imagination, in which "received language and sound mingle with inner speech; each individual consciousness tumbles through pirouettes of metaphor and meaning . . . achieving a special kind of intimate knowledge."
Newt Gingrich ought to add these books to the occasional reading list that he distributes among colleagues, but he won't. They would muddy the conservatives' purity of argument in the eternal American debate over how much government we should tolerate.
This country has always nurtured a healthy distrust of government, which can be good for democracy unless taken to the extreme by bomb-making militias. "Society is produced by our wants, and government by our wickedness," Thomas Paine wrote a couple of centuries ago. "Society in every state is a blessing, but government, even in its best state, is but a necessary evil; in its worst state an intolerable one." With that as ideological background, NPR emerges as a remarkable model of government's creative interaction with "society." It's too bad that none of these books examine how this is accomplished. Since NPR works better in radio than private enterprise does, it challenges some venerable American doctrine and needs to be preserved.
