LENGTH: 2449 words

HEADLINE: The Urban Gollfer

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTINB 

 BODY:
With its verdant fairways and stately trees, Van Cortlandt Golf Course in the northwest Bronx shimmers like a slice of summertime heaven. But here, as on the city's dozen other municipal courses, heaven comes with a decidedly New York inflection.
 Korean grocers arrive before sunrise to get in a round before work, Spanish (including appropriate curse words) is common, and one of the many clubs within the club is made up of black golfers. Homeless people live in a tunnel they have furnished that connects the second and third fairways, and neighborhood children sometimes dart onto the 16th fairway to steal balls. Tournaments are both frequent and maniacal: outings sponsored by nearby Irish bars are outdone only by the police and firefighters' get-togethers, which sometimes degenerate into games of bumper carts. 
 This is big-city golf played in a big-city context. Last year, a contractor illegally dumped tons and tons of construction debris on the 17th fairway, killing 90 trees. Two years ago, a morning threesome arrived at the 14th green to find a dead man dangling from a maple tree. A year or two earlier, a golfer had his cart stolen; he retrieved it a half-mile away and finished the round. Corpses are occasionally found on the opposite side of the lake in front of the clubhouse. Freeways built in the 1950's slice through the course. Low-flying planes drop toward La Guardia Airport like street pigeons.
 But golfers -- a handful in limousines and multitudes on the No. 1 subway line -- keep streaming to Van Cortlandt, which celebrates its centennial this year. Golf reference books confirm that it is the oldest municipal course in the nation, a surprisingly tradition-laden place: its old-fashioned wooden lockers beneath gaping skylights were filmed in the movie "Wall Street" to connote a sort of clubbish timelessness. In January, Golf magazine named Van Cortlandt one of the "golfiest" places in the United States. When the Three Stooges played the course a half-century ago -- an event commemorated by a picture on the clubhouse wall -- they were serious, serious, serious.
 This year has been the busiest at the course in more than a quarter- century. Rounds -- which because of the freeways slicing through the course -- can be 4, 14 or 18 holes -- are running about 60 percent above preseason estimates by the American Golf Corporation, the California-based company that operates Van Cortlandt and six other city courses. Early projections were for 15,000 rounds to have been played by now, far fewer than the actual total of 24,000. In fact, the pace is brisker than in 1969, when a record 55,000 total rounds were played.
Indeed, municipal golf in New York City, which the National Golf Foundation calls one of the country's most golf-deprived areas, is rising like a smartly struck wedge shot. Total rounds played on the 13 city-owned courses last year exceeded 850,000, up from 535,822 in 1980. In part, this is because the city's links are just about the only game in town: the only private golf club in the city is Richmond County Country Club on Staten Island.
 The downside of this popularity: golfers almost always need a reservation to tee off. Reservations cost $2 per player, in addition to greens fees. Seven foursomes are booked an hour, with an eighth slot reserved for walk-ons.
But in a metropolitan region that the golf foundation ranks 289th of 302 areas in per capita golf holes, it is worth the wait to addicted floggers. And the price is surely right: greens fees for city residents at all municipal courses are $15.50 on weekdays and $17.50 on weekends, $6 less than for those without resident cards, which cost $6 a year. By contrast, public courses in Westchester County and New Jersey charge nonresidents at least $35 in greens fees. (Westchester residents, by contrast, pay $12 on weekdays and $15 on Sundays.)
Most important, the convenience offered by many city links is dazzling. "You can be out on the course by 6, done by 9 and back in the city showered and shaved by 9:30. Boom!" said Larry Wasserman, a lawyer preparing to tee off the other morning. "Where else can you do that?"
The 75-acre Van Cortlandt course is in sprawling, 1,146-acre Van Cortlandt Park -- a craggy wonderland of horse trails and old farmhouses, forests and wetlands that was one of the great Bronx parks, along with Bronx Park and Pelham Bay Park, acquired by the city in the late 1880's.
The course was the brainchild of a group of well-to-do golfers in Riverdale, who had hoped to persuade the city to build them a private country club. Instead, the city built a nine-hole public course on a rolling patch of wild carrots and hay at a cost of $624.80. The New York Sun on May 5, 1895, reported, "The park links should be popular with business men, clerks and mechanics, when they learn the benefits of golf."
And so it was. In less than five years, the course was expanded to 18 holes. By 1913, about 700 golfers a week were playing. City officials raced to capitalize on the sport's popularity, building or acquiring 12 other courses by the 1930's. Because of its easy accessibility, Van Cortlandt became the glamour destination for celebrity duffers. Babe Ruth, Joe Louis, Sidney Poitier and Willie Nelson have played there.
But golf's local popularity peaked in the 1950's and 60's, followed by a slide that was accelerated by the city's population decline in the 1970's. The quality of the courses, which were maintained by the Department of Parks and Recreation, sank, too, especially during the fiscal crisis. By the early 1980's, the number of golfers had dropped to half the level of the late 1960's. Greens kept getting smaller because of inadequate maintenance, even though the department work force was widely regarded as bloated.
But in 1979, when Gordon J. Davis, then the Parks Commissioner, suggested selling the course in Forest Park, Queens, he was greeted by a hailstorm of protest from Queens golfers, parks officials said. By the early 80's, the city's golf courses were running $2 million a year in the red. The solution: in 1983, private concessionaires were hired to run them.
This private enterprise approach has turned the city's golf courses around financially; last year, they raised $1.8 million for municipal coffers. Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern calls it one of the earliest and most successful privatization initiatives in city government. "The operation of golf courses," he explained, "was one area not cut out for socialism."
As the private companies took over, attendance climbed. In part, Mr. Stern says, this was because maintenance improved. But it also reflects a rising tide of interest in golf: for the fourth straight year, the number of courses built in the United States has increased, and nearly one of eight Americans now plays golf, according to the National Golf Foundation.
Participation has broadened to include women, who account for 37 percent of the two million Americans taking up the game each year, the golf foundation says, as well as an array of ethnic groups. The number of black and Hispanic golfers is growing, and more and more Japanese and Koreans are enthusiasts of the city's courses.
Public courses, not private clubs, are benefiting from golf's resurgence. The golf foundation reports that the number of public courses has grown by 40 percent over the last 20 years, while private clubs have declined by 8 percent. Fewer than half of the duffers are white-collar professionals, it says, with 40 percent blue-collar or clerical workers. Shouts of "Yo!" are as likely to resound on municipal links as "Fore!" Blue jeans far outnumber knickers.
But even with this growth in interest, it is easier to play on the city's courses than it used to be. In the early 1960's, courses were so congested that golfers would arrive at 2 A.M. at Van Cortlandt and other popular public courses to throw their names in a lottery for tee-off times.
Once a player has teed off, golfers say, he or she is likely to encounter one of the bigger annoyances of the city's courses -- hackers whose plodding play holds up all behind them. Interminably. And, invariably, they do not know enough to let players behind them play through.
A typical comment came from Kirk Michel, an investment banker who likes to play at Van Cortlandt before work. "I tell anyone who's not a golfer to come after 12 on weekends," he said. "Because I don't want them in my way."
But even with its share of novice slowpokes, Van Cortlandt carries a serious look this year, as rain and special centennial grooming have combined to give the course its best appearance in memory. There is fresh sand in the bunkers, and fairways and greens feel like plush carpet.
But the truest charm of the course is in its legends, its characters, its special jokes and gentle breezes. For the old-timers and those who have heard their stories, Titanic Thompson, a legendary golf hustler, is as alive as the rambunctious boys catching bullfrogs at the 12th hole.
This is a public course that staged a Halloween costume tournament five years ago; the Bride of Frankenstein played 18 holes in a wedding gown. It is a place where trees have been planted to commemorate dedicated golfers, some of whom had their ashes strewn over the course.
A recent Monday was a typical day at Van Cortlandt. About 6 A.M., Arty Appell, the 75-year-old short order cook in the clubhouse, was holding court with the regulars, one of whom asked for two eggs on a roll. "I'm too tired," Mr. Appell sighed lazily. "Maybe when you wake up," the regular chirped.
The cook, a scratch (no handicap) golfer and self-acknowledged hustler, makes fun of all sartorial pretensions, accusing a man in plaid shorts of imitating Chi Chi Rodriguez. He points to pictures of Willie Mays and other celebrities over the grill. "I never had an opportunity to beat them out of some of their money," he says with more than a twinge of regret. "But some of my buddies got into a few of their pockets."
Mr. Appell makes it clear that Van Cortlandt does not exactly aspire to be Augusta National. "If the starter says you're going with these or those two guys, you just go and play with them," he says. "It don't make no difference what color or creed or nothing they are."
He tells of his own tournament, among the many held each summer. Usually, the proceeds go to somebody's bachelor party, but no golfing buddy is heading down the aisle this year, so orphans in Ireland will benefit.
Outside the clubhouse, a crowd gathers. The golfers scratch their heads and try to figure out how to help an injured baby skunk, just one example of the wildlife that increasingly roam the course. A family of coyotes regularly visits the fifth green, deer are spotted occasionally and snapping turtles just a tad smaller than Toyotas lurk along the wooden walkway between the ninth hole and 10th tee. Crows, wild turkeys and pheasants are frequently spotted.
A threesome of friends assembles: Vito DiBenedetto, a retired banker; George Innes, a retired transit worker, and Joe Stanton, an unemployed iron worker. At the first tee, they greet the starter, Al Luciano, a retired newspaper delivery man who volunteers in sending golfers to the first tee in return for free greens fees. It was Mr. Luciano whose cart was stolen as he teed off on the 14th hole. He chased it to the Kingsbridge Armory on Jerome Avenue, where he recovered it, though the thief escaped. Mr. Luciano returned to play the final four holes.
The three comrades wave to Andy Rodriguez, who two years ago discovered a dead man who had hanged himself on the hole he was playing, the 14th. Mr. Rodriguez is 84, does not use a cart and plays every day of the year. Behind him are four Korean Air pilots, who keep clubs in a locker and take turns using them during layovers in the city.
On other days, Mr. DiBenedetto, Mr. Innes and Mr. Stanton volunteer as marshals, patrolling the course in an effort to speed up play. Mr. Stanton ticks off the important things for golfers to remember if they hope to avoid a queue of muttering players behind them: Do not wait too long between shots, cut down on practice swings and give up looking for lost balls after a few minutes. "Some of these guys examine their putting lines like they were pros," he groused. "You'd think they were putting for a birdie instead of a 10 or 11."
Golfers keep arriving. There is Tae Chun Ko, a Korean-American, who owns a pizzeria on Madison Avenue and is finally finding time to relax after raising two daughters in a new land. There is Jeff Willbanks, a bartender, who yearns to celebrate his 35th birthday with a 35 for the first nine. And there is Edith Harrington, who lives within walking distance of the course and forgets her troubles when she takes out her clubs.
Maguire Neblett, a 34-year-old Manhattanite, who makes her living styling models' hair, is a good example of golf's growing popularity. She never played until three years ago, and now tees off at Van Cortlandt three times a week. One day a week, she volunteers to tend the gardens around the clubhouse, in return for free golf. The course was where she met a man she may marry. They agree on at least one thing: the first tee would be a great place for the ceremony.
"Golf has become my passion," she said.
Bill Young, by contrast, is a proud emblem of Van Cortlandt's past. He is 80 and cannot play much anymore because of arthritic hands. But he recalls every millisecond of his two holes-in-one at Van Cortlandt, and can look at the course today and visualize the grand old holes, before the Major Deegan Expressway wove weird discombobulations in 1953. Mr. Young recalls the old Scotsmen who gave the course its early flavor, and its first Japanese golfer, Jimmy Yoshita, who came to America in 1919.
Despite Van Cortlandt's relatively short length, he insists it is not easy, not by a long shot. "You think it's a straight putt and it will leak off an inch or two," he said. "There are subtle breaks here and there."
Perhaps the wisest golfer at Van Cortlandt is one of the most talented women who plays there, Way-Sun Oh, a nurse at Columbia University. She says golf is so expensive in her native Korea that the city's public courses "seem like heaven."
She says she has never tried to better her scoring, which is good enough to have won her the club championship at the Mosholu Golf Course, another municipal course in the Bronx. "It just happened," she explained. Her approach to the game is equal parts fatalism and adventure.
"Wherever the ball goes, I enjoy," she says. "A different story starts each time it lands."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
How Do the Bulls Think? With a Smile

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
It's been a long time since it was a good idea to be bearish on the American stock market. In fact, the market has never before gone this long -- since 1990 -- without a single decline of 10 percent or more.
The following was written by a professional investor who is, as you might suspect after reading it, quite bearish on the stock market. He has been, in his words, "around for more than one market cycle." 
 He has lately lost more than a little money through selling technology stocks short -- that is, betting that they will decline. In fact, tech stocks have been market leaders.
The author titled it, "Things I've Learned in the Last Year." Whether for reasons of modesty or to avoid humiliation, he does not want his name used.
 FLOYD NORRIS
 
A STRONG economy is good for earnings, which is good for stocks.
A weaker economy lowers interest rates, which is good for stocks.
Share repurchase programs shrink the available float, which is good for stocks.
New share issuance raises book value and infuses liquidity, which is good for stocks.
Acquisitions promise synergy, which is good for stocks.
Divestitures rid companies of losers, usually past acquisitions, which is good for stocks.
A weakening dollar increases our competitiveness, which is good for stocks.
A strengthening dollar would encourage foreign investment in the United States, which is good for stocks.
Capital gains tax cuts favor equity over debt, which is good for stocks.
No capital gains tax cuts help reduce the deficit (since no one ever cuts spending), which is good for stocks.
The collapse of Mexican and other developing markets induces American investors to invest their funds in the United States, which is good for stocks.
Recovery in developing markets creates stability, which is good for stocks.
Trade conflicts with Japan show our resolve, which is good for stocks.
Resolution of trade conflicts shows unity, which is good for stocks.
Mutual fund investors, who historically have invested heavily at tops -- as in American and foreign bond funds, biotech funds and emerging market funds -- will be correct in American equity funds, because this time is different.
Mutual fund managers were right to retain the lowest cash reserves in 20 years at a time when stock yields are at a 70-year low.
All-time high price-to-book values, which once were considered signs of market excess, now are deemed irrelevant because huge write-offs have depressed book values. But it is O.K. to ignore the higher earnings that stem from the absence of depreciation from the written-off assets, thereby artificially depressing reported price-earnings ratios.
Fund managers have discovered the perpetual motion machine. Concentrating new investments in stocks one already owns pushes up their price and enhances performance, thereby attracting new money that can be invested in the same stocks, thereby pushing their prices still higher, etc.
The market always mysteriously rises at the end of the day.
Momentum is forever. More analysts recommend Intel at $115 than at $60.
Everyone will know when to sell, and there will be willing buyers at that time.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Is It Time to Refinance? Homeowners, Start Your Calculators

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
AS mortgage rates have fallen the last few months to tantalizingly low levels, many people have begun wondering whether they should refinance.
"We are getting a lot of calls about refinancings, and more activity, too," said Bruce R. Lublin, president of the Homerica Mortgage Corporation in Harrison, N.Y. "If rates fall further or even stay where they are, I can see a little boomlet occurring. It's probably already happening." 
 Preliminary figures for the week ended June 2 showed that 24 percent of the mortgages made nationally were for refinancings, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, a trade group in Washington. That portion has more than doubled in two months.
The refinancing surge, however, is nowhere near the crush in 1992 and 1993, when 30-year fixed-rate mortgages dipped below 7 percent and some adjustable-rate mortgages had initial rates as low as 3 percent. Back then, more than 70 percent of all new mortgages were refinancings.
Although rates are not scraping rock bottom as they were then, they are still low by historic standards and sufficient reason for homeowners to take notice, said Keith T. Gumbinger, a vice president at HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J. The average adjustable rate is now 5.85 percent, only 1.7 percentage points above its all-time low of 4.15 percent on Oct. 29, 1993. (Adjustable-rate mortgages came to the scene in 1980.) And the fixed rate, at 7.71 percent, is less than 1 percentage point above the 6.87 percent of Oct. 15, 1993 -- the lowest since 1965.
"Rates have also gone down so far, so fast recently that the drop has virtually erased the rise in interest rates that occurred over the past year," Mr. Gumbinger said. The recent high on a fixed-rate loan was 9.41 percent on Dec. 16, whereas adjustable loans peaked a little later, at 6.90 percent on Jan. 20, according to HSH.
In the short term, the percentage of refinancings probably will not go much higher, mainly because many homeowners who took out high-rate loans in the 1980's have already refinanced. A few, however, could not do so in 1992 or 1993 because of credit or other problems, and those people are now jumping at an unexpected second chance.
More common on the refinancing front are homeowners who took out one-year adjustables a couple of years ago and who have watched their rates rise above today's fixed rates.
Thomas and Francine Rinaldi of New Rochelle, N.Y., recently prepaid their one-year adjustable mortgage. Its rate started at 5.25 percent two years ago but was scheduled to hit 8.75 percent on Aug. 1. And the loan could have risen to 10.75 percent next year, because the rate was permitted to rise two percentage points a year and six percentage points over the loan's life.
In its place, the Rinaldis took out a "10-1" mortgage, a hybrid loan that is fixed for 10 years and that adjusts annually thereafter for 20 years. Hybrids, which usually have fixed rates for 5, 7 or 10 years, are technically adjustable loans. Their rates, while higher than on one-year adjustables, are lower than on mortgages fixed for 30 years. The Rinaldis' new loan came in at 8 percent and required no points, or upfront fee.
"We wanted to lock in a lower rate, and also take some money out," said Mr. Rinaldi, a food service equipment salesman who also restores houses. "If we hadn't taken the money out, our payments would have dropped a bit, maybe $50."
The original $155,000 mortgage had $154,000 remaining, but as part of the refinancing, the couple took out $39,000, which they plan to use to buy another house; they also borrowed $6,000 to cover closing costs. With improvements, their two-family home has appreciated in value to $299,000 from the $175,000 paid in 1993. Their new $199,000 mortgage costs $2,052 a month, including taxes and insurance, up from $1,669.
Deciding whether to refinance can be a cumbersome chore. For starters, many of the rules of thumb about when and how to do it have become outdated. The old formula was called "2-2-2," meaning refinancing was practical if borrowers had been in a home at least two years, intended to stay at least two more years and refinanced at a rate at least two points lower than their current mortgage rate. But that applied when people were refinancing from one fixed-rate loan into another fixed-rate loan and when refinancing fees were high.
A couple of calculations now serve as a better guidepost. Homeowners should add up how much they would pay in closing costs, fees and points on a new loan. Then they should figure out how much their monthly payments would drop. (Savings depend on the size of the loan and the interest rate. The payment on a $100,000 mortgage refinanced to 7 percent from 8 percent will decline by $69.70, to $699.21 from $768.91.) By dividing the monthly savings into the total cost, homeowners determine how long it will take for the transaction to pay off -- and then must decide whether they will keep the home that long.
Homeowners taking cash out in a refinancing need to do essentially the reverse. They should calculate how much more they would pay each month and multiply that by how many months they intend to keep the loan. Then they can compare that added cost with the lump sum received.
To make refinancing even more appealing, some lenders are offering hybrid mortgages at what they call "zero cost." In exchange for a fee equal to about three-eighths of a percentage point on the new loan, the borrower pays no points, appraisal fees, document preparation charges, credit report fees or other fees.
For people sitting on a high-rate mortgage or an adjustable that is headed up, it looks like time to get out the calculator.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
This Stock Market Sails a Sea of Calm

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
THE last few weeks on Wall Street may have seemed pretty turbulent to many investors, with the Dow industrial average swinging up -- and down -- by 80 points or more in a single day.
By most measures of volatility, however, 1995 has been fairly typical. And the last three years have been practically placid. This calm makes a future storm more likely, though, and that means investors should think about how to weather it. 
 To be sure, some sectors have been more volatile. Semiconductors, casinos, autos, footwear and computers all had average annual stock price swings of more than 20 percent during at least one of the last three years, according to a recent report by David L. Babson & Company, an investment counselor in Cambridge, Mass. And some stocks have swung that much in a single day. When I.B.M. made its $3.3 billion bid for the Lotus Development Corporation on Monday, for instance, Lotus stock rose nearly 90 percent, to $61.4375.
The broad indexes, however, have not budged nearly as much. During the last 50 years, the average annual range of the high and low on the Standard & Poor's 500 has been about 18 percent, said H. Bradlee Perry, a consultant for Babson. In 1995, though, the spread so far has been only 16 percent. And for 1992, 1993 and 1994, the high and low points deviated only 10 percent, 8 percent and 9 percent, respectively -- the lowest three-year level of volatility in 50 years.
The Dow has been just as quiet. Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst with Birinyi Associates, a research firm in Greenwich, Conn., noted that the Dow had not closed up or down more than 2 percent on any day this year, and the average spread between the daily highs and lows had been only 1.68 percent for 1995. Since 1980, the average has been 1.90 percent.
What does all this calm mean for the stock market? "Chances are that it is going to get more volatile," Mr. Perry said. "If you were worried about volatility in '92, '93 and '94, you haven't seen anything yet. Just the fact that we have a pretty enthusiastic market right now increases the risk factor of that."
Mr. Perry also said that future volatility could be amplified by the millions of people in mutual funds. These investors, he said, can instantly move in and out of the market with toll-free telephone calls. Then there is the market's tendency to react to news, no matter how arcane. For example, last September the Dow surged 58.55 points -- or almost 1.5 percent -- after a low regional inflation report by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, a drop in jobless claims and a rise in business inventories.
Indeed, with 1995 bumpier than the three preceding years, the market may already be leaving the calm behind. For investors, that signals both opportunities and dangers. Mr. Perry said long-term investors should not try to jump in and out of stocks but should stay abreast of volatility "so they don't act irrationally when the pattern changes."
They should also make sure that their stocks are realistically valued. "The most vulnerable stocks in a sharp market downturn are usually those that are the most popular and are overpriced," Mr. Perry said.
And if the market falls, he added, "Investors should consider stepping in and buying bargains."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND;
The Blockhead's Final Bow?

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON

 BODY:
For 15 years, the Sideshows by the Seashore and the Coney Island Museum, on the Boardwalk at West 12th Street, have offered the boardwalk stroller a chance to see the very last "10-in-1" sideshow in the country. There are an escape artist and a snake charmer and eight other acts, including Mike Wilson, "The World's Most Heavily Tattooed Man," and "The Human Blockhead," who promises to bang nails into his head and "live to laugh and joke about it."
But the sword swallower may well be on the unemployment line this summer, and the Human Blockhead may have to find work in the construction business. Arts funds were withdrawn, the lease has expired and the museum owes $20,000 in rent and is being evicted. 
 And it looks as though McDonald's may be thinking of moving in: agents came to look in May, the same day the eviction papers were served. A spokeswoman, Laura Vega, confirmed that McDonald's was looking at sites in Coney Island, though she did not say where.
"It's kind of ironic," said Dick Zigun, the museum's director. "In helping to gentrify this boardwalk, which was ridden with gangs, arson and violence in the 70's, we actually helped make it safe for places like McDonald's to set up here."
Until recently, Coney Island U.S.A., the nonprofit organization that owns and operates the sideshow and museum, was receiving over $30,000 a year in city, state and Federal grants that helped preserve an almost extinct part of American entertainment history. "P. T. Barnum began sideshows in this country in the 1840's in lower Manhattan," Mr. Zigun said. In the 1860's, they started in Coney Island and grew to their heyday in the 1920's, with the Dreamland Circus Sideshow and its 300 midgets in a Midget City.
Without this aid, Mr. Zigun said, the show cannot go on. "We have a staff of 12, a 45-minute show and a 150-person capacity," he said. "It's still theater, and that is a hard sell in today's world. If we're a wacko arts group, we have to be."
But Sherry Simon, a spokeswoman for the National Endowment for the Arts, said Mr. Zigun's application "did not show sufficient artistic merit and excellence, the two criteria for the grant."
Mr. Zigun says the museum, which also runs the annual Mermaid Parade on the Boardwalk, has plenty of merit. "We've brought honky-tonk chic to the Boardwalk," he said. "That brings tourists, crowds and hipsters, and the neighborhood appreciates it."
Fans can attend a Sideshow of the Stars benefit on June 26 at Irving Plaza. It will be a traditional 10-in-1 sideshow, but with several twists. The actress and model Karen Duffy will be in the Blade Box, and a talk-show host, Jon Stewart, will sit on the belly of Indio -- who will be lying on a bed of nails.
Mr. Zigun hopes to pay the back rent: he says he has no quarrel with the landlord and hopes to regain his lease. And in any case, he doesn't want to just hand over the building, on which he says the government has already spent $120,000. "It is McDonald's that is insensitive to the neighborhood and the art world," he said. "In essence, this has become the freaks from the sideshow against the clown from the hamburger stand." COREY KILGANNON

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EASTERN QUEENS;
The Blighted House Next Door

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII

 BODY:
Moline Street in Bellerose is a well-kept block of neat, single-family homes, a picture of residential pride. Then there is the house at number 89-29.
Over the years, the ceiling in the back of the city-owned house had been chewed through by rodents and blown away by wind. The gutters were breeding grounds for pigeons and rodents, whose carcasses were strewn throughout the house. 
 After years of complaints from neighbors, the city Department of Health cleaned up the dilapidated, Colonial-style home two week ago. The city now plans to renovate the home and sell it, but neighbors, angered by the unpleasant memories of filth and what they call municipal ineptitude, want it torn down.
"It's a potential hazard," said Sally Martino-Fisher, the district manager of Community Board 13. Despite the cleanup, neighbors said, a moldy stench still wafts through the cracks and pigeons still flutter about, leaving droppings. That, Ms. Martino-Fisher said, means the house could be a breeding ground for disease, and she contends that it is structurally unsound.
In March, E. Randy Dupree, assistant commissioner of the Department of Health, declared the house a public health hazard." but that declaration was rescinded after the home was cleaned up. The Department of Buildings, which inspected the house on Wednesday, said despite problems -- the bathroom floor is in danger of collapsing into the kitchen, a rear wall is damaged and the chimney is out of plumb -- the house may be safely rehabilitated. And the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which owns the home, said its guidelines call for rehabilitating city-owned properties deemed structurally sound.
"There is a severe shortage of housing in New York City," said Mara Neville, a spokeswoman for the housing agency. "Our policy is that in buildings where they are not structurally unsound, we will try to renovate them so families can live there."
Ms. Neville said the department took over the house in 1990, when the owner died and his daughter could not pay thousands of dollars in back taxes. She said the daughter rented the house from the department and paid rent of about $360 a month until the end of March. Because the woman had been paying rent until then, the department had no authority to order a cleanup, Ms. Neville said, but neighbors said the house had been unoccupied for years.
"H.P.D. inspectors drove by the house all the time and they never get out of the car to go inside to see what it was like," said Patricia Fallacaro, who lives next door. "It has no business owning houses." JANE H. LII

HEADLINE: New Isolationists Weaken America

BYLINE: By Arthur Schlesinger Jr.; Arthur Schlesinger Jr. is professor emeritus in the humanities at the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York. This is adapted from the forthcoming issue of Foreign Affairs.

 BODY:
The United States will never -- unless Pat Buchanan, the Republican Presidential candidate, has his way -- return to the isolationism of no "entangling alliances."
 It will continue to accept international political, economic and military commitments unprecedented in its history. It will even enlarge some, as in the curious mania to expand NATO, which would commit United States forces to the defense of Eastern Europe from, presumably, the menace of a Russian Army that cannot even beat Chechnya. 
 But such enlargement hinges on the assumption that other nations will do as we tell them. The isolationist impulse has risen from the grave, and it has taken the new form of unilateralism.
 The Clinton Administration began by basing its foreign policy on the premise that the United States could not solve the world's troubles all by itself. "Many of our most important objectives," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said, "cannot be achieved without the cooperation of others." The key to the future, in the Clinton view, was collective action through the building of international institutions and through multilateral diplomacy in the spirit of Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt.
 But the incentives for international collaboration have faded. The Republicans' capture of Congress gave unilateralism new force and momentum. In a perhaps ill-judged attempt at conciliation, President Clinton issued Presidential Directive 25, which restricted United States participation in collective-security operations and declared that "the United States does not support a standing U.N. army, nor will we earmark specific U.S. military units for participation in U.N. operations."
 Predictably, this retreat failed to appease the House speaker, Newt Gingrich, who promptly accused Mr. Clinton of still cherishing the "multinational fantasy" and of a continued desire "to subordinate the United States to the United Nations." Nor did it appease the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, who argued that international organizations too often "reflect a consensus that opposes American interests or does not reflect American principles and ideals."
 The House has already passed a Gingrich-backed bill with the Orwellian title of the National Security Revitalization Act. This bill would cut financial support for current U.N. peacekeeping operations by more than $1 billion and limit the President's ability to approve new peacekeeping missions. The effect, should the bill be enacted, would be to eviscerate the American role in collective security.
 For its part, the Senate has under consideration Mr. Dole's Peace Powers Act, which would amend the U.N. Participation Act of 1945 to give Congress a statutory role in the relationship between the United States and the United Nations. This bill, Mr. Dole tells us, "imposes significant new limits on peacekeeping policies which have jeopardized American interests, squandered American resources and cost lives."
 Among other things, the bill would generally forbid our troops to serve under foreign commanders and, in the words of The Washington Post, "would make it difficult if not impossible for the President to commit U.S. troops to new or expanded U.N. operations or even continue support for ongoing activities."
 "The American people," Mr. Dole says, "will not tolerate American casualties for irresponsible internationalism."
 Sir Nicholas Henderson, the former British Ambassador to Washington, characterizes the situation as "the rejection by the Republicans of the main plank of U.S. foreign policy for the last 50 years." And it is not as if America is at present deeply involved in collective security. The United States stands 20th on the list of nations making troop contributions to U.N. operations, well behind such world powers as Bangladesh, Ghana and Nepal.
 Despite the popular impression that foreign aid is a major charge on the budget, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development recently reported that the United States, once the world's top aid donor, has cut back its allocation to a mere 0.15 percent of its gross domestic product, placing it last among the 21 industrial nations. If Congress has its way, foreign aid will be cut still further.
 Nor can it be said that this recoil from collective security misrepresents popular sentiment. A public opinion survey by the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations and the Gallup Organization shows that, while Americans are still ready to endorse euphonious generalities in support of internationalism, there is a marked drop-off when it comes to committing not just words but money and lives.
 The wave of neo-isolationism draws strength in part from the understandable desire to concentrate on improving things at home -- a desire justified by the neglect of domestic problems during the Reagan-Bush years. The neo-isolationist enthusiasm also results from waning popular confidence in the bureaucracy, competence and peacekeeping skills of the U.N.

Neo-isolationism gains further support as America (indeed, all nations) confronts the ultimate price of collective security. For the essence of collective security remains, as Churchill said, the readiness to act against evildoers "by force of arms." Denied military enforcement, and with economic sanctions of limited effect, the international community's effort to restrain aggressors becomes hortatory.

Are Americans prepared to take a major collective-security role in enforcing the peace system? How to persuade the parents in Xenia, Ohio, that their children should risk their lives in Bosnia or Somalia or some other place where vital American interests are not involved? How many stalwart internationalists in the Council on Foreign Relations would send their sons to die in Bosnia or Somalia?
 Dying for world order when there is no concrete threat to one's own nation is a hard argument to make. For understandable reasons, our leaders are not making it. We have a professional army made up of men and women who volunteered for the job -- and the job, alas, may include fighting, killing and dying. But let a few soldiers get killed, and the Congressional and popular demand for withdrawal becomes almost irresistible.
 Surely this flinching from military enforcement calls for a re-examination of the theory of collective security. Despite two hot wars, a draining cold war and a multitude of smaller conflicts, the Wilsonian vision is as far from realization today as it was three-quarters of a century ago.
 In the United States, neo-isolationism promises to prevent the most powerful nation on the planet from playing any role in enforcing the peace system. If we refuse a role, we cannot expect smaller, weaker and poorer nations to insure world order for us. We are not going to achieve a new world order without paying for it in blood, words and money.
 Perhaps our leaders should put the question to the people: What do we want the U.N. to be? Do we want it to avert more killing fields around the planet? Or do we want it to dwindle into impotence, leaving the world to the anarchy of nation-states?
 National interest narrowly construed may be the safer rule in an anarchic world. But let us recognize, as we return to the bomb, that we are surrendering a magnificent dream.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Tamra A. Siegel, Scott P. Lichtman

 BODY:
Tamra Alison Siegel, the daughter of Claudine and Allen Siegel of Westport, Conn., is to be married today to Scott Philip Lichtman, the son of Sydelle and Jules Lichtman of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Paul Golomb is to perform the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.
The bride, 30, is an associate marketing manager at the Clorox Corporation in Oakland, Calif. She graduated magna cum laude from Haverford College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She and the bridegroom received M.B.A.'s from Harvard University. Her father is the senior adviser to Concurrency Management, a real estate holding company in Greenwich, Conn. Her mother is the managing lawyer of the family unit at Connecticut Legal Services in Bridgeport. 
 Mr. Lichtman, 29, graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and received a master's degree in economics from the London School of Economics. The bridegroom is the director of pricing and licensing strategy at the Oracle Corporation, a software company in Redwood Shores, Calif. His mother retired as an administrative assistant at the Tenafly Board of Education. His father is an associate vice president of investments at Prudential Securities in New York.

HEADLINE: The World;
Sure, Ebola Is Bad. Africa Has Worse.

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KIKWIT, Zaire

 BODY:
WITH the gruesome death of scores of people from the Ebola virus last month, this lost city of 500,000, and with it a largely forgotten continent, was suddenly, if momentarily, found.
 For weeks now, the scenery of Kikwit has been utterly transformed as space-suited scientists scurry about the government hospital compound and white Red Cross vehicles comb neighborhoods whose dirt roads had lost all habit of bearing vehicles. Foreign doctors and foreign correspondents uneasily rub elbows, one group hoping to bare the secrets of the scourge and the other hoping to flash the news. 
 Meanwhile, from only a few hundred miles to the east, word has filtered out of an older scourge: 250 people have been stricken with polio. Simultaneously, deadly cholera rages in Mali. To the south, in Angola, 30,000 people were recently infected with sleeping sickness. And a few weeks back, thousands died when meningitis swept across a broad belt of West Africa.
 Unlike Ebola, all of these plagues are easily mastered by modern medicine, so Westerners need not fear their spread. But all of them already have killed, or likely will kill, far more Africans than today's celebrity virus. And for Africans, the troubling question arises why none of this continent's daily, deadly encounters with mostly preventable diseases hardly provokes a flicker on the screen of the world's conscience.
 If it is true that Ebola represents a formidable and intriguing scientific puzzle, for many Africans it also seems true that these days the world's most miserable continent can only capture the West's attention by fulfilling new superlatives of human catastrophe or primordial exoticism.
Hence, death by the thousands in annual measles outbreaks, or a toll of millions from malaria, are non-events for an outside world that has already moved on to associating Africa with endemic H.I.V. infection and has found an even more spectacularly grim image of a diseased continent: Ebola.

 
 
A Savage Stereotype
 For Britain's Sunday Telegraph, indulging in one of the oldest stereotypes about the continent, the newest epidemic was an example of "savage African diseases ready to break out anywhere at any moment."
 By the same token, a world already jaded by the scale of death in Rwanda and Somalia scarcely notices that in nearby Sudan, where slavery on a large scale is still commonplace, many thousands have been starved to death or killed in a civil war.
 "Where Africa is concerned, there is a constant search for tragedy with a new face, like what else is new in genocide," said Ali Mazrui, an African scholar at the State University of New York at Binghamton. "There is a hardened insensitivity to things which happen in Africa which are regarded as on the margin of human importance, even if hundreds of thousands die, which can only be called malignant neglect."
 A United Nations official in Liberia who threw his hands up at the lack of international effort to help end that country's civil war put it differently. "Let's face it," he said on condition of anonymity, "the world's threshold for suffering is just higher in Africa than it is for other places."
If this statement is true, many Africans say that with the end of the cold war there have been subtle changes in the criteria that determine when outside powers focus on African misery. Backing dictators on the basis of ideological fidelity for three decades, East and West both ignored questions of human rights or economic development.

 
 
Bloody Hands
 Long is the list of tyrants, like Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire or Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia, whose hands were bloody with their own people's slaughter and who left their economies in ruin while enjoying the indulgent support of Washington, Paris, London, Moscow or Havana.
 Now the West is quick to condemn African dictators, but, many African intellectuals say, it is shockingly stingy when it comes to compassion for the people whose lives they have wrecked.
 "They have learned how to sanction people, it seems," Guillaume Ngefa, president of the Zairean Association for the Defense of Human Rights, said of foreigners. "But as they sit back and watch the destruction of whole societies, it doesn't seem they have learned how to assist."
 This kind of attitude nearly played a catastrophic role even in the Ebola outbreak. Zairean doctors in Kikwit say they had been sending S.O.S. messages for weeks about the spread of an unusually virulent diarrheal disease before they succeeded in getting any serious foreign attention.
 The reason, they said, was that after three decades of propping up President Mobutu, the West had all but severed its ties to Zaire.
 "Kikwit hospital literally begged for help," said Dr. Dan Fountain, an American missionary physician who practices near Kikwit. But he said the initial response was that Bandundu was not one of the three provinces that aid organizations had decided to work in.
 He said the Zairean director of Kikwit hospital asked him, "What do I need, a full-blown epidemic here before anyone notices?" The answer, it turned out, was yes.

HEADLINE: For Noncandidate Gingrich, All New Hampshire's a Stage

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: KEENE, N.H., June 10

 BODY:
Racing by helicopter from event to event, Newt Gingrich barnstormed today around this first-in-the-nation primary state like a full-fledged Presidential candidate, greeted by overflow crowds, demonstrators and 130 news organizations as he tried to dispel the notion that he would rather be President than Speaker.
Even as he basked in attention and ovations that the eight declared candidates for the Republican nomination have yet to receive -- 23 television cameras recorded his arrival at the Manchester airport on Friday -- Mr. Gingrich told New Hampshire residents that he had been playing coy about his intentions for 1996 only to lure people into paying attention to his ideas. 
 Mr. Gingrich, like the Wizard of Oz showing off the levers on his thunder machine, explained to audiences how he was manipulating reporters to get his message across.
"I decided to be cynical," the Georgia Republican told 800 people Friday night at the politically influential Nashua Chamber of Commerce dinner. "What I've learned is, if I keep the door open just this much, they'll all show up. And I could teach. And they'll actually cover it. They'll go, 'Ah-hah! This is a very sneaky way to run for President.' "
Mr. Gingrich spent the day making the most of the opportunity he created, chattering away about weighty subjects, and then successfully maneuvering a half-serious invitation from President Clinton into a commitment that the two would meet, one on one, for a discussion of the issues on Sunday.
Between the fund-raisers and helicopter hops and preparation for a "moose watch," negotiations went on over what form their meeting should take. White House officials and Mr. Gingrich's aides went round and round over whether the two men would get together for the kind of joint appearances usually limited to the last weeks of a Presidential campaign, although both sides were emphasizing to their fullest that all they had in mind was a dialogue.
The White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said this afternoon that Mr. Clinton would be "delighted" should Mr. Gingrich join him at a senior citizens picnic that had been arranged for the President. But the White House had been anything but delighted by the Speaker's counter-invitations that the President swing by a Republican event in the morning, or that they find a bigger venue for the picnic.
White House officials made clear that Mr. Clinton would not be altering his schedule to suit Mr. Gingrich.
Finally, Mr. Gingrich agreed to attend the picnic, which will be held in Claremont, N.H. The Speaker said: "I would hope that it is a very friendly, very positive dialogue and the people say afterward, 'It is nice to see that leaders who belong to different parties and different branches can actually find some way to deal with each other that isn't hostile.' "
Mary Ellen Glynn, a White House spokeswoman, said this evening: "We will be delighted to see the Speaker in New Hampshire tomorrow. It will be a good chance for the President and the Speaker to address the issues that affect the citizens of New Hampshire and the elderly, in particular. It should be a productive dialogue."
Mr. Gingrich has emphasized that really all he wants to do is frame the debate for whoever really does run next year. And he said that is fine with Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, who is the leading candidate in every major poll for the Republican nomination for President and the one who arguably has the most to lose by Mr. Gingrich's continued display of his power to draw a crowd and articulate the big ideas of the day.
"The truth is, Bob Dole thinks it's fine I'm up here, because he understands what I'm doing," Mr. Gingrich said. "I'm trying to shape the entire language and ideas of the 1996 campaign."
His central theme is that America is in crisis -- with 12-year-olds having babies and 17-year-olds unable to read their diplomas -- and what he describes as a liberal media elite too bored and cynical to write about it.
He laid out his solutions in nine specific strategies, including balancing the budget, decentralizing government out of Washington, re-establishing the work ethic and asserting American leadership around the world.
He gets particularly strong applause for calling for the death penalty for those who smuggle drugs into the United States. And he would like to force rock stars and athletes who use drugs to perform two days of community service a week, like picking up trash, which he said would be a more severe penalty than making them pay a fine.
Mr. Gingrich's style is persuasive to many here. "It doesn't make any difference if he runs, the message is there," said an admiring Ed Ellis, 50, a marketing executive and a Democrat who heard Mr. Gingrich in Nashua on Friday night. He voted for Bill Clinton in 1992 but said Mr. Clinton had demonstrated no leadership. "He doesn't know which way he's going when he gets up in the morning," said Mr. Ellis, while he believes Mr. Gingrich gives a strong sense of what he wants to do.
As the commander who shaped last year's historic Republican takeover of Congress, Mr. Gingrich may lay easy claim to setting the agenda for 1996. But doing so also reinforces the perception of him as the engine driving the Republican machine, and it continues to cast his party's declared candidates in his shadow.
Besides, Mr. Gingrich hardly had trouble getting access to a microphone before he became a noncandidate.
But Mr. Gingrich said it was very hard, even for him, to get his message out unfiltered. He said that he shut down his daily Speaker's press briefings in Washington -- in which he was frequently asked about ethics accusations against him or the details of policy -- because the questions were too "nitpicking." He added, "I don't mind occasionally talking about the trees, but when we're arguing over a beetle on the bark, I think there's something wrong with the whole style."
It is different in New Hampshire, he said, where his staff has accommodated the gaggle of reporters and camera crews with bus caravans, telephones and filing centers, because here, he is talking about ideas. Besides, the press is a handy prop to have along. Mr. Gingrich gets great mileage out of deriding the press corps while using it at the same time to amplify his voice.
All of that said, several New Hampshire residents who have been listening to Mr. Gingrich this weekend think he is not really running for President and they do not want him to, partly out of fear that he might lose. His visit coincides with polls that show that if he entered the primary, Mr. Gingrich would not do even as well as Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, who is running a distant second to Senator Dole.
Jim Smith, a retired geneticist, who heard Mr. Gingrich speak here at Keene State College this morning, said he would support him for President because he is "the best possible candidate of all" and he could beat Mr. Clinton. But because Mr. Gingrich probably could not win the party nomination, Mr. Smith does not want him to fail. "We would be better off as a party to have him exactly where he is, at least for the next four years," he said, rather than risk losing him as Speaker, too.
Some are taking Mr. Gingrich's visit in the spirit in which they assume it was intended.
"He's just having fun," said John Byrnes, a retired Keene police officer. "And you people are having fun following him around and inventing all these things. But it's great for the state of New Hampshire, all the money you bring in." He laughed about how Mr. Gingrich was "raining" on Mr. Clinton's parade, "and poor old Billy Boy is sweating it out down there."
Indeed, Mr. Gingrich cannot help but fault Mr. Clinton, for perceived sins old and new.
In response to Mr. Clinton's criticism that the House-passed foreign aid bill was "isolationist," Mr. Gingrich noted that Mr. Clinton had been the Texas field director for Senator George McGovern's 1972 Presidential campaign, which "was far more isolationist than anything we've ever done."
And he casually asserted that the Presidency had become "relatively less important" than the legislative branch, and that this was "a past tense statement of fact," no mere burst of hubris.
He said the drug problem would be easier to solve if the Administration demonstrated a tough attitude against drugs, not a soft attitude.
He said that the war in Bosnia was "a historic mess" for which both parties were responsible, one that might have been prevented several years ago if the United States had established what he called a Balkan economic development bank and a Balkan trade zone.
But he also faulted Mr. Clinton for the current muddled policy in the Balkans. At a breakfast fund-raiser here this morning, he cited the decision not to destroy Serbian positions when Capt. Scott F. O'Grady was rescued from hostile Bosnian territory last week. American fliers had determined that Serbian radar had pinpointed their location, but the Americans were denied permission to fire on the Serbs, in part to protect United Nations hostages.
"It is inexcusable to allow Serbian radar to work," Mr. Gingrich said. "If we're going to fly aircraft over Bosnia, we should have set the ground rule -- they turn on the radar, we kill 'em." Big applause.
He also erupted in anger at the notion of United Nations peacekeepers who wear "baby blue helmets" and do not look or act like soldiers. "Any system which would put soldiers out in such an unmilitary manner as to allow them to be taken hostage is a disgrace to civilization," he declared to much applause. The United Nations model in Bosnia, he said, "is utter, total insanity."
His solution is to use the threat of overwhelming military power from the United States to force the Serbs to the negotiating table.
He had been asked what he would do about Bosnia if he were President. But in answering, he was careful to say, "As Speaker the advice I would give the President is this." And the audience applauded again.

HEADLINE: 2 Rivals in A.F.L.-C.I.O. Are Seeking Its Presidency

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Now that Lane Kirkland has decided not to seek re-election as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., an unprecedented battle for the leadership of the union has broken into the open, with the two contenders promising to revitalize the federation. It is a pledge that may be hard to fulfill in a time of weak public support for unions.
The contenders are Thomas R. Donahue, who has been Mr. Kirkland's second-in-command for 16 years, and John J. Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union, whose more than 1 million members are mostly janitors, window washers and other building service employees. 
 Mr. Donahue and Mr. Sweeney are expected to announce their candidacies this week. They were freed to do so when Mr. Kirkland, bowing to pressure from within the federation, told other union leaders last week that he would not seek a ninth two-year term as president.
The leadership struggle is in part a reaction to Republican gains in last year's Congressional elections. Angry that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. had been unsuccessful in lobbying a Democratic Administration and Congress -- and alarmed by the prospect of a Republican-led Congress -- the leaders of a dozen major unions within the federation began to urge the ailing Mr. Kirkland in February to retire at the end of the year, when his term expired. What the organization needed, they said, was a more aggressive, charismatic president. Their choice was Mr. Donahue.
But Mr. Kirkland, who is 73, refused to retire, and Mr. Donahue, 66, said he would not run against his boss, whom he has served as secretary-treasurer since Mr. Kirkland became president in 1979. Mr. Donahue announced in the spring that he would retire rather than oppose Mr. Kirkland.
That changed early last week when Mr. Kirkland began to tell leaders of the 81 unions in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. that he would not run after all. Mr. Donahue quickly started to canvass them for support but found it had dwindled.
The Sweeney campaign "has gone too far down the road to pull back," the president of a major industrial union said yesterday, speaking on condition of anonymity.
Discussing his re-emergence as a candidate, Mr. Donahue said in an interview yesterday, "What I said was that I would never be a candidate against Lane Kirkland, and since Lane has now indicated that he does not intend to run again, I have said that in the light of that I want to examine a candidacy which I believe can be a unity candidacy."
Mr. Donahue's appeal for support, which includes the reminder that up to a few weeks ago Mr. Sweeney himself supported his candidacy, does not play well in the Sweeney camp, which contends, among other things, that Mr. Donahue is too identified with Mr. Kirkland's lackluster policies to revitalize the labor movement.
As of last week, Mr. Sweeney's loyalists appeared to control enough votes among the labor organization's 13.3 million workers to insure Mr. Sweeney's election at the federation's annual meeting in New York in October. But with the election still months away, Mr. Donahue shows no signs of yielding.
Mr. Donahue and Mr. Sweeney, who is 61, are part of the aging white male hierarchy that leads and dominates the union movement in the United States and has never in the 40-year history of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. fielded two competing candidates for president. "The campaign debate itself is revitalizing the federation," a union president said.
Complicating the struggle, white men are declining as a percentage of total union membership, while women, African-Americans and Hispanic workers represent a rising share. In recognition, Mr. Donahue and Mr. Sweeney are the first candidates for federation president to promise to have a member of a minority as a running mate.
The Sweeney camp, which has scheduled a news conference in Washington for Tuesday, is expected to announce then that Linda Chavez-Thompson, who is Hispanic, will be Mr. Sweeney's running mate as secretary-treasurer, union officials said. Ms. Chavez-Thompson is a vice president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
Richard L. Trumka, 45, president of the United Mine Workers, is also to be on the ticket, in a newly created post of executive vice president -- if the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council agrees to create such a post. Mr. Trumka, who is white, is one of the nation's youngest union presidents.
Mr. Sweeney, who was in Vancouver, British Columbia, this weekend for a meeting of his union's leadership, could not be reached for comment. Mr. Donahue, who has not announced his potential running mates, has emphasized that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. under Mr. Kirkland brought five minority members onto the federation's 33-member executive council and greatly expanded the hiring of members of minorities for the organization's staff. Mr. Donahue said he would continue this push for diversity.
Beyond minority representation in the leadership, there are two burning issues. One is how to mobilize the grass-roots membership in support of legislation and candidates favored by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The other is how to make the A.F.L.-C.I.O. more effective in helping its members organize nonunion workers at a time when American labor law makes organizing difficult and workers often fear losing their jobs if they antagonize management.
"Revitalizing the A.F.L.-C.I.O. may be a little like pushing on a string, absent either labor law reform or a change in sentiment among workers and managers," said Barry Hirsch, a labor economist at Florida State University.
Mr. Sweeney brings to the campaign a reputation for having doubled the size of his union's membership, to more than one million men and women, at a time when union membership nationally has fallen. Much of his emphasis as a union leader has been on organizing.
Mr. Donahue, whose union career has been mostly as an A.F.L.-C.I.O. official, argues that he has increasingly sent federation representatives into the field to help unions conduct strikes. He is also largely responsible for doubling the money that the federation spends on training organizers.
"It is more a question of spirit and style than fundamental differences on issues," Mr. Donahue said of himself and Mr. Sweeney.

HEADLINE: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE SERBIAN ROLE;
WESTERN OFFICIALS SAY SERBIA HELPS BOSNIAN COMRADES

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 10

 BODY:
Even as the West courts Serbia's President in hopes of bringing peace to Bosnia and winning the release of the 52 remaining United Nations hostages, his military is secretly assisting the Bosnian Serbs, American and European officials say.
The Serbian leader, Slobodan Milosevic, vowed last year to seal the border between Serbia and Bosnia, and he won an easing of United Nations sanctions as a result. Mr. Milosevic insists that since then only non-lethal aid has been sent to the Bosnian Serbs, an assertion generally accepted by United Nations monitors. 
 But American and European officials with access to intelligence reports said the Yugoslav Army was paying the salaries of many Bosnian Serb officers and also supplying their forces with fuel, spare parts, training and ammunition.
Several American analysts said the Yugoslav Army, which is dominated by Serbia, provided the parts and technicians to maintain the Bosnian Serb air defenses that shot down a American F-16 jet fighter on a NATO monitoring mission. The system remains electronically linked to the Yugoslav Army's computers and radars, although there has been no evidence that the Yugoslav Army was directly involved in shooting down the plane, officials said.
While there are differences about precisely how much military materiel is flowing to the Bosnian Serbs, American experts say the assistance has enabled the Bosnian Serbs to remain an effective fighting force. Even those skeptical of the reports agreed that the supply line had not been cut off.
"Despite what Mr. Milosevic would like you to think, they have not severed their ties," one Administration official said. "The support is there."
That view is not universely embraced by Administration policymakers, who have urged the negotiations with Mr. Milosevic, nor by Government intelligence analysts. Some say Mr. Milosevic is acquiescing in his military commanders' support of their Bosnian Serb colleagues, rather than actively directing it. Others question the extent of the Yugoslav shipments described in what one official termed "anecdotal" reports.
In response to questions, Defense Secretary William J. Perry issued a statement that said while what he called "leakage" persists, he knew of no "credible evidence" that the Bosnian Serbs were receiving a broad range of military help from the Yugoslav Army.
Since the Bosnian Serbs began fighting three years ago against the independence of Bosnia and Herzegovina, American intelligence agencies have mounted extensive efforts to eavesdrop on communications and compile satellite photographs of military movements.
This has produced persistent reports that the Bosnian Serbs have continued to receive help from the Yugoslav Army. Yugoslavia now consists of Serbia and Montenegro.
According to American and European officials, the reports say the Bosnian Serbs' trucks, tanks, and other heavy equipment are maintained with parts supplied by the Yugoslav Army.
American officials said they have evidence of regular conversations and consultations between the Yugoslav Army's general staff in Belgrade and the officers directing operations in Bosnia. They said Bosnian Serbs wounded in battle are flown to Yugoslav military hospitals.
 
U.S. and West Face A Thorny Question
 Intelligence reports about Mr. Milosevic's continuing role in the war raise a nettlesome question. Should the West lift economic sanctions against a Government that appears to be sustaining the Bosnian Serbs' war effort, even as it pledges to do the opposite?
Several American and European officials said that having decided not to directly confront the Bosnian Serbs, the West has little choice but to bargain with Mr. Milosevic. That conclusion, said a European official, has made both Washington and its European allies more eager to play down reports of military assistance to the Bosnian Serbs.
"The guy is a key factor to a resolution, " one senior American official acknowledged, referring Mr. Milosevic. "Whether we want to deal with him or not, we have to."
The talks are at a delicate turn. Some of the lesser economic sanctions against Serbia were lifted last year after Mr. Milosevic announced he would close the border with Bosnia. Now, the five nations trying to find a peace formula for the Balkans is offering to suspend the remaining sanctions if Mr. Milosevic recognizes Bosnia.
But he rebuffed that offer after an American envoy, Robert Frasure, insisted on an independent means of reimposing the sanctions if Mr. Milosevic reneges. American officials said Mr. Milosevic wants that matter solely in the hands of the United Nations Security Council, where the Russians, historical allies of the Serbs, hold a veto.
 
Good Cop, Bad Cop: A Serbian Version
 American officials disagree about the significance of the split between the Bosnian Serb leader, Dr. Radovan Karadzic, and Mr. Milosevic. Over the past week, for example, Mr. Milosevic said he had intervened to gain the release of about half of the United Nations soldiers taken hostage by the Bosnian Serbs after NATO air raids on a Bosnian Serb ammunition depot. Then, Mr. Milosevic cited his cooperation on the hostages as an argument for lifting the sanctions on his terms.
The military relationship between Serbia and the Bosnian Serbs began long before war erupted in April 1992. In the months before the conflict, the Yugoslav Army moved tons of tanks, artillery and heavy equipment to Bosnia, where there were already huge stocks of ammunition from the time when Bosnia and Herzegovina was part of Yugoslavia. After fighting broke out, the communication networks left behind by the Yugoslav Army remained tied to Belgrade.
That summer's campaign of "ethnic cleansing," in which Bosnian Serb soldiers and paramilitary militias rounded up Muslims and detained them in camps or drove them from their homes, were directed by officers in the Yugoslav Army's headquarters in Belgrade, according to a former American official who was briefed on the European intercepts of military communications.
The Yugoslav Army's heavy weapons remain the Bosnian Serbs' key military advantage over the more numerous Bosnian Government forces.
There also were extensive personal ties. Gen. Ratko Mladic, the commander of the Bosnian Serb forces, was a career officer in the Yugoslav Army and was selected to lead the Bosnian Serbs by Mr. Milosevic shortly before the war began.
As the war continued, the Yugoslav Army openly supported the Bosnian Serbs, sending convoys of trucks and oil tankers across the border. At times, elite Yuguslav Army units reportedly joined the fighting. This open support prompted the West to ban all trade with Yugoslavia.
 
Oil Tankers Head for Croatia
 Belgrade proved adept at evading the sanctions and smuggling goods. But the sanctions still hurt, and by last fall, Mr. Milosevic was looking for a deal to end them. He offered to close the border with Bosnia, and allow an international mission to monitor his compliance.
On Oct. 3 of last year, two Western mediators -- Lord Owen of the European Union and Thorvald Soltenberg of the United Nations -- announced that the border had been closed. At the same time, however, Lord Owen declared that oil tankers and trucks going across Bosnia to the Serb-held areas of Croatia were not subject to the cutoff.
Immediately, American officials say, 50 to 60 oil tankers a week began showing up at the border with papers indicating they were traveling to Croatia. The international monitors had no means of checking whether, as many American officials suspect, they dropped their cargo in Bosnia.
In rural Serbia, several Yugoslav Army officers told American diplomats that they were still running supplies to Bosnia. Since then, American officials agree, there has been some tightening of the border, with fuel shipments to Bosnia initially cut as much as 50 percent. This has prompted fuel shortages in Bosnian Serb territory.
But the officials asserted that the military assistance and fuel deliveries have continued, and that the Bosnian Serb army has had no difficulties in sustaining operations. Indeed, two American experts said this week that the cross-border traffic was increasing.
American officials agree that the deliveries of fuel and repair of vehicles are an essential element of the support from Belgrade. The Bosnian Serb forces are outnumbered, yet American officials say they maintain the upper hand along a 1,000-mile front by moving armor and heavy weapons rapidly to counter the Government's offensives.
 
Who Is Paymaster For Bosnian Serbs?
 Another aspect of Belgrade's support is more basic: The salaries of many Bosnian Serb officers serving at their headquarters in Pale, near Sarajevo, and elsewhere are paid by the Yugoslav Army. The Bosnian Serbs use the same currency as Yugoslavia, and one official said, "We've seen instances of Pale Serb commanders going to Belgrade and saying, 'Hey, where's our cash?' "
The air defense radars illustrate the continuing ties. Brig. Gen. Selmo Cikotic, the Bosnian Embassy's military attache in Washington and a former Yugoslav Army officer, said the radars in Bosnia and Serb-held Croatia remain linked to Belgrade.
General Cikotic, who was himself an air defense officer, asserted that the SAM-6 missile that shot down the NATO F-16 jet last week was equipped with a Russian-manufactured modification supplied to the Bosnian Serbs Yugoslavia.
American officials could not confirm that detail, but said spare parts for the system were sent by Belgrade. The operator who fired the SAM-6 missile had either "prior training" or "current technical assistance" from the Yugoslav Army, one Administration official said. "It's not something someone could just up and do, and be successful."
Asked to assess the true relationship between the Yugoslav Army's general staff and Bosnian Serb forces, an American official pointed to the recently appointed commander of Serbian forces in Croatia: Lieut. Gen. Mile Mrksic. Until a few weeks ago, the official said, General Mrksic was serving on the general staff Yugoslav Army in Belgrade.
