HEADLINE: Treatment for Many Ills;
An Area Centers on Lincoln Hospital

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
Tony Glenos, the owner of the Donut Shop on 149th Street in the South Bronx, paused in his morning routine of flipping bacon and stirring home fries to wipe his hands on his grease-stained apron and gesture across the street. "Today they get paid over there," he said with a jagged-tooth grin. "Everybody will spend more money here today."
Payday at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, the huge, rust-colored brick building that dominates the view from Mr. Glenos's window, does not go unnoticed by the 250 small-business owners in the neighborhood. "The hospital gives a little bit to every business here," Mr. Glenos said. "If there was no hospital, I'd close, and everyone else would." 
 Like the huge factories that once brought middle-class stability to today's poor neighborhoods, New York City's public hospital system has evolved into an economic and cultural engine, driving growth and dominating the predominantly low-income neighborhoods they serve. Besides being among the largest employers in their communities, these hospitals attract and sustain small businesses, including health-care-related services.
As city and state officials start to shrink the public hospital system, saying it would save money and improve care, they are only beginning to confront the economic and political reality that the hospitals have become a source for much more than health care in their communities.
Lincoln alone has annual total revenues of about $280 million and produces more than $500 million for other health-service companies in the city, according to an internal study conducted by the City Health and Hospitals Corporation in 1993. Another 7,600 jobs created at other health-service companies throughout the city also depend on the hospital and account for $205 million of the city's annual household earnings.
The hospitals corporation study found that $17.8 million a year was paid to employees who live within the five ZIP codes that comprise Lincoln's primary service area. Estimating that people spend about 60 percent of their income on food, rent and other local expenditures, the study found that $10.7 million of employees' income was reinvested in the neighborhood.
The surrounding community also draws on Lincoln for everything from meeting spaces to meals for the homeless. It has provided medical training for high-school interns -- and enough patronage jobs to build the power base of Ramon S. Velez, the community organizer and political baron of the Bronx, who has often been accused of putting his own interests ahead of Lincoln's and the community's.
Like other public hospitals, Lincoln has often been accused by city and state officials of providing poor health care. Most recently, hospital officials acknowledged that several babies had been injured because of delivery-room mistakes.
Maria K. Mitchell, the Mayor's special adviser on health policy and his recent appointee as chairwoman of the hospitals corporation, says that changes in the hospital system could be expected to improve care.
"Everybody thought that Detroit would be gone after the automobile crisis when the Japanese market really took over," she said. "And they did succeed because they figured out a different way to do things. They retooled, they re-engineered, they figured out how to pay attention to quality, which, by the way, is probably a big problem in the H.H.C. system."
 
Source of Money, Direct and Indirect
 But perhaps no single place better typifies the importance of hospitals to their neighborhoods than Lincoln. Situated in one of the poorest sections of the city, Lincoln provides livelihoods for people who range from Mr. Glenos of the Donut Shop to Roberto Rodriguez, who was raised in the nearby Patterson Projects and is now the hospital's executive director.
Of the 3,300 people employed at Lincoln, 60 percent live in the Bronx, according to statistics compiled by Lincoln and the hospitals corporation. An additional 1,000 local residents are classified as volunteers, and many of them receive small stipends for services like changing beds and bathing patients.
Beyond the hospital, there are 59 health-care-related businesses in Lincoln's ZIP code that employ more than 700 people. "I don't think of Lincoln as the economic engine here," said Neil Parisher, senior vice president of the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, "I think it's more of a locomotive, because it's pulling a lot of stuff."
With 609 beds and 26,000 in-patients, 160,000 emergency room visits and 400,000 clinic visits a year, Lincoln is the hospitals corporation's busiest site after Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn. And it is emerging as the most profitable, having averaged an $8.9 million net operating surplus for the last three years. Its neighbors, mostly Hispanic and African-American, have a median household income of $16,500, according to the 1990 census; 89 percent of them pay their hopital bills through either Medicaid or Medicare.
Because of its heavy patient load and its efficiency, it is unlikely that Lincoln will be shut down. But, like other public hospitals, it is anticipating cuts in its Medicaid reimbursements and city financing, and they are prompting concern.
"It could have a devastating blow to us," said Rev. Reuben Diaz, executive director of the Christian Community in Action Home Attendant Program, a Bronx-based nonprofit provider of home-attendant care that employs 1,300 people. It is financed through the city's Human Resources Administration, and Mr. Diaz said that about 50 percent of his 900 clients -- all on Medicaid or Medicare -- receive their treatment at Lincoln.
Gregory Chugranis, whose family-run flower shop has been in the South Bronx for 89 years and who moved the business opposite Lincoln 15 years ago, said the hospital "sort of brought this area to life."
Before it was built, he said, you could count the shops and restaurants on one hand. "Now they're all over the place," he said. "No doubt, Lincoln is the anchor. It's more than just a neighborhood hospital."
 
Community Leaders Use Their Clout
 Lincoln's current home was built in the mid-1970's, when Mr. Velez, then a fast-rising community leader, organized an unlikely coalition of doctors, the Young Lords street gang and the Black Panther Party to lobby City Hall to replace the hospital's decrepit building at 141st Street and Concord Avenue.
Dr. Frank Williams, director of oral surgery and president of the medical staff at Lincoln, recalled that Mr. Velez was "the single person most responsible" for the new building, which opened in 1976. Because of that, Dr. Williams said, Mr. Velez has significant clout in the hospital's operations. And that has helped him build an empire of social service programs and become a fierce power broker in the Bronx.
A controversial man who has amassed a personal fortune through a tangle of nonprofit organizations and private companies, Mr. Velez said his primary goal has been "to make sure there was community involved in the administration and that hospital jobs went to people in the community." In addition to operating a nonprofit home-attendant concern that depends on Lincoln patient referrals, Mr. Velez has also run Federally funded jobs programs that screen candidates and refer them to the hospital for work.
George Rodriguez, a close associate of Mr. Velez and the current chairman of the hospital's community advisory board, frankly acknowledged that the two of them have been "very instrumental in getting jobs to certain people." He and Mr. Velez have influenced hiring at all levels, he said, "all the way down to housekeepers and maintenance, and on up to top administrators."
Even though Mr. Velez is not as visible a force as he once was since coming under fire in recent years, hospital officials say his presence can still be felt. One former administrator, who would speak only on the condition that he not be named, said that when he tried to lay off unproductive workers, he was sometimes informed that they were "untouchable." Mr. Velez denied that such tactics were ever used.
Mr. Rodriguez, who as chairman of Bronx Community Board 1 is supposed to help Lincoln serve its community, has his own financial ties to the hospital. He runs a nonprofit home-attendant service, which employs 300 people and receives many of its Medicaid-sponsored patients from Lincoln referrals. The walls of his cluttered Third Avenue office are covered with photographs of himself with New York City mayors dating back to John V. Lindsay. There is even a photograph of him with Lincoln's former executive director, Dr. Carlos Molina.
"He was a gentleman," Mr. Rodriguez said, "but we weren't involved in selecting him. He was imposed on us. So we got him out."
Roberto Rodriguez (no relation to George), the man who replaced Dr. Molina as executive director in 1992, acknowledged that Mr. Velez and other community leaders have a "quiet presence" at the hospital. "Not once since I've been here, in three years, has Ramon Valez or anyone approached me about a job, not arm-twisting or threatening," he said. But Mr. Rodriguez acknowledges that he has discussed the hospital's operations with Mr. Valez. "He's a leader here," Mr. Rodriguez said. "How do you turn a deaf ear?"
Mr. Rodriguez, who was raised across the street from the hospital, said that he had been accepted by local power brokers because he was a known quantity. He has gone about his job at Lincoln like both a chief executive and a community organizer. At nearby Paul Robeson Intermediate School last year, Mr. Rodriguez sat in on a budget session and "really offered some suggestions that were helpful to me," said John Crawford, the school's principal. "He is really reaching out and making the hospital the focal point of this community."
 
Place of Opportunity For Local Youth

The effect the hospital can have on neighborhood youth is evident in Mustafa Stanley, 18, who was stabbed in the neck, chest and shoulder three years ago while "hanging with the wrong crowd," he said. After spending the last year as a high-school intern in the radiology department at the hospital, Mr. Stanley is now frantically searching for financial aid to begin pre-med studies this fall at Norfolk State University in Virginia. "I can play basketball," he recently said. "You know, I could be like the next Michael Jordan. But I want to be a trauma specialist. I want to make a difference."
Rosa Diaz, a student at Hostos Lincoln Academy, a local magnet school, who said that if she wasn't volunteering at the hospital she "would probably be in the streets, being a follower." Instead, Ms. Diaz, 18, spends her afternoons in a uniform following the directions of doctors and midwives at Lincoln's women's health clinic.
The hospital's emergency room is where the community turns for practically anything. Besides handling thousands of trauma cases each year, Lincoln's emergency room staff helps local residents who are searching for food, shelter and counseling, or even things like diapers, baby formula and aspirin. "Oftentimes people just need to be plugged into social services," said Dr. Peter Wyer, an attending physician in pediatric emergencies.
Some patients come in feigning problems in an attempt to obtain controlled medications, said Dr. Victoria Paz. Anti-depressants like Prozac are used by addicts to prolong the effects of heroin, and drugs like Valium and Zanex are taken as downers and can sell for as much as $3 each on the street. Dr. Paz said that tighter restrictions in recent years have allowed the hospital to minimize such abuse, but that the problem still exists.
On a recent Friday evening, the area outside the adult emergency waiting room was unusually quiet. Dr. Ramnath Kapoor, a chief attending surgeon in adult emergencies, had just finished up with a 25-year-old woman who had come in complaining that she couldn't move her arm. After six hours of testing and X-rays, said Dr. Kapoor, "we realized what she was really looking for was shelter." The hospital called in social service workers to help her find somewhere to stay, but in the meantime, "she got two meals, she saw the doctor, she got cleaned up," Dr. Kapoor said.
"No private institution would have ever touched such a patient," he added. "But we make her feel like she's somebody."
Estimating that 10 percent of the 160,000 visits each year that are classified as emergencies are actually for something other than medical problems, he said, "We are an emergency room, but we give more than medical care."
In the winter, when the temperature drops below 40 degrees, one section of the emergency waiting room is converted into a shelter, where as many as 25 homeless people, some of them families with small children, sleep and receive meals. Each Thanksgiving, emergency workers prepare dinner for the homeless.
The auditorium has been used for performances by local theater groups and high school graduation ceremonies. Community groups ranging from the National Council of Negro Women to the Gay Men of the Bronx meet regularly in the conference rooms, which this month are being used to conduct seminars for first-time Bronx home buyers.
"This is not a hospital isolated out there just for medicine," Dr. Williams said. "It encompasses the entire community and all of its activities."

HEADLINE: After Decades of Wariness, Forces of U.S. and India Begin to Cooperate

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: COCHIN, India

 BODY:
More than 250 miles out in the Indian Ocean, Capt. Kizhupalli Mohanan of the Indian Navy leaned out from an observation deck aboard the Abraham Lincoln, straining to catch a view of an F-14 Tomcat fighter as it screamed down over a cobalt-blue sea toward one of the newest nuclear-powered American aircraft carriers.
For Captain Mohanan, a grizzle-bearded navy pilot with hundreds of carrier landings behind him, there was little of the first-timer's thrill in the full-throttle roar of the Tomcat's engines and the cracking impact of the 30-ton fighter hitting the deck one. 
 But there was novelty in the experience nonetheless, for Captain Mohanan commands the Vikrant, an aging Indian aircraft carrier, and this was his introduction to the United States Navy at sea.
Back on land at an Indian Navy air station at Cochin, Captain Mohanan was asked if he thought that the Indian Navy could benefit from a widening of the tentative military contacts now being taken up between the two nations after decades of estrangement.
His face lit up. "Oh yes," he said, standing beside a navy transport plane that ferried a group of Indian officers to the American carrier. "Indeed I do."
The Vikrant commander's enthusiasm was an apt symbol of how things have moved between the two navies. More than 23 years ago the Vikrant was involved in an incident that stood for many years as a symbol of the wariness, and sometimes hostility, that characterized relations between India and the United States for much of the last 50 years.
In December 1971, when Indian forces entered what was then East Pakistan to seal the victory of the rebels fighting to create Bangladesh, President Nixon sent a naval battle group led by the aircraft carrier Enterprise into the Bay of Bengal. Prime Minister Indira Gandhi interpreted the deployment as a military threat; the Vikrant, patrolling farther north, was placed on battle stations.
The Enterprise sailed away. But among Indians, the incident has stood as an emblem of the United States' readiness to assert itself militarily in what many Indians regard as their backyard -- and as a marker of Washington's unwillingness to accept India for what it believes itself to be: a regional superpower with wide-ranging military interests.
"Of course, the Enterprise could have sunk the Vikrant in 20 minutes," said Jasjit Singh, a retired Indian fighter pilot who is director of the Institute for Defense Studies and Analyses, in New Delhi. "But, for us, that was never the point."
What was, Mr. Singh said, was that the United States had tried to dictate terms to New Delhi on the creation of Bangladesh, an issue of crucial strategic importance to India.
Now planners in Washington and New Delhi say the time has come to start developing the closer military ties that many on both sides hoped might develop after India gained independence in 1947. Partly, the changes have been made possible by the collapse of the Soviet Union, which was India's closest ally, and its principal source of military hardware.
Russia remains a major military supplier; in one of several recent arms purchases, the Indian Air Force bought two additional squadrons of MIG-29 fighters, at a cost of more than $2 billion. But because American policy in the region is no longer aimed at containing Soviet power, the nexus that made Pakistan a fulcrum of American military policy for decades has been broken.
In turn, Washington and New Delhi have been freed to seek a new military relationship that is no longer hostage at every turn to American ties with Pakistan.
Equally important, India is now in its fifth year of economic reforms that have featured moves toward dismantling the socialist economy built in the 1950's, when Soviet influence in India was rapidly gaining, and toward market principles.
Although total foreign investments have been modest so far compared with elsewhere in Asia, American companies have led the way, creating a momentum that has energized relations across the board.
The new military relationship was on show recently at both ends of India, in the visit of the Indian officers to the Abraham Lincoln, and in ceremonies in New Delhi organized by the United States to commemorate the last time Indian and United States forces worked closely together, in World War II.
The New Delhi ceremonies focused on veterans of the India-China air bridge across the Himalayas, known among American fliers as the Hump, that kept American and Chinese forces in China supplied from 1942 to 1945.
During their four hours aboard the Abraham Lincoln, a group of Indian officers had lunch with Rear Adm. Jay B. Yakely, commander of a carrier battle group comprising four surface ships and a submarine that sailed from San Francisco in April for a six-month deployment in the Persian Gulf.
Afterward, the Indian officers, including Rear Adm. John C. DeSilva, commander of India's western fleet based in Bombay, toured the hangar deck, watched flight operations and fanned out to discuss technical issues with American officers.
When Admiral DeSilva was asked if the presence of an American aircraft carrier off the Indian coast raised uncomfortable memories for India, he said: "We meet here as fellow sailors, as members of the brotherhood of the white uniform. The ocean is our street, and we are like neighbors. When we meet, we like to shake hands."
Admiral Yakely, a veteran carrier pilot who served on the military staff in the White House under Presidents Bush and Clinton, was equally circumspect, although he did say that having aboard Indian naval fliers -- several of whom trained in the Soviet Union -- was a measure of how the world had changed.
"I spent 20 years of my life preparing for the possibility of a war with the Soviet Union," he said. "My job was to keep their Bears and their Badgers as far away from our carriers as I could. Now, it's a different world."
On a visit to India in January, Defense Secretary William J. Perry signed an agreement that set a framework for expanded military contacts, including joint naval exercises, training exchanges and high-level consultations on military and security issues.
For now, the two Governments seem eager not to rush the pace; although the Perry visit emphasized areas in which the two countries can cooperate on military matters, major political obstacles remain.
Among these are the tense relations between India and Pakistan, and differences between Washington and New Delhi on nuclear weapons. India shunned the recent United Nations meeting that renewed the treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons, and has rejected American proposals that would cap the secret nuclear weapons programs of both India and Pakistan.
But looking to the future, many Indians say they believe that the United States has crossed a crucial threshold that could herald much wider military cooperation.
In his New Delhi office, Mr. Singh offers visitors photocopies of a speech Mr. Perry made to the Foreign Policy Association in New York after his India visit, with heavy underlining in the section where the Defense Secretary said, "India wants to retain its nuclear capability to deter the Chinese military, which is superior to India both in nuclear and conventional capability."
To some Indian military experts, Mr. Perry's words suggested that the limited military contacts could give way, as China's military might grows, to something much broader, possibly even to having Washington encourage Indian military growth as a counterbalance to China.
"The United States is going to have to look very carefully at where its long-term interests lie," Mr. Singh said. "And when they do, they'll find that it doesn't make any sense to deal with us any longer as though we were a boy in short pants."

HEADLINE: Number of Mexicans Fleeing in Boxcars Alarms U.S. Officials

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HARLINGEN, Tex., June 10

 BODY:
Economic crisis and drought in northern Mexico have driven increasing numbers of Mexicans into suffocatingly hot boxcars or other spots on rail cars to make their way into the United States to search for work and hope.
"I think a lot of them don't realize how dangerous it is," said Charles Dill, an agent with the United States Border Patrol. "A rail car is not a safe place." 
 According to the Federal Railroad Administration, 529 people were killed and 450 were injured while trespassing on railroad tracks or train yards in 1994. Some of those killed were hit by trains; others died trying to hop them. The agency does not have a breakdown of how many were illegal immigrants.
But illegal immigration is certainly up this year because of the economic crisis and drought, said a patrol spokeswoman, Letty Valadez. Arrests in the McAllen sector for the first five months of this year are up 31.5 percent from the same period in 1994 -- to 82,041 from 62,387.
The potential for tragedy is compounded by immigrant smugglers -- known on the border as "coyotes" -- who can be as careless as their often uneducated and desperate clients are trusting, border patrol agents and rail companies said.
The smugglers often lock their human cargo in boxcars without food or water, telling them that someone will let them out when they reach a destination such as San Antonio or Houston.
"To victimize people like that is just unbelievable," said Mike Furtney, spokesman for Southern Pacific Lines of San Francisco.
"We appreciate that some of these people are in tough economic straits, but we don't want them to get hurt any more than they want to get hurt," he said.
Sixty-two people were discovered in a sealed car at the Union Pacific yard in Harlingen on May 26, including seven women and two children. More than half were among 102 people rescued a week earlier from a boxcar at the Southern Pacific yard in Harlingen.
On May 10, Southern Pacific workers discovered a group of 48 immigrants pounding on the door of a boxcar in which temperatures had reached 120 degrees. Five were hospitalized for dehydration.
"If we had been in there two more minutes, I think I would have died," one immigrant said.
In 1987, 18 immigrants died in a stifling freight car in Sierra Blanca, near El Paso.
John Bromley, a spokesman for Union Pacific, said illegal train-hopping carried a financial cost along with the safety risk. Although he did not have precise figures, Mr. Bromley said companies must hire extra inspectors and delay shipments so that the trains could be searched.
He said some loads were pilfered during transit, upsetting the company's clients.
In addition, last month the border patrol charged Nestor Ibarra Osuna, a 28-year Union Pacific employee, with conspiracy to transport illegal immigrants. Investigators said the 54-year-old advised smugglers about which freight cars were most likely to be searched.
Mr. Dill, a 17-year veteran of the patrol's Harlingen station, says he always sees increases in illegal border crossers when the Mexican economy stumbles.
"I can't fault them," he said. "If I were in the same situation, I'd probably do the same thing."

HEADLINE: Crash Focuses Attention On Equipment Conditions

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
The Transit Authority has spent 13 years modernizing the New York City subways, including the antiquated signal system, which is suspected of having contributed to a fatal train crash last week. The job is about half done, and will not be completed until 2020.
A project to replace subway switching towers, which has been under way for 35 years, should finish sooner, about 2010. By then it will be time to start over. 
 Meanwhile, the pace of maintenance work is slowing. The Transit Authority is eliminating 23 maintenance positions and abandoning plans to add safety workers.
The subways have begun to look a lot better in the last few years. Cars are cleaner and more reliable, and crime and graffiti are down. But the accident last Monday, in which a J train slammed into an M train on the Williamsburg Bridge, killing a motorman, has focused attention on the condition of the system's soft underbelly: the tracks, switches, signals and other vital equipment whose upkeep and improvement require time spans so long that they are practically abstractions.
Since 1982, the Transit Authority has modernized about 40 percent of the subway signal system, but even so, today only 52 percent of the signals are in "a state of good repair"; meaning, among other things, that they are no more than 50 years old, according to the engineers who run the system. Modernization is expected to be completed by 2020, but that date is far from certain. "That's provided we get the same level of funding we anticipate, and it keeps up with inflation," said Dr. Nabil N. Ghaly, the head of the signal division.
Dr. Ghaly's time scale and caveat apply to many of the subway's crucial components. After 13 years of intensified effort and $20 billion, there is a sense of timelessness to the modernization of the subways, and a planning horizon that is uncommon in government. Dr. Ghaly, who is 49 years old and has spent 26 years at the Transit Authority, is discussing projects that will outlast his career by 10 years or more.
For example, in the late 1950's, when Robert F. Wagner was Mayor, the subway system set out to replace its 225 switching towers, each with operators pulling mechanical switches, with 32 remote-controlled master towers.
Today, 25 master towers have been built, allowing 173 of the old towers to close. Work continues on the other 7 new towers, so the last 52 old towers can be closed. By the time work is finished, around 2010 or so, it will be time to start replacing the first master towers, which will be 50 years old.
Of course, signal system modernization, like most subway projects, could go faster if more money were available, but in an era of budget cuts, planners are now delaying parts of the modernization program.
The Transit Authority had $9.6 billion in its capital budget for modernization of the entire system, including buses, from 1992 to 1996, but had to scale back plans when New York City reduced its contribution by $500 million. Most prominently, it has delayed the renovation of 17 stations.
Some less visible improvements will also be delayed. Engineers had planned since 1992 to spend $10 million to upgrade the signals on a 4 1/2-mile stretch at the northern end of the No. 5 line, to allow trains to run in either direction on either of the two tracks. Now the job will be delayed 10 years or more.
Engineers put off rebuilding the Franklin Avenue Shuttle in Brooklyn. They cut $44 million out of a program to modernize station lighting. And the elevated White Plains Road line, from 149th Street to 241st Street in the Bronx, was supposed to undergo a structural rehabilitation; now the authority plans to issue a contract only for the stretch from 149th to 180th Streets, for $45 million. The line north of 180th Street will have to wait.
Maintenance has also been cut back. The signal repair force will lose 11 people working as maintainers, about 1 percent of the total. Twelve technician jobs will also be cut, leading to longer maintenance cycles for public-address and emergency telephone systems, and for some subway lines. A fire safety specialist job will be eliminated, and a safety manager position that was to have been filled this year in the stations division will not be.
A spokesman for the Transit Authority, Jared Lebow, said that none of these cutbacks would compromise safety, and there is little evidence that cutbacks have made the subways more accident prone. The pattern of accidents is inconclusive. There were 7 collisions or derailments in 1991, 8 in 1992, 13 in 1993 and 8 in 1994. Halfway through 1995, there have been 4.
The Transit Authority also records deaths and injuries on the subways, but officials say that the statistics have little bearing on how they operate the trains. Most injuries result from incidents like passengers' falling between cars or down stairs, Mr. Lebow said. Accidents per million passengers have been constant at around 4.2, officials say.
Outside experts generally do not focus on the specifics, but they say they are worried.
"We're very concerned whether these cutbacks in inspections and maintenance might have contributed to the accident, or might contribute to future accidents," said Gene M. Russianoff, staff lawyer of the Straphangers Campaign, a riders' advocacy group. Cutting has been going on for a few years, he said.
Deferred maintenance is always a bad idea, said Samuel I. Schwartz, a former deputy city transportation commissioner, now a professor at Cooper Union. "I don't think anyone riding the system understands about the bridges and the tracks and the switches and the signals," he said. "Those will always be hidden, and the public will never be clamoring for those things until there is an accident."
David L. Gunn, president of the Transit Authority from 1984 until 1990 and now chief general manager of the Toronto Transit Commission, struck a similar note. What everyone wants, he said, is "stations, and fare collection systems and all that stuff." But he said he put priority "on the nuts and bolts, if you will, tracks, power, things like that."
"You can always do a little more," he said in a telephone interview. "We were assuming that there would be a third capital program, and given that assumption we thought we were moving ahead in a fairly comprehensive way."
There was a third capital program, due to be finished next year. But Gov. George E. Pataki recently asked the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Transit Authority's parent agency, to delay issuing $690 million in bonds that are part of that program. Even before that, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani balked, as Mayor David N. Dinkins had before him, at paying $500 million of the city's share.
The immediate effect of slowing modernization is on efficiency. Outdated signals, for example, cost passengers time. Often it is the signals, not tracks or trains, that control how many trains can be pushed through a station; if they were modernized, engineers say, stations that can handle only 26 to 30 trains per hour now could take 36 to 40 trains. In a system in which building new track is almost impossible, that would be a major capacity improvement.
But that would take a major investment, in signals and cars to match.
The signal system on the Williamsburg Bridge, now 77 years old, was scheduled for replacement, but the Transit Authority decided to delay until the Department of Transportation finished rebuilding the bridge. The signal system's possible role in the accident last week is now under the scrutiny of the National Transportation Safety Board.
Investigators have found evidence of a defect that may prove to have been crucial, a trip bar meant to trigger the train's emergency brakes that did not rise high enough from the side of the track.
Engineers use a formula to determine the condition of signals. Physical condition counts for 50 percent, age for 35 percent and engineering -- whether the design of the system is close enough to modern standards -- for 15 percent.
The Jamaica line, from 121st Street in Queens to Chambers Street in Manhattan, ranks at 64.3 percent, in a system in which 58 is a passing grade. It ranks 17th of 34 lines in the city.
But the stretch on which the accident occurred last Monday had a lower rating. The rating for physical condition of the 66 signals on the route was 38.9 percent. Since it was built in 1918, the age rating was 25 percent. The engineering rating was 53.1 percent, and the overall score was 36.2 percent.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Lukas Knows The Count On Anything

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
D. WAYNE LUKAS had just won yet another triple crown race yesterday -- Thunder Gulch had something to do with that -- when somebody asked him to test the microphone for the news conference.
"One, two, three, four, five," Lukas said, deadpan. 
 Nobody got it.
"Come on, you got to be quicker than that," Lukas twitted the slow-witted reporters.
Five, get it? D. Wayne has now won five straight triple crown races, which nobody ever did before. That was the point of yesterday. Five straight triple crown races is a biggie. And D. Wayne did it with three different horses -- the 1994 Preakness and Belmont with Tabasco Cat, the 1995 Kentucky Derby with Thunder Gulch, the 1995 Preakness with Timber Country -- which tells you that wealthy people trust D. Wayne Lukas with their expensive horses. That is a biggie, too.
Racing needs more biggies, particularly a triple crown horse, to draw people back to the Belmont. The joint is haunted by the big red horse who came thundering down the straightaway in 1973, winning by 31 lengths. At the Belmont, everybody knows there will never be another Secretariat. That's history. That's tradition. It's also a downer.
The Kentucky Derby and the Preakness are gigantic garden parties, but the Belmont is becoming a drag. Yesterday's attendance on a cool but unthreatening afternoon was 37,171, the lowest Belmont in at least half a century. It's nice to know that racing in New York is not trying to show up poor baseball, a sign of professional respect from one sport to another.
The Belmont often used to draw in the 50's and 60's, but last year the attendance dropped to 42,695. The lowest attendance on record was 38,477 in 1959, and yesterday the crowd fell below that.
Where was everybody? Maybe thousands of people decided not to come after hearing that Timber Country was scratched from yesterday's Belmont, late Friday afternoon. The Preakness winner had a fever for a brief time, but Lukas took no chances and scratched him.
Poor Lukas. He was now down to one triple crown horse. He started this season, five weeks ago with three -- Serena's Song, Thunder Gulch and Timber Country. He raved about the toughness of Serena's Song and the potential of Timber Country, and he conceded Thunder Gulch was a "stepchild." But Lukas is cool. When Thunder Gulch stole the Derby, he promptly said with a straight face that he had always liked the colt.
He loved him even more yesterday when the afterthought rumbled past Star Standard (with Julie Krone apparently trying to keep her horse from lugging out) to take the Belmont, too. It's almost too late for Thunder Gulch to get a huge amount of respect, but Lukas is getting his. And he wants all of it.
When he finally whipped the audio into shape yesterday, Lukas bristled at a question that he only began racing thoroughbreds in 1978. He delivered a rather crisp travelogue of all the bush-league tracks where he not only raced horses but built his own barns, too. He didn't just put away his basketball coach's whistle in 1978 and start training horses. D. Wayne Lukas was not born yesterday.
He's heading down the stretch toward 60 on Sept. 2, and he sends horses out in twos and threes sometimes. And yes, the trainer from Wisconsin is still hungry.
"Wayne's going for this record, it gets a little heavy," admitted Gary Stevens, who was relieved he hadn't messed up Wayne's personal triple crown.
Lukas was asked about his place in history. He gave the feeling he has one. "Statistically, we have made a place," Lukas said. "We've carved out a spot in the sport."
Then he gave a few reasons for his success: "All the great ones, Charlie Whittingham, Woody Stephens in his heyday, had an unbelievable work ethic." And, "You have to have a feel for it. I change my mind daily." And, "You have to have a bad memory, there are so many setbacks, they'll eat you up." And, "The owners have to believe in your philosophy."
There was a rough period a few years ago when the economics were bad, but the owners believe in D. Wayne Lukas -- a hot hand in a chilly age at the Belmont.

HEADLINE: Common Sense on Immigration

 BODY:
A bipartisan Federal commission proposed last week that the United States slash legal immigration by one-third and virtually close the nation's borders to "extended" family members of American citizens. President Clinton swiftly embraced the report. But after representatives of Asian and Hispanic immigrants complained bitterly, the President's press secretary volunteered that perhaps the White House had not carefully considered all the issues.
 The press secretary spoke the truth. The White House seems to have reacted before deliberating carefully on an issue that begs for deft handling. Immigration, along with affirmative action, promises to become an incendiary issue in the 1996 elections. It plays to racial fears. It plays to economic fears of workers whose wages have stagnated for two decades. The President can easily embrace the commission's basic policy thrust: admit more skilled, and fewer unskilled, workers. But he should hesitate before endorsing its proposal to reduce immigration levels and impose a "fee" on employers who hire foreign professionals. 
 The emotional issues aside, immigration is a tough subject to get right because so little is known about its economic impact. Historically, the United States has been enriched by a steady influx of energetic and ambitious immigrants. But no one knows whether current levels, about 900,000 a year, are too low or too high. There are, however, disturbing trends. Twenty years ago, immigrants and those born in America were equally educated and earned equivalent wages. Since then, the percentage of immigrants who have dropped out of high school has risen and their wages fallen. In the 1970's, immigrants collected relatively little welfare; now they depend on welfare more than the native born do.
 Since the early 1970's, the gap between the earnings of college graduates and high school dropout has risen by more than 50 percent. Experts disagree, but many believe that low-skilled immigrants have driven down the earnings of low-wage native-born workers who compete for the same jobs. A study by Prof. George Borjas of the University of California estimates that perhaps a third of the increased inequality can be traced to immigration.
 The commission would lower annual immigration from 900,000 to 550,000. It would reserve 400,000 slots for members of an American citizen's nuclear family (primarily young children and spouses). But it would end the current law's preferential treatment of siblings and other extended-family members -- a provision that has inflamed Asian-American and Hispanic families.
 The commission would reserve 100,000 slots for workers who receive job offers from American employers -- a drop from current levels but high enough, the commission believes, to accommodate employer demand. But, in a change from current law, few of these job-based slots would be allocated to workers who lack a college degree.
 The logic of the plan is clear. For humanitarian reasons, immigration slots would first go to members of a nuclear family. All other slots would be restricted to skilled workers. The total would bring immigration back down to the levels of the early 1980's. These proposals are defensible.
 But they come at a cost of shutting out brothers, sisters, adult children and others whom America has often welcomed. Thus Congress will be obliged to raise and debate alternatives. Congress could create additional slots for family unification, but choose among the applicants on the basis of skills they would bring to the work force. That could unite families, recruit skilled workers and protect the nation's low-wage employees.
 Some of the commission's ideas are hard to defend. It would, for example, tax employers who recruit skilled foreign workers and make the employer pay them above-market wages. That idea runs counter to the goals of bringing valuable skills to the economy and closing the earnings gap between high-paid and low-paid workers.
 The forthcoming debate on immigration will take surprising turns. The ordinarily unified Republicans are deeply split -- with Senator Alan Simpson and Gov. Pete Wilson urging restrictions while the House majority leader, Dick Armey, urges the opposite. The commission has provided some reasonable words on a deeply sensitive issue. But they are surely not the final words.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
McMullen's 'Suiteheart' Plan: Run the Arena

BYLINE: By DAVE ANDERSON 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

 BODY:
INCHING their way south, the Devils were on a bus last night to Philadelphia for today's fifth game of their Stanley Cup playoff that is now 2-2 after yesterday's 4-2 loss. But the bus wasn't going on to Nashville. At least not yet.
"We're not going to do anything," John McMullen was saying, "until our playoffs are over."
In a two-and-a-half-hour conversation with three New York Times reporters at his Norton Lilly International shipping headquarters in nearby Secaucus, the Devils' owner insisted that "it's not too late" for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to keep the team in Byrne Meadowlands Arena but it can't keep dawdling.
"You know what Nashville is offering," McMullen said, as if talking to the state agency. "Give us a proposal." 
 Around that same time Friday afternoon, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was telling the Devils to put a proposal on the table.
So while all the country-and-western fiddlers in Nashville fiddle, the Devils' future in the Meadowlands is burning.
Nashville is offering a new $120 million arena, a $20 million relocation payment, 100 percent of game-ticket revenue (including luxury suites), 75 percent of parking fees and 40 percent of gross revenue on concessions. Even so, McMullen indicated he would keep the hockey team here if the Devils operated the arena.
"I want to run it," he said.
That's the crux of this power struggle. McMullen wants a luxury-suiteheart deal here in order to lift the Devils to the economic level of other National Hockey League teams with new arenas either already open or under construction. But the sports authority doesn't want to relinquish its control over the 19,040-seat (for hockey) arena in its Sports Complex with Giants Stadium and the Meadowlands race track.
"The sports authority doesn't care about us; they'd rather have us leave," the 77-year-old shipping tycoon said. "They told us, 'We can make more money with rock concerts.' "
In the N.H.L. bylaws, 24 guidelines pertain to the possibility of a team moving to another market. McMullen was asked to respond to those guidelines that mostly pertain to the Devils-to-Nashville situation. The guidelines and his answers:
Are the Devils financially viable where they are? "No."
Have the fans historically supported the club? "Yes."
Have the Devils historically operated profitably? "No."
Has he made a good-faith offer to sell the Devils to someone who would keep the club here? "I don't intend to sell."
Are the arena authorities willing to remedy any deficiencies in the arena? "No willingness as of yet."
Would the departure of the Devils to Nashville damage the N.H.L.'s image? "I don't think so."
Would a proposed transfer adversely affect traditional rivalries? "Our rivalry with the Rangers, yes."
If the Devils leave, would the sports authority sue the N.H.L. to enforce its lease? "Ask the authority."
When the questions and answers ended, Lou Lamoriello, the Devils' general manager who accompanied McMullen to Friday's meeting, issued a reminder.
"The commissioner," Lamoriello said of Gary Bettman, "is the sole interpreter of all the bylaws."
Bettman has described the Byrne Meadowlands Arena and the Devils' television contract as "substandard." Bettman also has suggested that the sports authority's conduct "presents a very serious issue." To that, Charles Francis, the authority chairman, insisted that it has honored all its obligations, commitments and responsibilities to the Devils.
McMullen remained bitter that the authority suspended the Devils' lease on Dec. 22 during the N.H.L. labor dispute.
But when Lamoriello was asked if he had visited Nashville, as reported, to talk to officials there in December before the arena lease was suspended, the general manager declined to answer.
So it goes, this power struggle between the Devils and the sports authority over the hockey team's future either here or in Nashville.
Although the Devils' arena here opened in 1982 and is considered to have better sightlines than Madison Square Garden, McMullen sounded transfixed by the new arenas that will enable the Boston Bruins, the Philadelphia Flyers and the Buffalo Sabres, among others, to retain so much more income than the Devils do now.
That's why McMullen wants a luxury-suiteheart deal involving control of the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the equivalent of having your cake and eating it, too. So far that cake has fallen flat with the Governor and the sports authority.
The more John McMullen talked on Friday, the more his heart still seemed to be in New Jersey, where he was born and bred and lives. He complained that "nobody has ever said 'thanks' to me" for bringing the Devils here in 1982 after purchasing the Colorado franchise and for building a Stanley Cup contender.
But any multimillionaire businessman's heart is only as true as the best deal he can make.

HEADLINE: MARKET TIMING

 BODY:

Monday
 
The United States and Japan are scheduled to begin talks in Geneva over trade in autos and auto parts and the trade sanctions the United States imposed on $5.9 billion of Japanese luxury car imports.
 
Tuesday
 
The Labor Department delivers its key indicator on inflation when it releases the consumer price index for May. Forecast: up 0.4 percent, the same as the advance in April. The index rose 0.2 percent in March.
 
The Commerce Department releases retail sales for May. Forecast: up 0.6 percent on stronger sales of home furnishings and clothing, after falling 0.4 percent in April. Sales had jumped 0.8 percent in March.
 
The Senate Finance Committee holds a hearing on the tax status of the American Association of Retired Persons.
 
Wednesday
 
The Commerce Department reports April business inventories and sales. Forecast: inventories are expected to continue their rise, up 0.5 percent, after climbing 0.7 percent in March and 0.8 percent in February. Sales did not change in March, but rose 0.2 percent in February.
 
The House Economic Committee discusses a bill that would nullify an executive order barring Federal contracts with companies that hire permanent replacements during strikes.
 
Thursday
 
The Federal Reserve reports on the state of the American manufacturing industry when it releases capacity utilization and industrial production numbers for May. Forecast: utilization is expected to drop again, to 83.6 percent, down from 84.1 percent in April and 84.7 percent in March. Production should also decline, by 0.3 percent. It dropped 0.4 percent in April and 0.3 percent in March.
 
International Multifoods is expected to release quarterly earnings. Forecast: 20 cents a share.
 
Friday
 
The Federal Reserve releases its report of assets and liabilities of commercial banks.

HEADLINE: The Bureaucracy: What's Left To Shrink?

 BODY:
Republicans have been complaining loudly that government is America's No. 1 growth industry, bigger than cars, computers or even health care. The only way to curb this rampant monster? Shift more and more responsibility from Washington to state capitals and city halls.
 You'd never guess from all that complaining that the Federal bureaucracy, far from burgeoning, has been shrinking. Nor would you guess that all the growth in government has occurred at the state and local level. 
 It's true though.
 The Government's own employment data, reported every month since 1939 by the Department of Labor, show that Federal jobs, not counting the military, are a smaller share of all jobs now than at any time since the eve of World War II. The ratio of Federal bureaucrats to American citizens is lower -- a lot lower -- than it was when Dwight Eisenhower was in the White House. Since the end of the 1980's, while the economy has added 8 million jobs, the number of civil servants has dropped, to 2.8 million from 3 million.
 Granted, nobody would argue that a smaller Federal payroll means that the Federal Government is less powerful than it used to be. It is spending as much money as it ever did. Equally important, Washington makes the rules. Robert Higgs, an economist and author of "Crisis and Leviathan," the conservative classic about the natural tendency of government to grow over time, points out that government employment "only counts the people who work for the government, not all the people who are only doing what they're doing because of the government."
 Nonetheless, the image of a Government vastly more bloated than it was in the golden 1950's and 60's is clearly misleading.
 The shrinkage of the Federal bureaucracy isn't tied to one political party, either. It started not when Ronald Reagan moved into the White House, but when Newt Gingrich and Bill Clinton were in still in college, in the mid-60's, not long after Lyndon B. Johnson coined the term "Great Society."
 And the bureaucracy's failure to grow in lockstep with the economy can't be traced to any single group of workers. The number of civilian defense workers, who account for a bit more than a quarter of Federal employees, dwindled after Vietnam and the end of the cold war. But so did the number of postal workers, who make up almost as large a share of the total. And so did the other categories, include everyone from Department of Agriculture meat inspectors to national park rangers to National Institutes of Health physicians.
 What growth there has been in government employment, it turns out, has been at the state and local level, exactly where the Republican reformers think government should be most active. But this shift is no product of the recent anti-Washington mood. The biggest expansion of payrolls took place in the 1950's, 1960's and early 1970's, when the 75 million-strong baby boom generation flooded into schools and suburbanization placed heavy demands for roads and other public works. And while some of the growth in state and especially local government jobs undoubtedly reflects mandates like Medicare that are imposed by Washington, most of it has been driven by education. Half of the 17 million state and local workers work in the schools.
 Indeed, as states and local governments have taken on larger roles, the Federal Government's function has changed as well. As entitlement programs have grown, much of what Washington does involves gathering taxes and transferring money to people who get Government checks, whether it's farmers who get crop payments, mothers who collect welfare, students who receive subsidized loans or people who get Medicare reimbursements.
 "The Federal Government has gone from being a service provider to being a provider of cash," said Stephen Moore, an economist at the Cato Institute, a libertarian research organization in Washington, "and that doesn't take a lot of people."

HEADLINE: In Budget Battle Between Mayor and the Council, the Devil Is in the Details

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

 BODY:
There is a small nursery at New York Foundling Hospital in Manhattan, supported by the taxpayers of the City of New York, where troubled parents can drop off their children for a day or so when for whatever reason -- drugs, illness, domestic violence -- they feel they can no longer cope.
It is only one of scores of programs that have given New York City its national reputation for expansive social services. And it is one of the programs that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says the city can no longer afford. 
 With the city facing a $3.1 billion budget gap for the fiscal year that begins in less than three weeks, the Mayor and the City Council have moved the fight over the city's budget from the abstract political debate of recent months to the specific debate over whether the city will continue to pay for places like the Foundling Hospital nursery.
Saying the city had to end what he often calls "out of control" spending, Mr. Giuliani, the Republican who has pledged to wrestle the city's fiscal problems under control, has proposed a $31.1 billion budget that includes the largest cut in total spending since World War II. His budget would reduce spending to myriad services, affecting millions of New Yorkers in ways large and small -- from schoolchildren to the mentally ill.
To the Democrats on the City Council, as well as advocates for various services, the Mayor's budget has put on the chopping block some of the very services and programs that have made up the city's historic mission: to provide for the young and old, the ill and the poor.
The budget would, for example, sharply cut music and arts classes and summer school in public schools, while junior varsity sports and the summer youth competition known as the Big Apple Games would be eliminated. It would slash funding for foster care and for preventive services intended to keep the children of troubled families out of foster care.
It would trim the city subsidies of cultural institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Arts, while hitting more than 400 smaller arts groups even harder. It would cut street-cleaning in central business districts and on major highways, reduce recycling outreach efforts and end financing for virtually all the city's youth services.
"The impact of these cuts are going to be the worst anybody has seen in years," said Councilman Stanley E. Michels, a Democrat from Manhattan. "There are people who think they are immune to all these cuts, but they're going to feel it every way."
As the Mayor and the Council continued to negotiate over the weekend -- mostly, as with the state's budget process, behind closed doors -- many Council members have pledged to restore many of the cuts. But they acknowledge that the sobering reality of the city's nagging budget problems leaves little room to preserve them all.
In fact, the realization last week that the state's budget had given the city $670 million less in assistance than the Mayor sought has made a difficult task even more so -- with Mr. Giuliani proposing still deeper cuts to schools, hospitals and welfare recipients.
The League Treatment Center, which operates five-day programs in Brooklyn for mentally retarded and disturbed adults and children, faces a $500,000 cut from the city, which triggers another $1 million in cuts in matching state funds -- 10 percent of the center's $15 million budget.
The executive director, Hannah Achtenberg Kinn, said although the cut may not mean closing, it could mean ending special work programs for retarded adults. "These are vulnerable, vulnerable people," she said. "Where will they go?"
Council leaders have called for softening the blow of some of the cuts by finding other, still-unspecified ways to balance the budget. They say the Mayor should agree to such measures as selling assets or refinancing debt, which cost the city in the future but mean fewer cuts now. The Council's Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, has also proposed raising property taxes on single- to three-family homes that are used solely as rentals, raising $80 million that he said could offset the worst budget cuts.
"A budget hole of this size can't be solved with cuts alone," the Council's finance director, Thomas L. McMahon, said.
So far, Mr. Giuliani has rejected those ideas, forcing the Council's negotiators into a difficult calculus: each dollar restored in one area means they have to propose another dollar to cut elsewhere.
What is at stake are scores of services and programs like the center at Foundling, called the Crisis Nursery. Taken singly, each makes up only a fraction of a $31.1 billion budget -- the nursery, for example, receives only $93,000 a year from the city -- but together they add up to millions.
Mr. Giuliani has argued that the city must wrench down the size of government if the city hopes to revive its sluggish economy. Even so, he says that the budget cuts will still leave New York with the most generous services of any city in the nation. And he has characterized the most dire warnings raised by his opponents as exaggerations, saying the budget cuts last year have not markedly affected people's lives.
"Believe me, you will hear all of the predictions about how terrible all these cuts are going to be," the Mayor said recently. "You will hear the same predictions you heard last year. The end result is I'll stand here a year from now, and we will not have the kind of impact those people who argue in favor of this spending and try to pretend it will happen."
But for the people who run the Crisis Nursery, the Mayor's budget has raised the specter of closing a program they say has saved children from abuse, neglect and even death.
Opened in 1982 with the support of Mayor Edward I. Koch, the nursery operates as a respite for children who face abuse or neglect. The nursery can accommodate 10 children, offering meals and beds and everything in between. For parents, the nursery tries to locate needed services -- from detox to counseling -- to prevent abuse and to hold families together. It also operates a 24-hour hotline.
The $93,000 the nursery gets from the city's budget enables it to receive three times that in state matching funds -- its entire budget except for administrative support from the Foundling Hospital.
Echoing the criticism by other advocates, Sister Helen Murphy, the executive director of Foundling, said the cuts would prove counterproductive. "It's cheaper," she said of programs like the nursery. "That's a horrible word to use when you're talking about people, but it costs less to have them in preventive services than in foster care."
Not all the Mayor's cuts would fall on the neediest. Many, advocates say, would land squarely on the working and middle classes -- from the cuts to local arts groups to the elimination of junior varsity sports in high schools in all five boroughs to the reduction in the city's subsidy to the Transit Authority, which could end free passes on subway and buses for schoolchildren.
For Adenike Cumberland, a sophomore who lives in Far Rockaway, Queens, and rides the subway to high school in Manhattan, the cut in subway passes would cost her parents dearly since an extra $2.50 a day quickly adds up. "I don't know how I'd get to school," she said, "unless I swim across the bay."
To critics of the Mayor and to an extent the Council, it is the budget's impact on ordinary New Yorkers that has often been obscured in the political and fiscal debates.
"The Mayor has looked at the budget as a purely mathematical problem," said Gail B. Nayowith, executive director of the Citizens Committee for Children, a nonprofit advocacy group that has criticized Mr. Giuliani's cuts to schools and youth programs. "The fact is what's at stake is not as flat as that: it's human."


GRAPHIC: These are the highlights of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that are the subject of the some of the sharpest disputes with the City Council. HEADLINE: Research Park Rising on Site of Audubon Ballroom

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
THE grainy black and white photographs in the architect's office show an empty room with folding chairs pushed haphazardly aside. Tiny black dots ringed with white chalk -- bullet holes outlined by police technicians -- pepper the podium.
After a decade of major and minor confrontations among a kaleidoscopic array of city agencies, Washington Heights residents and officials of Columbia University, 40 percent of that room -- where Malcolm X was assassinated on Feb. 21, 1965 -- still stands, newly shrouded in white sheetrock and waiting for its promised museum and memorial. 
 Only five years ago the building, the Audubon Ballroom, a fanciful entertainment complex built in 1912 at Broadway between 165th and 166th Streets and decorated with red foxes and a blue and green tympanum of Neptune and a maiden riding a tempestuous sea, was destined for destruction. But through the efforts of Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, along with a number of community groups, about two-thirds of the exterior of the two-story complex has been preserved and a painstaking $7 million restoration has just been finished.
A new six-story, $28 million structure of gray-painted aluminum and green glass, designed by the architectural firm of Davis, Brody & Associates, has been built about 15 feet behind the facade of the old building. The terra-cotta encrusted structure once housed, in addition to the ballroom, a 2,500-seat movie theater, a 200-seat cabaret and a downstairs bistro where magic tricks were performed.
The new 105,000-square-foot structure is part of a planned five-building Audubon Biomedical Science and Technology Park across the street from Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. The new building was built by Columbia University to house individual laboratory facilities for a group of still undetermined emerging biotechnology companies, and is just receiving its finishing touches. Along Broadway and wrapping around the corner of 165th Street, all the bays of the original decorative facade have been restored, but the huge brick back end of the old San Juan Theater has been demolished, leaving what is now an empty lot.
After the first commercial laboratory building fills up, Columbia plans to build another commercial laboratory on the lot. Mitch Gipson, the Columbia official in charge of leasing, said he was negotiating with three or four companies that were looking for anywhere from 1,000 to 12,000 square feet apiece in the building that has just been completed.
Some of these potential tenants "are quite serious and some are just kicking the tires," Mr. Gipson said. Columbia plans to spend about $5 million inside the new lab, fitting out what is now raw space for its tenants, building partitions, lab benches and other amenities.
GROUNDBREAKING for the second building in the complex, the 170,000-square-foot, $65 million Center for Disease Prevention, is scheduled for June 19. This second building, across St. Nicholas Avenue, is to be an academic research center. Davis, Brody is the architect for the entire project, including the restoration.
John S. Torborg, project architect for Davis, Brody, said the large ground floor space at the corner of West 166th Street will become a 3,200-square-foot restaurant similar to West End Gate, a restaurant at Broadway and 114th Street, across from Columbia's main campus. It is set for an October opening, he said.
A 550-square-foot shop is to be rented to one of the city's large coffee bar chains. A 3,250-square-foot Barnes and Noble is scheduled to open sometime in July.
Above the two restaurants and the book store will be a city health clinic promised to the residents. Bids for construction are out, and the city is negotiating with health-care providers.
In the southern half of the ground floor, bounded by West 165th Street, is a Chemical Bank branch that opened for business in February.
On the second floor, above the Chemical Bank, is the space for the memorial to Malcolm X. Money to restore the exterior of the historic building and renovate the interior shell came from a combination of city and state agencies, primarily the Urban Development Corporation and the Economic Development Corporation; the original seed money was provided by Ms. Messinger's office.
But there is some confusion about where the $1 million to furnish the memorial museum -- a rough estimate from the architects -- is to come from. "Money's always been an issue," said Mr. Gipson of Columbia. "It's never been resolved how you'd pay for it. Everybody is aware of the issue."
According to Howard Dodson, head of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, who is part of an advisory committee named several years ago by then-Mayor David N. Dinkins and charged with developing a plan for the memorial, the "ball is with the city."
"Somehow, millions of dollars were appropriated for the buildings and no funds were appropriated for the specific activities within it," Mr. Dodson said. "I'm sure eventually there will be a memorial."
According to Marty Algaze, a spokesman for Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, the ball is in Mr. Dodson's court.
"We're waiting to get a proposal on the table" from Mr. Dodson's group "so we can discuss where the funding will come from -- whether private or city," Mr. Algaze said.
Dr. William Polf, Columbia's vice president for strategic planning, said that although the university was only involved in an informal way, his associate, Mr. Gipson, may have come up with a possible solution that is to presented to the parties involved in a week or so. He declined to elaborate. Mr. Gipson also declined to comment, citing the "extremely political" nature of the discussion.
Right now, plans are going ahead to finish the lobby to the memorial -- which the architects said was once the elaborate niche-filled, plaster-decorated entrance to the movie palace. The terrazzo floor has been restored and extended to what will become a curving lobby stage.
A life-size bronze statue of Malcolm X by Gabriel Koren has been commissioned with city money; a maquette was finished several weeks ago. Another large mural -- depicting Malcolm X's life -- is being designed by Daniel Galvez, a West Coast artist, for the long wall in the memorial space.
THE wooden stage, where Malcolm X was standing when he was shot, has been dismantled and preserved, but the architects said it was so rotted that a new one must be built, perhaps symbolically incorporating some sections of the old one.
Lew Davis, a partner in the architectural firm, said the outside of the new building, with its gray aluminum panels and green glass windows echoing the Alpine green of the wooden trim of the old Audubon, was designed as a "background building" to show off the ornament and style of the older building.
J. Max Bond, another partner, called the building "neutral and gridded" and said the six-story height echoed the height of neighborhood tenements.
On the 166th Street side, where several bays of the 1913 building were demolished for the entrance to the new laboratory, the new building is neatly fitted to the old, with the creamy terra cotta of the old butting the limestone-colored concrete of the new.
The project is not without its critics.
"In terms of a fitting memorial to Malcolm X, it still strikes me as an injustice," said Michael Henry Adams, a Harlem preservationist. "To take part of something, tear it down, build on top of it and present it to the people is an injustice."
But Mr. Adams said he had been wrong several years ago, when he announced it would be better to tear the Audubon Ballroom down than to leave just fragments.
"I think now that I was wrong," he said. "It's just like people might say it would be better to tear the Parthenon down rather than leave it in a ruinous condition; they still can learn from it. And people from all over the world will come to see the Audubon. Thee quality of the architecture is so high; they retained all the plasterwork and the terra cotta for all to see."
The decision not to save the whole building, he said, will nevertheless be judged by history "to be as irresponsible an act of vandalism as the destruction of Penn Station."
"Unfortunately," he said, "we don't seem to learn much from our mistakes."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

HEADLINE: The World;
Racism? Mexico's in Denial.

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
SHROUDED in mystery and myth, the heroes of Mexico's Aztec past are honored in glorious monuments all over the country.
 But the living descendants of Moctezuma are not allowed to eat in some of Mexico City's best restaurants. 
 Although all Mexicans are considered equal under the country's Constitution, Mexican society remains deeply divided on racial lines. And as the richest and poorest of the 91 million Mexicans are driven farther apart by such sweeping changes as the North American Free Trade Agreement, many Mexicans are starting to discover the dangers of their own deeply ingrained -- yet rarely acknowledged -- brand of bigotry.
 The racial inequities are not just limited to the Maya Indians in the state of Chiapas who took up arms on the very day Nafta took effect more than a year ago, in what is slowly taking on shades of a national civil rights movement for Indians. Indigenous people all over Mexico, and those with Indian features -- and dark skins -- all feel a degree of the same kind of intolerance.

 
 
Bigotry? What Bigotry?
 While Mexicans typically deny that discrimination exists, the not-so-subtle racial undertones of their society are apparent to foreigners who live and work here since Nafta was passed. When Henry B. McDonald, director of the Cushman & Wakefield Real Estate office in Mexico City took his family out for dinner last November, he didn't think twice about inviting his 45-year-old housekeeper, Gabriela Miranda, an Indian. It was a Friday night and they went to a popular Italian restaurant called Prego in the Polanco section of Mexico City.
 "We got there early by Mexican standards, around 7:45, and the place was empty," Mr. McDonald said. "But we stood there waiting and waiting until finally the maitre'd came along and told me, in English, that domestics are not served here." Mrs. Miranda was not wearing a uniform, Mr. McDonald said. The restaurant simply assumed that because she was an Indian she was a maid.
 The restaurant manager, Mario Padilla, acknowledged that it is policy at Prego and other top restaurants to prohibit servants and drivers, many of whom are Indians. "The type of people who usually come to restaurants of this class all have servants, but they usually leave them at home," Mr. Padilla said. He said the restriction was needed to protect patrons against people who "lack discretion" and try to bring their servants. He denied the policy was discriminatory. "We're not racists," he said. "We're just trying to protect the image of the restaurant."

 
 
Social Tension
 Now that Mexico is struggling to overcome an economic crisis caused by the peso's devaluation last December, there is concern that racial tensions will flare. More than half a million Mexicans have been thrown out of work in the last six months, and the struggle to survive is likely to be decided on the basis of education, access to money and cultural connections, all of which are based in large part on racial identity.
 "There is going to be a sharp increase in social tensions," said Sergio Aguayo, a human rights activist in Mexico City, "and some of it is going to be racially inspired."
 Bias against Indians has long been more economic than personal. Sixty percent of Indians over 12 are already unemployed and of those who work most earn less than the minimum wage of about $2.50 a day.
 But most Mexicans say bigotry does not exist here. Schoolchildren are drilled on the life of Benito Juarez, a Zapotec Indian who was President of Mexico in the 19th century, and told that his election proves all Mexicans are equal. Mexico has no affirmative action laws. The National Commission of Human Rights has never received a discrimination complaint and does not even have a process to handle one.
 Complicating questions of race is the mixed lineage of most Mexicans. From the Spanish founding of Mexico, social class has been determined by racial purity, with those born in Spain at the top, and full-blooded Indians on the bottom. But over centuries of intermarriage, nearly all Mexicans are considered part Indian.
 Now it is the degree of Indianness, or the darkness of brown skin, that determines status. Many Mexicans living in the cities rely on hair dyes, skin lighteners and blue or green contact lenses to appear more white or European and less Indian.
 "Yes, Mexicans honor their Indian roots with statues," said Miguel Acosta, an investigator at the Mexican Academy of Human Rights at the Autonomous National University of Mexico, "but historic roots are not at all useful when it comes to eating or just living today."
 Mexico City has the highest concentration of Indians in the country, yet most times they are nearly invisible, showing up only in knots of beggars at busy intersections and among the feathered dancers who perform for tourists. No Indians serve in the Cabinet of President Ernesto Zedillo and only a handful are in the Congress, although 1 in 10 Mexicans is considered Indian.
 The racial insensitivity extends to blacks, although few live in Mexico. A recent commercial on national television featured a dark-skinned man in a white tuxedo telling viewers that at Comex, a Mexican paint company, "they're working like niggers to offer you a white sale."
 There were no complaints about the ad "because we don't have a racism problem -- that's the key to it all," said Marisela Vergada, an account executive at Alazraki Agency, the large Mexican advertising firm that produced the 20-second spot. "It is simply an expression that everyone uses."
 Such "expressions" pop up in a commercial for packaged toast that features a black baker boasting that his skin color gives him the expertise to recognize the right shade of toast. Aunt Jemima pancake mix goes by the brand name "La Negrita" here.

 
 
'Racial Hierarchy'
 The few blacks who live in Mexico are either immigrants or the descendants of about 200,000 African slaves brought here before slavery was abolished in 1829. While researching a book about African slaves in Mexico, Colin A. Palmer, a history professor at the graduate center of the City University of New York, said he quickly noticed that beneath an initial friendliness "a racial hierarchy existed in Mexico."
 "It is based on skin color, with white the higher value as opposed to those who are brown and those, God forbid, who are black," Professor Palmer said.
 Mexican society's denial that discrimination exists makes it more difficult to combat. "In that regard it is worse than in the United States, where it is recognized and a lot of people of good will are trying to change it," Professor Palmer said. "By and large in Mexico it is unrecognized and unaddressed, which leads to a perpetuation of the status quo and a continuing assault on people of African or Indian descent."
 Visiting Americans sometimes get a taste of the same bigotry. Michael Waller, president of Cleveland Telecomunications Corp., of Solon, Ohio, accompanied United States Commerce Secretary Ron Brown on a Nafta-related business trip to Mexico a year ago. He said Mexicans were eager to talk to an American businessman on the telephone. But that changed when he arrived.
 "It was obvious from the moment I came into the airport and people reacted as if I had been beamed down from the Enterprise," Mr. Waller, who is black, said. "I guess what they expected was what they saw on TV, the Crips and the Bloods, you know, that kind of thing." He said that when he did not receive a single follow-up letter, he decided to focus on multiracial Brazil, where he now has several deals pending.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 18, 1995, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption last Sunday about Mexican Indians standing beneath a billboard, with an article about racism in Mexico, misstated the location of the scene. It was Monterrey, not Mexico City.
