PUB-DATE: June 11, 1995
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2748 words

HEADLINE: ...and Then There Were 2

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SURELY, when Americans talk about the need to shrink government, this can't be what they have in mind.
For the first time in its 61-year history, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Government agency responsible for safeguarding trillions of dollars of investors' money, may operate with only two commissioners, both Democrats. 
 Set up in the aftermath of the 1929 stock market crash to restore faith in the nation's securities markets, the commission was deliberately established as a bipartisan agency whose five voting members were to be selected by the President and confirmed by the Senate. These men and women police the securities industry, voting on whether to take enforcement actions against companies believed to have violated Federal securities laws. They also determine the rules by which everyone involved in the nation's stock and bond markets must play.
But of late, the commission is a child of neglect, an odd status for one of the few Government agencies that actually makes money -- lots of it, in fact. No one powerful has it in for the agency, but no one particularly cares about it either. What's more, the White House, which already has a record of botching high-level appointments, has its hands full, what with the crisis in Bosnia and the battle of the budget. So, unlike vacancies on the Supreme Court, which all of Washington would be scrambling to help fill, the S.E.C. is making little progress filling the openings for its $115,700-a-year commissioner jobs.
"It's a deplorable situation," said A. A. Sommer Jr. a former S.E.C. commissioner appointed by President Carter. "The failure of the Administration to make timely appointments tends to signal the Administration doesn't consider the commission important."
Two seats have been empty since the departures last year of Mary L. Schapiro and J. Carter Beese Jr. And barring immediate intervention from the White House and Congress, the shortage of commissioners will become more acute this month when Richard Y. Roberts, who was appointed as a Democrat but now considers himself a Republican, is expected to step down.
That would leave only Arthur Levitt Jr., the commission's chairman for the last two years, and Steven M. H. Wallman, a newcomer who is just learning the ropes, in place to conduct business. To avert total gridlock and "preserve its flexibility" in the event its numbers dwindle even further, the agency changed its rules in April so that one commissioner, rather than the customary three, could function as a quorum should it become necessary.
But the remaining commissioners are painfully aware that anything they tackle on their own could be challenged in court later. "I'm hopeful that the process will develop to nominate and recommend to the Senate very, very quickly," said Mr. Levitt. "I need and want commissioners."
A White House spokeswoman, Ginny Terzano, would not discuss candidates, but said the Administration was "in the process of filling the vacancies." A spokesman for Senator Bob Dole, the Republican majority leader, said he could not be reached on Friday.
AT least some Washington officials insist that nominations are imminent. But at the very least, the delays pose some awkward problems for those who have to hold down the fort while the politicians deliberate. For instance, the sixth floor of 450 Fifth Street in northwest Washington, where the commissioners could once be found vigorously debating one issue or another, is eerily quiet these days. Because sunshine laws require that any gathering of commissioners sufficient for a quorum be publicized in advance, Mr. Levitt and Mr. Wallman can't be seen talking shop much at all.
And what to do, for instance, if they split down the middle on a crucial vote, as they are likely to do given their different temperaments and agendas? Mr. Wallman is an intense corporate lawyer who favors easing the S.E.C.'s filing requirements, while Mr. Levitt is a genial businessman who is more concerned with winning points with small investors by cleaning up the municipal-bond business. They've already been said to have some dust-ups. "It's become the incredible shrinking agency," said a former commissioner who insisted on anonymity.
The situation would almost be funny except the agency has so much on its plate. The mounting debate in Congress over securities litigation reform, which would make it harder for individuals to sue companies, would place more of the burden of investor protection on regulators. Mr. Levitt, a popular figure here, has come out swinging against many of the proposals, but would be helped greatly if he had a Republican commissioner by his side.
In coming months, the S.E.C. must also weigh in on such fundamental issues as how the nation's regulatory framework applies to banks, insurers and securities firms as the barriers between their activities under the Glass-Steagall Act erode. The agency is also expected to play a role in reviewing the operations of the country's second-largest stock market, operated by the National Association of Securities Dealers. Its market-makers, the firms that buy and sell over-the-counter securities, are under investigation by the Department of Justice for possible violations of antitrust law.
"I think it is important for the commission, the people who work with the commission and the people the commission regulates to know where it is headed," said Philip Feigin, the president of the North American Securities Administrators Association, which represents state regulators. "For all Arthur Levitt's energy and the like, it's still an incomplete vision."
Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat, issued a similar warning last month in a letter he sent President Clinton. "It will be very difficult for the commission to conduct routine business with only two commissioners," the letter stated, "much less to make important policy decisions for our nation's financial markets."
In essence, it chided the President for squandering an opportunity to shape an important Government agency: "The new appointments which you must soon make will comprise the majority of members of the commission and will in large part determine the course it wil follow over the next five years."
THE calming presence of the agency's commissioners would also be handy, to say the least, if the stock market suddenly developed a bad case of nerves. With just two commissioners, both of whom have hectic travel schedules, the agency could have no commissioner in Washington on a day when stocks plunged, a growing possibility as the Dow Jones industrial average flirts with new records daily.
There's also little doubt the agency could use all the help it can get to fight its battles on Capitol Hill. Those include a turf war over which regulatory body will be given the authority to monitor securities issued by banks or insurers.
Then there's the struggle to keep its budget intact. Last year, the commission collected $588.2 million just in fees it levies on companies that register with it, and it only cost $260.3 million to run, leaving taxpayers with a tidy $327.9 million surplus. For all that, the Republican Senate, for example, held up the agency's budget last fall, temporarily forcing the S.E.C. to cancel some investigations and make plans to shut down its electronic filing system.
It's no wonder Mr. Levitt is feeling a bit underappreciated these days. A longtime Wall Street executive who cofounded the brokerage firm that eventually became Shearson Brothers and later was acquired by Smith Barney, he also headed the American Stock Exchange before Mr. Clinton asked him to join the S.E.C. Since his arrival two years ago, Mr. Levitt has struggled to clean up the municipal-bond business and expand what companies disclose to investors.
He is optimistic that the staffing problem will be remedied soon. But like most everyone else in Washington, he is hard-pressed to explain why it has taken so long to replace the two commissioners who stepped down last year, let alone deal with Mr. Roberts's imminent departure, which was announced a year and a half ago.
Ordinarily, there would be plenty of takers for such a prestigious job, despite the fact that top securities lawyers, the most obvious candidates, can usually make several hundred thousand dollars more in private practice. "I can't believe there's any dearth of qualified and interested candidates," said Ms. Schapiro, a former commissioner who now runs the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
But what has made the job a little less attractive, at least in the opinion of one securities lawyer, are new conflict-of-interest rules requiring anyone who leaves the job to wait five years before doing business with the agency.
A bigger hurdle by far, however, appears to be the White House's skittishness about mishandling another high-level nomination. After being criticized for bungling the nominations of Zoe Baird for Attorney General and Dr. Henry W. Foster for Surgeon General, to name just two of many, the process has become even slower as the White House seems determined to head off another Republican attack.
Thus, for tactical reasons, even though President Clinton has the power to name one more Democrat to the commission, he appears to be delaying until the Republicans come forward with a Republican name for him to propose, so that the two can be considered in tandem.
BY most accounts, no one expects the White House to risk any political capital trying to fill the fifth seat on the commission: it lapses next June anyway, and the Republicans seem to prefer waiting until 1997 when they might have one of their own as President. "White House appointments tend to get all wrapped up in political subtleties," said James Doty, a former S.E.C. counsel who is now a lawyer for the Washington firm of Baker & Botts.
What has also struck many people formerly or currently involved with the commission, is that many of the names that have surfaced as possibilities seem heavily motivated by a desire to win approval from an important constituency or Washington ally, suggesting that President Clinton does not feel he can singlehandedly strongarm his choice through a Republican Senate.
For instance, Ellen Seidman, a White House aide who once worked closely with Robert Rubin, the current Treasury Secretary, is sometimes mentioned as a candidate and would presumably have Mr. Rubin's support. Likewise, Brian Borders, the president of the Association of Publicly Traded Companies, an industry group that enjoys broad backing from small business, was briefly considered a candidate.
In the current cutthroat climate in Washington, even people once regarded as shoo-ins like Dennis Shea, a key aide to Senator Dole, have either removed themselves from consideration or been swallowed up by political intrigue. The frontrunner for the Republican bid is now thought to be not Mr. Shea, but Norman S. Johnson, 64, a Salt Lake City securities lawyer and one-time S.E.C. staff attorney. He is believed to have the support of Senators Dole and Orrin Hatch, the Utah Republican.
As of last week, the White House was said to be settling on Isaac C. Hunt Jr., 57, the retiring dean of the law school at the University of Akron in Ohio, as its nominee for the remaining Democratic seat. The first black to graduate from the University of Virginia Law School, he, too, worked for a time as an S.E.C. staff attorney and went on to serve on the Kerner Commission that investigated the 1967 race riots.
To be sure, a lean S.E.C. won't bring the securities markets to a halt. Other agencies, such as the commodities futures commission, have made do with just two commissioners for periods of time. Mr. Levitt and Mr. Wallman are both well-respected, and the agency is known for its strong and capable staff. "The public shouldn't worry that the job isn't being done," said Ms. Schapiro. "It will weather this. Still, it's nice to have more hands on deck."
But even if the long-awaited list of names were announced tomorrow, it could take months to get through Congress, and then the appointees would have to get up to speed. Other forces in Washington are also at work that could set back any progress. For instance, though he strongly discourages such talk, Mr. Levitt's name is being bandied about as a possible replacement for Ronald H. Brown as Secretary of Commerce should Mr. Brown have to step down as a result of a likely investigation into his business dealings.
IN the meantime, the agency will have to make do with less than its full complement of commissioners. For instance, sometimes, a commissioner simply needs to be on hand to assist with a breaking insider-trading case, where it's necessary to convince a judge to freeze assets before they disappear.
It may also have trouble signing off on the bigger initiatives investors expect it to take. The S.E.C.'s general counsel, Simon Lorne, himself said to be a possible candidate for a top job, believes that the agency acted well within its authority when it amended its rules on quorums in April to insure that the agency could "take effective action in the event, however unlikely, that there would be a period with only one commissioner in office."
But outside lawyers aren't so sure. Defense lawyers are already said to be delving into whether a decision reached by just two commissioners, let alone one, would be legally binding. "The issue hasn't been resolved by the courts, so nobody really knows the answer," said Harvey Pitt, a former S.E.C. counsel and lawyer with Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson.
More troubling, even if the S.E.C. can legally operate with just one or two commissioners, it does so at the risk of its reputation. "The credibility and moral authority of the comission's actions and decisions are somewhat hindered," said Mr. Pitt.
That is at least in part because the agency has had a long unblemished record of acting independently of the commissioners' politics, as when it investigated possible securities violations by George W. Bush, the son of the former President.
Besides insuring that both major political parties are represented, the whole point of having a five-member commission, rather than an agency headed by an individual, such as the Food & Drug Administration or the Office of the Comptroller, is the belief that five minds are better than one in making critical decisions. "I was made better by my colleagues," explained Joseph A. Grundfest, a former commissioner.
Walking back to his office from lunch one afternoon a few days ago, Commissioner Roberts was stopped by a colleague who asked whether he is still at the agency. "Thirty days," the commissioner replied with a smile. Is Mr. Roberts the only one counting?

HEADLINE: For Now, the Job Outlook Is Brighter

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
THREE years into the recovery, there is finally a window of opportunity for graduates entering the job market. Analysts and career counselors say the employment outlook this spring is better than it has been in five years for high school and college job applicants, with recruiting activity up and salaries on the increase.
But the advice from the experts to would-be workers is: hustle or else. 
 There are signs that the economy is slowing again, suggesting that the period of opportunity may be short lived. Career counselors and economists say that anyone hoping to get a foot in the door had better do it soon. What is more, competition is keen for the best positions.
"Things may be looking up at the moment, but grads are also having to work harder and do more to land a job than they did 5 or 10 years ago, especially those who want their dream job," said Thomas S. Corbin, an economist with the New York State Department of Labor. "The late 1980's were a golden time. It was easy to find work. The 1990's have been harder."
Computer-related occupations -- like programming and managing information systems -- offer the most opportunities for graduates, studies show. After that, the job market is good for those majoring in engineering, sales and marketing, accounting and finance and medical and health care services.
Salaries are highest for chemical engineers, who can expect to earn close to $41,000 their first year on the job, according to data compiled by the Collegiate Employment Research Institute at Michigan State University. Mechanical, electrical and industrial engineers will earn from $33,493 to $35,713 a year.
Computer science jobs pay about $33,000 a year, nursing jobs about $30,078 and accounting positions about $28,022, according to the research institute. Those in journalism and telecommunications are at the bottom of the scale, earning slightly less than $21,000 their first year.
Recruiting at colleges reflected the upbeat trend this spring, with a return to campuses of manufacturing employers, many of whom had been absent several years. Manufacturers represented automotive, electronic equipment and chemical and allied products fields, according to the National Association of Colleges and Employers in Bethlehem, Pa. Colleges also reported that more companies were being represented at career and job fairs and said those employers had made early job offers to top candidates.
At Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, Carole Bieber, coordinator of career services, said that 54 employers showed up for the spring job fair in Purchase, which was sponsored by Sarah Lawrence and three other colleges, Purchase, Manhattanville and Marymount. "It is indicative of the new opportunities for liberal arts majors," Mrs. Bieber said. Recruiters attending the fair represented nonprofit agencies, law firms, advertising agencies, publishing houses, financial services, health care and human services and sales. At the Pace University campus in White Plains, Joan A. Mark, executive director of cooperative education and career services, agreed that graduates were facing "a brighter job market this year, despite all the downsizing and right sizing that is still going on."
But she has advised students to include work internships and previous job experience on their resumes in order to land an entry-level job in an extremely competitive market.
She also reported that the Internet was beginning to play a crucial role in job searches.
"All the talk now at the conferences is cyberspace, tele-interviews, writing a scannable resume," Mrs. Mark said last week on her return from a meeting of the National Association of Colleges and Employers. "Technology will increasingly play a role."
At Mercy College, Jean Harris, director of cooperative education, said students who know ahead of time what kinds of jobs they want and understand how to market their skills fare best. "I tell the students to target a career and not to go out there just looking for a job, any job," Ms. Harris said. "Job applicants have to be clear about what they want."
Vaneet Sekhei, a 23-year-old accounting major who graduated last month from Pace University, heeded the advice of his career counselors and landed an internal auditing job with Chemical Bank in Manhattan. He included three work internships on his resume, along with top grades, and began looking nine months ago.
"It's not my dream job, but it's very close to it," said Mr. Sekhei, who will be earning $30,000 a year when he reports for work later this month. "The jobs are out there, but you have to keep going at it until you find the right one."
Other students worked part time -- even at low-paying jobs like stock clerks -- hoping to parlay temporary positions into full-time employment. Others visited their schools' career-counseling offices daily to peruse the latest listings.
But for some, no matter which tactics they take, their search for employment has not proved fruitful. Consider the case of Michael Gayle, a 26-year-old Mount Vernon resident who graduated with honors this spring from the State University of New York at Albany.
The economics and political science major, who made the dean's list and was an intern in Dean Witter Reynolds' assistant stockbrokers program and was an intern management assistant for Pitney Bowes, said he has been searching for an entry-level banking position since December.
He observed that many companies were offering sales-type positions, on a commission-only basis, but he and many fellow students cannot afford to accept those jobs. "We have our student loans to pay back," he said.
Many graduates said that despite some figures showing a brighter job outlook, their experience was that conditions have not improved.
"The word on the street is that it's actually a bad year," said James Martucci, 23, who graduated late last month from Mercy College with a degree in business administration and management. "Things are tougher now. We're having to work double time to find work."
Graduates may be observing a skepticism among employers about the future of the economy, following the sluggish performance of economic indicators in recent months. Although the economy appeared to be in a recovery, employers remained conservative about hiring, and many reported that jobs obtained by college graduates were not guaranteed, according to Career Development and Placement Services of Michigan State University.
"On the negative side of the ledger were corporate right sizing, potential layoffs, potential consolidation of business operations, slower employee turnover, cost-cutting measures and increased utilization of technology and automation," a report on recruiting trends from the university said. It added that companies intent on cost saving looked for college graduates "as a cheaper payroll expenditure."
At Westchester Community College, Pauline Sonenshine, a placement coordinator, said graduates looking for jobs in the county were "having an especially tough time," because the local economy had been slower to recover from the recession. "It's still a little better than last year," she said. "There are more openings. The pay is better."
But the market remained competitive, and the versatile student who had experience in more than one field was most sought after, she said.
Using a different terminology to describe a similar phenomenon, Mr. Corbin at the State Department of Labor observed the "promising growth of the hyphenated fields."He said: "Employers are looking for biologists-writers or computer technicians-teachers."
Also, he said that with the ranks of middle-management depleted, employers were looking for mature new hires that could work independently and manage themselves.
At the high school level, the outlook for well-trained graduates -- even those who were not college bound -- was also improving, said Dr. Joseph Schwartzberg, director of occupational education for the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Education Services in Valhalla.
By contrast, high school graduates without vocational skills "are lost, they're in trouble -- on the nowhere track," Dr. Schwartzberg said.
The job placement success rate for vocational students was especially high this year for paraprofessionals and technicians, he said. Licensed practical nurses, air-conditioning and heating technicians, computer-repair technicians and automobile mechanic were in high demand.
Starting salaries for licensed practical nurses ranged from $25,000 to $35,000, Dr. Schwartzberg said. For technicians, starting pay was about $25,000 a year.
For those planning to take at least some college courses, the outlook was even brighter. Keith Millar, an 18-year-old vocational student from New Rochelle is in a three-year apprenticeship program as a cabinetmaker with a custom furniture company. He plans to take college-level business courses and go into business for himself someday.
"For students like these," Dr. Schwartzberg said, "the opportunities are endless."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Patrice Kunesh;
Defining How a Tribe Governs Its Land

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
PATRICE KUNESH of North Stonington is a counselor for the Mashantucket Pequot tribe in eastern Connecticut whose tasks include drafting amendments to the tribe's constitution.
Ms. Kunesh, a member of the Hunkpapa band of the Lakota -- the most famous member of that tribe was Sitting Bull -- is a native of Minnesota, and a 1989 graduate of the University of Colorado Law School. She worked for the Native American Rights Fund from 1988 until 1994, where she was part of a team that examined the constitutions of five tribes, including the Mashantuckets. 
 In addition to developing expertise on tribal governance, Ms. Kunesh has worked on water, oil and gas rights, tribal jurisdictional issues, and Indian child welfare matters. In 1994 she accepted a position with the Mashantuckets, the first and still one of only two federally recognized Indian tribes in the state.
Ms. Kunesh discussed tribal governance issues at her office in the Mashantucket Community Center recently. Following are some excerpts from that conversation.
Q. The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 established constitutions for tribes -- why does the tribe need its own?
A. We have more than 500 recognized Indian tribes in the United States. Each one of those tribes is a distinct and unique sovereign nation. The Federal Government in some respects doesn't want to deal with each unique tribe, so they gave them a boilerplate constitution, or governing document.
It's very much like the Federal Constitution. What the Indian Reorganization Act constitution has is oversight by the Secretary of the Interior for many of the tribal government's actions.
Tribal governments under the Act see themselves more as puppets of the Secretary of the Interior, and those constitutions don't recognize the unique history and culture of the individual Indian tribes. We've had a system of government here for hundreds of years. The classification of that system was reduced to writing and submitted to the Secretary for Federal recognition. We wanted to maintain a system of government that reflects our history and our customs and culture.
Q. Can you give examples of how a constitution could reflect the history and culture of the tribe?
A. It's the structure of the government. A unicameral government, which you see in a lot of tribes, would have all the governmental functions in one body -- the judicial, the executive and the legislative. That creates, necessarily, some conflicts, when the person who makes the law also has to interpret the law and enforce the law. There are other tribes that have a bicameral body, a legislative-executive and a judicial.
Second, just the name of the tribe is very important. A lot of the names of tribes you see are not the names they call themselves. The Standing Rock Sioux, for instance -- Sioux is not an Indian name. We call ourselves Lakota. What Sioux actually means is enemy.
Another important part of the constitution is the preamble. Much like the preamble to the Federal Constitution, many tribal constitutions acknowledge a relationship to the Great Spirit, and that really sets the tone for the rest of the document.
The constitution defines membership -- how does a tribe decide who is eligible to be a member of the community? It defines how officials are elected -- in some tribes you have officials elected for life, in some tribes they are inherited positions, in some leadership follows through patriarchal or matriarchal lines.
Q. If the tribe has had a structure in place, why the efforts to change it?
A. With the introduction of a very strong and successful economic development project, the tribe has seen an opportunity and probably a need to take a look at its governing document and ask, "Does this give us adequate protection? Does this define the government structure? Does this allow us to do as much as possible with our community?" I think you will find it's not unique to this tribe, that tribes all over the country are reviewing their constitutions.
We're also looking at the underlying structure, the law and order code. This tribe has not had the resources before now to develop a tribal court system, or a law enforcement system, or public safety system, with emergency medical services and fire services. We're doing a lot of code writing, ordinance drafting. And in a business sense, the tribe is exercising its sovereignty, which impacts the governing document.
Q. Why are these governance issues getting so much attention?
A. One reason is the casino. I think, though, that a lot of the attention is because the tribe has been almost an overnight success story. My sense is the local people don't have a good understanding of the development of Federal Indian law and tribes. I think we were invisible to them before, and now we are so incredibly visible that they are reacting to it.
Part of our responsibility is to educate them, or share with them our history and our culture. We've always been here, but we haven't always been visible, and that's made a lot of people uncomfortable.
Q. Are the Mashantuckets coordinating with any other tribes on self-governance issues?
A. We're in contact on a national scale. Skip Hayward, the Mashantucket tribal leader, is on the board of directors of the Native American Rights Fund, which is active in Indian law on behalf of tribes all over the country. Through organizations like the United Southern and Eastern Tribes, the National Congress of American Indians, the National Indian Gaming Association, we converse with other tribes about what they're working on and how they've addressed certain issues.
Q. How common are the governance structures between tribes?
A. The general systems are fairly similar. There is a tribal council, there is a chairperson or a president, there is a section of law and order code. How they implement that is quite different.
Q. How much autonomy does the tribe have in criminal matters?
A. We have a law and order system on the reservation, where we prosecute violations of tribal law. Under the Indian Civil Rights Act, the tribe can sentence a person up to one year for each offense, and a fine of up to $5,000. If we were to incarcerate someone, we have a arrangement with a private detention facility in Central Falls, R.I.
Many tribes have agreements with the state so the law enforcement officers are also state officers. Under that system tribal officers can arrest for violations of state law, and turn them over to the state authorities. We are open to that kind of dialogue here, because we see there may be a need for it. That's not to say we have a law and order problem on the reservation.
Q. Taxes are becoming another issue involving reservations. What is the state authority in this area?
A. As tribes become more of an economic presence in a state, they are competing with the state in many respects, and the state wants to see how far it can extend its regulatory jurisdiction on the reservation.
The Federal Government has always said the states have no authority to impose their tax laws in Indian country. But what about activities on trust land? That's where states are getting more aggressive.
The Supreme Court has said where the tribe is engaged in activity involving non-Indians, the tribe has to facilitate the flow of taxation. For example, in the New York case last year, the state was trying to tax the tribe's sale of cigarettes to non-Indians, and the court ruled that sales to non-Indians are taxable, sales to Indians are not. Income for tribal members living on the reservation is not taxable by the state, though tribal members pay Federal income tax. The tribe's payroll, however, generates hundreds of millions of dollars in state income tax, because we have 11,000 employees.
Whatever resources the tribe produces on its own land are not taxable. Natural resources such as gold or coal or oil, there's been more activity by the state to try to tax that, but the Supreme Court has said that if it's a resource generated by the tribe on its property, that's not taxable.
Q. The Mashantuckets have generated controversy over attempts to expand their reservation. What is the legal basis for that expansion?
A. After a time period where the Federal Government had defined Indian territory by reservation, a lot of the reservations were broken down into smaller parcels called allotments, which were held in trust for 25 years and then a lot of them were sold. Between aboriginal territory and then reservation territory and then allotment territory, millions of acres of Indian territory were lost. Just when the allotment act was passed in 1877, 92 million acres of reservation land were lost.
One of the things the Indian Reorganization Act did was stop further allotment. It held everything in trust. And it authorized tribal governments to acquire land and put it into trust. This "land into trust" activity the tribe has been doing comes under that authority of the Indian Reorganization Act.

HEADLINE: Schools Face Renovations of Aging Buildings

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
RISING student enrollments are creating problems for school districts that are also plagued by shortages of space and aging buildings that need repairs, renovations and expansion.
Many districts are asking voters to approve bond issues of several million dollars to finance such improvements. 
 Since the early 90's, when the state drastically cut aid to education, most districts have been putting their money into programs, services and salaries, mostly ignoring their buildings and equipment.
Many buildings on the Island are more than 50 years old and need new doors, windows, roofs, furnaces, insulation and other repairs. Changes in education are also dictating renovations like larger classrooms and upgraded electrical capacity for machinery like computers. Districts that sold or rented out buildings as enrollments declined in the last 10 years may not have sufficient space.
"The 80's would have been a perfect time to redo buildings, when school budgets allowed for such repairs," Superintendent Ed Mavragis of Amityville said. "But now, at the same time that student population is growing, the economic climate is difficult, and things are wearing out from age. This is the worst possible combination of factors."
Increased enrollment across the Island has created a space crisis, said the president of the Nassau-Suffolk School Boards Association, Bruce Brodsky. By the year 2000 the association projects the populations in the 127 districts to total within 2,500 students of its peak, in 1984, of 430,000, and then to continue to climb.
Districts that sold or rented buildings are forced to consolidate classes, redistrict or add portable classrooms, Mr. Brodsky said.
Districts have also had to renovate to keep up with changes in education, said Roger Smith, an architect with the firm of Burton, Behrendt, Smith & O'Callaghan in Patchogue. Older buildings were constructed with small classrooms, cafeterias and libraries that are no longer adequate, he said. Older schools often had inadequate electrical service and inadequate access for handicapped students, to comply with the Americans With Disabilities Act, he added.
"Many old buildings were constructed for second floors to be added, but it's hard to build a second floor when kids are in the buildings 10 months a year," Mr. Smith said. Hewlett-Woodmere recently completed the first phase of a long-range modernization plan, with the renovation of the 600-student Hewlett Elementary School. The school was built more than 50 years ago with small classrooms and large bathrooms, said Superintendent Bert Nelson.
"During that era desks were screwed down to the floor and kids stayed put," Dr. Nelson said. "Buildings had small classrooms, while large bathrooms were a necessity, since going to the bathroom was a large group activity, with the whole class going at the same time."
The architect for the redesigned school, Michael Spector of the Spector Group in North Hills, said computers were critical in the design plan. Libraries are no longer simply books, tables and chairs, but electronic centers.
"Our goal," Mr. Spector said, "is to create space for kids that is exciting and innovative, so that they look forward to coming to school."
The renovation cost $9 million, $3 million of which came from a capital reserve fund from the sale of one of the district's oldest buildings. The remaining $6 million was financed by a bond issue.
Island Park recently approved a $6.7 million bond issue for repairs for two school buildings. Safety was a problem, said Superintendent Erich Stegmeier. In February a gymnasium wall moved, and the gym was closed, he said. "We were faced with a very serious situation," he said. "There has been a rapid acceleration of ground sinking at both our buildings, causing interior and exterior walls to move. We are most concerned about assuring the safety of our pupils, staff and the public."
Two years of repairs and reconstruction begin in the summer.
In the spring voters in Levittown approved a $19 million bond issue for three years of capital improvements in all 14 schools there, beginning in the summer. The work includes roof repair, window and door replacement, kitchen improvement, asbestos removal and improving access for the handicapped.
"These repairs are not optional," the assistant superintendent for business and finance, Dr. Alan Groveman, said. "They are vital to the education, safety and welfare of the children."
An important factor in winning voters' approval was convincing taxpayers that a bond issue was the cheapest option, said Dr. Groveman, and that it would cost less than including the projects in the operating budget.
He added that the bond allowed the district to receive yearly state aid of more than 50 percent of the district's costs, as well as provide an increase of $1.24 per $100 assessed value, compared with $2.60 if financed through the regular budget.
Bond issues usually have minimal effects for taxpayers, Superintendent Elliott Landon of Long Beach said, because they spread the financial burden over 20 to 25 years.
In Long Beach a $10 million bond issue is financing work that begins in the summer, including renovations at Lido Elementary and Middle School, adding modular classrooms and a new gymnasium, replacing doors and windows and adding eight permanent classrooms.
In poorer districts, bond issues have met resistance. But Wyandanch recently approved two issues totaling more than $10 million to rebuild a school that burned down, renovate three other buildings and connect two schools, to operate with one principal.
"It was a difficult effort to win approval for the bond," Acting Superintendent Anthony Pecorale said. "But if it didn't pass the district would have had to go on a split schedule. While most districts on the Island are growing in student population at a rate of between 2 and 3 percent, Wyandanch has a growing enrollment of more than 10 percent. For the average homeowner the bond issue will mean a tax increase of about $70 a year."
In some communities voters said no. Last month Oceanside defeated a $5 million bond issue. Several factors contributed to the defeat, said Superintendent Elliot Garfinkel. It was the third bond proposal in eight years, Dr. Garfinkel said, adding that many voters also disapproved of the renovations, which would have meant moving some students to other schools.
Oceanside has added 500 students in four years, said Dr. Garfinkel, and growing enrollment has to be addressed. "For next year we'll have to rent portable classrooms," he said, "while the board continues to explore options of how to address this issue."
Several districts are working with community groups and architects to decide on building repairs and renovations and how to finance them.
The Garden City Board of Education is to decide soon whether to submit a bond issue to a vote, said the assistant superintendent of business, Daniel Bryan. In September, the district plans to reopen an early childhood school that had been leased, he said.
"In addition to needing new classrooms to house the increasing number of students," Mr. Bryan said, "there's the normal wear and tear that must be addressed like roof repair, new ventilation and electrical systems. It's nothing exciting, but these are things that have to be done."
In Syosset, renovations have been planned for the high school and two middle schools. The repairs are essential, Superintendent Carole Hankin said. "We've got windows that don't open, doors that don't shut," she said. "We're not going to do what we'd really like to do, but what must be done, a little at a time, so we won't have to close down the high school during the renovations."
A bond issue will probably be put up for a vote in the fall, Dr. Hankin said, adding: "It will be a minimal tax raise for the average homeowner. This is a long-term investment that will benefit the kids who are now in the schools and those who are coming."
Amityville is reviewing proposals from two architects to renovate its 750-pupil 70-year-old elementary school. The interior is to be gutted, but the traditional exterior will be retained, to fit in with the village architecture, Mr. Mavragis said.
"Every time we turn around we've had to throw in another $10,000 to repair broken pipes or fix other problems," he said. "Patch jobs just won't do it anymore. The school has an undersize cafeteria and undersize classrooms, with only one outlet in each room. The school is simply running out of years."
The district plans a vote in the fall for the $10 million of renovations, Mr. Mavragis said.
"We've got to reach local civic and community groups to win their support," he added. "As soon as the board approves the plan, we'll go on the road. This is a serious undertaking to convince the public that we're talking about an investment for the next 50 years, for both the kids and the community."

HEADLINE: Competition Is Cutthroat At the Paris Air Show

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: LE BOURGET, France, June 11

 BODY:
"World's No. 1 missile technology for all your needs," reads the pitch at this week's Paris Air Show for Spetstekhnika, a Russian company specializing in advanced air-to-ground destruction techniques.
Need a retreaded fighter aircraft, cheap? "Defense budget cuts have forced Canada to sell their recently upgraded F-5 fighters," says a sticker on one of the planes, originally designed by the Northrop Corporation (now Northrop Grumman) of Los Angeles but modernized by Bristol Aerospace Ltd. of Winnipeg, Manitoba. 
 Prices are negotiable, and prospective customers from around the world have until next Sunday to place orders for the latest available civilian and military aviation products at the air show, a technology bazaar that opened Saturday on the field where Charles A. Lindbergh landed in the Spirit of St. Louis after the first solo trans-Atlantic flight in 1927.
The United States Air Force stole the show today by flying in the Spirit of Missouri, one of its six supersecret B-2 batwing stealth bombers, designed by Northrop Grumman to be almost undetectable by radar. This one stayed only for an hour before returning across the Atlantic to Whiteman Air Force Base in Missouri.
With military budgets shrinking everywhere and commercial aviation in crisis in many countries, the competition to woo customers is cutthroat, and many European competitors argue that the American giants are getting an unfair advantage from today's cut-rate dollar.
President Jacques Chirac of France, who visited the show today to see a flypast of the Dassault Aviation Group's Rafale and Mirage-2000 fighters, said he would call on President Clinton and other leaders meeting in Halifax, Nova Scotia, later this week to take stronger international action to keep the dollar stable against other currencies.
Suspicion runs strong in France that the Clinton Administration, despite denials, is using the weakness of the dollar to improve the American balance of trade, since the cheaper it is for foreign customers to buy dollars, the more American exports they are likely to buy.
"When the greenback plummets, European aircraft manufacturers suddenly see everything crumbling around them; their productivity gains -- and their profits are wiped out," said the French aerospace monthly Revue Aerospatiale in a special issue on the show. "We are in the presence of a monetary war in which the weakest of the hard currencies is used as an offensive weapon."
American aviation manufacturers exported $38 billion in advanced technology and equipment last year, down $1 billion from 1993. Of the total last year, $12.4 billion was sold to customers in the countries of the European Union, which sold $8.5 billion in aerospace products to Americans.
The Clinton Administration is pushing aviation exports hard, and sent Thomas F. McLarty, the former White House chief of staff, to say so publicly. "The President has noted and recognized early that international trade is the key to economic growth and the key to the creation of high-skill and high-wage jobs in the American work force," Mr. McLarty said.
Shortly afterward, the Lockheed Martin Corporation and Russia's Khrunichev Enterprise announced plans to offer joint commercial satellite launches with Atlas and Proton next year to fight the inroads made by the European Space Agency, whose accomplishments are highlighted by a mockup of its big Ariane-5 rocket launcher towering over the runways here.
And the Boeing Company's new B-777 twin-jet intercontinental airliner arrived today to go head-to-head with the four-engine A-340 of Airbus Industries, the biggest European civil aviation manufacturer. Russia's Ilyushin-96M airliner, powered by four American-made Pratt & Whitney engines, is also on display.
Boeing announced agreement today on letters of intent by Air Europa of Spain, Lauda Air of Austria and Eurobelgian to buy 12 of its 737-800 short-range passenger planes; Lauda Air has already ordered four B-777's.
The V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft produced for the United States Army, Marines and Air Force by Textron Inc.'s Bell Helicopter division, in partnership with Boeing, is also attracting attention from potential civilian customers as well as military ones. It hovered like a helicopter Saturday and then zoomed past spectators looking like a twin-propeller airplane.
Many American companies refused to come to the last Paris show two years ago after a scandal about French Government and industrial espionage aimed against them.
This year, there was a spy scandal in France about reported Central Intelligence Agency attempts to bribe highly placed French officials to reveal secrets about trade policy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The big hit of the Paris Air Show at Le Bourget airfield yesterday was the brief visit of the Air Force's B-2 batwing stealth bomber. Designed by Northrop Grumman to be almost undetectable by radar, the plane stayed only an hour before returning to Whiteman Air Force Base in Missouri. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Unicef Asks Broader Aid For Children

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 9

 BODY:
The United States now ranks lowest among 21 industrial countries in the amount of foreign aid it gives in relation to its gross national product, according to a new study by Unicef, the United Nations Children's Fund.
Although American aid is second only to Japan's in dollars -- $9.7 billion as calculated by international organizations using 1993 figures -- it represents 15 hundredths of 1 percent of G.N.P. 
 The Scandinavian countries and the Netherlands lead the list, with levels above 80 hundredths of 1 percent, and in those countries, as in the United States, aid budgets are facing new cuts.
The general reduction in foreign aid comes at a time when Unicef is urging all countries to look at the situation of children in the broadest terms, including the environments in which their mothers live.
"The child can't really be seen as separate and on an island," said Carol Bellamy, Unicef's executive director. "You can adopt some concrete objectives and go out and seek to achieve them, but the child has to be seen in the broader context of the community."
In an interview here last week before leaving for Berlin, where she released the report today, Ms. Bellamy said the Unicef board had recently approved clean water and education programs that would benefit whole villages and people of all ages.
Taking a broader look, she said, means that programs can be tailored to national needs and levels of development: basic survival in a country like Chad or children's rights in Argentina or Chile.
Among its recommendations, the report calls for campaigns to attack vitamin deficiencies and malnutrition, the precursors to disease in many countries, and to ameliorate or end deprivations and social abuses of children that weaken them and ultimately threaten their lives.
"In all regions of the world," the report said, "children continue to be malnourished, to be plagued by preventable disease, to be denied even a basic education."
Unicef says that about 200 million children worldwide suffer from vitamin A deficiency, which impairs the immune system and can lead to blindness and death. One million to two million children's lives could be saved each year by vitamin supplements, the report says.
About half of the 13 million children who die each year are victims of three major illnesses: pneumonia, diarrheal disease and measles. While measles is in retreat, the report says, pneumonia, the single largest killer of children, is not. And AIDS is now a threat. About one million children now have the virus that causes AIDS, many in Africa and Asia.
With the world population growing fastest in the poorest countries, where children are likely to live in the worst conditions, Ms. Bellamy said the reduction in aid was especially unfortunate.
"None of us benefit if our partners in development are being hurt, because we are actually all in the same development boat," she said.
Ms. Bellamy, a former Peace Corps volunteer in Guatemala and director of the Peace Corps before she joined Unicef in May, said she had the point of interrelationships driven home when she became City Council President in New York in 1978.
"Here in New York City -- the industrialized world -- we had not had a full-scale immunization program for a number of years," she said. "A third of all youngsters in New York City schools and close to a half of poor youngsters were not immunized. So we started a program to get all kids immunized.
"There is a direct connection between that investment in aid and health care back here in the United States. If polio breaks out one place in the world it can just come back and spread again. The walls between nations are now very thin curtains."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Ready to Resume Negotiations

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Ready or not, the owners apparently are finally prepared to resume negotiations with the players for a new collective bargaining agreement. That is the word delivered by people who attended the owners' meetings in Minneapolis last week.
Although Bud Selig, the acting commissioner, and the chief negotiators haven't said anything about the resumption of talks, one owner said during the weekend that, based on the discussion at the meetings, he expected talks to begin "very soon." 
 Another person made that timetable a little more specific, saying he expected something to happen in the next 10 days to two weeks.
"We're going to see some prompt action," the second person said. "They'll see what happens with the N.L.R.B. thing, then move on to the next stage. It will be very quick."
Negotiators for the owners and the players have not met since March 30, the day before a Federal judge issued an injunction that prompted the players to end their strike and return to work. But lawyers for both sides have been meeting in discussions for settlement of the National Labor Relations Board charges against the owners.
The lawyers will meet again this week. If they reach an agreement or even make progress toward one, they are expected to ask for a postponement of the trial on the N.L.R.B. charges scheduled to begin next Monday before an administrative law judge.
Talks for a collective bargaining agreement then could resume.
"We've got to get an agreement," said the owner, who spoke on the condition he wouldn't be identified. "That was stressed. The pressure's on, and it's coming from all directions. Huizenga, Angelos and others spoke, people from different positions. The consensus clearly is let's get it done."
Wayne Huizenga of the Florida Marlins is considered a hard-liner, Peter Angelos of Baltimore a moderate. From one extreme to the other, the owners and the players believe it is imperative to reach an overall agreement to show the fans it's safe to return to the ball park.
To be in position to resume talks in even two weeks, the owners' negotiating team will have to work quickly. The owners haven't selected a chief labor lawyer to replace Chuck O'Connor, whom Selig has dismissed, and they don't appear to be certain about their approach to the key economic issue -- how to put some form of restraint on player salaries.
When they adjourned talks, the owners were trying to get a luxury tax on payrolls, having abandoned their initial strategy of getting a salary cap. Some owners want to return to the cap, but others have said that strategy surely would precipitate another work stoppage.
John Harrington of Boston, chairman of the negotiating committee, has hinted at a new wrinkle the committee could be developing.
Some people on the management side are talking about the possibility of the N.L.R.B. settlement discussions producing an impetus that will enable the negotiators to begin resolving issues one by one.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
A Chinese Puzzle

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
In China over the last month a number of high-ranking establishment intellectuals have joined activists for democracy in petitions to the Government. They called for a more open society -- for "a spirit of tolerance," as one petition put it.
The Communist authorities responded by detaining some of the signers and keeping others under house arrest. In the days around June 4, the sixth anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, there were stern warnings against dissent. 
 The pattern of protest and crackdowns seems familiar. But there are important differences this time, ones that raise questions about where things are going in Beijing.
One change is the participation of the intellectuals, members of the Chinese Academy of Sciences. The most significant of the petitions was drafted by Xu Liangying, a 75-year-old physicist who translated Einstein's work into Chinese, and signed by, among others, Wang Ganchang, 88, a key figure in the design of China's first nuclear weapon.
"It is the first time these establishment intellectuals have joined the democratic activists," Prof. Merle Goldman of Harvard said. "Until now they have kept them at a distance. The party leadership may find the change disturbing."
The question is why people in a privileged position as academicians decided to speak out for democracy with the activists. And why now?
Some China scholars in this country say the reason is that the Communist regime faces a time of transition from the leadership of Deng Xiaoping, who is 90 years old and has not been seen in public since last October. The intellectuals see a chance to influence the direction of the leadership that will succeed Mr. Deng -- to push it toward more tolerance and independent thinking. One way for a new leader to establish his identity is to differ from his predecessor's policies, as Mr. Deng did with Mao Zedong.
The official view of the student democracy movement that was crushed in Tiananmen Square is one key to change. The petition drafted by Xu Liangying called on the authorities to "re-evaluate the June 4, 1989, incident according to the spirit of 'seeking truth from facts,' and release those people who remain in jail."
The Xu petition is in many respects a remarkable document. It says the Government should "never again regard individuals of independent thought as 'hostile elements' and submit them to repressive attacks." It asks the authorities to "boldly end the ignominious tradition of literary inquisitions that has persisted in our country since ancient times."
That petition and the others ought to end any lingering tendency among Americans and Europeans to think that Chinese intellectuals are any less eager for freedom of thought than, say, Russians were in the Soviet years. They are an answer, too, to the contention of Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew that Asians value freedom less than order and economic progress.
The Communist Party Secretary at Mr. Xu's research institute called him in and asked him not to disturb "social stability." Mr. Xu said later, "I told him what we're doing is good for social stability."
The petitions for freedom are also a comment on the difficulty of framing American policy on human rights in China. A year ago President Clinton stopped tying renewal of China's trade status under U.S. law to its human-rights record. Since then repression and torture have increased. It is not clear how the U.S. can bring effective pressure for decency on a totalitarian regime that evidently fears for its survival.
The most powerful symbol of the Chinese regime's use of extreme, lawless methods to repress nonviolent demands for democracy is the case of Wei Jingsheng. He was arrested in 1979 for his part in the Democracy Wall movement, was tried in secret and served nearly 15 years in solitary confinement.
In September 1993, when Beijing was trying to win the year 2000 Olympics, Mr. Wei was suddenly released. He spoke out for freedom, undaunted. On April 1, 1994, he was detained again. Not a word has been heard since from him or about his condition or whereabouts.
If a new Chinese leadership wants to win the world's respect when it comes to power, its first act should be to free Wei Jingsheng.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Black Leaders of Diverse Views United at Meeting, Chavis Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, June 11

 BODY:
Declaring a three-day conference "fruitful and successful," the Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr. said the National African American Leadership Summit would organize a million men for a march on Washington in the fall.
Mr. Chavis, the former head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said his group adopted a constitution and bylaws at its second annual meeting. 
 "The N.A.A.L.S. has taken on more of a sense of permanence in terms of building our organizational infrastructure," Mr. Chavis said.
Representatives from more than 100 African-American organizations attended the summit, which was intended to unite black leaders across religious and political lines. The entity includes the Nation of Islam, the National Black United Front and several N.A.A.C.P. chapters.
One goal, Mr. Chavis said, is to mobilize black men for the Million Man March in Washington on Oct. 16, which will follow another meeting by the summit.
There, the group will encourage participants "to take responsibility for raising our families, to take responsibility for ending the drugs and violence that plague our communities and to move forward in terms of our economic empowerment," Mr. Chavis said.
Other issues discussed at the Houston conference were protesting the scheduled execution of Mumia Abu-Jamal, a black journalist in Pennsylvania, and fighting recommended "right-wing cutbacks" in Congress.
Mr. Abu-Jamal, a former award-winning radio reporter, is scheduled to die on Aug. 17 for the 1981 shooting death of a police officer. Supporters say Mr. Abu-Jamal, who insists he is not guilty, was framed because he supported the radical MOVE organization.
Other goals of the group include black economic and political empowerment.
"We want to serve notice on the Congress of the United States, to Newt Gingrich and to all of those who are voting and recommending these right-wing cutbacks on health care, on education, on welfare, on scholarships for black students," Mr. Chavis said, adding, "We are not going to stand still."
Mr. Chavis supported a similar agenda before he was dismissed from the N.A.A.C.P. post in August for using group money to settle a sex discrimination claim without telling the board of directors.
Even before the ouster, Mr. Chavis had clashed with board members over his desire to collaborate with the Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan and about his secret meeting with black nationalists in March 1994.
On Friday night Mr. Farrakhan attended a town meeting that was a part of the weekend conference.
Mr. Chavis said he sensed, during the various sessions, that "there is a bonding taking place."
"Despite all of the tactics of groups trying to divide and conquer us," Mr. Chavis said, "we're coming together and we're going to stay together."

HEADLINE: Microsoft Developing Electronic Cash Card

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The Microsoft Corporation's dominant software business often seems like a license to print money. But now the company wants to go a step further and make cash itself, at least the electronic kind.
Microsoft is developing a plan to offer plastic cards embedded with microchips, known as smart cards, that can be used to make payments, said Warren T. Dent, the director of business development for the company's consumer systems division. 
 "I hope in a year or so we are testing something with a stored-value card," Mr. Dent said. The initial test may be with Microsoft's own employees before the technology is offered more widely, he said.
 Microsoft would be entering what has rapidly become a crowded field of companies hoping to become to electronic money what Microsoft is to computer software. In July, two large British banks will begin testing Mondex, a so-called electronic purse card, which stores cash. Mondex is economical for small purchases because merchants would not need a telephone link to a central computer. The card's current value is imprinted on the card, which means losing the card is like losing cash. A debit card, by comparison, is more like an electronic check.
Mastercard International and Visa International are also developing chip cards that can hold cash, as are Bank of America and other banks. Separately, a number of independent companies have started to create schemes for sending payments over the Internet, in which cash is loaded onto computer disks rather than on smart cards.
Microsoft is working with chip manufacturers to develop the specifications of its card, and then expects to approach banks that would stand behind the payments on the card. Executives of several of the country's largest banks say they have been approached by Microsoft.
"No matter how much technology you have, one day someone will outfox you," said Richard Lonergan, executive vice president of Visa. "The bank card systems have the risk-management and early-fraud- detection systems that they don't have."
 Microsoft might have difficulty finding partners. It frightened many bankers with its now-aborted plan to acquire Intuit Inc., the maker of Quicken personal finance software, which was seen as an attempt to dominate the market for computerized banking and payments known as electronic commerce. Microsoft's chairman, William T. Gates 3d, did not make any financier friends when he was quoted as calling bankers "dinosaurs."
Last week, Mr. Gates tried to mend fences at a meeting in Seattle of the 100 top executives of the world's largest banks. "I actually said the computer systems of banks are dinosaurs," Mr. Gates said at a news conference after the meeting.
 Mr. Gates said Microsoft would develop smart cards, software programs and other programs that would work with banks.
"In no way will we be competition to banks in what we're doing," Mr. Gates said. "We're coming up with ways for banks to use our technology. We will never be in the business of doing what banks do."
Microsoft officials have long expressed a desire to write operating systems and software for computerized devices of all shapes and sizes. The company has already introduced a watch, in conjunction with Timex, that stores telephone numbers and appointments.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Al electronic cash card being tested by Mondex inSwindon, England.
 
Chart: "Electronic Cash"
 Digital smart cards look like credit cards, but they have an embedded microchip that can perform a variety of functions. Microsoft is developing a smart-card system that would compete with several others aiming to replace cash with digital money that would be stored on a card and be spent for small purchases.
 Unlike today's debit cards, which electronically transfer money from a customer's checking account, the cash value would be digitally stored on the card itself. Retailers would use a smart-card terminal to deduct the amount for each purchase. At least four other organizations are developing such cards, which they plan to begin testing over the next year:
 
Mondex

MasterCard

Visa

HEADLINE: On the Annual Scoreboard of New Magazines, It's Sports 67, Sex 44

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
Sex sells -- no doubt about that. It may come as a surprise, however, that for the first time in five years, sex has fallen out of first place as the leading topic for new magazines.
With 44 new sex magazines last year in the United States, 51 fewer than in 1993, the category ceded first place to sports, which accounted for 67 of the 832 magazine start-ups. 
 But the sex category, which also fell behind food magazines last year, is not about to fade away. A subgroup with myriad possibilities is growing that could reverse the decline: ethnic sex magazines, including titles like Black Satin, Hot Salsa and Exotic Blondes of Scandinavia.
All of this arcane information comes from "Samir Husni's Guide to New Consumer Magazines," an annual compilation of thousands of facts about magazines. For the first time in its 10-year history, it is being published as a full-fledged book by Hearst Magazine Enterprises, a new division of the Hearst Corporation. The guide, published this month, also offers data on subscription prices and numbers of advertising pages.
Mr. Husni, the director of the magazine service journalism program at the University of Mississippi, goes about the counting and collecting of new magazines in a decidedly old-fashioned way. Every week for 10 years, he has made the 80-mile round trip from his home in Oxford, Miss., to Memphis, where he tours bookstores and newsstands, looking for new titles. He also receives information through the mail from publishers, and his students help compile the lists.
Unscientific as his method may be, Mr. Husni notes with some amusement that no one has come up with a better way to count new titles. "There is no other way," he said.
If counting start-ups is a hit-and-miss proposition, counting magazines that have ceased publication is even more difficult, and Mr. Husni does not list them. Companies love to trumpet the magazines they are starting but rarely send out releases when magazines are shut, unless the titles are so well known that their demise is real news. When asked why a magazine has not appeared for a while, publishers tend to say that it has been suspended and that its future is up in the air.
The 832 start-ups of 1994 were a record, beating the previous high in 1993 by 43 titles, Mr. Husni said. In 1985, the guide's first year, 231 titles were introduced.
Mr. Husni's guide covers the gamut. It ranges from the highly promoted Family PC, published by the Walt Disney Company and the Ziff-Davis Publishing unit of Forstmann Little & Company, to Soap Opera Hair (a how-to magazine for achieving the hairdos of your favorite soap opera stars), published by Starline Publications of River Edge, N.J.
There are now about 4,000 magazines in the United States, up from 2,500 in the mid-1980's, Mr. Husni estimated. And the big publishers are back in a start-up mood after the recession of the early 1990's, when companies were more apt to close publications than to start them.
The bulk of the new magazines, though, come from a growing number of small entrepreneurs whose narrowly aimed publications -- The Medieval and Renaissance Times, say, or Tattoo Savage ("radical tattoos and body piercing for those who walk on the wild side") -- are making their presence felt on newsstands around the country. Most of their revenues come from circulation rather than advertising.
"This is where the major corporations are waking up, as all of a sudden more and more of these little magazines are starting to take away from the big pie," Mr. Husni said. "The big corporations have started to launch new magazines like crazy."
Still, start-ups remain a risky business, whether they come from media giants or small entrepreneurs. Of the magazines started in 1985, he said, just 3 of every 10 that appear four times a year or more are still in business.
And in 1994, for the first time, the average cover price of new magazines climbed to more than $4, to $4.15. Ten years ago, it was $2.60.
Though sports magazines took first place last year, the category's total of 67 new titles was down 17 from 1993. The 45 new food magazines took second place, helped by the growing popularity of titles featuring lean cuisine and quick recipes.
Third place was a three-way tie, at 44 apiece, among sex, music and a catchall group of publications specializing in crafts, games and hobbies. The computer category was next, with 41.
Fast-growing categories included military and naval magazines, with 24 new titles, up 16 from 1993, and health publications with 31, up 13.

Graph: "Fewer Birds and Bees" shows the number of new sex magazines from '85-'93. (Source: Samir Husni's Guide to New Consumer Magazines)

HEADLINE: For Police, She's a True-Blue Friend

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9

 BODY:
She has all the accouterments of a good Cambridge liberal. She lives in a big house not far from Harvard Square. She drives a green Ford Explorer; has a Labrador retriever, Charlie, and is married to a Harvard University economist.
But from her basement office, using a small computer and an array of printers, Cynthia Brown has become the darling of a hefty segment of the nation's law-enforcement community. Ms. Brown publishes a 40-page, tabloid-style newspaper designed for, and written partly by, the police. At $12.95 for a one-year subscription, American Police Beat is read by more than 150,000 officers nationwide. Among its subscribers is Rush Limbaugh, the radio and television talk show host. 
 In a world in which police officers often feel that they are under attack by a relentlessly hostile media, Ms. Brown's publication is a welcomed exception. "I never imagined such a paper could be produced," said Tom Scotto, the president of the New York City Detectives Endowment Association and head of the National Association of Police Organizations. "Cynthia Brown puts out the best law-enforcement newspaper I've ever seen."
There are other police publications -- newsletters mostly with local or limited circulation. Only American Police Beat has a national audience and tackles issues that the police say are neglected by the mainstream media: lack of support from police chiefs, the newest vogue in weapons, the effect of affirmative action on white officers. There is even a police horoscope.
Ms. Brown, a slight, energetic woman, admits that her Cambridge neighbors don't all share her views about the police, whom she calls "some of the best, most caring and concerned people I've ever met."
A few doors away, for example, is the house of Alan M. Dershowitz, the Harvard Law School professor and a member of the O. J. Simpson defense team, who said on television earlier this year that police officers, during their training, are taught to lie.
In her next issue, Ms. Brown carried a response by Thomas Nee, a vice president of the Boston Police Patrolman's Association. "This statement has libeled and slandered police officers nationwide, and demeaned and degraded the integrity and credibility of every public safety officer," Mr. Nee said. He suggested that Mr. Dershowitz should be sued.
The June issue leads with a lengthy feature on four police officers in Riverside, Calif., whose homes have had liens placed on them after they were sued for shooting a suspect who was fleeing arrest. A radio dispatcher had alerted the officers that the suspect, Brian Forett, had shot a person in the neck and tied up two other victims in their house while making off with three guns and 250 rounds of ammunition.
"You can't do police work like you used to before," said Joe Scanlon, a retired detective from the Los Angeles Police Department and an ardent fan of Ms. Brown's paper. "My main beef isn't crime on the streets, it's the public's attitude." Speaking by phone from his home in Anaheim, Calif., Mr. Scanlon, whose son is a police officer in nearby Fullerton, said: "It's like the old Kipling saying about the British army, you're great when there is a war on, but after that, you're just a bum."
Ms. Brown, who grew up in an affluent Boston suburb and whose father, Daniel Rossborough, was an advertising executive, was converted to the police cause in the 1970's when she volunteered for a pilot community policing project in Boston's poor, racially mixed South End. The program was led by a young lieutenant, William J. Bratton, now police commissioner in New York, and was supposed to break down long-standing barriers between local residents and the police.
"At first I was taken aback by how conservative the police were," Ms. Brown said. But as she spent time with them, she said that she realized that they usually managed to maintain "their self-control, compassion and a sense of humor" despite the danger and drudgery of their tasks.
Ms. Brown, who financed the paper by mortgaging her family's home, said she started the enterprise because "there really was no vehicle where the street cops could communicate with each other."
She has turned it into a kind of family operation: She writes the editorials -- most recently attacking people and organizations that have derided police officers as thugs and fascists. Law-enforcement officers throughout the nation contribute articles, as does her son by a previous marriage, Mark Nichols, a college student.
Ms. Brown's husband, H. James Brown, a professor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government and director of Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies, set up the accounting system. Her father faxes her advice on advertising from his home on an island off Maine.
The paper has yet to make a profit, Ms. Brown said, so she and her husband, sit on the floor every month to stuff copies into mailing envelopes.
But they are encouraged by letters to the editor from police officers nationwide, like the note sent by Gene Gentile, president of the Lawmen Motorcycle Association of Hauppauge, N.Y.: "In each issue we find great encouragement and inspiration. Your courageous stand for truth is a welcomed beacon of light and a fountainhead from which we can derive nourishment and vigor in our daily battle against an ever growing criminal society."
