HEADLINE: A Giuliani Voting Bloc Is Eroding

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
At a recent City Hall news conference, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced an appointment that would otherwise have drawn little attention: the new chairwoman of the Mayor's Commission on the Status of Women. But in a uncharacteristic act, the Mayor prominently noted that his selection was a woman of Hispanic background.
Such an observation seemed distinctly out of character for a Mayor who has habitually eschewed any mention of ethnicity in announcing his appointments. But to many, the emphasis on Amalia V. Betanzos's background underscored the depth of the problems the Mayor is currently having with Hispanic New Yorkers. 
 The troubled relationship took an embarrassingly public turn yesterday, when Mr. Giuliani was met with intermittent booing as he marched in the annual Puerto Rican Day parade. The reception was a striking turnabout for a man whose support among the city's largely Democratic Hispanic voters helped propel him to the Mayor's job less than two years ago.
But poll after poll in recent months has depicted a sinking level of support among Hispanic New Yorkers for the Republican Mayor. A survey released Thursday by Baruch College and Louis Harris and Associates showed that Mr. Giuliani's support among Hispanic people has sharply declined recently, with 62 percent of the 1,005 surveyed saying they disapproved of his performance, compared with 39 percent in a survey by the same pollsters a year ago. Some Hispanic leaders said the results stem from a growing dissatisfaction with Mr. Giuliani's policies.
"The Mayor's handling of the budget certainly indicates a departure from programs that Latinos believe work, because these programs have been of help to many of them," said Luis Miranda, president of the Hispanic Federation of New York City, an umbrella group of more than 50 health and service agencies and the group that commissioned the poll. Mr. Miranda resigned in March as chairman of the Health and Hospitals Corporation after disagreeing with the Mayor over the depth of cuts in Medicaid.
Interviews with leaders of Hispanic neighborhood groups and civic and service organizations as well as ordinary Hispanic New Yorkers indicates a current of discontent with Mr. Giuliani, with many singling out his budget for criticism. They complain that cuts to youth programs, education and social service programs have disproportionately affected Hispanic New Yorkers.
"He has done a deplorable job based on cutting, cutting, cutting," said Daniel O. Camejo, a 27-year-old Cuban-American who is assistant director of a housing management organization in the Bronx. "On education, he has no agenda other than to be contentious with the Chancellor and to cut the budget for community colleges. And on everything else, he has been insensitive."
The complaints echo those voiced by many black New Yorkers. But while Mr. Giuliani received no more than 5 percent of the black vote, nearly 4 of every 10 Hispanic voters cast their votes for him in 1993, and the Mayor has worked to maintain, and expand, that support.
For Mr. Giuliani, the poll results point to a potential weakness that could undermine a re-election bid, and are evidence that his spending cuts to close the city's huge budget deficit are beginning to have a negative political impact.
Hispanic New Yorkers provided Mr. Giuliani with an estimated 78,000 votes in 1993 in a race the Mayor won by about 50,000 votes. Several aides to the Mayor said that they find the poll results deeply disturbing and that since Mr. Giuliani won the election by only 3 percent, he cannot afford to alienate any group that supported him. Moreover, they say they are frustrated that the Mayor's successes in crime and job creation have not resonated more among Hispanics.
"This is one group where we thought we would expand our base," said a senior aide who spoke on condition of anonymity. "This is a problem."
While New York's Hispanic community is diverse and far from monolithic, Mr. Miranda said that the poll results indicated that discontent with Mr. Giuliani stood at comparable levels whether the respondents were Puerto Rican, Dominican or Cuban, immigrant or native born.
In acknowledging the dropping poll numbers, Mr. Giuliani said that he has had to make difficult budget decisions that are bound to be unpopular. But he contended that his crime-fighting initiatives, coupled with his efforts to stimulate small businesses, would ultimately have a positive impact on his image among Hispanic people.
"I am confident that as we stick to our agenda and we accomplish the things we can accomplish for this city, those numbers will go back to where they were six or seven months ago," Mr. Giuliani said. "At budget time, mayors, governors and others have to make difficult decisions, and we have to work our way through that."
But many contend that the Mayor, in seeking to keep Hispanic support, has broken some of his rules of governance by making appointments based on nationality, not necessarily merit, and by failing to take strong stands that would antagonize Hispanic people.
Ms. Betanzos's appointment was the second of a Hispanic official in the last month; the Mayor also named Raul Russi, the head of the State Parole Board, as the new City Sheriff.
The appointments came after the departure of two of the most prominent Hispanic officials in the Giuliani administration, including Carlos M. Rivera, a special adviser to the Mayor. After he was dismissed in February, Mr. Rivera accused the Mayor of being "insensitive to Hispanic people."
Also, some city officials suggest that the Mayor's concerns about Hispanic support led him to remain silent on the plans to help finance the building of a huge Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem, despite the Mayor's longstanding support for superstores and similar economic initiatives. The project was bitterly opposed by owners of small markets, many of them Hispanic merchants. It was eventually approved.
Mr. Giuliani has vehemently denied that ethnicity had any role in his position, explaining that the decision was better left to the board of Manhattan elected officials who had to sign off on the initial stage of the project.
Ninfa Segarra, a Deputy Mayor and the only Hispanic person among the Mayor's senior aides, said that Mr. Giuliani's troubles in the polls are due in part to the administration's failure to convey the progress the Mayor has made in economic development, public safety and education. "We have to make sure our message is clear enough to indicate that we, and the Latino community, have similar goals," she said.
To that end, Ms. Segarra said, the Mayor has been active in meeting with Hispanic journalists, appearing on more Spanish-language radio and television programs and meeting with influential Hispanic New Yorkers. "Maybe he needs to do it more aggressively and more frequently," she said.
Angelo Falcon, president of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, a nonpartisan research and advocacy group, agreed that the administration has been seeking to increase its visibility among Hispanic people.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Cordiant Explores Cuts in Operations

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
Cordiant P.L.C., continuing to look at cutting costs, is exploring the possibility of eliminating duplication in the service, back-office and other noncore operations at the United States offices of its two agency networks, Bates Worldwide and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide.
"We're developing task forces to consider efficiencies," said Judy Torello, a spokeswoman for Bates in New York, in areas like office services contracts, purchasing, telecommunications and computer services, employee benefit programs and administrative systems. The task forces will focus on outside core areas like account management, creative services and research because Cordiant wants to continue to operate two separate agency networks to avoid potential conflicts among clients. 
 Cordiant has sought to cut costs since its former chairman, Maurice Saatchi, assumed large debts to finance a skein of acquisitions in the mid and late 1980's. Those economy efforts have accelerated since Mr. Saatchi was ousted in December and several large accounts left Bates and Saatchi & Saatchi in protest. The company's problems are expected to be addressed by top managers tomorrow at the Cordiant annual meeting in London.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Fishermen Want to Tell Tales

BYLINE: By DAVE STOUT 

DATELINE: LONG BRANCH

 BODY:
It is not easy to catch fish for a living. "These are hard times for working fishermen because of declining stocks of fish and increasing Federal regulations on what you can catch," Nils Stolpe of the New Jersey Seafood Harvesters' Association said last week. 
 The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey seems to agree with Mr. Stolpe. Last week, the authority awarded Mr. Stolpe's association and another commercial fishing group, the Association of United Boatmen of New Jersey and New York, $50,000 a year for three years to help them inform the public and business interests about the challenges they face.
"We'll work to build up the image of commercial fishing and make the public aware of its contributions to the character and economy of the Jersey shore," Mr. Stolpe said.

HEADLINE: Let's Bring Public Pensions Into 21st Century

 BODY:
To the Editor:
On behalf of the more than 500,000 retired public employees in New York State, I must respond to "The Education of George Pataki" (editorial, June 5), which links "pension sweeteners" to legislators' pet projects. 
 I doubt that a 1983 retired former cafeteria worker or school nurse trying to survive on an average annual pension of $7,343 would agree that a monthly increase of $35 to make up for a loss of $209 in monthly buying power is unconscionable.
Many of the 44,000 retirees represented by the Retired Public Employees Association do not receive Social Security payments, and they must somehow get by on pensions based on substandard salaries from years past.
Money for pension supplementation for state and most local government retirees is already in the Supplementation Reserve Fund, and would require no additional expenditures that would affect taxpayers.
We have suggested a task force to overhaul the state's public pension system, inaugurated in 1921. We hope you will take up the cause with us to redesign the system to meet the needs of a 21st-century economy, rather than the conditions of a 1921 economy.
 
JAMES F. MCGUIRK
President, Retired Public
Employees Association
Albany, June 8, 1995

HEADLINE: CURB ON MOB AIDS GARMENT MAKERS

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
Three years after prosecutors claimed they had broken the Mafia's choke hold over vital trucking routes in New York City's garment industry, many manufacturers say that shipping costs have dropped sharply and that dozens of new trucking companies are competing for business.
Garment manufacturers estimate that in three years, the average price for shipping a dress, a pair of jeans or a blouse has plunged to 15 to 20 cents from 40 to 45 cents. 
 Prosecutors said the falling costs reflected the demise of a mob cartel that had inflated prices and milked customers for half a century. Members of the Gambino crime family, they said, had forced manufacturers to use trucking companies they owned or controlled, stifling competition with threats of violence and adding a mob "tax" of about 7 percent to the price of finished garments.
The system crumbled in February 1992, officials said, when Thomas Gambino, now 65, and Joseph Gambino, 58, agreed to give up routes controlled by their companies in exchange for avoiding possible prison sentences.
Since then, total shipping costs in the city's garment industry have fallen about 20 percent, said Robert J. McGuire, a former New York City Police Commissioner who was appointed by a state judge to oversee the terms of the Gambino brothers' plea bargain.
"For the first time in decades," Mr. McGuire said in an interview, "customers are shopping for truckers and willing to move if they don't get the right prices or good service."
"In the old days, nobody considered they had an option to change once they were in the clutches of a company with organized-crime connections," he added. "Now we have unprecedented competition, with new truckers actively seeking business."
Most manufacturers said it was too soon to determine whether falling costs would lead to cheaper clothing or to higher wages for their employees. But in a report issued last month, Mr. McGuire said gross annual fees for the 9 trucking companies that took over routes from 11 companies accused of mob ties had declined to $23.4 million in 1994 from $27.5 million in 1992.
Daniel Zar, who designs and sells dresses in the midtown garment district in Manhattan, and Thomas Wong, who manufactures them, said in interviews that lower prices would save each of their companies about $40,000 in shipping costs this year.
And Louis Chan, who started a trucking business, Jetsway Company, only five years ago, said the end of Mafia influence had allowed him to acquire new customers and to expand his small fleet in lower Manhattan and Brooklyn to 12 trucks from 3.
Mr. Wong, the owner of T and L Fashions at 129 Lafayette Street in lower Manhattan, said that before the court order, he had no choice in truckers. Nor could he negotiate prices.
"Once the shop belonged to a trucker, you could not use any other company," he asserted. "There were no physical threats. But if they found out you used someone else, the bottom line was you had to pay them anyway to get off the hook."
Michael Slattery Jr., a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Mr. McGuire's deputy, said that in the last three years about 75 new trucking companies, known as independents, had emerged. Unlike established companies with dozens of trucks, the new companies often have only one or two trucks or vans, he said.
But while the new competition has been a windfall for garment manufacturers, it has created tensions between the established trucking companies that took over mob-controlled routes and the newer independents. The bigger companies say their prices are being undercut by new companies that hire undocumented immigrants, pay low wages without Social Security taxes and do not provide health and welfare payments to their employees.
"Sure, there's a lot of competition out there and it's a good time for the manufacturers," said Alan Rubin, the president of Conduit Rapid Delivery, which took over the customer lists of several companies that prosecutors said had been owned or controlled by members of the Gambino crime family. "But these new companies have no unions, no cargo insurance, no terminals and no overhead."
City officials estimate that the garment manufacturing industry generates about $14 billion a year in gross sales and wages for the city's economy. About 1,000 designers or wholesalers and sewing factories -- mainly companies with fewer than 50 full-time employees -- operate in the city.
Because of an increase in garment factories in other states and countries, the industry's economic importance to the city has steadily declined. Since 1961, the number of garment industry employees in the city has dropped from 260,000, to 80,000.
In February 1992, the Gambino brothers interrupted their trial on state charges of extortion and running a trucking cartel to plead guilty, each to a single felony count of illegally restraining trade. If convicted of the most serious corruption charge, they could have faced 8 1/3 to 25 years in prison each.
They were spared prison sentences by paying a $12 million fine and agreeing to get themselves and their associates out of a business they had long controlled: the trucking of unfinished clothing, known as cutwork, and patterns from companies along Seventh Avenue to sewing shops and factories in Chinatown and elsewhere. The Gambino companies also transported the finished garments from the factories to warehouses for distribution by manufacturers.
The agreement, however, did not affect the Gambino brothers' ownership of several long-distance trucking companies that haul garments to and from warehouses, airports and storage centers used by department and chain stores.
The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, whose office brought the indictment against the Gambino brothers, contended that their companies had fixed prices for cutwork and finished garments and refused to allow customers to switch to other truckers. Prosecutors said the Gambino brothers' companies compelled manufacturers and contractors to pay them even if an independent trucker was used for an emergency delivery.
Mr. McGuire, the president of Kroll Associates, a private investigation concern in Manhattan, oversaw the liquidation of the 11 trucking companies that prosecutors said were owned or affiliated with the Gambino brothers. He is empowered under the court agreement to insure that competition exists among the companies, known as covered companies, that have taken over the old Gambino-controlled routes.
He has prohibited the companies from fixing prices, dividing territory and transferring and selling the rights to clients. The companies also are banned from requiring wholesalers and contractors to use their services exclusively.
"This is a new approach to solving an endemic problem of organized-crime infiltration of an industry," Mr. McGuire said. "Sending one organized-crime figure to jail and having him replaced by another has no long-term effect. This is a systemic attempt to change the fundamental way business is conducted in the garment industry and to level the playing field for all competitors."
Mr. Slattery, senior managing director at Kroll Associates, said English and Mandarin Chinese copies of Mr. McGuire's rules, titled "Know Your Trucking Rights," have been distributed to more than 500 contractors and manufacturers in the city.
"Our analysis shows that there has been an explosion of about 75 new, independent truckers serving the marketplace," Mr. Slattery said in an interview. "All of the covered truckers have suffered from the increased competition by lowering their prices, shifting their business or simply losing customers."
Mr. Slattery said the Gambino brothers' fine, of which about $10 million has been paid so far, was being used for the oversight and other costs.
The Kroll company, which is authorized to monitor the industry until February 1997, has received $2.3 million for legal and auditing expenses, Mr. McGuire said. The Manhattan District Attorney's office received $1.6 million, and the state police got $1 million as reimbursements for the cost of their investigations of the Gambino companies, Mr. McGuire said.
Twelve contractors that were found to have been overcharged by the Gambino companies have received a total of $700,000 in compensation, he said.
The state has been paid $2.4 million and is to receive whatever is left after final expenses for Kroll Associates, Mr. McGuire said.
Thomas Gambino, who avoided a possible prison sentence in 1992, was convicted in 1993 on unrelated Federal accusations of running gambling and loan-sharking rings and of being a capo, or captain, in a crime family.
He was sentenced to five years in prison but is free on $500,000 bail while awaiting a ruling on an appeal of his conviction.
The Gambino brothers' father, Carlo Gambino, died of natural causes in 1976.

HEADLINE: Experts See Peril for U.S. Pact To Buy Up Russian Bomb Fuel

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Three years after Russia agreed to provide the United States with uranium from scrapped Russian nuclear weapons, the deal is unraveling, prompting a quiet struggle to save the accord, Federal and private experts say.
Russia was to get $12 billion in desperately needed hard currency, and the United States was to get 500 metric tons of bomb-grade uranium, which was to be diluted to make fuel for American nuclear power plants and ultimately electricity for consumers. 
 In addition to bolstering national security for the United States, the agreement was expected to strengthen the shaky Russian economy, reduce the risks of nuclear accidents and theft and, less explicitly, help disarm a former foe. Further, it was not expected to cost taxpayers anything, since revenues from the sale of reactor fuel were to offset the total $12 billion cost.
But efforts to carry out the three-year-old deal have been stymied by administrative missteps, disagreements over pricing for the uranium and even trade disputes, the experts say. On Tuesday, the Senate Energy Committee is to hold a hearing on aspects of the deal, which the Russians are privately threatening to drop.
The unraveling of the deal is on the agenda for Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Victor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia, who are to meet late this month in Moscow. The Administration wants to resolve the problems, if only to give Russia a source of nuclear revenues other than Iran and rogue states interested in acquiring atomic weaponry.
Republicans have strongly criticized the Clinton Administration for not pressing Russia harder to drop plans to sell Iran nuclear reactors, which could serve as the basis for an atomic-bomb program.
The innovative agreement was announced by the Bush Administration in August 1992 and was carried forward by the Clinton Administration, which negotiated a detailed contract in 1993.
The deal, a high point of nuclear disarmament at the end of the cold war, represents a substantial part of the Russian nuclear arsenal, but far from all of it. Russia is estimated to have 1,200 metric tons of bomb-grade uranium, as well as 170 metric tons of plutonium, the other critical ingredient for making warheads. Even so, 500 metric tons is enough to build more than 30,000 bombs as powerful as the one dropped on Hiroshima -- and enough to run the 109 operating nuclear power plants in the United States for about a decade.
After many delays, a small initial shipment of less than a ton of the Russian uranium is expected to arrive in the United States this month. It is part of an initial order of 6 tons, but private experts say the prospects for significant deliveries beyond that are dim.
The accord is lost in a "quagmire of incompetent implementation" and is "in danger of coming completely undone," Richard A. Falkenrath, a fellow at the Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard University, concluded in a recent report.
Thomas L. Neff, a physicist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who proposed the deal in 1991, said in an interview: "The patient is in need of a heart transplant. Unfortunately, it seems we have only plastic surgeons."
The Administration has yet to develop a position on what steps to take and appears leery of speaking out. Senior officials were contacted at the State, Energy and Defense Departments, but only deputies would talk and then only on the condition of anonymity, saying some analysts were overstating the problems and that remedies in any event were sure to be found.
But they added that no consensus exists on what steps to take while insisting that a solution is reachable if only because the stakes for national security are so high.
"Hard things can be made to work," said a State Department official who is laboring on the issue. "This is worthwhile. It's worth putting a lot of effort into."
An official at the Energy Department said: "The situation's not simple. This is the only real money in the U.S.-Russian relationship. It's high stakes because of the big money and it's complex because of all the different constituencies involved. But I don't think things are as bad as people say. Like anything else, the devil is in the details, and we're working on those."
Some analysts say one trouble is that the deal tries to mix private gain and public policy. A federally owned corporation, the Enrichment Corporation of Bethesda, Md., which was chosen to carry out the deal, is deadlocked with the Russian Ministry of Atomic Energy over pricing, with no signs of compromise.
"Serious difficulties have arisen in the way of meeting the original expectations of both parties," Victor N. Mikhailov, head of Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy, said last week in a letter to Lynn E. Davis, Under Secretary of State for International Security Affairs.
More broadly, many analysts say the deal was problematic from the start because it was so novel, involving substantial East-West transfers of nuclear material rather than its disposition by individual states, as in more usual forms of arms control.
William H. Timbers Jr., president of the Enrichment Corporation, said in an interview that the White House and Congress would fix the flaws and allow the deal to go forward. He added that analysts were unduly pessimistic, and that perhaps they had been misled by statements from Moscow.
"The Russians are very tough and wily negotiators," he said. "We try to be the same way."
Natural uranium is made up of a mix of isotopes, or different forms of the same element. Less than 1 percent of it is uranium 235, the fissionable isotope used in bombs and reactors. Uranium for most American nuclear power reactors is enriched to a level of about 4 percent uranium 235, while fuel for bombs is enriched to more than 90 percent.
The idea of reversing the usual process and diluting warheads was suggested in 1991 by Dr. Neff of M.I.T., who argued that it could aid Russia's transition to a market economy while helping to avoid a series of nuclear perils.
In 1992, President Bush announced the 20-year accord to buy 500 metric tons of bomb-grade uranium, hailing it as "making the world a safer place to live."
The Enrichment Corporation was chosen to carry out the deal, even though its specialty was concentrating uranium 235 rather than watering it down. Moreover, the company enjoyed a virtual monopoly in the United States on such work, enriching uranium for about $60 per separative work unit -- the standard measure of the effort used in processing varying amounts of the material -- and selling it to utilities for $120.
In contrast, the deal called for the company to buy the uranium from Russia for $82 per separative work unit in its first annual order, giving it a lower profit margin. In response, the company has unsuccessfully sought to recoup the difference from the Federal Government, and also unsuccessfully sought to drive the Russians down to a price of $68 per separative work unit on future orders.
More positively, the Russians, with an advance payment of $60 million, are starting to ship the initial order of six metric tons after overcoming dilution hurdles. The first shipment is to arrive by ship this month, said Mr. Timbers of the Enrichment Corporation. It consists of 0.786 metric tons of bomb-grade uranium from warheads that has been blended with other uranium to form 24 metric tons of reactor fuel.
The enrichment-pricing dispute is compounded by one involving world trade in uranium ore. As the Soviet Union collapsed, the Russians began selling ore at low prices in the United States, and the Commerce Department brokered agreements to stem this flow as a way to protect the domestic uranium industry.
This curtailment affected the deal because the Enrichment Corporation is having Russia dilute its bomb-grade uranium in Russia with Russian low-enriched uranium. But that material is now barred, in effect, from the United States market by strict trade quotas.
The company's plan is to circumvent the problem on a technicality by paying the Russians only for the enrichment costs and not for the uranium itself (about one-third of the product's value) until after the trade quotas expire in 2004. The Russians are objecting, saying they want the money now.
Solutions to these problems are being debated in the legislative and executive branches, including the National Security Council. The Administration seems to be moving toward a stance that favors relaxing the uranium-sale quotas so the Russians can be paid full price and putting the Enrichment Corporation on notice that it can be replaced if it is intransigent in its enrichment-pricing stance.
The force of such threats is limited, however, since getting a new agent would undermine the Enrichment Corporation's virtual monopoly and lessen its value, which currently stands at about $1.5 billion. The Government wants a high valuation so the Treasury reaps the maximum benefit when the company is sold, an action now planned for 1996.
Senator Pete V. Domenici, a Republican of New Mexico who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, has introduced a bill that takes a different approach by creating a futures market that would generate cash now for delivery of the Russian nuclear material after the trade restrictions have expired. The bill's features, and the Administration's response, are to be discussed at the hearing on Tuesday.
Private experts say such steps are too timid, and many are calling for the replacement of the Enrichment Corporation or at least the reassertion of strong Administration control over the company and the deal. National-security concerns, they say, are being held hostage to corporate greed and domestic politics.
Among other solutions, Dr. Falkenrath of Harvard suggests that the Government throw open the process to competitive bidding. The Enrichment Corporation would have the first purchase option each year, which could be picked up by other companies if it showed no interest.
More boldly, he suggests, the Government might simply forgo the commercial route and buy the Russian bomb-grade uranium outright, feeding it slowly into the domestic market and eventually recouping its expenses.
"Those responsible for the national security of the United States," Dr. Falkenrath said in his report, could thus salvage the deal "from the quagmire of incompetent implementation where it now resides."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

With a Sweetened Offer, I.B.M. Wins Its Prize
 Lotus Development accepted I.B.M.'s initially hostile takeover offer, after I.B.M. raised its price by about $220 million, to more than $3.5 billion in cash, and guaranteed the innovative software manufacturer a degree of independence extremely unusual among its divisions. Lotus's six directors met Saturday and voted to accept the offer of $64 a share. 
 The acquisition gives I.B.M. a creative and nimble partner whose Lotus notes can serve as a translator among the wide range of operating systems in the industry. [Page A1.]
 Has I.B.M. given up on its OS/2 operating system? The deal to acquire Lotus has many analysts thinking so, but the company says no. News Analysis. [D4.]
 
Jawboning the Fed
 The Clinton Administration made its most conspicuous public effort to persuade the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. Leon Panetta, the President's chief of staff, said the Administration would appreciate the central bank's help in preventing a recession. [D2.]
 
Changes in Salomon Pay Plan
 Salomon Brothers is scrapping its much-debated compensation plan, which led to the departure of more than 20 senior managing directors and traders, people at the firm said last night. [D8.]
 
Europe's Chance in Auto Dispute
 Taking advantage of the bitter auto trade dispute between the United States and Japan, Europe is playing each side against the other in an effort to secure gains in the Japanese auto market for its own companies while emerging with an image as the ultimate protector of free trade. [D2.]
 
Kodak Takes Aim at Fuji
 Kodak has asked the Government to investigate what it says is a conspiracy by Fuji and the Japanese Government to protect 70 percent of the consumer photo film and paper market in Japan from competition. [D3.]
 
Microsoft's Top Priority
 The biggest worry for Microsoft these days is that the Justice Department's investigation of its plans to market its new on-line service could delay or interfere with the introduction of its Windows 95. Technology. [D3.]
 Microsoft wants to offer plastic cards embedded with microchips, known as smart cards, that can be used to make payments. It is working with chip manufacturers to develop the specifications of its card, and then expects to approach banks that would stand behind the payments on the card. Executives of several of the country's largest banks say they have been approached by Microsoft. But it might have difficulty finding partners, so scared are bankers of its might. [D3.]
 
Hard Sell at Paris Air Show
 With military budgets shrinking and commercial aviation in crisis in many countries, the competition to woo customers was cutthroat at the Paris Air Show. European competitors argued that American plane makers were getting an unfair advantage from the cut-rate dollar. [D9.]
 
Advertisers Sticking by Baseball
 Baseball's attendance is down 20 percent, but ESPN's ratings for televising the game have dipped only slightly, and advertisers seem undeterred. Lawrie Mifflin: Television. [D5.]
 
Blurred Line Between AM and FM
 FM radio, which lured listeners from AM by providing more varied music with far more clarity, is now embarking on an experiment: borrowing the news, talk and sports programming from its older cousin. [D6.]
 
Difficult Coverage
 Time magazine's dogged coverage of the controversy involving its parent, Time Warner, and gangsta rap music may burnish the publication's reputation. But it could exacerbate the strains inside Time Warner. [D5.]

HEADLINE: At Fair for Survivalists, Fallout From Oklahoma

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., June 11

 BODY:
In their first big gathering since the Oklahoma City bombing, leaders and members of self-styled citizen militias converged here with hundreds of survivalists and seekers of self-sufficiency and holistic health for a Preparedness Expo, at which they did their best to distance themselves from the nation's worst act of terrorism.
The event was billed as a consumer fair to educate people about how to prepare for emergencies, including hurricanes, riots and "threats to our personal freedom." Booths were selling as much survival gear as herbal remedies. 
 For the first time in seven years, news cameras and tape recorders were banned, a sign of the resentment some groups hold against those who they say have unfairly linked them to the April 19 bombing that killed 167 people in Oklahoma City. Both suspects arrested in the attack, Timothy J. McVeigh and Terry L. Nichols, have been widely described by news organizations as militia sympathizers.
Some militia members said publicity had helped increase their numbers by making people aware of their movement. Bob Starr, who said he was the commander of the 112th battalion of the "Militia at Large of the Republic of Georgia," said membership in his group had quadrupled since the bombing, although he declined to give specific figures.
"It has done nothing but wake people up," he said. "They're beginning to see that government will do anything to restrict our freedoms."
In a speech on Saturday, a former Green Beret commander who is a leader of what he calls a Christian patriot movement, James (Bo) Gritz, spoke about current events that he said had fulfilled Bible prophecies. But he digressed to rate Mr. McVeigh as merely a driver who could not possibly be the "Rembrandt" behind what he called a sophisticated and highly professional demolition job. Mr. Gritz thought a Federal Government operative was a more likely culprit.
"Somewhere, somebody says, 'If this happened it would probably clear the way for some progressive programs,' " he told an audience of 450 people. "That's all it takes."
He then made a pitch for his paramilitary training videos, which came in a three-tape set for $60 and "would make you as qualified to wear a Green Beret as any Special Forces soldier," he said.
Dan Chittock, a 36-year-old entrepreneur who has organized the show since 1989, said 2,000 to 3,000 people came to the Orange County Convention Center for the three-day event, which ended today. Among them were newcomers who said they were looking for a different point of view, regulars who swapped conspiracy stories, and the curious. These included some members of the Loyal Order of Moose and the Women of the Moose who migrated to the Expo from their 107th annual meeting elsewhere in the hall.
A retired postal worker who said he also attended last year said he was increasingly alarmed by the "decay of society" and wanted to learn to prepare for emergency situations, like finding out what kinds of edible plants are in the woods.
"This is a very unstable world we live in," said the 55-year-old man, who like many other participants refused to give his name. "What makes us immune to wars?"
But first-timers like Roy Olsen, 33, a communications technician from Boynton Beach, Fla., said he was taken aback by the paramilitary aspects of the fair.
"I was looking into self-sufficiency more in the way of getting myself a farm together," he said. "I didn't know it was more militia type."
Mr. Olsen, who bought a juicer and was considering leaving early as he waited for a lecture billed as "Preparing for the Economic and Political Convulsions of the 90's," said he could not help but feeling a little paranoid.
"Last night I started having bad thoughts. Gee, I can get on an F.B.I. list," he said.
As men in camouflage mingled with naturopathic doctors, and browsers strolled by displays of gold jewelry, Army field manuals (including "Explosives and Demolitions") and information on how to obtain news about the paramilitary movement on the Internet, familiar militia themes echoed from the stage. There were warnings about the United Nations and a movement toward a single world government, the so-called New World Order.
There were attacks on the anti-terrorism bill in Congress that would give law-enforcement officials expanded powers and on what speakers saw as efforts by the anti-gun lobby to use the Oklahoma bombing as an excuse to force Americans to disarm.
"My definition of gun control is hitting the target with every shot," Mr. Gritz told the crowd on Friday night during a panel discussion.
In a fiery speech on Saturday night, Mark Koernke, who comes from Michigan and calls himself a militia strategist and who until recently had talk show on short-wave radio, said patriots were not anarchists or anti-government. They are, he said, unwavering defenders of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, which militia members say makes every American one of them.
Mr. Koernke urged the audience to prepare against any possible attacks on "the republic" and to teach their children to put differences and infighting aside and take advantage of the attention showered on them. He also advocated using the political process by moving together to towns where they could create majorities and control the local government.
"We're literally a vast movement," he said. "This is not the time to sit back. This is not the time to hide."
But for some, it was time to take off from the serious programs and go to Walt Disney World nearby. These included Jack McLamb, a retired Arizona police officer who wrote a booklet warning of a plan to unite the world under the United Nations by 2001. The booklet, "Operation Vampire Killer," was among the papers found by the F.B.I. while searching the pickup truck of Mr. McVeigh's sister, Jennifer.

HEADLINE: The Hamptons-Bound Find Luxury in Coach

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
Outside, the Saabs and Land Rovers air-kiss each other's bumpers as they crawl east on the Long Island Expressway.
Inside, the ladies come and go, their drying toenails held apart with puffs of cotton as they pad about, from the styling chair, to the table laden with salmon sandwiches and fresh strawberries, to the marble-floored toilet cubicle. 
 Margarita Levitin, 26, a Cindy Crawfordesque brunette with wraparound sunglasses tucked into the deep V-neck of her black sweater, lights up as she watches a video on fashion trends, courtesy of Vogue. "Fendi furs!" she exclaims. "The best!"
This is the Magic Bus, circa 1995, where the magic is makeup and the destination is the summer swirl of high-society weddings and see-and-be-seen restaurants of the Hamptons.
The luxury bus, officially the Gil Gamlieli Beauty Express, began offering its mobile pampering this summer to clients willing to spend $250 and up -- usually up -- for a three-hour salon session on wheels. Leaving from Mr. Gamlieli's Upper East Side salon on Friday afternoons and returning Monday mornings, it offers almost every usual beauty service except hair coloring and cutting (scissors are deemed too dangerous for the road).
"It's amazing, amazing, it's really amazing," Mr. Gamlieli, an Israeli-born stylist with a long face and luminous eyes, says of the interest the new bus service has evoked. "I really like the feeling we hit the right thing at the right time.
"Europeans went crazy about it," he says. "They say, 'Only in New York.' "
For those who question the wisdom of applying coats of foundation and hairspray on the way to the beach, the answer is simple: The Hamptons are so much more than a beach.
"The weather's not like New York City, but you get the same people," says Donna Lourie, 30, a travel agency owner on her first Beauty Express trip. "People think they're very laid-back out here. I don't think so. They're the same. And for the single person who's actively looking, this is the place. It's a scene. It's a total scene."
To prepare for last weekend's scene, three women -- Ms. Lourie; Ms. Levitin, an unemployed clothing buyer, and Linda Siegal, a 31-year-old entrepreneur who runs a concierge service -- board the bus at 2 P.M. Friday. All hair washing, coloring and cutting has already been done in the salon.
"This is definitely hot and new," Ms. Siegal says as the blow-drying and face-painting get under way. "Who cares if you're sitting in traffic, if you're getting your nails done?"
Passengers are cosseted by a staff of four -- Mr. Gamlieli, a manicurist, a makeup artist and an attendant who offers coffee, champagne, fruit and sandwiches every 15 minutes or so. The bus's driver and owner, Hilik Swimir, says the coach, with its long leather seats and divans, microwave, refrigerator and television, is worth about a half-million dollars.
Unexpectedly, the bus jounces as it hits a pothole.
"Hilik!" Mr. Gamlieli calls in cheerful annoyance.
"I'm sorry, it's really bumpy today!" Mr. Swimir calls back.
"Tell us, 'Now is the bumpy time,' like in the airplane!" Mr. Gamlieli implores.
The bumpy time can be tricky: one weekend the makeup artist had to ask for a mascara stop, and lip-liner can present a major challenge. Boxes of powders or swabs crash to the floor once or twice a trip.
As the bus hits a smooth stretch of highway, the talk turns to the dates the women are planning for the weekend, and to the hard work they have put in all week that lets them feel deserving of this special treatment.
Ms. Siegal, who runs the concierge business, tells of a dinner she is planning for connoisseurs of Scotch and cigars, at "only $125 a plate." Ms. Lourie's nails, done in Pretty in Pink, are drying. Mr. Gamlieli describes the super-bus he plans for next summer, with a giant water tank to allow shampooing on board.
Ms. Lourie mentions some of her clients, "Young guys making millions -- they don't know what to do with all their money."
"Where are they?" Ms. Levitin asks, half-smiling.
The conversation switches to the impending death of Broadway, and Brooke Shields's inability to sing, dance or act. A giant souffle loaf, filled with various crustless sandwiches, is broken open, and the networking begins.
"Next week we'll sit down and we'll talk," Ms. Siegal says to Ms. Lourie. "I could refer you a lot of business."
Mr. Gamlieli observes with approval, "I think New York grows so fast a new generation of business ladies."
Ms. Siegal heads back to have her hair blown out. Ms. Levitin, her hair now retro-mod with a 60's-style flip and side part, is getting black 50's-style eyeliner to match. Ms. Lourie notes that this is the first time she has had the luxury of letting her pedicure dry. Usually, she says, she crams her wet toes into her shoes and goes back to work.
"I'm, like, in shock," Ms. Levitin says when her makeup is done. "I don't recognize myself. I'm like Nancy Sinatra in the white boots."
Time for the Vogue trend report on video. The passengers watch fitted suits parade along the runway.
"This is how the French have looked for years," Ms. Levitin says. "When you go to Paris, they're so put together."
On the video, beauty gurus preach: "The lip is pale this season. The nail is ultra-groomed."
The regular bus between Manhattan and the Hamptons, the Hampton Jitney -- $36 for a round trip -- passes going the other way. The Beauty Express passengers laugh with cheery disdain.
Ms. Siegal is looking at herself in the mirror, at the bold blue shadow on her eyelids and the swirling blond curls that Mr. Gamlieli dubs "the romantic look."
"I do not feel like me at all," she says. "This has been the most enjoyable ride I've ever had to the Hamptons. I never do this -- I don't pamper myself enough. I get manicures and pedicures but I never blow my hair dry. I never have my makeup done."
Mr. Gamlieli, pinning up Ms. Siegal's hair, is thrown onto a seat as the bus rounds a sharp curve.
"Hilik!" he calls. "Tell us before!"
Coffee is offered all around, and fragrant hot towels. The vegetation has grown flat; the sea is near. Ms. Siegal and Ms. Levitin chat about restaurants.
"Everywhere I go, no matter where I go, I know people," Ms. Levitin says. "You know where I haven't been yet? Robert De Niro's new sushi restaurant."
"I was there last night," Ms. Siegal says.
The bus glides into Southampton, and a Mercedes convertible whizzes by.
"I want to be in that car," Ms. Levitin says, then reconsiders. "But then, the hairdo . . ."
"Keep it for Sunday," Mr. Gamlieli recommends.
The bus lurches up to the beach. A sign says weekend parking is $20 a day. Mr. Gamlieli weaves his plans out loud for beauty services by the shore: conditioning to protect hair and bring out highlights, "a quick bikini wax for the women who forgot it, and she's really embarrassed."
The passengers walk off the bus. Ms. Levitin lights a cigarette and wiggles her Ballet Slipper pink toenails in the soft sand.

HEADLINE: A Rare Nudge for a Drop in Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today made its most public effort to persuade the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, with Leon Panetta, the White House chief of staff, saying that any help from the central bank in preventing a recession would be appreciated.
Asked on the NBC News program "Meet The Press" whether the Federal Reserve should reduce interest rates to prevent the American economy from slipping into a recession, Mr. Panetta said, "Well, it would be nice to get whatever kind of cooperation we can get to get this economy going." 
 Asked if his comments were an effort to jawbone the Fed into cutting rates, Mr. Panetta replied with a laugh, "Is that what it's called?"
The Fed raised short-term interest rates seven times between Feb. 4, 1994, and Feb. 1 of this year. While many on Wall Street were anticipating a rate cut before too long, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, implied on Wednesday that such a step was unlikely. In remarks that sent bond prices tumbling and interest rates up, Mr. Greenspan raised the possibility of a recession but said he thought the economy would recover later in the year.
The decisions on interest-rate policy that the Federal Reserve makes in the next few months are likely to have more influence on President Clinton's re-election prospects than any other economic policy decisions in the next year and a half. Changes in short-term interest rates, which the Federal Reserve directly controls, can take a year to affect the economy fully and are the biggest single influence on the pace of economic growth in the United States.
Mr. Panetta's comments represented a breach of the Administration's policy for the last two years of refraining from comment about the highly independent central bank. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin imposed the ban on such comment while serving as head of the White House's National Economic Council.
The ban reflects the view of the Administration's economists and Wall Street veterans alike that nudging the Federal Reserve accomplishes little, particularly when done in public. The central bank has been known in the past to do the opposite of what the White House desired in order to demonstrate its indepenence.
White House criticism of the Federal Reserve also tends to unnerve financial markets, driving down bond prices and the value of the dollar and driving up long-term interest rates. That is because investors worry that if an Administration succeeds in jawboning the Federal Reserve into lowering short-term interest rates for political rather than economic reasons, the resulting faster money supply growth and possibly faster economic growth will eventually lead to higher inflation.
When Mr. Greenspan abruptly canceled a speech in Houston on March 18, 1994, because President Clinton had called him to the White House, financial markets were thrown into turmoil. The bond market gave up a week of gains and long-term interest rates climbed.
The Federal Reserve might be vulnerable to pressure now because Mr. Greenspan's term expires next March, and he is widely believed to want President Clinton to appoint him to a third term. At the same time, Mr. Greenspan is described by close associates as eager to leave a reputation as an inflation fighter and is unlikely to sacrifice that reputation by slashing interest rates now if he thinks the economy's condition does not warrant such a move.
Notwithstanding his comment today on the Fed, Mr. Panetta said he did not anticipate a recession. "Everybody's a little concerned about where it is right now, but I think we all feel that it isn't going to go into a recession," he said. "We're going to see a period of growth take place at the end of this year and into next year."
Mr. Greenspan was in Basel, Switzerland, today for a meeting of the Bank for International Settlements. In remarks there to journalists, he repeated his assessment that the odds had diminished of the United States having a severe, inventory-led recession. But the likelihood of a brief economic downturn had risen, he noted, repeating the gist of his comments last Wednesday.
"Because of the dramatic slowing of the economy, the probability of the type of severe inventory recession that we would have had -- had the economy kept going and still been strong at this point -- the probability of that scenario has gone down dramatically," he said. "The probability of a modest adjustment -- whether you call it a recession or not -- has obviously gone up as a consequence."

HEADLINE: U.S. Plans Wider Links With Cubans

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
Once the furor over new rules on Cuban immigration dies down, the Clinton Administration plans to make an important shift in policy by announcing expanded contacts between Americans and Cubans as a way of undermining Fidel Castro.
Officials are quick to say that they plan to continue to isolate Mr. Castro and maintain the economic sanctions of the last 30 years, which the White House actually toughened last summer. But they contend that the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe demonstrated the value of increased contacts in the form of, for example, educational exchanges. 
 So far, they have held off out of concern that Cuban-American groups and Congressional Republicans would criticize the increased contacts as moves toward normalizing relations with Havana.
Among the many steps under consideration are allowing American news organizations to open bureaus in Cuba, funneling money and fax machines to Cuban human rights activists, and arranging exchanges of American and Cuban clerics, students, academics and artists.
"Eastern European officials told us that these tools made a real difference in bringing down Communism," said a senior policy maker.
Some of President Clinton's foreign policy advisers were pressing to announce the moves early last month when the Administration announced it would send boat people seeking refuge here back to Cuba. Many Cuban-American groups, especially the powerful Cuban-American National Foundation, condemned the change as a concession and a step toward normalization.
Senator Bob Graham, the Florida Democrat who is probably the Administration's chief adviser on Cuba, has warned against actions that might be construed as steps toward normalization until the anger dies down among Cuban-Americans.
"If a better climate gets created in two to three months -- that's about how long we think it will take -- then we have a moral obligation to take further steps to help people on the island push for democracy," a senior State Department official said.
Administration officials say the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 embraced two strategies to weaken Mr. Castro: tightening the trade embargo and increasing contacts among people of the two countries. The philosophy was that a greater flow of Western ideas to Cuba would speed Cubans' embrace of democracy.
"There is a strong sense in the Administration that we should be more aggressive in advancing the aims of the Cuban Democracy Act," said a top Administration policy maker on Cuba.
Senator Graham had told the Administration that the timing should turn in part on whether Havana fulfills its pledge to avoid reprisals against boat people sent back to Cuba. If there are reprisals, the reasoning goes, that will provide ammunition to critics who say the Administration was misguided and naive to trust Havana's promises.
"If there are credible stories of people repatriated being beaten up or worse, it will weaken the Administration's hand," Mr. Graham said.
Administration officials acknowledge they are wary that announcing increased contacts might widen the schism with the Cuban-American National Foundation. But they say that many Cuban-Americans, upset that their relatives are trapped on the Communist island, are lobbying for increased contacts as a way of breathing intellectual fresh air into Cuba.
Officials say they have been considering the new policy for months, and Cuba's recent decision to release its two most prominent political prisoners could help the Administration make this decision.
Responding to pleas from the United States and France, Mr. Castro freed the two prisoners 10 days ago in what was widely viewed as an effort to earn good will with Washington. The two, Rolando Indamiro Restano Diaz and Sebastian Arcos Bergnes, had been held more than three years on charges of seeking to subvert the Cuban state.
Officials said there was no link to whether Cuba hands over Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier arrested last week.
Judging from its recent remarks, the Cuban-American National Foundation does not trust the Administration to increase contacts in a way that turns up the heat on Havana.
"If such steps are pursued with the original intention -- to force open Cuban society -- and are used in an offensive way against Castro, then it's something we endorse," said Jose Cardenas, director of the foundation's Washington office. "But we worry that with this Administration, it will just mean Cubans and Americans sit around and have coffee, the Americans spend hard currency in Cuba and then everyone goes home. We can't be very excited about that."
Some Cuban-Americans say Castro might resent the moves and try to block some of them.
 Having defied the foundation's influential president, Jorge Mas Canosa, on immigration policy, the Administration seems less daunted about defying him again, partly because he is raising money for the Republican Party. Moreover, the Administration dismisses Mr. Mas's claim to speak for all Cuban-Americans since polls show that almost half the Cubn-Americans in Florida support the new immigration policy.
Another indicator of coming changes was the selection last month of Richard Nuccio, known as a pragmatist open to expanded contacts, as the President's special adviser on Cuba.
Several of the Administration's policy makers on Cuba say allowing American newspapers or networks to open bureaus in Havana should be a priority because it would -- at least in theory -- advance democracy and help focus attention on Cuba's human rights violations. But Representative Dan Burton, the Indiana Republican who heads the House Subcommittee on Western Hemispheric Affairs, says such a move would only prop up Castro with hard currency.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who wrote the Cuban Democracy Act, asserts that the Administration should have allowed news bureaus in Havana months ago.
"If Castro gains $7 million in foreign exchange from having newspapers and networks in Havana, that's money I'd welcome him to receive," he said. "These news bureaus will make it impossible for Castro to harass human rights people the way he has in the past."

HEADLINE: If Devils Leave New Jersey, Life on Rte. 3 Will Not End

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
The New Jersey Devils are threatening to skate into the Stanley Cup finals and then keep right on skating to a new home in Nashville. So the Stadium Cafe, across Route 3 from the Devils' home ice at the Meadowlands Sports Complex, should be a good place to listen to the fans' anguished cries, standard background music for any team on the verge of packing its equipment bags.
"Oh yes, I heard about that last night," said a waitress, nonchalantly, as she headed off to find the owner, Craig Petrillo. 
 Clearly, she just didn't get it. Mr. Petrillo, 32 and muscular, proudly displays a picture of the Devils' general manager, Lou Lamoriello, taken in his restaurant. Mr. Petrillo must be quite the Devils fan.
"Not a big one," he said sheepishly.
But what if they leave? He is not rooting for it, he said, but added, "Personally, I don't think it will be a tremendous blow."
New Jersey is used to being viewed by outsiders as just a string of rest stops along the highway, a way station for transients, the latest of which may be an ice hockey team.
The relatively subdued response to the Devils' threat to leave New Jersey is fitting, given that the response to their presence for many years was the equivalent of one fan clapping. Winning has brought them a surge in popularity, particularly among younger fans, as well as a fan club with a telephone line and an E-mail address. But their lure is peaking just as the team is slouching toward Nashville.
The fate of the Devils does not rank with the wrenching sports dramas of our time -- the flight west of the Dodgers and the Giants or the midnight exit of the Baltimore Colts. There is the usual back and forth between team owners and public officials about the terms of the Devils' lease, but there are no schoolchildren collecting nickels to make up the difference, no fans raising money to buy the team, no season ticket holders chaining themselves to the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
Hockey buffs are beginning to speak up, though. "My husband and I gave up our nine-year subscription to the Metropolitan Opera four years ago so we could invest in season tickets for the Devils," Nicki Silverstein of Pompton Lakes, N.J., wrote to The Record of Hackensack.
And Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the state's premier Devils fan, did to the Devils negotiations what Bill Clinton did to health care reform: she sent in her spouse, a friend of the Devils' owner, John McMullen, to try to smooth out inequities the teams sees with its lease. So far, the First Gentleman has had no more success than the First Lady.
And a New Jersey businessman, Robert E. Brennan, recently made an unsuccessful attempt to buy the Devils and keep them at the Meadowlands.
Hockey is a lower-rung sport in terms of fan attendance, and when the Devils arrived from Denver in 1982, New York City area hockey fans had considered the Rangers part of the family for three generations. Few households have room for a stray hockey team. Those that did already had the Islanders.
"I was a Rangers fan growing up. My father was a Rangers fan. My son was a Rangers fan. And if he has a son, I'm sure he'll be a Rangers fan," said Ben Leuzzi, the owner of the Verona Sports Center in Verona, N.J. Mr. Leuzzi even knows some of the Devils players, and wishes them no ill. But when the Devils and the Rangers play, "I throw all that away. I'm a Rangers fan."
Even as the Devils attract more fans as they move closer to the Stanley Cup, the moment of romance is being threatened by their potential exit.
"The love affair's just beginning, and what you have now is the possibility of coitus interruptus," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economist at Smith College who studies the sports industry, and a former New Yorker who roots for the Rangers. "Any human with a grain of intelligence in that situation will defend themselves, will not totally involve themselves emotionally in the team."
But what do kids know about romance? "My son is up in arms if the Devils leave New Jersey," said Linda Casale, a secretary in the New Jersey Supreme Court who lives in Nutley. Her 13-year-old son is part of the suburban hockey craze, and the Devils are the closest team to his house. Her husband is a different story.
"My husband is a die-hard Rangers fan," Mrs. Casale said. "That's what he grew up with. My son is in his glory with the Rangers out and the Devils going for the Stanley Cup. I kind of enjoy my little son giving it to Dad."
Hockey is a booming street sport, thanks to Rollerblades, which makes it possible to play in a driveway or playground just like baseball and basketball. When Brick Township in Ocean County announced an in-line skate hockey league for kids 5 to 17 this year, "We expected to have six to eight teams," said Bob Auriemma, the high school ice hockey coach. "We ended up with 22."
Mr. Auriemma coached Jim Dowd, one of the Devil players, and frequently comes to the Meadowlands to watch his most famous student. He can see the Devils' following growing stronger, but, he said, "They're battling with the old loyalties with the Philadelphia Flyers and the Rangers." Which brings up New Jersey's painful, endless search for an identity.
The Meadowlands sports complex has drawn an unprecedented four professional teams, but the two most prominent, the Giants and the Jets, refuse to put New Jersey in front of their names. So the state is left with the New Jersey Devils and the New Jersey Nets, a team widely derided for its losing ways.
"They're just a bunch of overpaid cry babies," Joe Poalillo, 38, said of the Nets as he dined late last week with his buddies at the lunch truck parked outside the Berlin & Jones envelope plant in East Rutherford. "They don't represent New Jersey. They belong in Connecticut."
Janice Ballou, director of the Eagleton Poll at Rutgers University, said she was hardly surprised that the threatened Devils' departure had not caused an uproar. The attempted escape of a team with a long tradition in a particular city would be different, she said.
"The arena is not in a real town," she said. "If it was the Newark Devils and it helped the local economy and people there really rallied around the team, then it might be different. The Meadowlands is sort of a nebulous place. East Rutherford is not really a town."
Yale Glazer, a 23-year-old legal intern for a state court judge in Hackensack whose family moved from the suburbs of Baltimore to Bergen County five years ago, said he still winces at the memory of the Colts' unexpected exit from Baltimore in 1984. He said it hurt Baltimore, but he doubts that the soul of New Jersey will suffer if the Devils leave.
"I don't think New Jersey really has an identity," he said.
But what does he know? He's just another transient.

HEADLINE: Foreign Aid HAs Its Uses

BYLINE: By Brent Scowcroft; Brent Scowcroft, president of the Forum for International Policy, a foreign affairs foundation, was national security adviser under President George Bush and Gerald Ford.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Foreign assistance is again undergoing the "perils of Pauline" as it wends through the Congressional gantlet. This happens yearly, but the dangers today seem especially ominous. With the search for budget economies so desperate, using up funds for what detractors call foreign giveaways when programs to assist needy Americans are being slashed seems unconscionable to many.
Foreign assistance, with us since the Marshall Plan, has been perhaps the most unpopular legislation to come before Congress for some years. The increased peril it faces arises mainly from the loss of the justification the cold war provided. 
 The case for foreign assistance is simple, basic -- and misunderstood. The core argument is that foreign assistance is a fundamental instrument of foreign policy.
There are three main ways through which, separately or in combination, we can exert influence abroad. One is traditional diplomacy. Another is economic or military coercion. When diplomacy alone is inadequate and coercion too extreme or inappropriate, we have to turn to foreign assistance -- the use of economic incentives.
Why the difficulty in persuading Congress and the nation of its merits? One reason is that some foreign assistance programs, however meritorious, have become so encrusted with activities and outlays that have so little to do with our direct national interests that the main purpose of the programs has become obscured.
In the cold war, our aid programs could carry this burden, but now the entire economic assistance edifice is endangered. We must refocus the programs to make them directly relevant to our national interests. For example, we need to emphasize the security requirements of countries of particular concern -- Israel and Turkey, for example. We have to strengthen stability in areas of strategic interest: Gaza, Jericho, Poland and Czechoslovakia. We should see the Central American peace process through to its conclusion.
We need to suitably compensate countries that provide military installations as well as cooperation and support on issues of particular importance to us. For example, we recently offered incentives to Caribbean countries to accept Haitian and Cuban refugees.
We need to be able to respond quickly to unforeseen circumstances and unusual opportunities. For example, right after the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, we helped Panama pay off its debts to international financial institutions, thus making other economic aid possible.
When Fidel Castro leaves the scene, economic assistance to Cuba may be needed immediately to ease the transition. A contingency fund for that purpose would be useful.
Support for democracy and for sustainable economic development serve our interests, but they are not top priorities. For example, help for the Development Fund for Africa would flow from the American tradition of compassion and altruism. And while our contributions to such international financial institutions clearly benefit us in the long term, we should base such aid on our wish to promote global prosperity rather than to promote specific American interests.
Like it or not, America has inherited the mantle of world leadership. In searching for budget cuts, we must not destroy foreign aid, a crucial means of exercising that leadership.

HEADLINE: How Albany Works, Lesson 1: Lobbying;
The Beverage Industry Pushes Hard for a Tax Break, and Succeeds

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 10

 BODY:
The economic studies calling for cuts in beer and soda taxes landed in legislators' offices last year along with complimentary cases of Pepsi. In March, soda bottlers treated lawmakers to sea bass and champagne at Lutece and the Four Seasons.
The payoff arrived last week: tax cuts worth $26 million a year to the soda industry by 1997, mostly to bottlers, and $16 million a year to the beer industry, mostly to wholesalers. 
 At bottling plants, supervisors gave workers pens and paper at the beginning of their shifts and prodded them to write to their legislators. Beer and soda industry trade groups delivered hundreds of thousands of dollars in campaign contributions to state officials and spent thousands more on retainers for Albany's best-connected lobbyists.
One beverage industry official estimated that the soda industry spent about $2 million in its four-year lobbying campaign for the tax cuts, and that the beer companies probably spent less. "That's a pretty good return on investment," he said.
The story of this year's cuts in New York's beer and soda taxes, passed by the Legislature on June 2 as part of a larger package of tax cuts, provides an object lesson in the way Albany works. Like most seats of government, it is a city where money, influence and intense lobbying are often the driving forces behind legislation, even when a case might stand on its own.
The beer and soda tax cuts make for a particularly compelling study because even the most ardent supporters of lower taxes, including the Business Council of New York State and the Pataki administration, did not identify those taxes as top targets for reduction. And the leading advocate for business tax cuts, Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader and a Rensselaer County Republican, acknowledges that there is no assurance that the tax reductions will produce either large numbers of jobs or lower prices for consumers.
But the tax cuts were enacted anyway, because of a confluence of tenacious lobbying, widespread sympathy for the beer and soda industries and an ideal political climate.
In a budget fight that had largely devolved into a partisan battle between Gov. George E. Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Mr. Bruno chose to assert his political relevance by insisting on cuts in business taxes. And with relatively little money available, the leaders concluded that it would be best to seek relief in specific industries, rather than to make a broad-based tax cut that might be too small to be felt.
Soft drink bottlers and beer wholesalers say that lower taxes will create jobs. Several soda bottlers have already announced plans for expansion or canceled plans to move out of state. "I can promise you that we would have gone to Connecticut," said Tim Tenney, president of Pepsi-Cola of the Hudson Valley, who recently announced that he would add 60 jobs at his plant in Newburgh, N.Y.
But critics of the cuts call them a giveaway to industries that have made large campaign contributions to Mr. Pataki and to legislative re-election committees. "I call it Slurp, or Special Lobbyist Unexpected Reward Package," said Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, a Manhattan Democrat. "And that's also the most prominent sound heard at Republican fund-raisers as benefactors meet legislators."
Four years ago, the leaders of New York's beer and soda industries decided that they would spare no expense to fight new taxes that were eating into their profits. They began to wage a war on several fronts to defeat Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, whom they considered a longtime enemy of their interests, and to strengthen support in the Legislature.
In last year's campaign, the New York State Soft Drink Association contributed $145,000 to state candidates, a large amount even by the standards of New York political action committees. Financial disclosure records show that the donations included $38,250 to Mr. Pataki; $33,000 to the Senate Republican campaign committee, which is controlled now by Mr. Bruno, and $12,000 to the Democratic Assembly Campaign Committee, which is controlled by Mr. Silver. Another $65,000 has gone out the door this year, said James Featherstonhaugh, an Albany lobbyist hired by Pepsi.
The New York State Beer Wholesalers Association gave $127,000 last year, including $40,000 to the Senate Republicans, $30,000 to the Assembly Democrats and $7,100 to Mr. Pataki. The contributions from both trade groups do not reflect other large donations from individuals and businesses, officials associated with the groups said.
Even more was spent on lobbyists. Mr. Featherstonhaugh will be paid $60,000 this year by Pepsi, and Robert J. Malito was retained for $108,000 by Coca-Cola, according to state lobbying commission records. Michael E. Vacek, the president of the beer wholesalers group, will receive $50,000. Anheuser-Busch retained the firm of Kopley & Ryan for $110,000, and Miller Brewing hired Richard L. Smith for $65,000.
Peter G. Wilcox, the manager of government affairs for Pepsi, which is based in Somers, N.Y., took Mr. Bruno and the state Republican chairman, William D. Powers, to dinner at Lutece with other party officials and a number of bottlers. The tab, according to lobbying records, was $1,397. He took Democratic legislators to the Four Seasons, where the bill ran to $2,354.
When it looked like the tax cut might be in trouble, Mr. Wilcox sent lawmakers letters that began "Please don't throw in the towel," and enclosed Pepsi towels. To firm up support in the Democratic-controlled Assembly, Don Thomas, a black executive with Pepsi in New York City, was recruited to lobby minority legislators.
"Every moment you get, you pitch your angle," said one soda industry official, who requested anonymity. "Every chance you get to get inside their agenda, you do it."
The five tax cuts ultimately selected by the leaders are expected to save the industry about $50 million this year and about $160 million next year when fully implemented. The leaders agreed to cut the 2-cent tax on nonrefillable soda containers in half and to cut the 21-cent excise tax on beer to 16 cents. They also cut the estate tax, parimutuel taxes and the petroleum business tax on aviation fuel, diesel motor fuel and heating oil for nonprofit groups.
When Mr. Pataki originally proposed his budget in February, he did not include business tax cuts, focusing instead on reducing income taxes. But in meeting after meeting with Mr. Pataki and Mr. Silver, Mr. Bruno made it clear that he would not agree to a budget without them.
"My attitude was that a business tax cut package had to be part of the budget if we were going to close," Mr. Bruno said.
The speaker's top priority was restoring spending for the social and educational programs that Mr. Pataki had proposed to slash. But it eventually became apparent to Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, that Mr. Bruno's price for agreeing to Democratic spending restorations would be a modest package of business tax cuts.
"He needed something to show that he had some part of the budget process," Mr. Silver said. But the state's large budget gap and the expense of Mr. Pataki's three-year package of income tax cuts insured that there would be relatively little for business tax cuts.
The Business Council of New York State, an influential voice on tax issues, pushed for a reduction in the gross receipts tax, a tax on utility revenues that is passed along to consumers in the form of higher rates. The leaders decided, however, that a meaningful cut there would be unaffordable.
Instead they chose to focus on the estate tax, which all sides believed was unreasonably burdensome, and on business taxes imposed on specific industries. The obvious goal was to choose tax cuts that would spur development. Mr. Pataki, for instance, favored cutting a tax on large real-estate sales.
But Mr. Silver opposed the real-estate measure, and Mr. Bruno made it clear that he wanted money set aside to lower the beverage taxes. "He just thought they were bad taxes," said one Pataki aide.
During the 1990 legislative session, Governor Cuomo and the Legislature created the 2-cent tax on non-refillable soda containers to pay debt service on a $1.95 billion environmental bond act that would appear on the ballot later that year. They also raised the tax on beer to 21 cents per gallon from 10 cents to pay off the environmental bonds.
That November, voters rejected the bond act. But with the state treasury choked by recession, the tax increases remained. They had strong support from environmental lobbyists, who argued that the revenue should be used for the kinds of projects the bond act would have financed. Even Mr. Pataki said during last year's campaign that some of the revenue should be dedicated to an environmental fund.
But beer and soda industry officials said the tax increases forced them to close bottling plants, lay off workers and shelve plans for expansion. Stiff competition, they said, kept them from passing the increases on to their consumers. Instead, retailers illegally bought cheaper beverages from wholesalers in neighboring states and avoided paying the New York taxes.
"The industry's view was that it was going to destroy the industry in New York," said Mr. Featherstonhaugh. "And they made a decision that this tax was so bad that they had to make an unusual and extraordinary effort to get relief."
 
 
 
How to Win a Tax Cut
The state budget approved last week included tax cuts ultimately worth $26 million for soda bottlers and $16 million for beer wholesalers. A page from the playbook of the four-year multi-front lobbying campaign shows how those industries helped make it happen.
 
1.) HIRE WELL-CONNECTED LOBBYISTS. The New York State Soft Drink Association, the Coca-Cola Company and the Pepsi-Cola Company hired James Featherstonhaugh and Robert J. Malito, two of Albany's most prominent lobbyists, for retainers totaling $168,000. The beer industry also hired a high-powered team of lobbyists, and Peter J. Wilcox, the government affairs manager for Pepsi, also played a vital role.
 
2.) MAKE POLITICAL CONTRIBUTIONS. The Soft Drink Association's political action committee contributed $145,319 to legislative and gubernatorial candidates, including $38,250 to Gov. George E. Pataki and $33,000 to the Senate Republican Campaign Committee. The New York State Beer Wholesalers Association gave $127,430 last year, including $40,000 to the Senate Republicans.
 
3.) WINE AND DINE LEGISLATORS. Pepsi lobbyists treated Senate majority leader Joseph L. Bruno, state Republican chairman William D. Powers, and other party leaders to a $1,397 dinner at Lutece. Democratic legislators were taken to The Four Seasons, where the tab ran to $2,354.
 
4.) GRASSROOTS ACTION. Managers at Pepsi bottling plants around the state encouraged workers to write local legislators and gave them time on the job to do so. The result: 6,000 letters.
 
(Sources: New York Temporary State Commission on Lobbying, New York State Board of Elections.)
