HEADLINE: THE SUPREME COURT: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION;
JUSTICES, 5 TO 4, CAST DOUBTS ON U.S. PROGRAMS THAT GIVE PREFERENCES BASED ON RACE

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
In a decision likely to fuel rather than resolve the debate over affirmative action, the Supreme Court today cast doubt on the constitutionality of Federal programs that award benefits on the basis of race.
Federal programs that classify people by race, even for an ostensibly benign purpose such as expanding opportunities for members of minorities, are presumably unconstitutional, the Court said in a 5-to-4 opinion. Writing for the majority, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said such programs must be subject to the most searching judicial inquiry and can survive only if they are "narrowly tailored" to accomplish a "compelling governmental interest." 
 This formidable standard is one that the Court has applied to state affirmative action programs since 1989, when it invalidated a public works program in Richmond in which 30 percent of all contracts had to be set aside for companies owned by members of minorities. The decision today marked an important doctrinal shift for the Court, which until now had given the Federal Government significantly more leeway for its affirmative action efforts. The constitutional guarantee of equal protection should mean the same at all levels of government, Justice O'Connor said.
While the standard the Court adopted today has historically been very difficult to meet, the Court stopped short of declaring unconstitutional either the particular Federal construction program before it today or Federal affirmative action in general.
The Court's ruling was greeted with enthusiasm by some conservatives, who saw it as the beginning of the end of the era of affirmative action. Supporters of affirmative action, however, while acknowledging the decision as a setback, declined to see it as a disaster. [Article, page D25.]
Justice O'Connor's opinion included an important qualification, leaving the door open to the defense of such programs in future cases. "We wish to dispel the notion that strict scrutiny is 'strict in theory, but fatal in fact,' " Justice O'Connor said, quoting from an opinion of the late Justice Thurgood Marshall. She continued: "The unhappy persistence of both the practice and the lingering effects of racial discrimination against minorities in this country is an unfortunate reality, and government is not disqualified from acting in response to it."
Two members of the majority, Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, would have gone considerably further and ruled that affirmative action can never be justified. "Under our Constitution there can be no such thing as either a creditor or a debtor race," Justice Scalia said.
Justice Thomas said: "In my mind, government-sponsored racial discrimination based on benign prejudice is just as noxious as discrimination inspired by malicious prejudice. In each instance, it is racial discrimination, plain and simple."
In declining to adopt those categorical views, the majority opinion, which Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Anthony M. Kennedy also joined, left numerous issues to be resolved in future cases. These include the fate of the preference program at issue today, which provides a financial bonus to contractors on Federal highway programs who subcontract part of the work to businesses owned by "socially and economically disadvantaged individuals." The presumption under the law is that blacks and members of other minorities meet that definition, although the presumption may be rebutted in individual cases and white contractors may seek to qualify as "disadvantaged."
The case today was brought by a white contractor who lost a job to a Hispanic-owned company that had submitted a higher bid for a subcontract to build guardrails on a Federal highway in Colorado. Both the Federal District Court in Denver and the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, also in Denver, evaluated the program under the relaxed standard the Supreme Court had applied in earlier decisions and upheld it. The lower courts must now re-evaluate the program under the exacting standard the Court set today.
The decision today overturned the most recent of the Supreme Court's Federal affirmative action precedents, a 1990 decision called Metro Broadcasting v. F.C.C. that had upheld a Federal affirmative action program designed to increase the number of broadcast licenses awarded to members of minorities. Today's ruling also cast grave doubt on the continued validity of a 1980 decision, Fullilove v. Klutznick, that had sustained a Federal public works program that set aside 10 pecent of the value of contracts for businesses owned by blacks and other minorities.
Despite the qualifications and unanswered questions in the majority opinion, Justice O'Connor's tone was forceful. The two-tiered approach that subjected Federal affirmative action programs to more relaxed judicial review than those of the states was inconsistent with the "basic principle" that the Constitution's guarantees of equal protection "protect persons, not groups," Justice O'Connor said.
"All governmental action based on race," no matter by what level of government or for what purpose, must be subject to the most searching judicial scrutiny, she said, adding: "Whenever the government treats any person unequally because of his or her race, that person has suffered an injury that falls squarely within the language and spirit of the Constitution's guarantee of equal protection."
The decision, Adarand Constructors v. Pena, No. 93-1841, is certain to encourage legal challenges to a range of Federal affirmative action programs. At the same time, the issue is being vigorously debated in Congress and in the White House, with the Clinton Administration now in the midst of a sweeping review of Federal racial preference programs. By refusing to foreclose affirmative action as a constitutional option, the Court has done little to relieve President Clinton, as well as other elected officials now confronting the issue, of the need to make and defend their own policy choices.
Affirmative action is also the subject of vigorous debate in the states. Last month, Gov. Pete Wilson of California ordered an end to all state affirmative action programs not required by law or by a court decree. Next year, Californians will vote on a ballot initiative to end affirmative action in state hiring and higher education.
Justice O'Connor's opinion did not precisely define the essential terms, "narrowly tailored" and "compelling interest," by which courts are to judge whether a challenged affirmative action survives the required "strict scrutiny." The opinion referred only to definitions that "this Court has set out in previous cases."
The terms are familiar in the jargon-filled discourse of equal protection, however. In earlier cases, the Court has insisted on evidence rather than generalized assertions about the history of racial discrimination to be overcome. The Court has also asked whether equivalently helpful results could have been achieved through alternative programs that did not classify people by race, and has sought evidence that the program will not last indefinitely.
There were three dissenting opinions today, filed by Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter and Ruth Bader Ginsburg. Justice Stephen G. Breyer, who also dissented, joined Justices Souter's and Ginsburg's opinions.
The position of Justice Stevens was perhaps the most interesting on the Court, because he was a dissenter from the 1980 decision that upheld the Federal public works set-aside program. Justice O'Connor, who was not on the Court in 1980, quoted at length in her majority opinion today from Justice Stevens's dissent, in which he said that the racial classifications the Court upheld in the Fullilove case "can only exacerbate rather than reduce racial prejudice" and "will delay the time when race will become a truly irrelevant, or at least insignificant, factor."
It is a measure of the Court's shift to the right in the intervening 15 years, and of the 75-year-old Justice's consequent journey from the Court's center to its liberal wing, that found Justice Stevens in dissent today, calling for adherence to precedent. If the rigidly race-conscious program the Court upheld in 1980 was constitutional, he said, "it must follow as night follows the day" that the more flexible program at issue today was constitutional as well.
Justice Stevens also voted with the majority in the 1989 decision, City of Richmond v. Croson, that held that state and local affirmative action programs must be subject to strict judicial scrutiny. Today, he said there were important reasons for Federal programs to receive more deference from the Court. "Federal affirmative-action programs represent the will of our entire Nation's elected representatives," he said, "whereas a state or local program may have an impact on nonresident entities who played no part in the decision to enact it."
Justice Stevens said that the majority today had overlooked the difference between invidious discrimination and efforts to "foster equality in society" through race-based preferences. "There is no moral or constitutional equivalence between a policy that is designed to perpetuate a caste system and one that seeks to eradicate racial subordination," he said.
Justice Stevens said the Court's search for "consistency" on racial classifications "would treat a Dixiecrat Senator's decision to vote against Thurgood Marshall's confirmation in order to keep African Americans off the Supreme Court on a par with President Johnson's evaluation of his nominee's race as a positive factor."
Justice Souter, in his dissenting opinion, suggested that at the end of the day, Federal affirmative action programs might be upheld even under the majority's analysis. "Of course there will be some interpretive forks in the road before the significance of strict scrutiny for congressional remedial statutes becomes entirely clear," he said.

HEADLINE: Administration Moves to Blame Fed Rate Rises For Slowdown

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 12

 BODY:
Faced with a significant slowing of the economy as the season of Presidential politics heats up, Administration officials say the White House is gradually zeroing in on a well-known culprit: the Federal Reserve and its interest rate increases over the last 16 months.
The evolution of the Administration's stance -- which comes despite the strong objections of the Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin -- began earlier this month, officials said today. It was given voice on Sunday by the White House chief of staff, Leon Panetta, who said the Administration would welcome a move by the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates. 
 Traditionally, the quasi-independent Federal Reserve has not taken kindly to pressure from any White House to act on interest rates. And, with rare exceptions, it has not taken such pressure very seriously, either. But if the central bank does not lower rates soon, what the White House hopes to do is deflect blame should the economy slip into a recession this year or next, as a few economists now predict.
The Administration also hopes to influence Federal Reserve policy indirectly, through business leaders and others who agree with its desire for lower short-term interest rates. "Although the Administration can't influence the Fed directly," a senior Administration official said, "it can change the climate of opinion by pointing out what many economists and business leaders already know, and thereby legitimize those voices or give greater weight to those voices."
Mr. Rubin insisted in an interview today that the Administration still had a policy of refraining from comments on the central bank. But that policy is clearly fraying, as some Administration officials have begun to comment more negatively about the Federal Reserve and as the tone of internal meetings moves toward more recriminations aimed at the central bank.
The goal of the finger-pointing is only partly to persuade the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates, Administration officials said. The purpose is also to sway working-class voters by convincing them that the White House is not to blame for their problems.
Indeed, until recent evidence mounted that the slowdown earlier this year might turn into something much worse, the Administration welcomed the Federal Reserve efforts to prevent the economy from overheating as offering the best chance to extend the expansion through next year's election.
But today, said the Administration official, who insisted on anonymity, the White House is especially concerned that "any economic slowdown is going to hit with particular force the working-class swing voters in the close-in suburbs." These are the auto workers and other Democrats who abandoned the Democratic Party to vote for Ronald Reagan in 1980 and 1984 and for George Bush in 1988, but returned to the party in 1992 to elect Bill Clinton.
The shift in Administration sentiment began during interagency discussions on June 2, the day the Labor Department announced that the American economy had shed 101,000 jobs in May. The news shocked Administration officials not just as a sign of a steepening economic downturn but also as a potential political disaster, since President Clinton has presented the creation of jobs as one of the biggest successes of his Presidency.
Indeed, when the May unemployment figures were released, the Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, gave several interviews in which he pointed to interest rates as a problem. "You don't have to be a rocket scientist to see there is a relationship between interest rates and where jobs were lost," Mr. Reich said. Asked whether he was referring to short-term rates, he said he was.
The new willingness to criticize the Fed represents at least a crack in the facade of an Administration that, until now, has been remarkably unified in its approach to economic policy. Mr. Rubin, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the Wall Street investment house, has long felt that Administration efforts to influence the Federal Reserve are doomed to fail, and may even provoke the Fed to raise rates to prove its independence. Moreover, Administration comments carry the risk of alarming financial markets, where long-term interest rates may rise if investors conclude that the Administration and the Fed are at odds over monetary policy, adding to uncertainty about the outlook for inflation.
The re-election prospects of Presidents are closely linked to the economy's health. And efforts by past Presidents to blame the Fed for economic troubles have rarely convinced many voters, as President Bush found when he tried this strategy unsuccessfully in 1992.
Mr. Rubin denied in a telephone interview today that the Administration had changed tack. "We do not comment with respect to the Federal Reserve Board, and we believe strongly that any comments with respect to the Federal Reserve Board may be counterproductive," he said. "The independence of the Federal Reserve is very important to the credibility of our markets and how those markets are viewed around the world."
George Stephanopoulos, a senior adviser to President Clinton, said in an interview this evening that "we have no strategy to pressure the Fed."
But several other senior Administration officials have recently commented anyway on the Federal Reserve and the short-term interest rates that it controls. When asked on Sunday whether the Federal Reserve should cut interest rates to forestall a recession, Mr. Panetta responded, "Well, it would be nice to get whatever kind of cooperation we can get to get this economy going."
The comment was particularly noticeable because Mr. Panetta is a former member of the House of Representatives, and House Democrats have led complaints that the Clinton Administration is not doing enough to challenge the Federal Reserve's policies.
The pressure for a more confrontational role toward the Federal Reserve has come primarily from political operatives at the White House. Mr. Rubin was able to enforce a ban on Administration comments about the Federal Reserve when he was the chairman of the White House's National Economic Council.
Mr. Rubin's replacement at the council, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, is perceived by some colleagues as more willing to permit criticism of the Federal Reserve. But Ms. Tyson denied in an interview this afternoon that she was prepared to make or authorize any criticism of the Federal Reserve.
Still, starting with the release of the poor job figures earlier this month, the first signs of mild criticism have emerged. From inside the White House, the President's Council of Economic Advisers issued a statement attributing the slowdown in part to "the rise in interest rates in 1994, which affected the interest-sensitive sectors such as durable goods and housing."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Airbus Gets $1.2 Billion in Aircraft Orders

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 12

 BODY:
Airbus Industrie, operating in what its managing director called "a fiercer, cutthroat competitive environment" with the Boeing Company, announced aircraft orders at the Paris Air Show today, one day after the American company had made its own announcement.
Airbus, the European consortium, announced an order confirmation and the exercise of an option that together call for the delivery of 30 A-319's valued at $1.17 billion. Boeing announced orders of $550 million on Sunday. 
 The battle between Boeing and Airbus is growing ever more heated. Boeing, the world's largest airplane maker, already holds 60 percent of the global market to Airbus's 30 percent. But Airbus vows it will win half of the new orders placed by 2000.
Airbus said it had won orders for 20 A-319's from Lufthansa of Germany and for 10 A-319's from Air Canada. The Air Canada order was a conversion of 10 options.
The A-319, which is not yet in service, is a smaller version of Airbus's A-320, which seats 150 passengers. The A-319 carries 125 passengers.
On Sunday, Boeing announced orders for the new generation of its 737. The company is expected to announce further orders at the show. Analysts expect Boeing to supply 40 737's to the International Finance Leasing Corporation.
A Boeing official in Seattle said it was close to signing orders with Taiwan's two largest airlines, China Airlines Ltd. and EVA Airways, for up to 12 of its new 777 jets. The order would be valued at as much as $1.75 billion, the official said.
In another transaction involving Boeing, United Parcel Service Inc. said it ordered five additional Boeing 757-200 aircraft for $300 million.
Also at the show, Daimler-Benz Aerospace, a unit of Germany's Daimler-Benz A.G., said it would provide the main propulsion systems for Arianespace Inc.'s Ariane 5 satellite-launching system, an order worth $150 million. And British Aerospace P.L.C. and Saab-Scania A.B. said they were joining forces to make and market Saab's JAS 39 Gripen light combat aircraft.

Northrop Gets Orders
 LOS ANGELES, June 12 (AP) -- France has agreed to buy two Northrop Grumman E-2C Hawkeye aircraft in a deal valued at $562 million, the company said toay.
The planes will be used aboard the aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle, which is under construction.
The purchase by the French Defense Ministry will keep Hawkeye production at a steady pace through the decade, said Northrop Grumman, which is based here.
France is expected to eventually buy a total of four Hawkeyes for the aircraft carrier.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Japan's banks need shoring up if its stock market is to revive.

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
IT used to look like Japan had most of the money in the world and was doing a good job of gathering up the rest. Now its financial markets are shaking because of fears the financial fabric of the country is unraveling.
Worries about the Japanese banking system -- still heavily burdened with bad loans that were made to real estate speculators during the boom years -- have helped produce the latest plunge in Japanese stocks. Share prices are nearing, or in some cases have already fallen below, the levels reached in 1992, when it appeared that the market had reached bottom after a sharp fall. 
 Moreover, the selling is coming in part from Japanese insurance companies, which need income to support the guaranteed returns they promised to policyholders and have decided that they are unwilling to wait for capital gains on stocks. The average Japanese stock pays less than 1 percent in annual dividends. Last week brought word that the insurers sold more stocks in the first five months of this year than in all of 1994.
That the worries are coming years after the Japanese stock market bubble burst is a testament to the belief that the Japanese Government would somehow stem the pain in the Japanese banking system. Those problems, however, have festered, and the apparent lack of a Government solution has been one cause of the latest decline. The Government released a plan last week that was meant to help the banks, but it was widely dismissed as being ineffective.
The Nikkei index of 225 stocks, the best-known indicator of major Japanese companies, has fallen 7 percent in the last five trading sessions and is down 25 percent since the end of 1994. At yesterday's close of 14,813.46, it is only 3.5 percent above the low of 14,309.41 reached in 1992. If it were to break through that level, it would be trading at its lowest levels since early 1986.
The Topix second section index, the leading index of smaller Japanese companies, fell just 6 percent over the five sessions, but it is down 32 percent for the year and has fallen through its 1992 low. At yesterday's close of 1,457.44, it was at its lowest level since Dec. 28, 1983.
For American holders of Japanese stocks, of course, some of the pain has been eliminated by the soaring yen. Measured in dollars, the Nikkei is down only 11 percent since the end of last year, and it remains well above its 1992 levels.
The short-term question confronting Tokyo is whether the Government will risk public anger and bail out banks that are in deep trouble but -- thanks to their failure to write down bad loans made during the years of Japan's bubble -- have not reflected that reality on their financial statements. Some argue that the Government is trying to prepare the public for that, but investors do not seem impressed by such gradualism.
At the same time, Japanese investors are worried about the ability of the country's industry to make money with the yen as high as it is against the dollar. "There is simply no ability in the export sector to generate earnings," said Steven Nagourney, global strategist at Lehman Brothers. "What we have been going through is a realization that there is no excess earnings power in Japan," in large part because of the currency factor.
Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Capital Investments International, a New York advisory firm, argues that the stock market is also reflecting the impending decline of the country's huge trade surplus. Much of it, he says, is now coming from the export of capital equipment to allow production to be shifted to other countries with lower costs. And, he adds, there are signs that imports are finally starting to penetrate the country as protectionist walls fall in some areas.
During the boom years, the stock market benefited from the interlocking relationships among companies, banks and insurance companies, all of which tended to own stock in one another. That helped to establish and protect various corporate relationships, including the close ties between auto parts suppliers and auto companies that have lately enraged the United States.
But it also meant that the real equity -- shares held by outsiders -- was relatively low in corporate Japan. Even when prices rose to unbelievable heights, Japanese companies were relatively restrained in selling new equity issues.
In the post-1992 revival, the Government intervened to effectively block most issuance of new shares, trying to avoid raising the supply of stock when demand was limited. It also forced large investments in Japanese stocks by public pension funds. Those investments now look like losers.
Bank stocks in recent days have fallen less than the market as a whole, and the Topix bank stock index is still above the lows it reached in March. But that could change. Although the situation varies from bank to bank, it is a widely quoted rule of thumb in Tokyo that a fall of the Nikkei 225 below 14,000 would leave many banks with inadequate capital as the value of their shareholdings declined. It will be interesting to see if the Government is able to come up with more vigorous action if that happens.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Big Economic Meeting, but Not Often a Success

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
When they gather in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on Thursday, the leaders of the seven leading industrial democracies hope to lay the foundation for a "currency early warning system" intended to protect the fast-growing economies of Asia and Latin America from the kind of catastrophe Mexico suffered when its peso collapsed in December.
But in doing so, the Group of Seven may only be adding to the list of not-very-successful efforts it has made in the last 20 years of these annual economic summit meetings. 
 Those efforts range from asking the International Monetary Fund to exercise close surveillance over the newly created floating exchange rate system at the Rambouillet meeting in 1975, to the more intense economic policy coordination that the Seven -- the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Japan, Italy and Canada -- agreed to at the insistence of James A. Baker 3d, then-Treasury Secretary, during the Tokyo summit in 1986.
Despite these agreements the dollar had become so overvalued by 1985 that the United States, France, Britain, Germany and Japan agreed to knock it down under their Plaza accord, and found that by 1987 it was so weak they needed to prop it up again with the Louvre agreement.
Today the dollar is again close to lows against the German mark and the yen, while the United States remains in deep deficit on its external payments and Japan continues to pile up enormous surpluses.
"I'm pretty skeptical about procedural fixes that purport to solve problems once and for all," said Robert D. Putnam, professor of government at Harvard and the co-author with Sir Nicholas Bayne, a British diplomat, of "Hanging Together," a history of the summit meetings. "But if the Seven don't talk it's a more dangerous world."
The new financial machinery that the seven nations are expected to endorse at Halifax also represents a first attempt to make good on their pledge last year to review all international organizations, both economic and political, to insure they are properly equipped to deal with the challenges of the 21st century.
To this end, they are effectively redesigning the I.M.F. to make it better able to preserve monetary stability in today's new world of global capital markets where vast sums of money shift between currencies at the touch of a computer key.
As Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told the Institute for Strategic and International Studies in Washington last week: "Our institutions must be as modern as the marketplace. With Mexico we have seen how poor policies and markets that lack depth in very short order can destroy a nation's finances and threaten the spread of financial instability."
So under the Group of Seven's plan, the fund will monitor the performance of all important currencies more closely; speak out forcefully both in public and private when it spots a misalignment in the making and alert financial markets if any country tries to disguise the true state of its economy by withholding critical information -- as Mexico hid its reserve losses last year.
Then, to enable the I.M.F. to lend heavily to countries suffering sudden capital outflows in return for their taking steps to rebuild investor confidence, the Group of Seven wants to double the $28 billion emergency standby credit line that the I.M.F. already has with its 12 richest members, known as the General Agreement to Borrow. It would press Austria, Spain, Australia and some Asian nations to pledge funds as well.
But recent events have also shown how difficult it may be to achieve some of the goals that the seven nations have set for themselves.
In a preview of the Halifax summit meeting published by Dalhousie University in Canada, Professor Putnam and Sir Nicholas warned that the cold war's demise was making agreement harder to reach at these meetings. They cited the Group of Seven's failure to meet its 1990 deadline for concluding the Uruguay Round of free-trade negotiations.
"While the cold war continued, Western governments felt bound to unite against the Soviet Union and did not allow economic disputes to damage their solidarity," they wrote. "That constraint is now removed."
Moreover, the seven nations will arrive in Halifax deeply divided over the weak dollar, and with Washington and Tokyo squaring off for a trade war over autos.
It is also unclear how effective the I.M.F. will be at spotting and curing currency crises before they get out of hand, just as it is also unclear whether governments will take the I.M.F.'s advice when it comes.
In April, the I.M.F. managing director, Michel Camdessus, called publicly on the Federal Reserve to defend the dollar by raising American interest rates. But the Fed took no notice. The American economy's subsequent weakening raised questions about the wisdom of Mr. Camdessus's advice.
Even if the seven countries can agree among themselves at Halifax, they must still win the rest of the world's consent before their new early warning system becomes a reality.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Budget Brawlers Bloody, but Smiling

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 12

 BODY:
The ruling triumvirate of state government emerged from four months of budget talks last week pecked, scabbed and bone-tired, but all three were still smiling.
Each of them claimed a measure of victory, but nobody really wins or loses by the calculus of New York budget-making. After all, Republicans control the governorship and the Senate, while Democrats dominate the Assembly, creating an exquisite balance of power in which each side has a veto over the final product. 
 This also means that no one gets everything he wants. So, victory often depends on how well each side -- Gov. George E. Pataki, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno -- can sell their victories and diminish their defeats to various constituent groups.
Yet, above all that, the budget does establish an order, both political and substantive, that can affect each leader's power and the primacy of their agendas. Here, then, is a thumbnail analysis -- distilled from interviews with lawmakers, government staff, political analysts and others -- of how Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno fared.
One theme threaded through the interviews: a major dynamic this year was that all three men were new to leadership, as were most of their staffs. This led to blunders, misunderstandings and delays as each side tried to stake its turf and feel out the others in the first real test of the new Republican administration.
"Pataki had a good agenda," said Fran Werner, the Queens Republican leader who is a former lobbyist in Albany. "He tried very hard. But we didn't get to the bottom line. It was amateur night in Albany."
"Everybody was running amok," she added. "I'm being too frank, but I'm a little ticked off at the whole thing."
 
The Governor
 Mr. Pataki can unquestionably claim -- with the simplicity that marked his campaign -- that he delivered on his three main promises: less spending, lowered taxes and reduced welfare, as well as a major change in the criminal justice system. Even candid Democrats concede that Mr. Pataki came out of the budget melee on top -- if only because his accomplishments are more easily explained and because the public focuses on Governors more than Assembly speakers or majority leaders.
"We won," Mr. Pataki said in a statewide radio address on Friday. "Together, we made history. We moved New York in a new direction."
But the welfare cuts were watered down, the tax cuts not as broad as he wanted. Spending was only a hair lower than last year and the process was, as even he acknowledges, "horrible" -- secretive and gimmick-ridden as ever. This suggests a leader less ideologically inclined and more practical-minded than his campaign might have indicated.
"We didn't get sweeping, fundamental change but we did get change," said Michael Long, the chairman of the Conservative Party and a strong Pataki ally. "We got the beginning."
Despite the shortcomings, many said that Mr. Pataki's most concrete achievement was changing the terms of the debate: for example, that it was not whether taxes should be cut, but by how much. "The Governor redefined the discussion right out of the box," said Andrew W. Goodell, a Republican who is the Chautauqua County Executive. "And that's an incredible accomplishment."
But it did come at a cost: Though he had pledged to work with individual lawmakers, he ended up running threatening advertisements in Democrats' districts and trying to withold their pay -- moves that may insure a hostile reaction to whatever he proposes. He has also had to combat the perception that he is not a forceful leader. "He's going to have to learn the fine art of terrorizing people," one ally said.
And as polls have shown, it is still far from clear that the public likes the redirection of Mr. Pataki's budget. The final word may depend on whether local property taxes rise, the state budget remains balanced and whether Wall Street upgrades the state's low bond ratings.
 
The Speaker
 Mr. Silver became Speaker only last year, yet was the veteran of the three leaders. But from the start, he had the toughest job in Albany: to uphold the Democratic vision after voters soundly rejected it in the fall. And though he seems the most bruised, he can point to several victories.
First, he held together the 94 fractious and ideologically diverse members who comprise the Assembly's majority -- despite predictions that he could not hammer out an agreement to satisfy both liberal members from New York City and conservative upstaters, whose voters are sympathetic to Mr. Pataki's aims.
"There is no doubt there was some creative tension," said Assemblyman Michael J. Bragman, Democrat of Syracuse. But, he added, "I said from the beginning of the session that our conference would remain rock-solid behind Shelly Silver."
Second, even though Mr. Silver conceded the philosophical ground in almost every instance, he often dominated the details. There was welfare reform, but Mr. Silver weakened it considerably, killing off benefit cuts and time limits. There was a tax cut, but he managed to shift it toward people earning less than $50,000 a year. He is now banking that voters will reject the budget and has already begun to disassociate himself from it.
"The budget passed earlier this week kicks off the Republican tax-shift era," Mr. Silver said in his response to Mr. Pataki's radio address. "Mark my words: local taxes will rise because of Republican economics."
But even several Democrats believe that Mr. Silver made several tactical errors. Some say he insured several more hard years of defending social programs because he conceded to Mr. Pataki the scope of his multiyear tax cut -- meaning that each year will require more programmatic cuts. Some also said that his focus on upstate concerns, in the name of holding his conference together, may cost him support in his political base, New York City, which is almost certainly the biggest loser in this year's budget debate.
 
The Majority Leader
 The price that the Republicans in the Senate have paid for having a Republican Governor is a degree of irrelevance. The real battles now are fought between Mr. Pataki and Mr. Silver, while Mr. Bruno sits largely on the side, a loyal supporter of Mr. Pataki, his old colleague. But this has its advantages. Mr. Bruno, irrepressibly outspoken, won a pot of goodies this year and, with a few exceptions, has few wounds to show for it.
Though several Senators distrusted him after he staged the coup in November that brought him to power, he has apparently united his conference, at least to the degree that he prevented Senators from attacking Mr. Pataki on budget cuts that they did not like. Senators, who like predictability and comfort, say Mr. Bruno listens and has a good sense for making government more like business. Sessions start on time and no longer run overnight.
In the budget, he won the package of tax cuts, and they have earned him friends in the business community (more specifically, a parimutuel tax deal good for Saratoga, part of his district, north of Albany). He won a number of other important projects for his district including $5 million in reconstruction to the Albany County Airport and a new medical facility in Troy.
He was also unabashed about restoring so-called "member's items" -- the pork-barrel spending on local projects that individual lawmakers dispense in their districts.
His biggest defeats this year have been of his own making: Mr. Bruno was accused of making statements that disparaged homosexuals and welfare recipients. And his loyalty to Mr. Pataki's budget cuts -- and the layoffs they entailed -- has cost him some support among labor, an important constituency because so many state workers live in his district.
"I think unfortunately, the Joe Bruno that C.S.E.A. has known for a lot of years suddenly disappeared this year," said Danny Donohue, president of the largest state workers union, the Civil Service Employees Association. "The sad part is, we like Joe Bruno."

HEADLINE: Chip Index Is Highest in Almost 10 Years

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., June 12

 BODY:
The Semiconductor Industry Association's book-to-bill ratio for May rose to its highest level in nearly a decade, indicating demand for computer chips remained strong going into the traditionally slow summer season.
The higher-than-expected ratio of 1.22 in May, up from a revised 1.17 in April, was buoyed by a record $4.3 billion in new orders from the North American market, the association said. 
 Some analysts warned that the closely watched numbers could be inflated because computer makers are ordering more chips than they need so they can amass the inventory they will need to meet demand in the fourth quarter.
The association's ratio measures the health of the semiconductor industry in North America by comparing the number of chip orders with the number of chips shipped each month.
A ratio of 1.22 means that for every $100 in orders shipped by chip makers, manufacturers received $122 in new orders. The ratio is computed using a three-month moving average and is seasonally adjusted.
Bookings for May rose 5.7 percent to $4.30 billion, from $4.07 billion in April. May orders were 54 percent higher than the $2.8 billion reported in May 1994.
Billings for the month rose 2 percent to $3.54 billion, from $3.47 billion in April. May shipments were 38 percent higher than the $2.57 billion of May 1994.

HEADLINE: Chicago's Boss Daley Inherited High-Rises

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Legacy of Boss Daley" (editorial, June 7) asserts that former Mayor Richard J. Daley's "most troubling legacy to Chicago" was the "mammoth housing projects like the Robert Taylor Homes and Stateway Gardens," which "went up along a lengthy stretch of South State Street, as Chicago began to put together the largest contiguous ghettos in the United States." 
 When Richard J. Daley became Mayor in 1955, he inherited a housing authority that had a new love affair with elevator buildings for families with children. And the Federal Government was ready to supply the money to build them. To quote Elizabeth Wood, the authority's executive director, the "vertical neighborhoods" surrounded by green space would "compete with the suburbs for social desirability, especially for families with children."
By 1955, the authority had built a third of the city's 185 family high-rises and had on the drawing boards 38 more, including Stateway Gardens' eight elevator buildings and the first 15 high-rises in Cabrini-Green Homes. By then, construction of the infamous State Street corridor was under way. The racial segregation so evident today was already entrenched in 1955.
 
ED MARCINIAK
President, Institute of Urban Life
Chicago, June 8, 1995

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
No Progress in Special Talks With Japan

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 12

 BODY:
Trade lawyers from Japan and the United States, after explaining to each other today why they thought the other side was violating international trade rules in their bitter auto dispute, said they were going home to "ponder."
"Both sides will reflect further," said Andrew Stoler, the No. 2 official in the United States trade representative's Geneva office, as he emerged from more than seven hours of talks at World Trade Organization headquarters overlooking Lake Geneva. 
 "Mental exercise," was how one Japanese trade official described it. Then, searching for some benefit from discussions that left both sides frustrated, he added: "I think they understand our legal reasoning better. And we understand theirs better, as well."
But it was clear that neither side had come to these specially arranged talks intending to give an inch in their growing trade war, in which the United States has threatened to impose punitive tariffs worth almost $6 billion on Japanese luxury cars in retaliation for Japanese practices that Washington says hinder the sale of American cars and parts in Japan.
Today's talks amounted to little more than a midlevel discussion of the legal justifications for the two economic rivals' separate actions.
Japan contends that the Clinton Administration's threat of sanctions is a violation of World Trade Organization rules, and it is suing Washington to nullify the action.
The United States argues that Japan's import curbs are unreasonable, and justify unilateral action.
Thus, it appears that each side will test the other's skills at brinksmanship as a June 28 deadline approaches. On that date, the United States says it will impose 100 percent tariffs on 13 luxury Japanese cars, retroactive to May 20.
Japanese officials repeated today that they would not agree to talks on substantive issues until Washington removed both the threat of sanctions and its demand that Japan set numerical targets for imports of American cars and parts.
Kazuo Asakai, deputy director general of the economic affairs bureau of the Foreign Ministry, said the American threat of sanctions "was already seriously affecting exports of products to the United States."
President Clinton is to meet on Thursday with the Japanese Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, before the broader sessions of top leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Little U.S. Optimism
 WASHINGTON, June 12 (Reuters) -- The White House said today that the outlook was grim for settling the trade dispute with Japan and that it was unlikely that President Clinton and Prime Minister Murayama would patch things up when they met later this week.
"We don't expect any resolution of our trade and economic issues as a result of the meeting between the Prime Minister and the President," the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said at a news briefing.
And Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said in a radio interview today that while the United States did not want a trade war with Japan, it was "very, very important" that Tokyo open its markets to more imports.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Rise In Reaction To Comments By Greenspan

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose moderately yesterday in quiet trading ahead of economic reports due this week.
After opening on a positive note from overseas trading, the market gained on the weekend remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who was in Basel, Switzerland, for a meeting of the Bank for International Settlements on Sunday. He reiterated that the risks of a "modest recession" had increased and that inflation data would be important in the forthcoming meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. 
 The market took one of its biggest slides in nine months on Friday, as a bevy of rumors lowered expectations of an early easing by the Fed. Dealers said some investors holding longer maturities used upticks in the market, notably those occasioned by Mr. Greenspan's comments, as an opportunity to sell some of their holdings and move to shorter maturities, thus stalling the initial moves up.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston in New York, said, "It was a quiet day," with some market participants selling and moving to the sidelines, reluctant to take a position before this week's economic reports.
He predicted that the Fed would not ease short-term rates at the July 5 and 6 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. Instead, Mr. Alexy suggested, the central bank could lower rates by 50 basis points, or half a percentage point, at its Aug. 22 meeting.
Among the data due out this week that the Fed will consider in making its decision are the May consumer price index, industrial production, May retail sales and the Atlanta Federal Reserve survey of regional business activity. The big story is likely to be retail sales, which might indicate whether the slowdown in production is signaling a recession or an attempt to lessen the inventory load that built up because of last year's brisk 4.1 percent growth rate.
Joel Marver, senior fixed income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said: "Monday's action was consolidative in comparison with the huge losses suffered on Friday. But it is a common pattern in the Treasury market to see prices effectively head sideways after a large-range session."
Elsewhere, the Treasury's auction yesterday of new three- and six-month bills drew decent investor demand, according to analysts. Rates were higher with the three-month maturity up 9 basis points to 5.57 percent from the previous auction, while the six-month bills rose 21 basis points to 5.56 percent.
The 30-year benchmark issue was up 8/32 to a price of 11127/32 for a yield of 6.70 percent, down from 6.72 percent on Friday. Bill rates were down an average of 5 basis points in secondary trading.
Most of the early weakness was attributed to a CNW Report, a weekly auto survey, that showed car sales rose 5.1 percent in May on a year-over-year basis. It gave the impression that there might be a bit of a rebound under way, and that, too, could keep the prospect of an easing on hold.
In the corporate market, issuance is expected to be heavy this week, with supply concentrated in 10-year maturities as companies take advantage of the low rate environment. The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to sell $1 billion of notes on Tuesday and a $500 million offering from Time Warner is also expected. Traders believe the high- quality T.V.A. offering will go smoothly and that Time Warner's longer- maturity debt offering may not travel as smooth a road.
Prices of tax-exempt municipal bonds fell for a fourth consecutive day on expectations that many of the bonds that make up this week's $3.5 billion of new issues will offer higher yields.
The average yield to maturity for the Bond Buyer's index of 40 municipal issues, if the issuer elects to call the debt now, was up 7 basis points to 6.11 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Over Concerns About the Tokyo Stock Market

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped against the yen and most other leading currencies yesterday as concerns mounted that a slide in the Tokyo stock market would prompt Japanese investors to sell overseas assets to cover losses at home.
The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell yesterday to its lowest close in nearly three years, fueling speculation that Japanese investors would bring capital home from abroad. That could hurt the dollar if Japanese investors sell American assets and convert the dollar proceeds into yen. 
 "I think there's a lot of repatriation going on," said Varick Martin, manager of foreign exchange at Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in New York. "Money has to come home to support their own market. The tendency at the moment is for a stronger yen and weaker dollar."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 84.04 yen from 84.29 yen on Friday. The dollar slipped to 1.4033 German marks from 1.4053 marks.
But the decline in the dollar was stemmed yesterday by speculation that central banks could act to support the dollar before leaders of the seven leading industrial powers meet this week in Halifax, Nova Scotia, traders said.
The Group of Seven meeting begins Thursday. At their last meeting in April, leaders of the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Japan pledged to support the dollar.
On May 31, the Federal Reserve and many other central banks began a surprise bout of concerted dollar-buying that bolstered the currency.
"People feel the G-7 will solidify what they did in April, which could mean more concerted intervention if they deem it necessary," said Jim Raphael, a currency trader at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City. "People are nervous to be short of dollars."
Currency dealers are also uncertain about the direction of interest rates in the United States. Many dealers had expected the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates, but comments by the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, on Wednesday indicated that the central bank would stay put on rates. Lower rates tend to hurt the dollar by making deposits denominated in it less attractive.
Still, traders said they would watch a number of United States economic reports due out this week for clues to the dollar's direction.
"There's enough news on the horizon this week that the market is anesthetized, unsure which direction to take the dollar in case a headline flashes," said Steve Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole in New York.

Misadventures in Hot Dog Trade

BYLINE: SUSAN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
The hot dog cart, parked outside state offices, did a booming business. The reason, the authorities say, is that it was at the heart of a scheme that illegally distributed $40 million in unemployment benefits over 25 years. Several people have already pleaded guilty in the case, including four former workers in the State Department of Labor who were sentenced yesterday to prison terms of 8 to 21 months.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. ATTEMPTS TO BLOCK ENGELHARD ACQUISITION

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The Engelhard Corporation, of Iselin, N.J., should not be allowed to acquire its largest competitor in the gel clay business, the Floridin Company of West Virginia, the Justice Department said yesterday in a lawsuit filed in Macon, Ga., to block the merger. "Engelhard and Floridin are each other's most significant competitor today," said Anne K. Bingaman, the Assistant Attorney General who oversees the antitrust division. "The consolidation will lead to higher prices for gel clay, affecting a wide range of products in important segments of the U.S. economy." The acquisition would give Engelhard, the largest company in the industry, about 83 percent of the gel clay business, according to the complaint brought by the antitrust division.

SECTION: Section B; Page 11; Column 2; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: 1995 U.S. OPEN;
At the Open, Canvas Comes With a Cash Lining

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

DATELINE: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 12

 BODY:
They are green and white settlements upon a dogleg -- tented Levittowns for a week. They are the corporate hospitality tents of the United States Open Championship, spacious, chandeliered, air-conditioned, catered, Astroturfed encampments upon the course of the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club.
There are three encampments here, each with a name like a Florida retirement community, each surrounded by picket fences and identified with shingles outside. All that's missing are mailboxes with decoy ducks atop them. 
 A 40-foot-by-60-foot tent in Centennial Village with views of the eighth and ninth holes costs $125,000 (lesser vistas don't cost less). A 40-by-40 tent in Shinnecock Village overlooking the first fairway before it doglegs right goes for $110,000. For the economy-minded, one of 40 tables in the 60-by-125 Champions' Pavilion, which provides a commanding view of the practice driving range, can be yours for $25,000.
Outside each village stands a topiary sculpture of a golfer ready to whack a ball, as if Edward Scissorhands had suddenly become enamored of Big Bertha. During a storm Sunday night, the bushy golfer outside Shinnecock Village fell flat on his face. He was upright yesterday. "He looks like a gorilla," joked Mimi Griffin, the Open's marketing director.
A veranda is outside each tent, with deck chairs and tables, with protective umbrellas and a potted plant. United States Open wine, from a local winery, is served, as is food from an outside caterer, which pays the United States Golf Association a fee.
The tents combine to make a lovely profit center for the U.S.G.A., which runs the Open; they are as expensive as a seasonlong luxury suite at many arenas and stadiums. The 21 buyers of Centennial and Shinnecock tents and the 40 denizens of the Champions' Pavilion pay a total of $3.46 million to eat, watch TV and entertain clients and themselves at a remove from Norman, Faldo, Azinger, Price and the gnats who call the course home.
"Maybe it costs the U.S.G.A. $15,000 to set up a tent," said Frank Hannigan, the former executive director of the U.S.G.A. "It's enormously profitable.
"I never minded ripping off AT&T," he added, referring to one of the companies that purchased a tent.
The tents are a small, but significant part of the U.S.G.A.'s revenues. In 1994, the organization had revenues of $48.7 million. About half was derived from its championships and television rights. Net surplus was $1.8 million. This year, NBC's rights fee for its first United States Open is about $14 million, up from the $11 million that ABC paid through last year.
The U.S.G.A. does not let outsiders lacking the proper passes enter its villages. It's like trying to crash the exclusive Bohemian Club unless you're Ronald Reagan, George Shultz or Michael Eisner.
"So this is just for v.i.p.'s right, not us?" asked one woman, relegated to a gallery pass yesterday.
"Corporate hospitality, that's right," said one volunteer.
"What are the tents like on the inside?" a reporter asked the volunteer.
"I wouldn't know," she said. "I'm not allowed in."
The U.S.G.A. does not make the names of its tent-buyers public. There are no programs listing which company is situated where. If someone comes to Shinnecock Village asking for a corporation located across the way at Centennial, a volunteer will not volunteer if the company is actually there.
Why the secrecy?
"Companies ask us not to release their names," Griffin said. "If we did, they'd get hundreds of requests from people asking for tickets. And in the age of downsizing, they don't want to broadcast how much money they're spending."
But by yesterday, the companies' names were plainly apparent. Among the $125,000 tent-buyers were AT&T, Metropolitan Life, Unisys, Nynex, Arthur Andersen, Chemical Bank, and Chase Manhattan.
Among those springing for $110,000 tents were Lehman Brothers, Sports Illustrated, NatWest Bank, I.B.M. (if you can pay $3.5 billion to acquire Lotus Development, you can get a tent), American Express and American Airlines. Several corporations are sharing tents, including The New York Times, Newsday, American Airlines and Hertz.
Shinnecock is not as propitiously located for the sale of tents, which are actually steel-reinforced structures upon which heavy tenting is draped. The club is 90 miles east of New York City, with limited hotel rooms nearby, and that has meant a scaled-back tent setup, said Griffin. The 1993 Open, held at Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J., had 46 tents selling at $125,000.
Next year's Open, to be held at Oakland Hills Country Club, in Birmingham, Mich., will feature 26 to 30 tents, and all are sold out. Tent sales there were bad at 1991's Senior Open, a reflection of huge losses in the automobile industry. Now, the tents are a leading indicator of the Big Three's health.
Griffin said Shinnecock had room for five more tents if New York's brokerage business were performing better financially.
Still, the tents are a permanent part of the U.S.G.A.'s business plan. At the 1986 Open, the Shinnecock course had only eight tents, Hannigan said. Now, tent sales have grown several times, and the U.S.G.A. has complete control over the golf course that hosts the Open; the U.S.G.A. runs everything on the course during the Open, and pays the club a rental fee.
"In '86, we paid Shinnecock $40,000 or $50,000," Hannigan said. "I'd be surprised if it wasn't double that now."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 16, 1995, Friday

 CORRECTION:
A sports article on Tuesday about corporate villages at the United States Open misstated the fee paid by the United States Golf Association to the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in 1986. It was $450,000 to $500,000 -- not $45,000 to $50,000.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Weak Retail Sales Revive Hope of Rate Cut
 Retail sales rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in May and consumer prices climbed three-tenths, meaning that, excluding inflation, retail sales actually eased slightly, a sign that the economy could stall. That renewed optimism that the Fed would cut interest rates. 
 Analysts said consumers were clearly retrenching. In the key automotive sector, sales rose five-tenths of 1 percent, did not rebound from April's 1.4 percent decline as well as expected. [Page D2.]
 The reports lifted the price of the 30-year Treasury bonds by 27/32 points, to 1144/32 . The yield fell to 6.54 percent, from 6.70 percent on Monday, the largest decline since July 29, 1994. [D20.]
 Stocks also rose, with the Dow industrials climbing 38.05, to 4,484.51, and the S.& P. 500 index rising 5.17 points to a record 536.05. [D10.]
 
First Data to Buy Rival
 First Data agreed to a $6.6 billion takeover of its archrival, First Financial Management. The companies, two of the country's largest independent processors of credit card transactions, expect combined revenue of $4 billion this year. [D2.]
 
Orange County Sells Bonds
 In its first debt offering since filing for bankruptcy, Orange County sold $295 million in insured "recovery" bonds, but had to pay a hefty 25 basis points above similar California debt offerings. Market Place. [D10.]
 
Morrison Knudsen Cites Loan Need
 Morrison Knudsen's bankers agreed to extend its loans, but the company said it needed sizable new loans to avoid bankruptcy. [D4.]
 
Sun to Cut 800 Jobs
 The Sun Company will slice 800 jobs and cut its dividend in an effort to lower operating expenses by $110 million a year. [D8.]
 
Nominee Chosen For Treasury Post
 President Clinton said he would nominate Lawrence H. Summers (pictured), the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs who oversaw the bailout of Mexico, to replace Deputy Treasury Secretary Frank N. Newman, who is resigning. [D10.]
 
Republicans to Limit Bank Bill
 House Republican leaders tentatively agreed to limit further expansion by federally chartered banks into selling insurance, thereby addressing insurance agents' objections to repealing the legal separation of the banking and securities industries. [D8.]
 
Bid Deadline Seen for Multimedia
 Bidders for Multimedia, including groups led by NBC and Ellis Communications, have reportedly been given a June 21 deadline to submit offers. Multimedia is expected to bring about $1.5 billion in a sale. [D9.]
 
Growth in Ad Spending
 The leading forecaster of advertising spending has revised his projections upward for this year, to $161.9 billion, up 7.9 percent from 1994. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D9.]
 
Steakhouses Are Expanding
 The Big Three of upscale steak houses, the Palm, Morton's of Chicago and Ruth's Chris Steak Houses, are expanding. Morton's opened in Costa Mesa, Calif. The Palm opened in Atlanta, and has plans for Boston and Denver, and Ruth's is coming to Garden City, L.I. Travel. [D5.]
 
MCA in Dreamworks Deal
 MCA has agreed that its Universal Pictures unit will distribute Dreamworks' films outside the United States, Canada and Korea. [D9.]

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1596 words

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;
PRESIDENT OFFERS PLAN TO BALANCE FEDERAL BUDGET

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
After weeks of debate about how to confront the Republican-controlled Congress, President Clinton tonight sketched his own plan for balancing the Federal budget -- but over 10 years not 7. He would do so by slowing the growth of Medicare spending far less than the Republicans want and making up the difference with reductions in corporate subsidies and other domestic spending.
In a brief televised address from the Oval Office, Mr. Clinton committed himself to balancing the budget by 2005 -- three years after the Republicans propose to -- with spending cuts of $1.1 trillion. Those would be stretched out to be less severe than Republican alternatives, and accompanied by the President's previously proposed tax breaks, much smaller than the Republicans have proposed and narrowly focused on the middle class. 
 "It took decades to run up this deficit," Mr. Clinton said. "It's going to take a decade to wipe it out. Now, mind you, we could do it in seven years, as Congressional leaders propose. But the pain we'd inflict on our elderly, our students, and our economy just isn't worth it."
"It won't be easy," Mr. Clinton said. "But elected leaders of both parties agree with me that we must do this, and we will."
In making his counterproposals, Mr. Clinton bucked the advice of almost all his top White House advisers, and infuriated Congressional Democrats, who argued that his criticisms of the Republicans' proposed cuts as a sop to the rich were just beginning to take hold. The House Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said the President had turned Medicare into a political football, adding: "The real losers will be the elderly and the families that support them."
Republicans praised the President for joining their camp, but said he was still too timid. The Senate Majority Leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, who gave the official Republican response, said Mr. Clinton offered "recycled reasons why big government cannot become smaller, why programs cannot be cut and why agencies cannot be eliminated."
Mr. Clinton proposes to save $124 billion in Medicare costs over the next seven years, about half what the Republicans want. He would do so -- as he did in his failed health proposal last year -- in the name of expanding coverage and overhauling insurance laws. He would also save $25 billion by abolishing some unspecified tax subsidies for corporations, and would cut scores of discretionary domestic programs.
For the first time tonight, as he sought to regain ground lost to the Republicans in Congress, Mr. Clinton unequivocally embraced the goal of balancing the budget by a fixed date, a question he has always finessed and explicitly abandoned just four months ago when he presented a budget that produced rising deficits into the future. Aides said he was trying to shift the debate from whether the budget could be balanced to how it should be. As a result, they said, he hoped to avoid a string of vetoes of spending bills later this summer, while persuading the public that he would stick up for his priorities.
Mr. Clinton sketched five broad principles tonight: Protect education; control health care costs but preserve services for the elderly; cut taxes for the middle class, not the wealthy; cut welfare but protect children; and "don't put the brakes on so fast that we risk our economic prosperity."
He added: "This can be a turning point for us. For 12 years our Government -- Congress and the White House -- ducked the deficit and pretended we could get something for nothing. In my first two years as President, we turned this around and cut the deficit by one third. Now let's eliminate it. It's time to clean up this mess."
The President issued that call only after weeks of intense internal debate in the White House, and just four months after offering a budget that left the hard choices to the Republicans and then trying to blame them for the inevitable cuts in popular programs. He spoke after a final, frantic day of preparations, in which he rewrote his own words up to the last minute, while senior budget aides and political advisers scrambled to outline complex proposals -- including a revived and scaled-back overhaul of the health care system -- in the opaque language of press releases.
The White House Chief of Staff, Leon E. Panetta, described Mr. Clinton's olive branch as "an act of optimism, an act of cooperation and leadership," an alternative to the orthodoxies of either party.
But many senior Democrats were unsparing in their criticism.
"I think most of us learned some time ago that if you don't like the President's position on a particular issue, you simply need to wait a few weeks," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking member of the House Appropriations Committee. "If you can follow this White House on the budget, you are a whole lot smarter than I am."
But in recent weeks, aides said, Mr. Clinton has become increasingly convinced that he will not be seen as leading if he defines his Presidency simply by saying no to the Republican advance, and that he is determined to be on what he calls "the solution side" of the daunting problems of the day, from welfare, to education to health care.
His proposal tonight, sketchy and broad as it was, was littered with small gestures of good faith. He proposed to trim $25 billion in corporate tax subsidies because that is the amount proposed by Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee.
Mr. Clinton would continue his promised expansion of the earned income tax credit that gives tax breaks to the working poor, in the face of Republican proposals to curtail it by about $21 billion. But the White House said he would save $3 billion by cracking down on fraud by illegal aliens who are not authorized to work in this country.
The President squarely acknowledged the need to slow the growth in spending on Medicare and Medicaid that is driving up the Federal deficit, but held to his longstanding pledge to do so only as part of broader efforts to expand health coverage. And he held to his proposal for a new $500-per-child tax credit for middle class families and new tax deductions for education -- first announced last December -- in the face of far bolder, broader Republican plans.
Before the President spoke, Mr. Panetta said Mr. Clinton had no intention of agreeing to the size of the spending and tax cuts the Republicans want.
"The President is basically saying let's recognize this. Let's work together and resolve it now."
Mr. Panetta, and almost all other senior White House advisers, were reluctant converts to the President's latest gambit, arguing that the White House should wait until later in the summer to duel it out with the Republicans on specifics. But Mr. Clinton, encouraged by his Connecticut-based pollster and informal adviser, Dick Morris, a confidant from his days as Governor of Arkansas, persisted in pressing for a "counterbudget" now.
For weeks, budget advisers had drafted detailed options, and Mr. Clinton reviewed them over the last 10 days. Aides said the President's resolve to speak out was only strengthened by the positive public reviews of his cordial encounter with Speaker Newt Gingrich in New Hampshire on Sunday, and that he made the final decision to seek television time for a speech this morning, dispatching Vice President Al Gore to lobby the networks. The rest of the day was one long repeat of a ritual that has become fixed in this Administration: fevered rewriting almost to the moment of delivery.
The exercise left some of the President's top advisers -- who just weeks ago had gone to great lengths to stress the dangers of trying to balance the budget too quickly -- scrambling to explain Mr. Clinton's new proposal. Their basic argument was that by stretching the balancing act over 10 years instead of 7, and persisting with tax cuts only about a third the size of the Republicans' proposals, Mr. Clinton would lessen the pain while preserving his own top spending priorities.
Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the President's chief economic policy adviser, said that in balancing the budget, "even the most carefully designed path will always carry some contractionary risk," to the overall economy. But she added, "One way to reduce the risk is to extend the period for achieving balance" and emphasized, "We got a date, or a path, out of our policy analysis; we did not allow an arbitrary date to drive our policy."
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, acknowledged that there had been "a significant debate and a significant choice for the President on whether to intervene in this process now." But he said the concern was if the President failed to speak out now, Republican appropriators would produce "bills that he would of necessity have to veto over and over again," or would make good on Republican threats to enmesh measures Mr. Clinton opposes in vital legislation to assure the orderly functioning of Government -- like that to increase the statutory ceiling on the Federal debt.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, was considerably more sanguine.
"Oh, I don't think there's any urgency at all," he said. "The President has been involved in a lengthy process of focusing on the tradeoffs with respect to all the factors that will determine what kind of an economy we're going to have in the years ahead -- jobs increases, increasing standards of living. And this is the fruit of an enormous amount of work about what we need to do for our economy."

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up 0.3%; Retail Sales Barely Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
The Commerce Department reported today that consumers raised their spending by just two-tenths of 1 percent in May, to a level of retail sales that remained below that of March, a sign that the economy could be about to stall.
In a separate report, the Labor Department calculated that consumer prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent for the month, meaning that retail sales, which account for about one-third of economic activity, actually eased slightly after allowing for inflation. 
 "Consumers remain in hibernation," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch, citing the two reports as "further evidence of a slow-growth, low-inflation environment."
The bond and stock markets greeted the latest figures with enthusiasm in the apparent belief that the economy is weak enough to prompt an interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve but not so weak as to seriously undermine corporate profits.
Edward F. McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, called last month's retail sales "pretty disappointing" and said the odds had improved to virtually 50-50 that the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates at the next scheduled meeting of its top policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, on July 5 and July 6.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, raised the possibility last Wednesday at a bankers' convention in Seattle that the economy would slip into a brief recession, while at the same time asserting that the chances of a long or severe recession had diminished.
Those remarks were widely interpreted as a sign of the Fed's hesitance to cut rates on the grounds that it could stimulate the economy just as it emerged from a transitory downturn.
But over the weekend Mr. Greenspan expressed a bit more concern about the economy's rapid deceleration, warning more emphatically of near-term risks while asserting again bright longer-term prospects. Many analysts interpreted these comments, made at a gathering of international bankers in Switzerland, as an indication that Mr. Greenspan's reluctance to cut rates was weakening.
Today's results added to the pressure for a cut, analysts said. Some noted that the overnight interest rate controlled by the central bank is, at 6 percent, exceptionally high when adjusted for current inflation.
Though the retail sales report was a rough estimate based on a small number of respondents, analysts said it had become clear that consumers were retrenching. Unlike last month, when there was a large upward sales revision for March, revisions today to earlier months were negligible.
The automotive sector did not rebound from April's decline as well as expected, rising five-tenths of 1 percent following a 1.4 percent April drop that initially had been put at 2 percent. Excluding automotive sales, consumers spent just one-tenth of 1 percent more in May than in April and the same amount in April as in March.
Among nondurables, items not expected to last at least three years, clothing stores posted a 1.5 percent gain while department stores and others selling general merchandise raised sales three-tenths of 1 percent in May. But the other categories suffered declines.
Total sales were $192.90 billion, after adjustment for seasonal, holiday and trading-day differences but not for price changes, compared with $192.49 billion for April.
As for the inflation report, the results were somewhat more benign than expected because the "core" Consumer Price Index -- excluding the erratic food and energy components -- rose just two-tenths of 1 percent, half the April increase and the smallest rise so far this year.
"No components of the C.P.I. are currently showing any significant inflationary pressures," said Dean Baker, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, a research group. "If anything, with the economy clearly weakening, the pressures on prices seems to be downward."
The index for food, which jumped sharply in April, edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent last month as the fruit and vegetable component contributed heavily to the moderation.
Apparel fell for the second straight month and transportation rose by less than in April as a 2.1 percent surge in the price of gasoline was partly offset by declines of 1.3 percent for automobile finance charges and seven-tenths of 1 percent for used cars.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk
