HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Starting Point for Talks

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
What President Clinton said tonight about the budget is not nearly so important as the fact that he said something at all.
The proposals he made for lowering spending, reducing taxes and balancing the budget over 10 years will not be approved by this Republican Congress. But they will be the starting point for the negotiations between the White House and Congress later this year that will ultimately determine how far the Republicans will get in their drive to revamp the Federal Government. 
 The President's coming forward now could be disadvantageous to him in two respects. It means that he is opening his budget negotiations with Congress by conceding that cuts can be made in popular Democratic programs like Medicare, rather than taking a hard line at the outset and working toward a compromise. And it leaves Mr. Clinton exposed in some politically sensitive areas going into the 1996 Presidential election campaign.
But Bill Clinton is a President who is deeply interested in government policy, particularly economic policy. His staff assistants and many of his friends in Congress said they could not imagine him getting involved in a policy fight with the Republican Congress without having laid down a marker of his own.
Until now, the President had given the Republicans center stage on the budget and tried to gain political advantage by taking occasional pot shots at them for protecting the privileged at the expense of the needy.
Mr. Clinton's proposals tonight for limiting spending on Medicare and Medicaid, for giving a tax cut to the middle class and for restraining the earned-income tax credit for the working poor are much more modest than those proposed by the Republicans. But he has severely limited the extent to which he can attack the Republicans' principles on these matters.
This was especially galling to some Democrats in Congress who believed that they had been scoring politically by opposing Republican proposals to limit spending on Medicare for the elderly, and education and nutrition programs for children. When the news that the President would present his own balanced-budget plan was announced at a lunch meeting of Democratic senators today, the response, according to someone who was there, was a collective groan.
A Democratic Congressman who spoke on condition that he not be identified said that the minority leaders in Congress, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, went to the White House last week to try to talk the President out of doing what he did tonight, but their appeal fell flat.
Representative Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat from California, said Mr. Clinton was "playing right into the hands of the Republicans."
Even so, some Democrats conceded that he had to take a stand or risk irrelevancy. "You can't beat something with nothing," said Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey.
Republicans had been baiting Mr. Clinton for weeks with the charge that he was failing to lead. Tonight they seemed delighted with the political cover that his proposals provided them, but they continued to take jabs at him. "It's just a nondocument by a nonplayer," said Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming.
The dilemma Mr. Clinton faces, and one the Congressional Republicans are just beginning to realize, is this: For all the talk about cutting waste and fraud, the fact is that the only way to reduce the Federal budget is to cut spending for popular programs, raise taxes or both.
Polls show that the public favors a balanced budget, but only in the abstract. Cutting the budget with specific spending and tax measures has never been politically popular. Witness what happened to President George Bush after he signed a tax increase in 1990, and to the Democrats in Congress after they voted for the Clinton deficit-reduction plan in 1993.
Since the outset of his Presidency, Mr. Clinton has held that the economic security of the nation demands a reduction in the Federal deficit. Oddly, he has received almost no political credit for the strength of the nation's economy after the enactment of his 1993 deficit-reduction plan, which received no Republican votes.
The debate so far this year has been between two factions of the Republican Party. The House and the Senate have both approved budget resolutions that are supposed to balance the budget by the year 2002, and the plans are now before a conference committee to resolve the differences.
The House measure would allow $350 billion in tax cuts starting next year. The tax cuts in the Senate plan would mostly not appear until after the turn of the century, if at all. These resolutions are guidelines for Congress, and the President has no say about them.
But no one doubts that the House and Senate will strike a compromise, probably within the next week or two. Then will come the heavy duty -- the adoption of legislation that puts the tax and spending programs into effect.
This is when Mr. Clinton will move into a pivotal position. Each of the tax and spending measures will be subject to his veto. Since the Republicans probably do not have enough votes to override his vetoes, they will have to negotiate with him.
So the President's eventual entry into the fray was inevitable. The question tonight was, why now?
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, offered an explanation, but it was not particularly convincing.
First, he said, Mr. Clinton hoped to influence the Congressional conference now under way on the budget resolutions. Second, he was afraid that if he and Congress could not reach an agreement by Oct. 1, the beginning of the next fiscal year, the Government would be forced to shut down. And third, Mr. Clinton wanted to show the leaders of the leading allied countries at their meeting in Nova Scotia this weekend that the United States was operating with fiscal responsibility.
The truth is, the President's people are frozen out of the conference on the budget resolution, just as Mr. Bush's advisers were when the Democrats controlled Congress. And Congressional leaders will not be prepared for months to begin negotiations leading up to the October deadline. As for the leaders of the other industrial nations, most of their budget deficits now are more serious than the one in the United States.
What complicates Mr. Clinton's position on the budget is that it has changed so often.
In the early Democratic primaries in 1992, Mr. Clinton sugarcoated his own proposals and denounced the bitter fiscal medicine offered by his main opponent, former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts. Then, in the general election campaign, Mr. Clinton vigorously advocated a tax cut for the middle class.
But in the first two years of his Presidency he abandoned the tax cut and made deficit reduction his highest priority. Then, after the Democratic defeat in the 1994 Congressional elections, Mr. Clinton quickly offered a new, specific tax reduction but put forth a budget with deficits of around $200 billion a year stretching into the next century.
Now, he is talking once more about deficit reduction.
"I think most of us learned some time ago," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the Appropriations Committee, "that if you don't like the President's position on a particular issue, you simply need to wait a few weeks."

HEADLINE: Jobless Legions Rattle Europe's Welfare States

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 13

 BODY:
Though the headlines would suggest that European leaders are obsessed with the quagmire in Bosnia, the most intractable problem facing most of the 15 countries of the European Union is jobs.
With unemployment rates above 12 percent in France and Italy, 23 percent in Spain and about 9 percent in Germany for May, joblessness is at the highest levels since recovery from World War II, and politicians all over the Continent are under pressure to get it down. 
 France's new President, Jacques Chirac, won election last month with a promise of "fundamental change" after the 14-year presidency of Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist. Italy's populist Prime Minister, Silvio Berlusconi, pledged before he was forced out of office in December to put the country back to work by sweeping away layers of bureaucracy and corruption by organized crime. The popularity of Spain's Socialist Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, is at the lowest point of his 12 years in power.
The prospect of chronic joblessness at politically dangerous levels is bringing Europe's leaders face to face with some deeply entrenched assumptions about salaries, benefits and tax policy.
Most European leaders agree that one important reason their economies are unable to create jobs -- indeed, have eliminated hundreds of thousands of them -- is the staggeringly high cost of providing tens of millions of Europeans with higher hourly wages, longer vacations and more comprehensive health and welfare benefits than most Americans have.
But voters do not want to lose these benefits, so European leaders are only slowly beginning to chip away at the edges of the welfare state, and trying to leave the foundations intact.
Germany, Europe's biggest economy, has had three consecutive years of union wage settlements below the rate of inflation, leaving millions of German workers in the unheard-of predicament of having less money in their paychecks than they had the year before.
Now, in France, Mr. Chirac is trying to shift some of the burdens of paying for health and social security benefits away from company payrolls and onto the general tax rolls.
Some people are skeptical that his plan will work. "There are so many rigidities in our economy," said Edmond Berbon, a retired businessman in Rheims who says government regulations and long-ingrained public attitudes make it difficult for local enterprises to create jobs.
"It is an aberration nowadays to pay people a 13th or even a 14th-month salary every year, but we do, and they want to hang onto these things," he said. "What we need is to change the way the French think, but that will take a generation."
Mr. Chirac plans legislation to cut back the Government-imposed payroll taxes, which now amount to an additional 55 to 65 percent of each employee's gross salary and are paid by the employer. These charges push the cost to employers of workers getting even the $7-an-hour minimum wage to about $1,800 a month, so many companies now think twice before taking on new workers. Employees have additional deductions, but pay less into the system than the companies they work for.
Mr. Chirac's plan would altogether eliminate charges companies have to pay on salaries of unskilled low-wage workers, and it would provide a $400-a-month subsidy for each young trainee or long-term unemployed person hired by small and medium-sized companies.
The total cost of the program, which employers' groups say could create 300,000 jobs in three years, is estimated at $15 billion a year, money the Government will probably have to raise general taxes to come up with. That would run the risk of thwarting economic growth instead of stimulating it. The Government has also announced plans to raise the minimum wage by about 4 percent this summer.
Most European countries are unwilling to follow the lead of the United States, which has created millions of jobs by allowing companies the freedom to hire part-time employees without traditional full benefits.
So France's plans to bring down its 12.2 percent unemployment rate -- more than double that in the United States, and higher than in Japan, Germany, Canada, Britain or Italy -- will be closely scrutinized when leaders of the seven countries meet in Halifax, Nova Scotia, this week.
European Union leaders will meet again in Cannes, France, on June 26 and 27 to discuss a European-wide government-financed construction project to stimulate job creation, a plan to create a link of high-speed rail lines across Europe in the next century. But nothing like the big government-sponsored work programs that Franklin D. Roosevelt created to reduce unemployment in the United States in the 1930's seems to be on the horizon.
In all, 3.3 million French workers are registered as unemployed, with as many as 2.2 million more driven off the labor rolls as big companies reduced payrolls in the quest for higher productivity and efficiency.
Mr. Chirac has asked government officials at all levels, as well as companies, to come up with fresh ideas for creating new jobs.
Rhone-Poulenc, the pharmaceutical and chemical giant based in Lyons, has cut back its employees based in France from 40,000 to 35,000 in recent years.
But Xavier Patrouillard, an official of the company, says it and other big companies in southeastern France have created a program to hire out experts in various fields to help smaller companies find niches in communities where the big ones have been closing plants.
"We decided that we couldn't prosper in a social desert," said Mr. Patrouillard, who oversees Rhone-Poulenc's contributions. "We can't just stay inside our factory walls nowadays. We have an obligation to help every company that can employ people to keep on doing so."
Mr. Patrouillard estimated that the initiative had created as many as 10,000 jobs in the region around Lyons over 17 years.
But a single French company, the automaker Renault, has eliminated 70,000 jobs around the country in the last 10 years. And, Mr. Patrouillard said, smaller European companies are now under just as much pressure as big ones are to keep costs down to stay competitive against East Asian and Eastern European economies where wages are a fraction of what they are here.
"For years, we thought there was nothing you could do about rising unemployment," said Jean-Herve Lorenzi, an economist in Paris who advised French Socialist Governments of the late 1980's and early 1990's.
Now, he says, part of the answer is to encourage the creation of part-time jobs, something most European governments and labor unions have taken a dim view of up to now.
"It's better to have work that isn't paid well, or is only temporary, than to have no work at all," Mr. Lorenzi said.
At their last gathering, in the German industrial town of Essen six months ago, European leaders agreed that welfare benefits should be scaled down if they were so high that they discouraged recipients from looking for new jobs.
In France, unemployment benefits start at 57 percent of a person's last gross paycheck, and are reduced automatically by 15 percent every four months. Eventually, they cease altogether and welfare kicks in, but many jobless people are reluctant to claim it.
Bruno Pinto, a 37-year-old French father of three in Rheims, last worked in 1991. "If my wife didn't work, I'd be out on the street now," he said. "You get so discouraged and demoralized that you lose your ability to work together with other people, to prepare and make reports, even to get up in the morning. Eventually, you become unemployable."
And even in Europe, some fall through gaps in the social safety net and drift into demoralization and homelessness.
"Many of these people need more than just job training -- they need to be taught the personal and interactive skills they never had or have forgotten because they've been cut off from others for so long," said Claude Potier, director of an association in the Lyons suburb of Vaulx-en-Velin that trains homeless people for jobs in the restaurant trade.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bruno Pinto, center, at a job training office in Rheims, France. Unemployed since 1991, he said, "You get so discouraged and demoralized that you lose your ability to work together with other people." (Lisa Sarfati/Contact Press, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Energy Department Research Is Defended by Outside Panel

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
With Congressional committees considering deep cuts in the Energy Department's research budget and some lawmakers suggesting that the whole agency be dismantled, the department today issued a report by outside experts who strongly defended its research programs.
The report's authors called the proposed budget cuts short-sighted, and said that a continuing program of broad energy research financed largely by the Federal Government was "essential to our nation's future well-being." 
 At the same time, the panel acknowledged that efforts to reduce the Federal budget deficit would probably force reductions in the program, and it called for the agency to explore new ways to draw money from the private sector, perhaps by collecting royalties from companies that use new technologies developed through its research.
The report recommended that the agency try to reduce its program of civilian energy research by a relatively modest 15 percent without cutting the flow of money to scientists and engineers, a feat it suggested could be accomplished by managing the programs more efficiently and spending less money at the department's headquarters.
The energy experts, drawn from industry and academia, warned that cuts like those being considered in Congress would devastate a research program that already has shrunk to barely a quarter of its size in the 1970's, when skyrocketing world energy prices and oil shortages gave birth to the department and its extensive research programs.
At stake is $2.5 billion in research into projects including ones involving building insulation, manufacturing technology and transportation, as well as solar, wind, nuclear, coal, oil, gas and hydroelectric energy. The department also sponsors basic research into chemistry, physics, mathematics and the like. Of the research money, which accounts for about a third of the department's current budget, about a third goes into work in Government laboratories, a third to projects conducted by business and a third to studies by universities.
Last week, the House Science Committee's subcommittee on energy approved legislation that would cap the Energy Department's total research budget at about $4 billion in the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1. The proposed reductions included a cut of more than a billion dollars, to $1.4 billion, in the money for civilian energy research. (The department also finances military research, mostly involving nuclear weapons.)
Meanwhile, a task force of freshman Republicans in the House has announced a plan to eliminate the department altogether over the next three years, shifting many of its functions to other agencies and eliminating much of the Federal financing for civilian energy research.
The Energy Department has been marshaling its forces to oppose these plans, offering its own plan for streamlining the department and emphasizing the benefits from its program of basic research, the kind of risky, exotic research that even the biggest energy conglomerates do not often finance independently.
The report issued today was requested by Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary last September, before it became clear how drastically the Congress, now in Republican control, might cut the department's budget.
"I think this report should be required reading for a number of people who have taken a hatchet to this budget," Mrs. O'Leary said today.
The panel was headed by Daniel Yergin, the president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, author of "The Prize," a history of the oil industry.
He and other panel members defended the research programs against the view that they were unwarranted subsidies for corporations. Rather, they said, the programs offered important environmental and economic benefits for the nation as a whole.
"This isn't corporate welfare," said Mason Willrich, a former chief executive of P.G.&E. Enterprises, a subsidiary of the Pacific Gas & Electric Company. "It is a partnership between Government and industry."
But the panel conceded that some large demonstration projects that dominated the research program in its early days, like the effort to make synthetic fuels from coal and oil shale, were misguided.
On the other hand, it said, many new technologies developed with Federal support, ranging from energy-efficient windows to extremely durable drilling bits for oil and gas wells, have produced billions of dollars in gains for energy producers and consumers alike.

NAME: Adolph Lowe

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 4; National Desk

HEADLINE: Adolph Lowe, 102, Economist Who Fled Hitler

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Adolph Lowe, an adviser to the Weimar Government in Germany in the 1920's and a professor of political economy at the New School for Social Research for nearly four decades, died in Wolfenbuttel, Germany, on June 3. He was 102.
One of a remarkable generation of Jewish intellectuals who immigrated to the United States in the 1930's and early 1940's, Professor Lowe was the last surviving member of the University in Exile, created in 1933 by the founders of the New School and the New York State Legislature expressly to snatch scholars like Professor Lowe from the jaws of fascism. 
 Professor Lowe was born in Stuttgart, a sleepy little city in southern Germany, in 1893. The son of a traveling salesman, he started out studying law, but the economic and political upheavals around the time of World War I turned him to economics and socialism. After that war Professor Lowe, armed with a doctorate, became an adviser to the ill-fated Weimar Government in the ministries of demobilization, labor and economics.
By the spring of 1933, when Hitler issued his first blacklist of "dangerous intellectuals," including Professor Lowe, the philosopher Paul Tillich and the sociologist Karl Mannheim, Professor Lowe had become a highly visible professor of economics at the University of Frankfurt with a large student following. His popularity was as much personal as political.
Diminutive and dynamic, Professor Lowe was an entertaining lecturer and avid amateur musician who frequently invited his students home for parties. His daughter Rachel Aubrey, a psychotherapist who lives in Manhattan, recalled that Professor Lowe regularly insisted that students who were having trouble finishing their dissertations live with his family until the task could be completed under his watchful eye.
Fleeing Frankfurt in the middle of the night just before the Nazis stripped Jews of their passports, the Lowe family went to Geneva and then England, where Professor Lowe spent the next half decade at the London School of Economics and the University of Manchester. In 1941, in the middle of the blitzkrieg, Professor Lowe finally accepted an invitation from Alvin Johnson, president of the New School, to come to New York.
Professor Lowe spent the rest of his career at the New School, where his broad, interdisciplinary approach to economics influenced several generations of students. "Lowe brought with him a tradition that saw no boundaries between economics, sociology and political science," said the economist Robert Heilbroner, the author of "The Worldly Philosophers." "Lowe was very impatient with artificial boundaries."
Initially an enthusiastic disciple of John Maynard Keynes, the British economist and patron saint of government management of the economy, Professor Lowe later became one of Keynesianism's early critics. He argued that the effort to turn economics into a predictive science was futile and that the evolution of a highly organized society could not be mapped out with mathematical models, large or small. In that insight, he anticipated the position that most economists had embraced by the mid-1980's.
Professor Lowe retired from the New School in 1978. After his wife, Beatrice, died in 1982, he moved back to Germany to live with a daughter, Hanna Lustig, who had settled in Wolfenbuttel with her family. Professor Lowe's retirement turned into something of a reconciliation with his past, Mrs. Aubrey said: he collected a clutch of honors from various German universities, continued to write and made many new contacts among young German liberals, including journalists, entertaining a steady stream of visitors until he was nearly 100.
In addition to his two daughters, Professor Lowe is survived by five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY'S BUDGET: THE IMPACT;
Budget's Pleasant Surprise: A Tax Cut

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
New Yorkers who own co-ops and condominiums will find a pleasant surprise in the budget agreement reached last night at City Hall: they will get a tax cut. So will business owners who pay a tax on their rent.
But residents who rely on the city for a variety of services and income supplements will have to make do with far less, to pay for those tax cuts and to fill a $3.1 billion gap in the budget. From hospitals to classrooms to welfare payments, the new budget, which still faces a full City Council vote, will force New Yorkers to change their expectations of what their city government will do for them. 
 Though Council leaders, in their final negotiations with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, were able to restore about $80 million to a group of programs that are among the city's most popular, that amount pales in comparison to the nearly $1.5 billion in spending cuts from last year's operating budget. The expected cuts were already enormous even before the state budget was approved last week, and their magnitude only grew when the state provided $670 million less than the city had asked for.
The biggest bright spot to emerge from the final negotiations involves capital spending for the school system. Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines had all but pleaded with City Hall to come up with money to repair school buildings with leaky roofs and to help expand schools suffering from severe overcrowding. Under yesterday's agreement, as part of the planned $2.3 billion sale of the city's water system to a public agency, the city will spend $200 million of the proceeds on school rehabilitation and construction, which Mr. Cortines said was his highest priority.
At the same time, though, the budget will cut $750 million from the Board of Education's projected general budget. Though the Mayor and Council leaders defend the cut as one the school system can absorb, the board will probably have to drop some counseling and after-school programs, and offer early retirement to thousands of teachers and administrators.
The budget will cut $400 million from Medicaid and welfare spending, mostly by reducing fees to hospitals. The Mayor's original budget in April estimated that $46 million could be saved by an intensive screening process to weed out fraudulent welfare claims. Late last week, the Mayor proposed saving another $100 million by even greater fraud detection methods, not yet specified. The money would be saved in the welfare programs for parents and able-bodied childless adults, as well as the Medicaid program.
Advocates for the poor had already questioned whether the original $46 million estimate was realistic, and said the new savings estimates, accepted with little argument by the Council's leadership, were unlikely to be achieved.
Council leaders, for their part, said there was little they could do to restore cuts in a year the budget gap loomed so large.
"It is unreasonable to expect that the City Council, the Mayor or anybody had an ability to substantially restore all of the monies that had to be cut without raising taxes," said Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Council Finance Committee. "And raising taxes is inconsistent with the philosophy of the Mayor and the Council at a time when city is in a major recession."
A few of the Council's restorations were substantial. The Mayor had proposed cutting $20 million from recreational and educational programs for youth, and the Council put back $15 million of that. The Mayor had proposed cutting $18 million from the cultural affairs budget, reducing spending on major museums by 10 percent and on smaller institutions by 80 percent. The Council put back $13.3 million of that.
The Council was also able to restore $4 million of a proposed $4.8 million cut to private organizations that help the mentally ill.
But in most cases, the restorations were far more modest. The city will be cutting $75 million from the budget of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which administers the public hospital system that serves many poor and working-class New Yorkers. The council was able to restore only $1 million of that.
The Council was unable to alter the elimination of free subway and bus passes for schoolchildren, which will save $128 million. Nor could the council members block the elimination of monthly discount fares for private express buses.
Other last-minute cuts agreed to by the council and the Mayor include the following:
*Lowering the estimated number of people who will need residential drug treatment under the city and state's Home Relief welfare program, saving $2.5 million. This estimate was revised because the city is assuming that fewer people will qualify for the welfare program under newly tightened eligibility requirements.
*Hiring the police academy class of 1996 at one second before midnight on June 30, 1996, the last day of the fiscal year, effectively delaying the deployment of 1,700 new officers on the street by about a year. This maneuver saves $15.2 million in pension costs because under pension rules, the cadets are not considered to be hired until fiscal year 1997. But they would still qualify as 1996 hires under the Safe Streets Law, which would have to be amended to allow the procedure.
*Delaying a quarter of the repairs to recently noticed bridge problems, saving $1.2 million.
The agreement also anticipates reducing overtime by $3 million each for firefighters and corrections officers.

HEADLINE: Closed Talks Held on Saving Watersheds

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Over the objections of environmentalists, Gov. George E. Pataki's office has been mediating confidential talks between officials from New York City and a galaxy of small communities near the city's upstate reservoirs on keeping the watersheds clean without stifling local economic growth.
The goal, according to a statement issued by the Governor's office after the latest meeting, on Monday, is "a global settlement of all watershed issues" by mid-August. The city is under a mandate from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to protect the watersheds or face the need to build a multibillion-dollar filtration system. 
 Several participants said the meetings had for the first time created a quiet, politics-free zone in which the city and the dozens of village, town and county governments in the 2,000-square-mile region can discuss issues.
"The idea was to create a civil forum," said an official from the Governor's office who insisted on anonymity. "At first, this was Beirut. These are people who three months ago were at each others' throats. If we'd continued down that path I think New York would have ended up in violation of the E.P.A. mandates, and the watershed communities would've gotten nothing for all their troubles except a pile of legal bills."
But some people who have been excluded see the process as skewed toward the interests of Mr. Pataki's upstate constituency.
"There are no private citizens, no representatives of environmental or civic groups and, as far as I know, no Democrats," said Eric A. Goldstein, a senior lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group that has worked on watershed issues.
The chairman of the City Council Environmental Protection Committee, Stanley E. Michels, Democrat of Manhattan, said: "The City Council has played a leading role on the watershed issue for years. We have a lot to contribute to this process. We wrote a letter to the Governor asking to participate, but we've been turned down. It's very disturbing that on an issue that is so critical to the health and safety of the people of this city we don't know what is going on."
Several participants said the meetings began last month, shortly after the Federal Environmental Protection Agency had granted the city a six-month extension to draft long-term plans to protect the watersheds.
Late last year, in an effort to avoid the need for filtration, city officials presented a package of proposed regulations and actions to protect the watersheds, including buying 80,000 acres to form a buffer against development and spending more than $100 million to upgrade sewage plants that discharge waste water in the watersheds.
The proposal was delayed, because critical elements, including the land acquisitions, would have to be approved by state health and environmental agencies. And upstate communities remained suspicious.
The official from the Governor's office said the intent was to disentangle what had become an impossible nest of lawsuits. "There were already at least 10 suits," he said. "Everybody was suing everybody. That's not a way to resolve a problem."
In part, he said, the extension from the Environmental Protection Administration was a response to the Governor's plan to develop a schedule for resolving the disputes.
The goal of the meetings is to resolve the legal issues by the middle of August, said Michael Finnegan, the Governor's counsel and former law partner. In an interview yesterday, Mr. Finnegan said that a resolution of the legal issues would pave the way for a final plan to be presented to the E.P.A. by the agency's deadline of Sept. 15.
Mr. Finnegan said advocacy groups, including the Natural Resources Defense Council, had been briefed about the meetings. But, he added, it is important to keep the meetings confidential, so an open atmosphere can be maintained for resolving the longstanding disputes.
"We are doing our best to keep all the balls in the air and everybody talking," Mr. Finnegan said. "We want to keep everyone focused on what we all have an interest in, protecting the environment and water quality in a rational way that also protects the interests of the landowners in the watershed communities."
The schedule will "kick into high gear next week," Mr. Finnegan said, with two meetings planned each week for the next month or so.
He said that politicians including upstate mayors and New York City Council members had wanted to participate, but that attendance would for now be limited to lawyers and appointed officials with expertise about watershed issues.
Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the E.P.A., which has had representatives at many sessions, said, "We don't consider the meetings to be closed, in that we understand that the environmental groups are being kept informed of the progress of all the meetings."
The confidentiality, she added, "has allowed an open exchange of views in a nonconfrontational manner."
"We think," Ms. Mears said, "the meetings seem to be yielding some progress."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Weak Economic Data Send Treasury Prices Soaring

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday as retail sales fell short of expectations and the Consumer Price Index showed only a slight rise, adding fresh evidence of an economic slowdown and subdued inflation.
The gains caused interest rates to drop back to week-ago levels as a general optimism among traders about the prospects that the Federal Reserve would ease interest rates added to gains in bond prices throughout the day. 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond gained 27/32 points to a price of 1144/32 , for a yield of 6.54 percent, down from 6.70 percent on Monday. CS First Boston said the decline in the yield was the biggest drop since July 29, 1994.
Donald Fine, chief market strategist at Chase Securities, said the bond market's surge was certainly tied to the release of a Labor Department report showing an unthreatening three-tenths of 1 percent increase in the May Consumer Price Index and a Commerce Department report that retail sales rose by only two-tenths of 1 percent in May.
"Consumer spending is still sluggish," Mr. Fine said, "and while this is simply further confirmation of weak second-quarter growth, there was at the same time scant evidence in the report of any near-term improvement."
He said this would be a cause for concern at the Fed, but still expected the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee to hold off any rate cut at its July 5-6 meeting. Mr. Fine said the Fed would probably wait until Aug. 22 before initiating a rate cut, to examine more data before reaching firm conclusions on the economy's course in the second half of the year.
He continued that while the bond market was back nearly to levels of a week ago, its tone was much more optimistic. "The surge after the payroll number last week was a euphoric event," he said, "but nevertheless doubts about weakness began creeping in. The numbers today removed those doubts. But these numbers are in no way indicative of a recession. Slow economic growth, yes, but declining economic growth, no."
In separate reports on regional activity, the Federal Reserve Banks of Atlanta and Richmond lent further weight to indications of a cooling of economic activity. The Atlanta Fed said its index of regional manufacturing was little changed at minus 21.5 in May, compared with minus 22.1 in April. The Richmond Fed said manufacturers reported lower inflation as business sagged.
Traders said this data erased a lot of doubt in investors' minds about whether the economy was weakening, and again confirmed that inflation was under control.
Good levels of overseas interest and statements by some Fed officials also lent support to bond prices. The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, Cathy E. Minehan, a voting member of the Open Market Committee, told Dow Jones that she still believed the economy was on a path for a soft landing this year and did not expect a recession in 1995. Growth should be about 2.5 percent by year-end, she said, helped by lower rates, income and export growth, and low unemployment.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at CS First Boston, said yesterday's retail sales report validated forecasts of a second-quarter gross domestic product report showing no growth. "Without an increase in demand from the consumer, inventory levels will become more of a problem," Mr. Alexy said. "This will lead to additional cuts in orders, production and jobs."
In the corporate bond market yesterday, the Tennessee Valley Authority doubled the size of its global offering to $2 billion amid strong investor demand even as corporations pumped out new bond issues.
When the 10-year noncallable bonds are priced today, it will be the largest global bond sale by a Government agency or Government-sponsored agency, said David Smith, T.V.A.'s chief financial officer.
The issue is expected to be priced to yield 30 to 33 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note with a 6.50 percent coupon due in 2005. By late yesterday, the 10-year Treasury was priced to yield 6.11 percent.
Traders said Chase Manhattan was also active yesterday, pricing for sale $1.365 billion in floating-rate, asset-backed securities. The asset-backed deal was the bank's largest.

HEADLINE: Stocks Rally on Expectations of Interest Rate Cut by the Fed

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
A crop of conflicting economic data hit the financial markets yesterday, but stocks and especially bonds rallied, as traders interpreted the reports to mean the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates, perhaps as early as next month.
The stock market has now recovered nearly all of last week's losses. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.05 points yesterday, to 4,484.51, not far from the 4,485.20 record set on June 6. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.17 points, to a record 536.05, and the Nasdaq composite index advanced 6.25 points to 894.23, also a record. 
 The real challenge, analysts said, would be the rest of the week when the release of more economic data, like industrial production, and the "triple witching" quarterly expiration of stock options on Friday are sure to add to trading volatility.
The bond market rallied even more than stocks yesterday, helping to fuel the stock rally as corporate borrowing costs fell lower. Bond prices rose sharply and the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond tumbled to 6.54 percent from 6.70 percent.
But the reports that prompted the stock and bond rallies were far from unambiguous. As many Wall Street economists expected, the Consumer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent in May, indicating that inflation was tame. Moreover, retail sales increased just two-tenths of 1 percent in May, even weaker than expected. Both reports supported the argument that the Fed may cut interest rates later this year to spur a flagging economy.
The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, though, said its May national production index, a measure of manufacturing activity, rose for the first time since January. And on Monday, the Semiconductor Industry Association said its book-to-bill ratio, a measure of demand, hit a level not seen in nearly a decade. Both reports, by signaling growth, undermined the argument for an imminent rate cut by the Fed.
Whatever the case, some analysts said that bond traders appeared to be betting on too large a Fed cut. All Treasury bills with a maturity of 12 months or less are trading for less than the 6 percent Federal funds rates -- as little as 5.55 percent for 12-month bills. That implies a rate cut by the Fed of half a percentage point or more.
"If the Fed eases as much as the bond market is betting, the dollar would go to hell in a handbasket," said Dirk van Dijk, equity strategist for C. H. Dean & Associates, which manages $4 billion in stocks and bonds. "Traders would flee and you'd see the dollar at 55 yen." The yen closed yesterday in New York at 84.60 yen, up from 84.04 yen.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.62 points, to 288.18, with advancing stocks outnumbering declining issues 1,611 to 753. Big Board volume totaled 340.2 million shares, slightly more than this year's daily average of 332 million shares. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.09 points, to 491.41.
Among advancing stocks, shares of First Financial Management, a credit-card processor, rose 7 1/4, to 84, after First Data announced a $6.6 billion acquisition bid for the company. First Data's shares fell 1/4, to 56 5/8.
Shares of ITT jumped 5 5/8, to 114 7/8, after the conglomerate announced a plan to split itself into three publicly traded companies.
Among declining stocks, shares of Turbochef, an oven manufacturer, fell 3 3/4, to 12 3/4. Fruit of the Loom dropped 3 1/2, to 23 5/8, after the company's management said second-quarter earnings would not meet Wall Street estimates.
The most active stock, at 6.7 million shares, was Intel, which fell 9/16 , to 111, after rising for much of the year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
A sunny forecast for ad spending grows even brighter.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
SLOWDOWN, schmodown. The leading forecaster of advertising spending has again revised upward his already optimistic projections for this year and issued an initial assessment for 1996 that is equally rosy.
"Despite a lot of negative rhetoric" about the potential for a weakening national economy, "the media marketplace is still very firm and expanding," said Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson USA in New York. 
 "The biggest advertisers are spending aggressively," he added. "Demand is very strong."
Mr. Coen spoke yesterday at a seminar sponsored by McCann and its parent, the Interpublic Group of Companies, at the University Club in Manhattan. This was the 22d annual midyear forecast for ad spending by Mr. Coen, who has been tracking marketing and media trends for 47 years and offers his predictions in June and December.
A year ago, Mr. Coen estimated that ad spending in the United States in 1995 would total $157.7 billion. In December, he revised that estimate to $159 billion. Now, he said in his presentation, the total is likely to reach $161.9 billion. That would be 7.9 percent higher than his final figure for 1994, which was $150 billion.
The increase for 1995 is "really outstanding," Mr. Coen said, "particularly on top of the strong gain we had in 1994." Spending last year grew 8.7 percent from $138.1 billion in 1993.
Ad spending is often considered an indictor of economic health because marketers will raise or lower the amounts of money they budget to pitch products depending on their gauging of consumer moods.
"The outlook for national advertising is much stronger than I thought," Mr. Coen said. "I'm now getting reports saying I was a little too conservative" in December.
Mr. Coen was once almost always bullish on ad spending, often issuing estimates higher than the data later proved. But he has tempered that ebullience since the recession in 1990.
"This year, I think he's right," said James D. Dougherty, who follows the agency industry for Dean Witter Reynolds in New York. "He's got the numbers."
Last year and this year are "the best two-year period in the U.S. advertising business in 10 years," added Mr. Dougherty, who attended the presentation. "And this recovery is in place well into 1996."
Indeed, Mr. Coen, in his first pass at predicting 1996, estimated ad spending at $175 billion, up 8 percent from his new estimate for this year. It should be "a pretty good year," he said, because of increased demand from Presidential election advertising and the heightened interest in the Summer Olympics because they are being held in this country for the first time since 1984.
Mr. Coen said he had raised his forecast for 1995 largely because of data for the first quarter indicating that the full year would be better than he anticipated. For instance, in the largest consumer product categories, many advertisers increased spending "on top of unbelievably strong gains in the first quarter of 1994," he said, citing spending by food advertisers in magazines, up 40 percent, and spending by automobile advertisers in spot, or nonnetwork, television, up 23 percent.
And in smaller product categories, there were also strong gains. Spending on cigarettes, for example, was up 32 percent in magazines, while spending on computers was up 778 percent in spot television.
National ad spending in the United States will end the year at $94.62 billion, he added, a gain of 8.4 percent, well above the 6.8 percent increase he estimated in December. In the first quarter, in nine categories of national media, five enjoyed double-digit percentage gains, including cable television, up 16.5 percent, and spot radio, up 23 percent.
Local ad spending in the United States will be $67.24 billion for the year, Mr. Coen said, up 7.2 percent. That compares with the 7.1 percent increase he estimated in December. Mr. Coen described himself as "a little bit more cautious about newspaper assumptions" than about other local media because gains during the first quarter in retail newspaper advertising were smaller than he had estimated.
For 1995 ad spending overseas, Mr. Coen forecast a total of $193.4 billion, up 8.4 percent from his final figure of $178.4 billion in 1994. Here, too, Mr. Coen has raised his predictions; a year ago, he projected an overseas total of $181.9 billion for 1995, which he raised to $186.7 billion in December.
Mr. Coen cited strong growth in large ad markets like Britain, France and Germany; double-digit percentage gains in emerging ad markets like China, and satisfactory growth in sluggish ad markets like Canada and Japan.
All that would result in total worldwide ad spending for 1995 of $355.3 billion, up 8.2 percent from $328.4 billion in 1994.
For 1996, Mr. Coen's initial estimate of overseas ad spending is $210 billion. Adding his estimate of $175 billion for ad spending in the United States would produce a 1996 worldwide total of $385 billion, up 8 percent from the 1995 estimate of $355.3 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Reports of Clinton Budget Plan Encourage Buying of Dollars

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against leading currencies yesterday, rebounding from early losses and helped by expectations that President Clinton would provide details on a plan to balance the Federal budget in 10 years.
Currency traders said they were encouraged in anticipation of the President's speech last night, after the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said Mr. Clinton would offer "specifics on how to achieve the goal" of a balanced budget, including ways to limit health care spending. 
 Amy Smith, senior currency-market strategist at the consulting firm IDEA, said "the dollar got its biggest boost when Clinton announced he's going to come out with his own balanced budget." That shows "he's getting on board and not being an obstructionist," she said.
Reducing and eventually eliminating the budget deficit would help the dollar by presumably bolstering bond prices as the Treasury reduced the amount of debt required to cover Federal expenditures.
"The dollar is very sensitive to the future economic plan of the United States Government," said David De Rosa of the Swiss Bank Corporation. "Anything that looks like fiscal responsibility tends to give support to the dollar."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.4088 German marks from 1.4033 marks on Monday. It traded at 84.60 yen, up from 84.04.
The dollar's value was also buoyed by a continuing notion that the Federal Reserve and other central banks might try another round of dollar-buying before leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations meet in Halifax, Nova Scotia, starting tomorrow.
When the Group of Seven met in April, finance ministers and central bankers from the seven nations -- the United States, Britain, Japan, Germany, France, Canada and Italy -- pledged to work together to bolster the sagging dollar. On May 31, the Fed and other central banks demonstrated that commitment with a concerted bout of dollar buying that increased the American currency's exchange value.
Earlier yesterday, the dollar slumped in Asia and Europe amid renewed speculation that the Fed might soon cut interest rates, a move that tends to make dollar-denominated assets less attractive. The speculation apparently came in response to remarks Sunday by the White House chief of staff, Leon Panetta, who urged the Fed to cut rates to promote growth.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Didn't Win the Cold War by Itself

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Who's an Isolationist?" (Op-Ed, June 6): I agree with Senator Bob Dole that President Clinton's claims that Congress is undermining his authority in foreign policy are unfair. However, many of Senator Dole's other remarks are inaccurate and misleading. 
 First of all, Senator Dole and other Republicans should give up the absurd idea that they single-handedly won the cold war in spite of Democratic opposition. The Soviet Union collapsed because of inherent weaknesses in the Communist system. Gigantic defense budgets did nothing to the Soviet Union that they did not do to the United States; the difference was that our economy was strong enough to absorb the costs and the Soviet Union's economy was not.
And Republicans should certainly not brag of unnecessary nuclear arms buildup or support of human rights abusers like the so-called freedom fighters of Nicaragua.
Senator Dole also supports the myth that the President has gutted defense spending. He accuses the Administration of "slashing" the defense budget over the past five years.
Actually, Mr. Clinton's budgets have averaged approximately $25 billion less than those at the end of the cold war. These savings are just a fraction of the huge increases that were said to be necessary to fight Communism. The United States defense budget remains more than five times higher than its nearest competitor's. It is clear that the military is in no danger.
Republicans should stop distorting these facts, and should also stop attacking the foreign aid system. While all should fight abuses in the system, it should not be destroyed.
If used correctly, foreign aid can help us to prevent and respond to catastrophes, creating a more stable world. Our leaders should remember that this is vital to every nation's interest. Despite its power, the United States is no exception.
 
KATHERINE HAWKINS
Baldwin, L.I., June 6, 1995

HEADLINE: 101,000 Layoffs Are More Than 'Sobering'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Payrolls Trimmed by 101,000 in May" (front page, June 3) is loaded with employer-biased language that obscures the real impact of the widespread layoffs it reports. 
 The article's first sentence says it all: "In the most sobering evidence so far of the economy's abrupt slowdown, employers lopped 101,000 workers from payrolls in May, the biggest monthly decline since the end of the last recession."
"Sobering" is an interesting word choice here, accurate no doubt for employers faced with the burden of signing pink slips, but perhaps wide of the mark for the 101,000 workers who suddenly found themselves unemployed. "Devastating" might more accurately describe their impression of the "evidence," while "alarming" might better serve for the millions of other workers who find that their jobs are increasingly at risk.
"Lopping" a payroll is not akin to pruning a tree, nor is "trimming" a payroll akin to dieting away flab. Your readers well understand that such terms are euphemisms for that singular, personal and brutal form of economic slowdown known as layoffs.
 
MICHAEL F. KEEZING
Providence, R.I., June 9, 1995

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET;
Clinton's Statement on Plan to Balance Federal Budget by 2005

 BODY:
Following is President Clinton's statement last night on balancing the Federal budget, as recorded by The New York Times:
Good evening. Tonight I present to the American people a plan for a balanced Federal budget. My plan cuts spending by $1.1 trillion. It does not raise taxes. It won't be easy but elected leaders of both parties agree with me that we must do this and we will. 
 We're at the edge of a new century, living in a period of rapid and profound change, and we must do everything in our power to help our people build good and decent lives for themselves and their children.
These days working people can't keep up no matter how hard they work one, two, even three jobs. Without the education to get good jobs, they can't make it in today's America. I don't want my daughter's generation to be the first generation of Americans to do worse than their parents.
Now balancing our budget can help to change that, if we do it in a way that reflects our values and what we care about the most: our children, our families and what we leave the generations to come. That's why my budget has five fundamental priorities.
First, because our most important mission is to help people make the most of their own lives, don't cut education.
Second, balance the budget by controlling health care costs, strengthening Medicare and saving Medicaid, not by slashing health services for the elderly.
Third, cut taxes for the middle class and not the wealthy. We shouldn't cut education or Medicare just to make room for a tax cut for people who don't really need it.
Fourth, cut welfare but save enough to protect children and move able-bodied people from welfare to work.
Fifth, don't put the brakes on so fast that we risk our economic prosperity.
This can be a turning point for us. For 12 years our Government -- Congress and the White House -- ducked the deficit and pretended we could get something for nothing. In my first two years as President, we turned this around and cut the deficit by one-third. Now let's eliminate it. It's time to clean up this mess. Here's how:
First, I propose to cut spending in discretionary areas other than defense by an average of 20 percent, except education. I want to increase education not cut it. We'll continue to cut waste. Under Vice President Gore's leadership we're already cutting hundreds of programs and thousands of regulations and 270,000 Federal positions. We'll still be able to protect the environment and invest in technology and medical research for things like breast cancer and AIDS, but make no mistake: in other areas there will be big cuts, and they'll hurt.
Second, we should limit tax cuts to middle-income people, not upper-income people, and target the tax cuts to help Americans pay for college like we did with the G.I. Bill after World War II. Let's help a whole new generation of Americans go to college -- that's the way to make more Americans upper-income people in the future.
Third, don't cut Medicare services to the elderly. Instead of cutting benefits, maintain them by lowering costs, crack down on fraud and abuse, provide more home care, incentives for managed care, respite benefits for families of Alzheimer's patients and free mammograms.
 
Insurance Ideas
 For all Americans I propose the freedom to take your insurance with you when you change jobs, to keep it longer after you lose a job, insurance coverage even if there are pre-existing conditions in your family and lower-cost insurance for groups of self-employed and small-business people. If we don't have tax cuts for upper-income people, as Congressional leaders have proposed, we won't need to make harsh cuts in health care or in education.
Finally, balance the budget in 10 years. It took decades to run up this deficit; it's going to take a decade to wipe it out.
Now mind you, we could do it in seven years, as Congressional leaders propose, but the pain we'd inflict on our elderly, our students and our economy just isn't worth it. My plan will cut the deficit year after year. It will balance the budget without hurting our future.
This budget proposal is very different from the two passed by the House and the Senate, and there are fundamental differences between Democrats and Republicans about how to balance the budget. But this debate must go beyond partisanship, it must be about what's good for America and which approach is more likely to bring prosperity and security to our people over the long run. We ought to approach it in the same spirit of openness and civility which we felt when the Speaker and I talked in New Hampshire last Sunday.
There are those who have suggested that it might actually benefit one side or the other politically if we had gridlock and ended this fiscal year without a budget. But that would bad for our country and we have to do everything we can to avoid it. If we'll just do what's best for our children, our future and our nation and forget about who gets the political advantage we won't go wrong.
Good night; let's get to work.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. and Japan Told to Solve Trade Dispute

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
When the World Trade Organization opened its doors in Geneva early this year, it was billed as the powerful new global referee that would rule on trade disputes that once bogged down in the old international trade bureaucracy. But the new head of the organization made it clear today that he would prefer not to have the battle between Washington and Tokyo over auto trade become the first test of his group's legal powers.
Urging the United States and Japan to settle their trade dispute quickly, Renato Ruggiero, the organization's Director General, issued a bluntly worded warning during an hourlong interview with reporters here. He called the argument over access to Japan's automobile and auto parts market "a delicate matter with nationalist implications" in each country. 
 Mr. Ruggiero, for all his tough talk, seemed eager to avoid being forced to issue a ruling in the claims and counterclaims of what has become one of the most contentious trade disputes in recent years. "There are legal considerations and then there are political considerations," said Mr. Ruggiero, a longtime European diplomat and former trade minister of Italy. "I much prefer to have this resolved in discussions than to reach a legalistic ruling."
[Mr. Ruggiero's comments came a day before Japan's chief trade official, Ryutaro Hashimoto, announced in Tokyo early Wednesday that Japan and the United States would resume their stalled talks on automotive trade on June 22 and 23 in Geneva. The talks would follow quickly on the heels of this week's summit meeting of the seven big industrialized democracies and would be less than a week before 100 percent punitive tariffs are scheduled to go into effect on $5.9 billion of Japanese luxury cars. Washington's insistence that Japanese car makers agree to purchase more American parts has been a stumbling block, but Japan will go to the talks in Geneva with a "completely open mind," Mr. Hashimoto said.]
Mr. Ruggiero's comments also raised a fundamental question about the future of the new trade organization: should it be more akin to a Supreme Court of economic conflict between nations -- issuing rulings and creating precedents -- or should it act as a political tool to help bring countries to the negotiating table?
Clearly, American officials who were involved in writing the rules for the new organization to replace the more loosely structured General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, envisioned a court-like institution whose rulings would be binding on more than 120 nations. But Mr. Ruggiero's view is more typical of the old school of trade politics, under which a pragmatic settlement is far more satisfactory that a precedent-setting ruling.
Just why is Mr. Ruggiero so interested in keeping the United States-Japan dispute from reaching a panel of W.T.O. judges? The reason, say many American and Asian officials, is that he fears that the argument between the two countries could smother the fledgling organization in its infancy. "He's afraid the W.T.O. will be trampled," said one American official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "Worse yet, he's afraid that Japan or the U.S. could ignore the rulings, even though everyone has indicated they will abide by them."
So far both Japan and the United States have refused to budge on the major issues.
Mr. Ruggiero was also implicitly critical of the United States for insisting on more concessions from other nations before signing on to a worldwide agreement on trade in financial services. That is an industry the United States dominates, and remains one of the sectors where it enjoys a surplus with its major trading partners. Asian countries have been reluctant to agree to allow American companies to claim a larger share of their domestic securities and insurance industries.
The issue was so controversial that it was split off in December 1993 from the rest of the GATT accord. The deadline for a separate agreement on financial services expires on June 30, and the Administration has said that it will revoke preferential trade status for many countries in that sector if it is not satisfied with the results by that date.
Mr. Ruggiero met today with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin but was unable to persuade him to sign the financial services accord quickly and seek more access to foreign markets in the next round of negotiations, scheduled for four years from now. Rebuffed by the Administration, Mr. Ruggiero promised to try to persuade Asian countries to improve their offering of market openings, in hopes of winning over American support for the accord.
More broadly, Mr. Ruggiero expressed fears that the United States was "no longer confident" about its leadership on international economic issues or about relying on multilateral institutions, including the World Trade Organization, to solve its problems with trading partners. He made no specific reference to the American decision to seek unilateral sanctions against Japan while also pursuing a complaint against the country within the W.T.O., but that seemed to be what was on his mind.
Washington is also concerned that the W.T.O. might rule in Tokyo's favor, siding with its claim that the United States is proposing to raise car tariffs that it had agreed to limit as part of the global trade pact.
"I see the U.S. almost defending itself from the system you have created," he said. "Now there is a feeling that these institutions take something out of your influence and power."

HEADLINE: Tackling New York City's Deficit

 BODY:
This has been a year of budget combat at all levels of government, so it is startling to see Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and the City Council actually reaching agreement on New York City's fiscal crisis. The accord that was negotiated by these two longtime antagonists looks as if it will blunt the most severe cuts in municipal services that the Mayor warned might be necessary. But it also appears to resort to some traditional budget gimmicks while overlooking alternative savings that should have been considered.
Mr. Giuliani deserves credit for recognizing the need for bold steps to close the city's $3 billion deficit. But the solutions he offered originally involved an unnecessarily harsh dose of cutbacks in services, especially for the poor, disabled and young. The Council has wisely resisted many of the cuts as dangerous and likely to lead to increased expenses down the road. 
 To his credit, the Mayor appears now to have accepted the Council's appeal to look again at the revenue side of the ledger. Mr. Giuliani has unfortunately rejected a sound proposal from the Council Speaker, Peter Vallone, for tax increases for some single-family homes, now taxed relatively lightly. But the accord with the Council does scale back Mr. Giuliani's proposed tax cuts for the next year.
Unfortunately, neither the City Council nor the Mayor could summon the will to demand more cuts in the police and fire departments, which have been largely spared since Mr. Giuliani took office. With the work force shrinking in so many other areas, the Mayor should have been willing to seek an amendment in state law to permit economies through use of civilians in desk jobs while retaining patrol force on the streets at its current level.
In like fashion, the Fire Department and other agencies could also demand changes in work rules, staffing requirements, overtime agreements and other practices to enable a reduced work force to deliver the same services and safety to the public.
The agreement between the Mayor and the Council is a disappointment in terms of achieving greater productivity in the work force. Mr. Giuliani has been too timid, at least in public, about demanding that the city's employees show greater flexibility and even sacrifice in the face of cuts that would damage the city where they work and, for the most part, live. As we have said before, hundreds of millions of dollars could be realized by limiting the open-ended health benefits for municipal employees. Negotiations with the municipal labor leaders need to be stepped up now that the Council and the Mayor have settled some of their own spending issues.
It is disturbing that the Council and the Mayor will rely on perhaps $500 million in gimmicks to balance the budget, including one-time-only revenues, sales of assets and newly optimistic budget assumptions. These are a potential recipe for trouble down the road, especially if the new budget projections do not pan out. Once again, Mayor Giuliani and the City Council have engaged in the kind of budget practice that has enabled generations of political leaders to postpone tough budget decisions while widening the deficits in each succeeding year.
The only justification for using one-shot revenues is to avoid the extreme hardship of absorbing the needed budget cuts in a single year. The one-shots buy time for a more orderly scaling down in the size of government. We welcome the objective of finding alternatives to painful budget cuts, but the city's fiscal monitors should scrutinize the latest budget accord to make sure that any use of such gimmicks is accompanied by a serious commitment and financial plan showing how the city will reduce the size and cost of government over time. Only with such a sustained approach and demand for sacrifice by everyone can the city hope to climb out of its chronic deficits in the next few years.

HEADLINE: Is This Any Good Way to Elect a President?;
Perot Is Here to Stay

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Ross Perot, Yet Again" (editorial, June 6) states that the United We Stand America conference is not about issues but about Mr. Perot. It also suggests that political leaders are somehow catering to him by consenting to address thousands of United We Stand America members at the Dallas convention center. It is a super-cynical editorial that lowers the stature of your newspaper. 
 Mr. Perot and United We Stand are nothing but vitally interested in the issues that affect our country. Mr. Perot became a national figure in the last Presidential election with the same issues that he and United We Stand have continued to fight for to this day.
They are the same issues that a majority of the nation is intensely interested in -- a balanced budget, debt reduction, term limits, lobbyist reform, campaign finance reform and economic policies that lead to more jobs for our citizens. More than anyone else, he brought the absolute need for debt reduction to the attention of the electorate.
Your editorial does not focus on the fact that Mr. Perot has invited all members of United We Stand and also John and Jane Q. Public to this three-day conference on "Preparing Our Country for the 21st Century."
As one who will attend, I regard it as a "renaissance weekend" for the common people, with prominent speakers at interesting seminars and the opportunity to hear directly from the nation's political leaders. If there is any catering by the Presidential candidates, it is because they will have the attention of thousands of independent voters who keep up with everything that Congress is doing and who will be a sure bet to cast their ballots in the next election.
Despite the attempts of political attack dogs and the media to trash Ross Perot, he is still a significant national figure and will continue to be one. It is to be hoped that you can accept that fact, get over it and quit trying to suggest that he and United We Stand shouldn't have the same privilege of being addressed by political leaders at a national conference too.
 
IRENE WINDER
Summerland Key, Fla., June 10, 1995
The writer is a member of United We Stand America.

HEADLINE: Illegal Migrants' Road West Crosses Old East Bloc

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: ZAKOPANE, Poland

 BODY:
On a recent Saturday morning, some three score residents of this picturesque mountain community assembled at the ski jump for a trip to the United States, first by bus to Germany, then on Lufthansa across the Atlantic.
They included a grandmother and her 3-year-old grandchild, a mother and her three children, several unemployed women in their 20's, and a few men in their 70's. Each had paid at least $6,000. 
 They had paid the money as sponsors of a local sports club and were accompanying the national weight-lifting team to a competition in Chicago -- or so their documents said.
But the only thing these people were sponsoring was their own entry into the United States. No sports team was going to Chicago or anywhere else.
It was all organized by the chairman of the club, who had been successful in the past in getting Poles without valid visas into the United States, said two people who signed up for the most recent attempt. This time, though, an alert immigration officer at the airport in Frankfurt, Germany, suspected that the American visas were forgeries, which they turned out to be, Polish and American law enforcement officials said. The immigrants were sent home.
This is not an isolated case by any means. It is, rather, part of a growing phenomenon -- trafficking in illegal immigrants from and through Eastern and Central Europe.
Immigrants from Sri Lanka, Bangladesh and Afghanistan and from Africa and the Middle East are being smuggled to the West, moved along routes that have developed since Communism fell and with it, the rigid border controls. They are being moved in many ways, among them freight-hauling trucks, the ceilings of trains and ship containers.
What worries law enforcement officials most is that international criminal syndicates are increasingly getting involved in illegal immigration. "There are tangible indicators that the smugglers of stolen automobiles and illicit narcotics have decided to diversify their portfolio to include alien smuggling," Thomas Tass, a Canadian immigration official, wrote in a paper he delivered recently to a conference in Budapest.
"These organizations should not be underestimated in their ability to move thousands of people illegally from one country to another while earning huge profits with minimum risk," said Mr. Tass, who is based in Warsaw and is considered the leading regional authority on this issue.
Smuggling people fits well into an organized crime conglomerate. A desperate alien who cannot afford the fee may be allowed to go in exchange for carrying drugs, and the immigrant will be expected to work for the gang in the United States or Europe as a prostitute or a drug dealer to pay back the money, law enforcement officials said.
As for profits, the organizer of the weight lifters' tour, 35-year-old Stefan Koziol, took in nearly $400,000, said two women in the group, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mr. Koziol is now in jail on charges of fraud. He has not been charged with smuggling people, which is not a crime in Poland and only a minor offense in most European countries. Polish authorities declined to allow him to be interviewed, but he has told Polish newspapers that he is innocent. The club "sponsors" have not been charged.
The International Center for Migration Policy Development, a nonprofit intergovernmental organization in Vienna, has calculated that illegal immigration syndicates in Europe raked in between $100 million and $1.1 billion in 1993.
The wide range in the estimate is a reflection of how little is known about the problem, the gravity of which is only beginning to register. Interpol, the international police organization, has no coordinated campaigns in this area, immigration officials and diplomats said. The funds the European Union has made available for economic restructuring in Eastern and Central Europe can be used to combat drug trafficking, but not trafficking in illegal immigrants, said Tamas Kiss, who works for the Migration Policy Center.
Not surprisingly, the traffickers have been successful in staying ahead of the ill-trained local police, who are inexperienced in dealing with this problem.
"It is like drugs -- there are routes," said Col. Attila Krisan, spokesman for Hungary's Border Guards, which seized nearly 15,000 illegal immigrants last year, from scores of countries, who were trying to move through Hungary.
Common European entry points for refugees from Asia, from the Middle East and from Africa are Romania and Bulgaria, which have more lenient visa requirements and weaker law enforcement than other countries in the region.
Earlier this year, somewhere in Romania, 60 Bangladeshis were loaded into the back of a long canvas-covered truck, which was hauling tomato paste to Germany. The truck successfully crossed into Hungary and in several hours reached Slovakia. There, customs officials lifted the cover and were shocked to find people. The men were heading for the West to find jobs and had paid between $2,500 and $4,000 apiece to a trafficker.
Bulgaria has become a popular entry point because Balkan Airlines has extensive routes to the third world and relatively low fares, said a report last year by the International Organization for Migration, an independent research organization based in Geneva.
In Bulgaria, trafficking gangs charge up to $4,000 per person to move the immigrants westward, often along routes used by drug traffickers. "Operating these organized channels is a profitable occupation and is often part of a larger 'Mafia-style' operation," the report says.
For illegal Asian immigrants, the Chinese restaurants that have sprung up in Eastern European capitals provide a cover. They provide the immigrants with work permits, which get them into the country. After working for a while, they move on, to Germany, and in many cases to the United States, law enforcement officials said.
"The raison d'etre for these businesses goes beyond providing alternative menus" for local residents, Mr. Tass, the Canadian immigration official, noted wryly at the conference in Budapest.
He told of one Chinese restaurant in Prague that employed more than 800 people. "Even more remarkable was the fact that the restaurant had only eight tables," Mr. Tass said. He told of another "very elegant and modern Chinese five-star restaurant smack in the middle of an industrial blue-collar working-class area," and without any parking.
Another growing gateway to the West is through the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Immigrants who move through these countries, including large numbers from the impoverished former Soviet republics of Central Asia, then travel by sea to Scandinavia.
Many of the immigrants reach the Baltic countries via Moscow.
Last year, 64 Kurds and Pakistanis, including 26 children, were discovered in a sealed container on a car ferry from Tallinn, Estonia, to Stockholm.
Last December, a Latvian ship with more than 100 Iraqis, Afghans and Palestinians, who had paid $5,000 a piece, ran aground off the coast of Estonia.
In late May, the Polish police detained 49 Asians, including 10 children, who had made it to the Baltic lands, then crossed from Lithuania into Poland, where their luck ran out.
Moscow has become a major transit center for migrants from Asia, Africa, the Middle East and former Soviet Republics in Central Asia. By train, bus or plane, they move west to Poland and the Czech Republic, and then on to the West.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 15, 1995, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption yesterday with an article about the smuggling of illegal immigrants through Europe referred incorrectly in some editions to a Hungarian town where Afghan families were staying. It is Kistarcsa, not Kirtarsca.
