LENGTH: 1204 words

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: SEEKING COMMON GROUND;
Clinton Team And G.O.P. Debate Deficit

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
A day after President Clinton issued his own plan to balance the Federal budget, his emissaries met Republican leaders on Capitol Hill today to explore the prospects for a compromise plan to erase the deficit.
To the astonishment of some and the sputtering frustration of many Democrats in Congress, the two sides ended the session with an arm's-length embrace and agreed to continue talking. Still, it was not clear where those talks might lead. 
 The Republicans, in the thick of final preparations for their own budget, said they would immediately study details of Mr. Clinton's plan and consider incorporating its most attractive features into their blueprint -- that is, if they found any.
"We're going to take a look and see how real it is," the chairman of the House Budget Committee, Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, said. For now, he added, "the only thing that looks attractive to me is that he said he wants to balance the Federal budget."
Speaker Newt Gingrich went further, saying some parts of Mr. Clinton's proposal were "eminently worth looking at."
For his part, the President said that talking compromise might not be good politics, but that he had to put the national interest above political gain. Given Mr. Clinton's good faith, said the President's spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, "there would surely be some give-and-take in the discussion" to come.
The hourlong meeting, in the office of the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, brought Mr. Dole, Mr. Gingrich, Mr. Kasich and Senator Pete V. Domenici, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, face-to-face with Leon E. Panetta, the President's chief of staff, and Alice M. Rivlin, his budget director.
Mr. Kasich said Mr. Panetta had assured Republicans that the President's budget-balancing plan, which would cut $1.1 trillion from projected Federal spending and $111 billion from Federal taxes over the next 10 years, was serious and real.
Republicans are combining the House and Senate's budget proposals into a single Congressional plan this week. Both Republican plans would eliminate the deficit in seven years, rather than 10, and envision tax cuts totaling as much as $353 billion over that span.
Both the White House and Democrats in Congress had maintained for months that setting a fixed date to erase the deficit was arbitrary and potentially damaging to the economy, and that balancing the budget was impossible without a complete overhaul of health care.
Most Republicans praised Mr. Clinton today for setting aside those positions. Mr. Gingrich praised the President's "statesmanship" in a speech to the Chamber of Commerce of the United States; Mr. Dole said Mr. Clinton was acting responsibly.
But many in Mr. Clinton's own party were stunned and outraged by a reversal that recently seemed inconceivable, and that they viewed as robbing them of their most potent political weapon on Capitol Hill.
In a private meeting of the House's Democrats this morning, one Democrat in attendance said, White House officials sat silently as the legislators repeatedly accused the President of abandoning and double-crossing them. The Democrats accused Mr. Clinton of casting his party's fortunes to the winds, in a nationally broadcast speech on the budget, for the sake of his own political survival. "The message a lot of members got was, 'You're on your own,' " a Democratic legislator said after the session. "The word 'betrayal' came up three times, from three different members."
Another Democrat, a veteran on the party's left flank, likened the post-speech situation of the House's Democrats to that of Capt. Scott F. O'Grady, the American airman who spent six days last week surrounded by the enemy in Bosnia, eating bugs and grass to survive. "The difference between House Democrats and Captain O'Grady," he said, "is that Captain O'Grady had allies."
One legislator, who refused to be named, said he had never seen the House's Democrats so angry at Mr. Clinton. Several others said the President's move may backfire by prompting a challenge in next year's Presidential primaries from the party's left flank.
There was some acknowledgment, now that Democrats had digested their anger overnight, that Mr. Clinton's action might actually prove good for the country, if it led to a serious bipartisan effort to rein in Federal overspending.
But that was overwhelmed by the belief among members and some strategists that the Democrats had only two effective weapons against the Republican ascendancy -- the arguments that their policies would wreak havoc on the elderly and the less privileged -- and that Mr. Clinton had now given both away.
"By reacting to everything the Republicans do, it's a sure way to fail," said Representative Donald M. Payne of New Jersey, chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus. "There are many people who are wondering, do we have a partnership going here or is the White House just moving out on its own course?"
Mr. Panetta and Ms. Rivlin met with some House and Senate Democratic leaders to brief them on the session with the Republicans. Later the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, issued a statement maintaining that Mr. Clinton's plan "shows again that there is a better way to balance the budget than crippling Medicare and Medicaid," among other programs targeted by Republicans.
But, in fact, Democrats appeared to recoil most at Mr. Clinton's own proposal to reduce the growth of the Medicare program, a pillar of Democratic policy rooted in the party's 1960's heyday. It is now among the largest and fastest-growing programs in Government -- and one of the most popular among voters.
Republicans had proposed to cut the growth of Medicare spending by as much as $288 billion through the year 2002. With the encouragement of the White House, Democrats had hammered away at that in the spring during budget debates in Congress, casting Republicans as heartless enemies of the old and poor.
And they had enjoyed some political success. But in his own proposal, Mr. Clinton calls for a $124 billion reduction in projected Medicare spending by 2010, and some Democrats said today that the President had all but wrecked their strategy.
"All of us have invested a lot of energy in the last two months criticizing the Medicare cuts," said Representative Nydia M. Velazquez, a Brooklyn Democrat, "and you know, here he comes now, and basically picked Medicare as the starting point for balancing the budget."
But a handful of other Democrats defended Mr. Clinton, saying he had done what he thought was right, even if they disagreed with his actions.
"On principle and substance, the President was right," said Representative Bill Richardson, a New Mexico Democrat. "The long-range politics are smart, but there are risks short-term with his Democratic base."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, was known to strongly disagree with Mr. Clinton's decision. But he told reporters today that Mr. Clinton was "coming forward and leading on a very tough set of issues.
"He is the President of the United States," Mr. Gephardt said. "He is trying to come up with solutions to this deficit problem."

HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE RATIONALES;
Good Economics Joins With Very Good Politics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
When Republicans made their promise of a balanced budget a keystone of the 1994 election campaign, no one was surprised. The party had long paid lip service to the goal, although not a single balanced budget was produced in the Nixon, Ford, Reagan or Bush years.
But now even the Democrats have jumped aboard. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, returned from a retreat with his troops a few weeks ago and proclaimed, "All of us believe our budgets must be brought into balance." 
 On Tuesday night, President Clinton joined the cause. The question, he said in his brief television address, is not whether to balance the budget, but when and how. This, after having submitted a budget just four months ago that allowed annual deficits of about $200 billion past the turn of the century.
So what's going on? The Federal budget has been in the red every year but one (1969) since the Eisenhower Administration. Why all of a sudden should a balanced budget be like the Holy Grail? What's so great about balancing the budget anyway?
The answer, of course, lies heavily in politics. Public opinion polls show that in the abstract, 80 percent of Americans favor balancing the budget. The number falls precipitously if people are asked whether they would still feel that way if it meant cuts in Social Security or Medicare, or tax increases. Still, when 80 percent of the public believes something, politicians pay attention.
But politics aside, strong economic arguments can be made for moving the country toward a balanced budget. Some economists on the left and the right have no problem with running large deficits. But the broad mainstream of economists holds that consistently large budget deficits -- the amount by which the Government spends more money each year than it receives in revenue -- endanger the country's economic future and cheat future generations of taxpayers.
Hardly any economists hold that revenues should exactly match expenditures every year. Ideally, most say, the budget would be in surplus in good times and run modest deficits when the economy was in recession.
The deficit this year is about $170 billion, and many economists believe that merely cutting that figure in half and keeping it there might be sufficient for the country's economic health. As the economy grew over the years, the deficit would shrink as a proportion of the economy.
But setting the more vivid goal of a balanced budget may be essential to bringing the annual deficit to a manageable level.
"If John Kennedy had stood up and said, 'I want to shoot a man in a rocket thousands of miles into space and bring him back again,' it wouldn't have caught the imagination of the American people like promising to send a man to the moon," said Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, who is now a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
Some economists believe that balancing the budget is a moral issue. James M. Buchanan of George Mason University, winner of the 1987 Nobel Prize in economics, told Congress a few years ago that the country had "lost the moral sense of fiscal responsibility."
William A. Niskanen, who was the top economic adviser in President Ronald Reagan's first term, agrees with that view. "If we were involved in a war or a major capital building program, I would have no problem with borrowing," he said. "But that's not the case. We're just shifting the burden of our consumption to the next generation."
Others look at the deficit strictly in practical terms. Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration, compares large deficits to termites eating at the foundation of a building. They may cause no worry this year or next, but, if nothing is done, eventually the building will fall down.
The problem is that the more the Government borrows to meet its debts, the less is available for productive investment, public and private. Money the Government spends on interest payments cannot be spent for education or medical care or research that would make the country a better place for future generations. Money the public invests in Government bonds is not put into private capital markets, where it could be used to buy computers or build factories.
The main reason to lower the deficit, said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, chairman of President Clinton's National Economic Council, "is to increase national savings; that, in turn, increases national investment in physical, human and technological capital; that, in turn, increases productivity growth and growth in incomes for all Americans."
But it is one thing to say that balancing the budget, or at least lowering the deficit significantly, is a wise course. It is quite a different matter to specify exactly how it should be done.
This is where the economists break ranks. Some would accomplish the task entirely by reducing Government spending. Others put much more emphasis on raising taxes.
In the current political climate, neither Social Security payments nor military expenditures can be cut, and taxes cannot be raised. That puts almost all the pressure of deficit reduction on a rather small slice of the Government's pie composed largely of Medicare, Medicaid and other social welfare programs.
Maybe enough money can be saved in these programs over the next 7 to 10 years to balance the budget. But as sure as they are that this would improve the economy, not all economists are certain it would be worth the price.

HEADLINE: Halifax Journal;
On a Paved Parking Lot, They Put Up a Paradise

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 14

 BODY:
First they paved the gravel parking lot, down along the Halifax waterfront. But the result was judged insufficiently pleasing for the important visitors scheduled to gather in the squat, green-tinted glass building overlooking it.
So last weekend workers hastily covered the lot with sod, potted trees, flowering shrubs and pansies, geraniums and chrysanthemums in blue, red and yellow -- the colors of the official logo for the annual summit meeting of the Group of Seven major industrial nations, which begins here on Thursday. 
 "It all comes away when the leaders leave," said Tom Gribbin, the landscape architect with Parks Canada who designed this pleasing if transient little summit park. "Still, I've had my moment of temporary gratification."
Along the waterfront and elsewhere in downtown Halifax, a frenzy of planting, painting, repaving, pothole filling and prettifying construction work has local commentators making comparisons with the "Potemkin villages" put up by the favorite field marshal of Catherine the Great to impress her.
"Potemkin couldn't teach Halifax a thing about putting on the dog," noted Jim Meek, columnist for The Halifax Chronicle-Herald.
It would take a far greater effort to counter the overall down-at-the-heels look of this gritty, red-brick, often fog-bound port city, depressed in recent years by military cutbacks and the depletion of Atlantic fish stocks. The unemployment rate, above 9 percent, is nearly twice that of the United States.
But not all the improvements are fake or temporary. Helped by provincial and federal treasuries, the city has pumped some $6 million into permanent waterfront recreation areas and seawalls, fresh streets and sidewalks, and new sidings and canopies for some of the more weatherworn buildings.
Doug Grant, 70, a former coal miner who bought the Midtown Tavern and Grill in 1949, lucked out, he says, with an outer wall, burgundy and green, for his landmark establishment on Grafton Street.
When construction crews tore up the road, he explained with a satisfied grin, they also had to install a new sidewalk. But in doing that they damaged his old siding, entitling him to a new one.
If the summit meeting proves to be a news dud, it will at least be what Janice Manders, executive director of the Downtown Halifax Business Commission, describes as "the catalyst for civic revitalization."
While giving a boost to Halifax, Prime Minister Jean Chretien, this year's host, has tried to tone down the extravagance of past summit meetings to make this one more businesslike and less ceremonial. He calls it a Chevrolet as opposed to a Cadillac summit. Yet some Canadian officials fret that all the penny-pinching will relegate it in history books as the "Chevette summit."
In keeping with fiscal prudence, the two negotiating tables, both cherry wood, one that seats at least 9 and the other at least 30, have been borrowed from Italy and recycled from last year's meeting in Naples.
Canada also asked each country to keep its delegations to a minimum. Only 1,500 officials are expected, about half the number at Naples. The press, 2,000 strong, will be only one-third the Naples contingent.
The talks are being held on vacant floors of that squat green glass building, recently renamed Summit Place but more familiarly known to Haligonians as the Green Toad. Normally it is used by Kodak Canada as an office building.
Also to check costs, which are running less than the $25 million Canada spent on its last go-around, in 1988 in Toronto, the Government has allowed private companies to "sponsor" the meeting by providing food and services in return for advertising before a global audience. About 100 companies, from Jost Vineyards offering a selection of Nova Scotia wines to McCain Foods distributing snack foods in news center, have signed up.
Tourism boosters are elated at the chance to promote the rich culture of Canada's sparsely settled Celtic heartland. Only a million people live in Nova Scotia, of whom about a third are in the Halifax area.
At least 2,000 policemen -- the precise number is a guarded secret -- are also on hand to provide security.
A 250-acre area near the waterfront, the "red zone," including the six hotels housing the leaders, is cordoned off by six-foot steel-and-concrete barricades and mesh fences. Only those with highest security clearance get inside.
To add even more security, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police have spent the last two days welding manhole covers, carting away mailboxes and vending machines and assigning snipers to rooftops.
A no-flight zone is being maintained around the harbor. Ten percent of the harbor is closed to vessels, enforced by a flotilla of police boats and navy minesweepers. Helicopters and planes scan the city virtually round the clock.
At their Halifax headquarters, the Mounties have a high-tech command center using newly installed security cameras to monitor everything that happens in each of the buildings where summit activities take place -- and to lock a building electronically should a security breach occur.
In addition, frogmen have had to secure the harbor's spewing sewer pipes against any terrorists. Halifax still dumps unprocessed sludge into its harbor on the theory that tides take it out to sea. One of the outfall pipes is only a few yards away from where Mr. Chretien is to welcome his guests as they are ferried across the harbor after landing at the Shearwater Canadian Forces base about six and half miles away.
Diving in the harbor, and especially entering those sewer pipes, acknowledged Inspector Terry Elliott, the Mounties' deputy commander of summit security, "is not an enviable job."

HEADLINE: U.S. Blacks Battle Nigeria Over Rights Issue

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
In past years, the Government of Nigeria and many prominent African-American leaders were more likely to be on the same side of international issues: debt-relief for sub-Saharan countries, ending white minority rule in southern Africa, ousting the military dictatorship in Haiti.
But these days, the two are engaged in a war of words and symbolic protests in an increasingly bitter dispute over human rights in Nigeria. 
 The latest manifestation of this is the reported pressure exerted by Nigerian diplomats on the United Nations Children's Fund not to hold a ceremony in the chamber of the General Assembly honoring Randall Robinson of TransAfrica Forum.
Responding to protests from supporters of Nigeria -- whose human rights record Mr. Robinson has been critical of -- Unicef officials said they decided to move it from the General Assembly to another location, thus downgrading its importance.
Shedding what has been their normal reluctance to rebuke a black African country for the treatment of its citizens, an increasing number of prominent African-Americans are calling for the same type of pressures -- diplomatic isolation and economic sanctions -- to be used against the military Government of Gen. Sani Abacha that were applied against South Africa.
"Nigeria is saddled with a military dictatorship that has looted its treasury and victimized its people," said Mr. Robinson, executive of TransAfrica Forum, a research organization concentrating on issues involving Africa and the Caribbean.
Last month the board of the cash-starved National Association for the Advancement of Colored People voted not to accept $20,000 that was pledged to it by Zubair Mahmud Kazaure, Nigeria's Ambassador to the United States, to protest the country's human rights record.
In March, a group of prominent blacks, including Bryant Gumbel of the NBC News program "Today"; the Rev. Jesse Jackson; the actor Danny Glover, and A. Leon Higginbotham Jr., a retired judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, called on the Administration to ban the import of Nigerian oil.
In April, Mr. Robinson and 10 other prominent blacks were arrested outside the Nigerian Embassy as part of a protest against General Abacha.
The Nigerians have responded by pressing charges against the demonstrators. The Nigerians have also attacked Mr. Robinson in Government-controlled newspapers and, critics of the Government say, have organized pickets of Mr. Robinson's office and placed full-page advertisements denouncing his campaign as merely a ploy to gain financing.
"I personally have a lot of respect for Mr. Randall Robinson because of the role he played on South Africa," Mr. Kazaure said today in an interview. "But what he is doing about Nigeria is not the right way to go about it."
Mr. Kazaure denied that the Nigerian Government had pressed the United Nations officials to move the Robinson luncheon or orchestrated any protests.
The protests by African-American officials over Nigeria stands in marked contrast to their relative silence in past years to crimes by African leaders like Idi Amin of Uganda or Jean-Bedel Bokassa of the Central African Republic.
"We wanted this spiritual embrace with Africa and sometimes didn't make the distinctions between the government of a country and its people," said Mr. Robinson, explaining the reluctance of black leaders to criticize black governments.
"We should have been critical of Uganda early on. But I don't think we were armed sufficiently in the upper reaches of our community with the right information."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Use of Taxpayer Money For Newsletter Is Ruled Illegal

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 14

 BODY:
Taxpayer money was used illegally by the Cuomo administration for a 1992 state newsletter that was "an unequivocal promotion of a partisan political position," New York State's top court ruled today.
The newsletter attacked Republican welfare reform proposals nationally and in New York as that year's Presidential election campaign was just getting into full swing. 
 In a 6-to-1 decision, the State Court of Appeals overturned two lower state court rulings. The top court sent the case back to the trial court for trial.
Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo declined to comment, saying he had no recollection of the newsletter, hadn't known about the lawsuit and had yet to read the ruling.
Mr. Cuomo's bid for a fourth term as governor was thwarted last year by George E. Pataki, who claimed during the campaign that his Democratic opponent had used state resources for political purposes.
"Praise God!" said Robert Schulz, a citizen activist from near Glens Falls who had brought the suit against the former governor.
"This is a victory for citizen vigilance," said the retired engineer, a nonlawyer who represents himself in court and has repeatedly sued the state over its fiscal practices.
The lawsuit asks the courts to order Mr. Cuomo and his former Economic Development Commissioner, Vincent Tese, to pay the state $1,500 each to offset the newsletter costs.
Mr. Schulz said about 50,000 copies of the newsletter were mailed out by the state's Office of Economic Development.

HEADLINE: U.S. Banks' Holdings of Derivatives Rose in First Quarter

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The derivatives holdings of American banks soared in the first quarter of the year, while the industry continued to profit from the potentially volatile contracts and manage the risks effectively, Federal bank regulators said today.
But the regulators pointed to some problems at smaller banks that bought structured notes, a type of derivative that pays interest according to often complicated schedules. A dozen small banks across the country have realized and unrealized losses on structured notes equal to at least a quarter of their capital, said Douglas E. Harris, the senior deputy comptroller for capital markets. 
 Mr. Harris said Federal examiners would keep a close eye on the finances of those institutions, which he declined to identify at a news conference today. He said it was possible that future moves in interest rates might erase some of the unrealized losses, but said that was unlikely.
Derivatives are contracts based on or derived from other assets like bonds, stocks, oil or foreign currencies; their prices vary with the underlying assets but tend to be far more volatile.
The criticism of derivatives was strong last year, as rising interest rates and reported misconduct by banks produced heavy losses at industrial companies, local governments and mutual funds. But the criticism has died down this year, as long-term interest rates have dropped and a new Republican majority in Congress has shown less interest in the issue.
At the end of the first quarter of 1995 the underlying assets of bank-held derivatives climbed to $18 trillion from $15.8 trillion at the end of last year, the biggest increase ever in a single quarter, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today. But the expansion appears to have come in relatively low-risk derivatives, and not in high-risk, exotic bets on the direction of the bond market or other markets, said Ricki Helfer, chairwoman of the agency.
The figures on the underlying assets of derivatives tend to overstate the actual risk to banks, which tend to hold offsetting bets on the same markets. The agency determined that for those derivatives held for trading purposes and priced at the end of the first quarter, banks had accumulated gains of $289.48 billion and losses of $285.03 billion, for a net gain of $4.44 billion.
In a separate study, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency found that the potential exposure to losses had risen for the nine main banks dealing in derivatives. Those banks had an average exposure equal to 312 percent of their capital, up from 269 percent at the end of last year.
Mr. Harris, the senior deputy comptroller for capital markets, said the higher ratio was not a cause for concern. It partly reflects growing bank profits on derivatives. And many banks have much higher exposures to loan losses, because banks lend much more money than their capital, Mr. Harris noted.
For example, the 25 banks with the largest credit exposures to commercial and industrial loans have an average exposure equal to 862 percent of their capital. The entire banking industry has an exposure to these loans equal to 163 percent of capital.
Mark C. Brickell, a managing director at J. P. Morgan, the parent holding company of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, said the big expansion in derivatives activity was not a cause for alarm. "These contracts were developed to meet the needs of our traditional clients as they manage interest rate and currency exposures that are part of their basic business," he said.
Mr. Harris agreed in general, but expressed concern about one peculiar feature of today's study. Nine big commercial banks now account for 93 percent of all off-balance-sheet derivatives contracts. But structured notes, which appear on balance sheets and have produced some of the heaviest losses, tended to be concentrated among very small banks that were particularly ill-equipped to gauge the risk.
The dozen banks that may lose a quarter of their capital or more on those investments are all tiny, with the largest of them having only $140 million in assets, he said.
Today's study also found that derivatives contracts linked to interest rates accounted for 64.2 percent of the market, while derivatives linked to currencies accounted for another 33.8 percent. The remaining 2 percent consisted of contracts typically based on stocks or commodities.
Citing concerns about derivatives, Moody's Investors Service downgraded its rating of the debt of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation today. Bankers Trust said the downgrading was unwarranted.

HEADLINE: High Court Rules an Award On Age Prejudice Is Taxable

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled today that money received from a successful lawsuit or settlement under the Federal law that bars discrimination on the basis of age is taxable as income.
The 6-to-3 decision resolved, at least in the context of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, a fierce dispute among the lower Federal courts on the taxability of such awards. While the Justices did not address an equally vigorous dispute over the tax treatment of punitive damage awards in negligence cases, there was language in the majority opinion by Justice John Paul Stevens to support the Internal Revenue Service's view that punitive damages are taxable as income to the recipient. 
 The decision today overturned a 1994 ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans. That court had ruled that a $145,629 age discrimination settlement received by a United AirLines pilot should not be counted as gross income.
The award to the pilot, Erich E. Schleier, was part of a $17.2 million settlement the airline, a unit of the UAL Corporation, reached in 1986 with about 100 pilots whom United had forced to retire at age 60. The Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which was passed in 1967, protects employees between the ages of 40 and 70 against discrimination on the job on the basis of their age. The law permits recovery of lost wages or, in the case of willful misconduct by the employer, twice the lost wages.
The I.R.S. has been in litigation with the former United pilots around the country, with differing results, depending on the Federal appellate circuits where the pilots live. Several of the other cases are pending at the Supreme Court as well.
The principal question for the Court today was how to interpret, in light of the age discrimination law, a section of the Internal Revenue code that excludes from the code's otherwise sweeping definition of gross income any damages received "on account of personal injuries or sickness." The pilots have argued that as victims of age discrimination, they suffered personal injuries for which the compensation should be excluded as income under that section of the law.
Rejecting that argument over a vigorous dissent by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, Justice Stevens said that the recovery of back pay under the age discrimination law was a purely economic award intended to make up for lost wages and was not linked to any personal injury the discrimination victim may have suffered.
"The amount of back wages recovered is completely independent of the existence or extent of any personal injury," Justice Stevens said. No matter how injured the employee felt, the financial recovery would be the same and thus could not be described as "on account" of the injury, he explained.
Three years ago, in a decision called United States v. Burke, the Court used similar reasoning, that award under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the general Federal law against workplace discrimination, were taxable as income. Congress has expanded the remedies available under Title VII and the I.R.S. has subsequently taken the view that some damages under the act should not be treated as income. That issue has not yet reached the Court.
In her dissenting opinion, Justice O'Connor, who also dissented in the earlier case, said that "age discrimination inflicts a personal injury." She said the injury to reputation and dignity caused by age discrimination was "no less personal and thus no less worthy of excludability" from gross income than physical injuries for which compensation is not treated as income.
The majority opinion, Commissioner v. Schleier, No. 94-500, was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, Ruth Bader Ginsburg, and Stephen G. Breyer. Justice Antonin Scalia concurred separately. Justices Clarence Thomas and David H. Souter voted in dissent with Justice O'Connor.

HEADLINE: Time Warner To Reduce Debt

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Time Warner Inc. plans to raise money for debt reduction by selling securities tied to its stake in the toy maker Hasbro Inc.
Separately, Time Warner, the big media and entertainment company, said yesterday that it was also offering $500 million of 7.75 percent notes due in 10 years, and planned to use the proceeds to replace debt on which it was paying higher rates of interest. The notes offering is to close on Monday. 
 Time Warner announced its intentions involving its 14 percent stake in Hasbro, which is based in Pawtucket, R.I., in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
No date or price was announced for the sale of the securities tied to Hasbro's stock, but it was believed that Time Warner hoped to raise about $400 million for reducing its debt of $15 billion.
The company said in February that it hoped to reduce its debt by $2 billion to $3 billion by mid-1996 through the sale of noncore assets.
So far, it has raised about $1.3 billion, with agreements to sell assets like its stake in the Six Flags theme parks.

HEADLINE: U.A.W., Ranks Thinning, Elects a Fighter as President

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 14

 BODY:
The United Automobile Workers union today elected its first new president in 12 years -- Stephen P. Yokich, a charismatic leader and deft tactician with a carefully cultivated reputation as a hothead.
Leaders of union locals are hoping that Mr. Yokich, whose outbursts of temper have delighted the rank-and-file and, at times, have kept the auto makers off balance, can reverse the U.A.W.'s steep membership slide and restore its political clout. 
 "I know Yokich will fight back," said Dave Yettaw, president of Local 599 in Flint, Mich., in an interview before the election. Mr. Yettaw, a leader of a dissident movement within the union, has been one of the most tenacious critics of the departing president, Owen F. Bieber, who is retiring.
Last fall, Mr. Yokich, who since 1989 has been in charge of relations with General Motors, authorized Mr. Yettaw to strike G.M. to force it to hire more workers at a gigantic parts-making and car assembly complex in Flint. It was one of five crippling local strikes Mr. Yokich called against G.M. last year.
The U.A.W. shut down the auto maker's operations in Flint, causing plants nationwide that depended on parts manufactured there to close as well. As in the other strikes, G.M. quickly met the union's demands.
Mr. Yokich, who was elected in Anaheim, Calif., at the U.A.W.'s triennial convention, has an impeccable union pedigree. Now 59, he first picketed G.M., famously, at the age of 22 months, in a stroller pushed by his mother, a G.M. worker and, like his father, a U.A.W. member. Both of his grandfathers also belonged to the union.
And among company executives who have bargained opposite him, Mr. Yokich, a former tool-and-die maker, has earned a reputation not merely as a firebrand but also as a savvy bargainer willing to help surmount what he sees as real competitive hurdles for the Big Three auto makers.
Behind the scenes at G.M., Mr. Yokich has cooperated with the company's efforts to become more efficient. On his watch, hourly employment at G.M. fell to 247,000 at the end of April, from 345,000 in 1989, mostly because of retirements. Under the terms of the U.A.W. contract, Mr. Yokich could have forced G.M. to hire one new worker for every two that left. But he did not invoke the rule, a fact the U.A.W prefers not to discuss.
Mr. Yokich had a similar record of cooperation at the Ford Motor Company, where he helped streamline operations when he was in charge of bargaining there in the 1980's. Such assistance from the U.A.W. has been key to restoring the competitiveness of the Big Three.
Although he has long been the leading candidate to succeed Mr. Bieber, Mr. Yokich, a trim man with a toothy grin, has not spelled out his plans. But he hopes to step into a broader role.
"We're more than a collective bargaining agent in this country," Mr. Yokich said in a recent meeting with reporters here. "We're a social movement as well."
The union's biggest challenge, he said, "is in the political arena."
"We have to get John Q. to the polls," he said.
While the U.A.W. was among the group of dissidents that has endorsed John J. Sweeney to replace Lane Kirkland as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Mr. Yokich has not publicly picked a candidate.
Like Mr. Bieber, Mr. Yokich said he favored tightening links with the Canadian Auto Workers union and exploring ties to Mexican workers. "We should have a North American Metal Federation," he said.
Mr. Yokich will need all his skills to deal with the U.A.W.'s myriad woes. For example, with no resolution in sight, the union has been battling Caterpillar Inc. for years to install a pattern contract negotiated at other equipment manufacturers. Union members walked off their jobs there a year ago, and since then the company has earned record profits using replacement workers.
Mr. Yokich must also move quickly to groom his own successor because he will only have time to serve two three-year terms before reaching the union's retirement age of 65. Labor officials at the Big Three are worried that no obvious successor is in sight, which could lead to disruptive battles within the union.
Longer term, Mr. Yokich's challenges are to articulate a clear role for the U.A.W. in a global economy and to convince younger workers who do not remember the battles of the 1930's of the union's relevance. As workers hired during the 1960's retire, the auto makers are expected to replace them with about 200,000 young and better eductated men and women during the next decade.
And his most difficult challenge is to rebuild the union's membership, which has fallen almost in half since 1979, to about 800,000 from 1.5 million.
The U.A.W. has so far failed to organize most of the plants foreign auto makers have built in the United States. Indeed, before a new drive started at Honda's plants in Ohio, the union seemed to have given up on the transplants. The U.A.W. has yet to begin an aggressive drive to organize the BMW plant in Spartanburg, S.C., or the one Mercedes-Benz is building in Tuscaloosa County, Ala.
The greatest erosion in the union's membership has been among suppliers of auto parts. While more than two-thirds of hourly employees at supplier companies were U.A.W. members in the late 1970's, fewer than one quarter are now, said Harley Shaiken, a professor specializing in labor issues at the University of California at Berkeley.
Because so many suppliers pay wages and benefits well below the U.A.W. scale, parts-making operations at the Big Three have trouble competing. Particularly at G.M., this has led to a deep rift with the union over "outsourcing," or contracting with outside suppliers to supply parts once made at G.M.
To avoid giving more ground to the Big Three on the issue of outside contracts, Mr. Yokich has to organize suppliers.
But Mr. Yokich is likely to face nagging distractions closer to home. Labor Department investigators are looking into whether he steered lucrative contracts for eyecare for auto workers to a friend, in exchange for financial benefits. Mr. Yokich denied any impropriety, saying he did not award contracts.
Mr. Bieber said, "Steve is not guilty of anything, and that will be proven."
Mr. Yokich never graduated from college, but pressed his children to do so, and both became lawyers. His daughter, Tracy, is a Democratic member of the Michigan House of Representatives. His son, Stephen, is a lawyer in the U.A.W.'s legislative office in Washington.

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY'S BUDGET: THE COUNCIL;
After Uproar Over Budget, Anger Fades To Handshake

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
For weeks, members of the City Council had roared about unconscionable cuts at the core of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed budget. Demonstrators had marched in fury on the sidewalks outside City Hall, and lobbyists had frantically swarmed through its corridors. The Council Speaker, fearing the worst, had even gone out on a limb and proposed a modest tax increase to head off some of the cuts.
But when the Mayor and Council leaders finally reached agreement on the budget late Tuesday in a friendly handshake beneath the City Hall dome, the scene held an air of unreality. The negotiations had been concluded so swiftly and so amicably -- Speaker Peter F. Vallone called it "the most cooperative budget negotiation we've ever had" -- that many observers wondered if this was still the same budget that cut spending more than any other since World War II. 
"What happened to all the rage?" asked Ronnie M. Eldridge, one of the few Council members who remains angry. "All of a sudden, it just seems to have dissipated."
For as long as anyone can remember, the Council has taken a subordinate role in the complex choreography of a municipal budget. Having been battered by a stagnant economy and a state government not inclined toward generosity, Council leaders argue that the city's financial situation was so withered that there was little room for them to make substantial changes in the Mayor's proposal without bringing government to a halt.
Unlike other legislative bodies, including the State Legislature, the Council is limited in its budgetary powers because the City Charter gives the Mayor sole control of estimating all city revenues, allowing him to cut his estimate and thus the entire budget if he disagrees with the Council's changes in expenses.
Though the Council could have taken a more confrontational approach to the negotiations -- delaying the agreement, distancing itself from the Mayor's enthusiasm for reductions -- that was not the chosen style of Mr. Vallone, the body's ruler. "If all you want to do is call each other names, you lose any chance you have of compromising," he said yesterday. "So we as a policy try to avoid that as much as we can."
Tuesday's cheery handshake ceremony came as a disappointment, if not quite a surprise, to opponents of Mr. Giuliani's proposals. Because of the growing political outcry over the state and city budget cuts, many had expected this to be the year in which the Council did more than simply tinker around the edges.
"The Council gave away its last opportunity to claim its Charter-given powers," said Penelope Pi-Sunyer, director of the City Project, a coalition of advocacy and labor groups. "Maybe they couldn't have gotten a different budget through, but at least they could have taken a stand on it."
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-financed watchdog group, said he had hoped the Council would at least try to challenge some of the shaky assumptions built into the Mayor's budget, like the $600 million in labor savings that remains a goal rather than a fact.
"Like a lot of people, I had hoped that the Council would give life to the concept of co-equality with the Mayor," Mr. Horton said. "But I didn't predict it. The Council turned out to be very much in the historical pattern of basic agreement with the Mayor with some incremental changes designed to protect a few public services."
Mr. Vallone and his colleagues in the Council's leadership spent the day defending themselves from just those criticisms. Not only could they not have done more to reshape the Mayor's budget because of the city's dire financial circumstances, Mr. Vallone said, but in fact the Council this year made the greatest number of changes to a mayoral budget in city history.
"There's never been a budget that I can recall where we've had this much ability to make change," the Council Speaker said in an interview in his office, outside of which lobbyists lingered in the hope of changing his mind. "Now that doesn't mean we could restore all the money the Federal Government and the state took away from us; that's silly. All we can do is, where we were able to have an impact, and we were able to fund things that the city can possibly fund, we did it."
Mr. Vallone pointed to $200 million the Council allocated for repair and reconstruction of school buildings, the largest single change he and his negotiators effected. The Council also persuaded the Mayor to restore about $80 million to a variety of programs that had been chosen for cuts, including significant restorations to youth programs, cultural institutions, child welfare and recycling programs. These were achieved by getting the Mayor to delay his planned cut in the commercial rent tax and to agree on a variety of fiscal gimmicks that he had vowed to oppose.
Several Council leaders insisted that they were amazed by Mr. Giuliani's flexibility in agreeing to even those changes.
"I've been here 18 years, and I've never seen a Mayor so agreeable," said Stanley E. Michaels, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Environmental Protection Committee. "Ed Koch would never have done it. But I think he wanted to show that unlike the Governor, he could bring in a budget on time and without a fight. So he gave in a lot."
The Mayor didn't give in to Mr. Vallone's most creative idea, which was to raise taxes on single-family homes not occupied by their owners, so that suggestion was quickly dropped. Nor, in the end, did Mr. Giuliani change more than about $300 million of his budget to suit the Council, a mere 1 percent of the overall $31.1 billion total. But the Council's leadership was extraordinarily pleased with what they did achieve, and insisted the overall battle is far from over.
"Some people say we used bows and arrows this year instead of bullets," said Kevin McCabe, Mr. Vallone's chief of staff, who did much of the detailed negotiating. "But the good thing about bows and arrows is that you can go pick them up and use them again."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Is a trade war coming? In some industries, it's already here.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
AS Washington and Tokyo duel over autos and the Europeans fidget on the sidelines, there is talk that this ugly tiff between political allies will mark the beginning of a real trade war. But a low-intensity global trade war has been under way for decades, with protectionists from all the economic powers using rigged national laws and sympathetic government bureaucracies to sabotage the foreign competition.
In the United States, the warriors range from flower growers to bicycle makers, and their weapon of choice is laws barring imports below "fair market value" -- a term only lawyers and lobbyists attempt to define. Two current cases, steel pipe for the oil industry and cement for road and home building, show the corrosive effects. 
 Not so long ago, these so-called anti-dumping laws were rationalized as extensions of antitrust law. If foreigners sold their goods here for less than they sold them back home, there was a presumption that they were attempting to knock out the local competition and then raise prices.
Yet such "predatory pricing" has been rare since John D. Rockefeller learned to play monopoly without a board. The standard reason for selling at more than one price is that some consumers are more cost-sensitive than others. That, after all, explains why airlines charge business travelers more than vacationers, and why hardcover books cost three times as much as the paperbacks.
But at least predatory pricing offers a veneer of plausibility to justify government intervention in foreign trade. Current American law, along with the laws of many countries that have imitated American practices, also defines dumping as selling below cost. And because "cost" includes just about anything that the protectionist-leaning bureaucracy of the Commerce Department decides, it is no surprise that Washington finds merit in more than 90 percent of the dumping complaints filed.
In the latest of many cases involving steel, American producers of pipe for the oil and gas industry petitioned for protection from foreign competitors, notably those in Argentina, Mexico and Japan. Japanese pipe exporters didn't bother to defend themselves and withdrew from the market after Commerce tentatively imposed a 44 percent tariff on pipe for lining wells.
To the relief of the State and Treasury Departments, which are eager to see free-market policies in Mexico and Argentina survive the aftershocks of the peso's devaluation, Commerce made a preliminary finding that neither was dumping steel pipe. But Mexican exporters are still holding their breath. The petitioners, it seems, argue that high interest rates in the wake of Mexico's crisis raised production costs -- and therefore the fair market value of Mexican pipe.
Even if Mexico and Argentina get away with nothing more than a stiff bill from their American lawyers, others will pay. With Japan, and most likely Italy, Austria and South Korea out of the American market, the Texas oil economy may not lose 3,000 jobs, as was predicted in a study by three economic consultants from the University of Houston. But any penalty on imports is likely to cut competition among suppliers and raise costs at a time when the domestic oil industry is hurting. "I hate to get in a situation where I'm dependent on one source for critical materials," said Michael Osborne, a senior vice president with Pennzoil.
The stakes are higher in the cement case. Cement is so costly to move by land, notes Robert Roy, the former chief economist for the cement makers' trade group, that the American market is really a half-dozen regional markets. When demand exceeds production capacity within a few hundred miles of the border, the cheapest alternative source is often imports from Canada or Mexico. Indeed, Mexico's Cemex, the largest cement company in North America, built capacity near the border in the 1980's in expectation of serving the booming markets of the Sun Belt.
But domestic cement producers along the southern tier of states won a dumping case in 1990, sticking Cemex with a 66 percent tariff that effectively drove it out of their regional market. Mexico won a ruling from the world trade body in 1992 that the tariff violated Mexico's due process. But the case drags on, now as much a tussle over jurisdiction as trade equities.
Meanwhile, Southern states are staring at rising cement prices -- as much as 20 percent in the last year. And Mexico City is steaming over the barrier that keeps one of the country's most efficient industries from exporting to its partner in the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The good news is that low-intensity trade wars rarely escalate. The bad news is that there is a new skirmish every month or two, raising prices for American consumers and undermining America's global leadership by confirming the most cynical views of American foreign policy goals.

HEADLINE: Bureaucrat-Bashing Can Lead to Tragedy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In light of the terrorist bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal building, "The Bureaucracy: What's Left to Shrink?" (Week in Review, June 11) highlights both the travesty and tragedy of bureaucracy-bashing. 
 The American public, with a good deal of help from politicians and the media, has made the Federal bureaucracy the scapegoat for many of our social, economic and personal woes. Pundits of every type have made careers by perpetuating stereotypes and falsehoods built on myths of a growing bureaucratic Leviathan that pathologically abuses its power. In its bowels reside individuals variously characterized as incompetent, inept and even evil.
The fact you highlight, that by any significant measure the size of the Federal bureaucracy is shrinking, points to the reality of a public sector work force that is dedicated and hard-working. Those of us who study and work with public administrators know that they are increasingly overburdened and underappreciated.
The tragedy is that popular myths that feed the scapegoating also feed hatreds that can lead to terrorist attacks such as occurred on April 19. Those scholars, politicians and journalists who inadvertently help sustain those myths must face their responsibilities and help put a stop to the madness.
 
MEL DUBNICK
Prof. of Public Administration
and Political Science
Rutgers University
Newark, June 11, 1995

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Retreat In Quiet Day After Gains On Tuesday

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday in quiet trading, as some investors sold to consolidate the large gains they had made in Tuesday's huge market advance.
Certainty that the Fed will ease sometime soon has given way to uncertainty as to whether it will act soon enough to keep interest rates from rising, traders said. 
 Douglas Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said, "The market has already priced in a decent amount of Fed easing, so traders and investors are reluctant to push things much further before they have clear confirmation that an easing is actually in the works."
The 30-year bond fell 12/32 , to a price of 11322/32 for a yield of 6.57 percent, up from 6.54 percent in the previous session. Shorter-maturity bills were mixed, with the three-month issue unchanged at 5.43 percent and the six-month maturity up 1 basis point, to 5.38 percent.
None of the economic data released yesterday had much impact on prices. April business inventories showed a gain of eight-tenths of 1 percent, and first-quarter nonfarm productivity was revised to a gain of 2.7 percent instead of the rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent previously reported.
Traders said that despite yesterday's drop, the market remained positive in tone. "There is only so far you can take the market without concrete proof the Fed is going to ease," Astrid Adolfson said.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said it was not easy for fund managers and investors when markets go from overbought to oversold and back again in a few days.
Anthony Dwyer, chief market strategist at Josepthal, Lyon & Ross, said the outlook at present was for "a slow growth economy, low inflation, and a low interest rate environment, which is favorable for returns on both stock and bond investments."
He added, "I still have priced in a Fed easing down the road." He put it at "25 to 50 basis points," or a quarter to a half percentage point.
Mr. Dwyer changed his asset allocations yesterday. "In January I took 15 percent out of cash and added it to bonds," he said. "And now I believe that the bulk of the appreciation in the longer maturities is behind us, and therefore, we took 15 percent out of bonds and added it to stocks because we think the lower interest rates since January will help prevent the economy from moving into a recession." His current asset allocation includes 65 percent stocks, 20 percent bonds and 15 percent cash.
"From a yield standpoint bonds are still attractive," Mr. Dwyer said, "but I believe the best total return will be in stocks. That's not to say I don't like bonds; if I didn't I wouldn't have any money in them."
Meanwhile, the corporate debt market, aided by the low interest rate environment, has become crowded with borrowers. The Tennessee Valley Authority priced a $2 billion global bond issue yesterday through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers International (Europe) and Deutsche Bank A.G. London.
Time Warner Inc. priced $500 million of 10-year noncallable notes through Morgan Stanley & Company. The issue was given a 7.75 percent coupon and priced at 99.314 to yield 7.85 percent, or about 170 basis points more than the Treasury's 10-year note. By late in the day yesterday the yield on the 10-year Treasury was 6.14 percent.
Underwriters said the issue was split rated, with Moody's Investors Service giving it a junk bond rating of Ba-1, while Standard & Poor's Corporation gave it an investment grade of BBB-.
Time Warner joined dozens of borrowers, including Viacom Inc., Rockwell International and Eli Lilly & Company, that have sold more than $50 billion of bonds since April to take advantage of a rally in Treasury bonds.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower Against the Mark As German Rates Unchanged

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark yesterday after the Bundesbank left German interest rates unchanged at its biweekly meeting on monetary policy.
Some market participants said they had expected the Bundesbank to cut rates to counter the slower economic growth in Germany. Lower interest rates often hurt a currency by making deposits in the country's banks less attractive. 
 "The Bundesbank's decision was a mild surprise, and that hurt the dollar," said John McCarthy, manager of foreign exchange at ING Capital Markets in New York.
Many analysts say economic growth in western Germany will slow to 2 percent or less this year from 2.4 percent last year, as the strong mark and slowing growth elsewhere in the world hurt German exports.
But in explaining the decision by the Bundesbank not to cut rates yesterday, the president of the central bank, Hans Tietmeyer, said, "We don't see any economic dip here."
As a result, the Bundesbank left its discount rate, which acts as a floor for money market rates, at 4 percent. The German central bank last cut the rate on March 30.
"There had been a little bit of pent up expectation that they could do something on rates, and there was a knee-jerk reaction after they didn't," said Jonathon Griggs, currency adviser at Barclays Bank in London.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.4003 German marks from 1.4088 marks on Tuesday. The dollar slipped to 84.39 Japanese yen from 84.60 yen.
While the enthusiasm about President Clinton's plan to balance the budget helped to lift the dollar on Tuesday, speculation that Congress would not agree to the plan weighed on the dollar yesterday, traders and analysts said.
"The overall market reaction was unfavorable" to Clinton's plan, said John Rothfield, international economist at Nationsbanc-CRT in Chicago. With the Clinton proposal at odds with those advanced by the Republicans in Congress, "it looks like we'll get gridlock," he added.
The prospects for a balanced budget would help the dollar by instilling confidence in American assets. Mr. Rothfield said the dollar could fall to 1.35 marks and 80 yen by the end of this month if Mr. Clinton and Congress did not agree on a deficit plan.

HEADLINE: New Data Offer More Signals of Slowdown in Economy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Businesses stockpiled more goods in the spring as consumer spending slowed, new Government figures showed today.
Analysts said the numbers were just the latest signs pointing to production cutbacks and weak growth. 
 The Commerce Department said that inventories rose in April for the 13th straight month, climbing eight-tenths of a percent, led by a buildup in interest-sensitive durable goods.
Meanwhile, sales fell four-tenths of a percent in April. That came after a tenth of a percent decline in March and marked the first time in more than four years that sales have slipped for two consecutive months.
The inventory-to-sales ratio rose to 1.41, the highest it has been since July 1994 when it was at the same level. The last time it was higher was November 1993 when the ratio was 1.42. The latest figure means it would take 1.41 months to exhaust stockpiles at the April sales rate.
Strength in spending has kept inventories at relatively low levels in relation to sales, even as stocks accumulated rapidly.
In an encouraging development on the inflation front, the Labor Department reported that the productivity of American workers increased 2.7 percent at an annual rate in the first quarter of 1995.
The department also said that unit labor costs -- typically two-thirds of the cost of a product -- rose 1.6 percent or less than half as much as a month-old estimate of 3.4 percent.
Analysts said the reports bolstered the case for slow growth and low inflation.
"An inventory correction will probably stretch over several quarters, rather than being concentrated into a single period," said Bruce Steinberg, an Merrill Lynch economist.
Some commentators predict the economy will be flat or even contract in the second quarter. But many expect a rebound in the second half of the year, even if the Federal Reserve leaves short-term interest rates unchanged.
"We are making progress in eliminating unwanted inventories," said Astrid Adolfson of MCM MoneyWatch, a New York financial advisory firm. "It's still plausible to have a soft landing, even if the second quarter is negative."
The latest inventory gain, roughly in line with analysts' expectations, was led by a 1 percent increase in durable goods, particularly autos. Durable goods inventories have surged 10.8 percent since April 1994.
Inventories of nondurable goods like food and fuel rose five-tenths of a percent and were 6.6 percent higher than a year ago.
The Commerce Department said inventories totaled a seasonally adjusted $949.9 billion in April, up from $942.7 billion. Inventories in April were 9.1 percent higher than a year earlier. Sales in April were at a seasonally adjusted $672.2 billion, down from $674.8 billion.
Retail inventories rose to $298.9 billion in April, up nine-tenths of a percent. Stockpiles at the wholesale level were up to $246.4 billion, a 1.2 percent increase. Manufacturers' inventories rose sixth-tenths of a percent, to $404.6 billion.
Business sales in April at the retail level fell three-tenths of a percent, to $192.5 billion. At the wholesale level, they rose five-tenths of a percent, to $184.1 billion. Factory sales fell nine-tenths of a percent, to $295.6 billion.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Prices of Corn Futures Climb On Forecasts of Dry Weather

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Corn prices surged yesterday after forecasts for hot, dry weather in Midwest growing regions increased the chances of a crop damage and further reduced yields.
Wheat and soybeans prices were also sharply higher. On other commodity markets, copper prices and crude and gasoline futures prices advanced. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 1.09 points, to 233.77. 
 Meteorologists are calling for temperatures in the mid- to upper-90s through next week in the Midwest with little chance of rain. Prolonged heat could destroy tender crops budding up to a month late because of spring flooding in the Midwest.
Traders bet that with yields already reduced by the planting delays, the American harvest this fall will be more than 20 percent below last year's and will not be able to meet growing overseas demand.
"We're on the fine edge here of tremendous world demand and the world's largest producer is watching supplies be steadily eroded," said Gerald Zusel, vice president for grains at E. D. & F. Man International Futures Inc.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, corn for July delivery rose 5 cents, to $2.7625 a bushel, the highest for the contract closest to delivery since June 17, 1994, when it closed at $2.8325. July wheat rose 7.75 cents, to $3.8675 a bushel; July soybeans rose 5.75 cents, to $5.855 a bushel.
The weather could once more force the Agriculture Department to reduce its estimates of the corn crop harvest, now predicted to come in at 7.9 billion bushels.
"The government tends to be conservative on those crop reports, and they were assuming normal weather for the rest of the summer," Mr. Zusel said.
Copper prices rose after the Commodity Exchange of New York reported yet another drop in its stocks.
The exchange's stocks have fallen to their lowest level in more than five years, and stocks on the London Metal Exchange also have fallen recently. That has spurred fears of short-term supply tightness despite evidence that the economy is slowing, said Stephen Platt, an analyst with Dean Witter, Discover & Company in Chicago.
The June copper contract rose 1.95 cents, to $1.353 a pound.
Gasoline prices advanced on the New York Mercantile Exchange on news that five refineries in Corpus Christi, Tex., were under environmental restrictions to comply with air-quality targets. July unleaded gasoline rose 1.07 cents, to 62 cents a gallon, the highest price for the contract since May 25. The July crude contract rose 14 cents, to $19.05 a barrel.

HEADLINE: Flea Market in Zoning Peril

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

 BODY:
THE Annex Antiques Fair and Flea Market is a shopping sideshow that has blossomed every Saturday and Sunday for 27 years on empty parking lots in the West 20's like a ragtag village of Brigadoon. But it may be dismantled in its present form under a proposal to rezone a stretch of the Avenue of the Americas.
The proposal calls for changing the designation of the blocks flanking the avenue from West 24th to West 31st Streets from manufacturing to commercial-residential. This would permit the construction of stores and apartments on the empty lots. Twenty percent of the apartments would be reserved for low or moderate-income tenants. 
 "Nothing is forever," said William Bernstein, a spokesman for the Department of City Planning, which put a preliminary stamp of approval on the plan on April 24 before sending it to Community Boards 4 and 5 for review. "Restaurants close, businesses close. There's nothing to guarantee that the flea market will continue to exist."
Board 4 approved the plan by 31 to 3, while Board 5 endorsed it by 36 to 0. But one caveat was that future development consider preservation of the Annex and the nearby Flower District.
More than 300 vendors take over a handful of lots between 24th and 27th Streets, said Alan Boss, who manages the flea market. An additional 125 vendors set up shop inside a parking garage on West 25th Street. Mr. Boss estimates that the vendors take in more than $500,000 each weekend.
Though the its bargain prices may be more fable than fact these days, the market still provides what Christopher Gable, a Pennsylvania perfumer who is searching for the perfect Humber touring bicycle, calls "one of New York City's rites of passage."
"It's as much a social event as a shopping experience," he added. The Annex has become an essential hunting ground for shoppers from around the world who hope to spot the perfect bibelot or catch sight of celebrities like Marisa Tomei, Barbra Streisand, the dandified photographers McDermott and McGough, and Philip Van Renssalaer, the dashing writer and cafe-society fixture.
Under discussion is the possibility of moving the flea market to an unused pier in the West 20's. "But that's the least attractive option," said Jack Goldstein, a chairman of Community Board 5, "because part of the attractiveness of the flea market is its centrality. It's not segregated from the fabric of the city."
The neighborhood was a manufacturing center from the late 19th-century through the 1940's. The factories have long since moved on, leaving behind a motley assortment of semivacant loft buildings, warehouses and parking lots.
Rezoning the area has been considered for more than a decade. But an application presented to the Planning Department was recently certified, which brings the notion one step closer to fruition. The application was presented by Leonard Adell, a developer and local property owner. If approved, Mr. Bernstein said, it would provide property owners, including those holding title to the flea-market lots, with an incentive to build potentially profitable apartments and stores. "Whether or not they would choose to take advantage of them would be their decision," he added.
Mr. Adell's secretary said he was out of town until next week and unavailable for comment.
Jane R. Crotty, the executive director of the 23d Street Association, a civic group, said it approved of the rezoning plan, which now enters a seven-month review before moving to the City Council for final approval. But given the labyrinthine procedures governing rezoning and development, no one familiar with the proposal expects the flea market to be disrupted until 2004.
"There is a great need for homes here, and providing commercial space will enhance the development of the area, which is not a bad thing," said Ms. Crotty, who enthusiastically noted that new book stores, home-design centers and clothing shops had revitalized the avenue below 23d Street.
"In all likelihood, a developer will develop the flea-market site," Mr. Boss said. But the market is expected to survive in one form or another.
"It's a powerful tourist attraction," Mr. Goldstein said. "The novelty of the experience has imprinted itself on people's imaginations." He added that the market has brought the neighborhood "a certain cachet" not unlike the Bermondsey flea market in London and the Marche aux Puces in Paris.
Mr. Goldstein's words will come as a relief to many flea-market habitues.
"I certainly hope it doesn't disappear," said Cynthia Byrnes, an advertising executive who lives in Westport, Conn., and often rises at dawn to drive to the flea market. "What would I do with my weekends if it went away?"
Virginia Pao, an executive at a crystal company, depends on the market for fine costume jewelry made in the 1950's. "It would devastate my wardrobe if the flea market closed," she said. "You go there, rummage around, come up with something great and then take it to breakfast or brunch for show-and-tell. That's the ritual."

HEADLINE: SENIOR CLASS;
On Town Councils, Voices of Experience

BYLINE: By ROBERT W. STOCK 

 BODY:
WE were just about to put a no-parking zone near the school," said John F. Petitt, the Mayor of Westhampton Beach, L.I. "Then Mark Raynor spoke up." Mr. Raynor, a member of the Village Board of Trustees, pointed out that parents who picked up children would have to park on a heavily traveled street nearby. "So we put off the vote," Mayor Petitt continued. "The thing is, he has kids at that school and he knows. The rest of us are a little past that."
Mr. Raynor is 40. The Mayor and the three other trustees range from 67 to 76. In that regard, Westhampton Beach, an oceanside town of 1,500 full-time residents, is riding a wave. All across the nation, particularly in small and medium-size towns, more and more older people are being elected to town councils. 
 The gradual aging of the councils is cited by students of town government and in surveys by organizations like the National League of Cities, which found that between 1979 and 1989, the percentage of council members age 60 or older had grown from 14 to 24. Among the 8,700 council members in the league's current data base who provided birth dates, 29 percent were 60 or older.
There are many reasons for the trend, experts say, including the growing demands on council members' time, something most retired people have in abundance, and it is expected to continue. Town government may never be the same.
"Some older people run for the Council because they don't want the city to do anything," said Elizabeth D. Rhea, the Mayor of Rock Hill, S.C., since 1986, who is 65 herself and clearly a doer. During her tenure, she has brought in new businesses to replace departed textile mills, and the unemployment rate in the town of 45,000 has gone from 17 percent to 3 percent.
"On my last Council," she said, "four of the seven of us were retired, and two of them were elected on a single issue -- they were opposed to our building a sports complex. Well, we had a lot of split votes, but we built it, and those two had a real education. By the time they left the Council, they'd decided the complex was a good idea."
One decided advantage older people offer councils, said James H. Svara, 52, a political scientist at North Carolina State University in Raleigh, is their greater life experience. "It gives them a longer-term perspective," he said. "When you combine that with the fact that they're healthier and more energetic than they used to be, their greater presence on councils is just logical."
Last year, Lyle Sumek of Longwood, Fla., was a consultant to 35 town councils, many of which required his services because their members were having trouble working together. One problem: age discrepancies.
"Some of the differences are minor," he said. "A lot of the 40-year-olds come to meetings in shorts and a polo shirt. They want to be comfortable. The elderly come dressed in a professional manner -- they're more concerned with the council's public image. That can create some stress."
But other differences go to the heart of council business. "Older members have a trust of authority," said Mr. Sumek, who is 50, "so they want thorough research and recommendations from their staff. Younger folks have a greater distrust of government. They want options, not recommendations, and they want to go out and check the potholes, not listen to a report about them. And where older people are comfortable with compromise, the younger ones say: 'Why do we have to compromise? We can push it through.' "
One recent Friday, in a meeting room of the firehouse-cum-village-hall in Westhampton Beach, Arma Andon, a 76-year-old trustee, held a training session for a dozen Department of Public Works employees. "Let's say you're doing repairs on Dune Road and a tank truck turns over," he said. "What's the procedure?"
"Run?" a young worker asked.
Mr. Andon was the Mayor of Westhampton Beach for eight years before stepping down last year and running for trustee. "On my first board, I was the only one 65 or over," he said. "Gradually, the number's been growing."
Trustees are rarely idle. Rosaria Del Bene, 75, goes on running Ria's Beauty Shop as she has for 57 years; she was the moving force behind the local senior center. Ora Belle (Ridgie) Barnett, 67, has a company that sells business forms; she has presided over the planting and computerized listing of hundreds of trees in the village.
And Mr. Raynor, the 40-year-old trustee, is a patrolman with the Southampton, L.I., Police Department. Both he and the other trustees say there is no generational friction on the board, but he does see himself as different: "I'm out there every day, so I can see how problems come about and how to fix them. I'm inclined to take a harder look at things than a retired person."
Mr. Svara, the political scientist, sees the trend toward elderly council members as a reflection of the changed nature of the council.
"When you withdraw Federal assistance from housing rehabilitation and neighborhood improvement and other programs," he says, "it means the councils have to find ways to come up with funds themselves. At the same time, national groups are bringing pressure on the local level over the environment, gun control and other issues. Suddenly, councils have to deal with demonstrations and with more meetings. How can younger people balance that with the demands of their families and their jobs?"
Yet another reason is offered by Michelle Frisby of the International City/County Management Association: no civics classes. "We used to teach kids how their local government worked and teach them about civic responsibility," she said. "Like most baby boomers, I never had that in all 12 years of public school." Mayor Rhea of Rock Hill adds: "Younger people are like a sort of silent majority, standing on the sidelines, not wanting to get involved. It's frightening."
So older people are filling the gap. Mayor Petitt, 73, of Westhampton Beach ran for office, he said, "because I'm not a golfer or fisherman and not one to sit around and do nothing -- and because I wanted to give something back."

HEADLINE: Tansi, Congolese Novelist, Is Dead at 48

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Marcel Sony Labou Tansi, a novelist considered by many to be Central Africa's greatest writer, died yesterday in Foufoundou, a remote village in the Congo countryside where he had gone for treatment of AIDS. He was 48.
The cause of death was complications from AIDS, including pneumonia, The Associated Press reported, quoting Eugene Banguissa, the former Mayor of Brazzaville, the capital. Mr. Tansi's wife, Pierrette, a nurse, had died four days earlier, also from AIDS complications, The A.P. added. 
 Mr. Tansi's novels, written in French, were known for their biting satirical treatments of colonialist Africa and the dictators who arrived after independence.
Critics have said that his books are difficult to read because they employ complicated puns, symbolism and imagery to reinforce his primary message -- that Africa's colonial masters exploited not just the continent's economic resources but also its spirit. But the novels had a great impact in French-speaking Africa.
Mr. Tansi's best-known novels are "Life and a Half" (1979), "The Shameful State" (1981) and "The People Before" (1983). "The Seven Solitudes of Lorsa Lopez" is to be published in September.
"The Antipeople," published in 1988, received positive reviews in the United States. It is a bleak account of a former soccer idol whose life is ruined by a young girl who commits suicide after he refuses to sleep with her. Mr. Tansi used the plot to reveal some of the darker elements of life in Zaire and neighboring Angola.
Mr. Tansi was a member of the opposition party and who won a seat in the National Assembly in 1993. But he refused to attend any legislative sessions out of defiance of the Government.
He and his wife returned to Congo in April from Paris, where they had been seeking treatment for AIDS. They moved to Foufoundou, which can be reached only by a long hike through a forest, and tried herbal medicine and ritual ceremonies that mixed African traditional healing and Christian evangelism in an attempt to heal themselves.
Mrs. Tansi continued to deteriorate after they arrived in Foufoundou, but in the weeks before his death, Mr. Tansi had seemed more robust.
While in Paris, Mr. Tansi finished a new work, "The Beginnings of Pain," which he said his publishers had initially refused to put out because of what they said was an excessively harsh tone toward France, which was once Congo's colonial ruler. He said a new nonfiction work, "La Cosa Nostra," would argue for a Marshall Plan for Africa.
"Africa is the only continent left that has not found its way," Mr. Tansi said in a recent interview. "We have this incredible wealth, of resources and of spirit, but outsiders like France are just robbing us while blessing our dictators."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marcel Sony Labou Tansi, at his village in Congo a few weeks ago. (Robert Grossman for The New York Times)
