HEADLINE: Cyprus Shores Wash Dirty Money

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: LIMASSOL, Cyprus

 BODY:
The offshore banking system on this Mediterranean island is being used to violate United Nations sanctions imposed on the rump Yugoslavia and to launder hundreds of millions of dollars made illicitly in Russia, say Western diplomats, bankers and even some of those involved in the business.
About three dozen of the 500 Serbian companies set up in Cyprus are believed to have links to the Government in Yugoslavia, which now consists of Serbia and Montenegro. 
 The companies are buying oil and other goods and then shipping them to Serbia through neighboring countries in trade worth about $10 million a week, the diplomats and bankers say.
Money is also pouring into Cyprus from Russian racketeers, sometimes in suitcases filled with hundreds of thousands of dollars. The money is usually deposited in accounts here and then transferred to accounts in Switzerland, Germany and Britain to mask its origin.
"The Serbian businessmen are intent on doing business either with Serbia or as middlemen for Russian companies trying to enter the European market," a Western diplomat said. "The Russians are often involved in shadier deals."
Russian arms dealers, for instance, use Cypriot investment laws, which allow transactions to be kept secret, to sell weapons and other military equipment to Iraq, in violation of United Nations sanctions. They launder the profits through the companies they have set up in Cyprus, said bankers who spoke on the condition that they not be identified.
The Greek Cypriots who dominate the internationally recognized Government of the island, which is divided with Turkish Cypriots, are seen as friendly to the Serbs and the Russians because of their shared Eastern Orthodox religion.
"Cypriots have welcomed Yugoslav people as offshore entrepreneurs while other countries have not," said the head of a major European bank in Nicosia, the capital. "Serbian businessmen have a terrible problem getting visas to other countries, but not to Cyprus."
American officials say senior Cypriot politicians and executives have even used their businesses as fronts for Serbian companies seeking to break the sanctions on Yugoslavia.
One of those Cypriot politicians, they say, is Tassos Papadopoulos, chairman of Parliament's foreign affairs committee, whose law firm was named recently by the United States Treasury as a front for Serbian businesses.
American officials also contend that senior Serbian officials have set up companies here on behalf of the Belgrade Government. The Serbs include Borka Vucic, managing director of the Cyprus Offshore Banking Unit for the Government-owned Udruzena Beogradska Banka, and Edo Alibegovic, a former official at the state-owned Yugo-Metal who now runs Metham (Overseas) Ltd. in Cyprus.
Cypriot officials bristle at the suggestion that they have lost control of the activities of the approximately 19,000 companies registered here, 18,000 of which are little more than brass plates on a door.
When the sanctions were imposed on Yugoslavia in 1992 because of its support of the ethnic Serbs fighting the Bosnian Government, the Cypriot authorities curtailed the activities of the three Serbian banks here and froze some $300 million in Serbian assets.
"These Serbian offshore enterprises are closely monitored," said Andreas Philippou, the chief senior manager of the Central Bank of Cyprus. "They are allowed to carry on activities not related to Yugoslavia. They have funds belonging to parties and persons not subject to the sanction."
The Central Bank also recently ordered a freeze on new Russian-owned bank branches. Cash deposits and transfers of more than $10,000 have to be reported, although several bankers said the requirement is largely ignored.
Cypriot officials also point out that the sanctions permit Serbs who do not have contact with the Belgrade Government or its enterprises to do business with other countries, including those from which the goods are known to be shipped illegally to Serbia.
Western diplomats said many of the Serbian companies, often subsidiaries of large Government corporations, were run by close associates of the President of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic. But they said the network of Serbian companies violating the embargo was worldwide, and they could not estimate what percentage of the illegal trade was handled through Cyprus.
Russian and Serbian business executives are reluctant to talk about their activities. Most immediately cut off the questioning.
"We don't want to publicize that we are here," said one of the managers of East Point Holdings Ltd. "We don't want to talk." The company, in Nicosia, is listed by the United States Treasury as one involved in breaking the embargo on Yugoslavia.
The few company officials listed as acting on behalf of the Serbs who would comment reacted angrily to the charges.
"This is a stupid, irresponsible act by the American Government, thought up by some 15th-rate Washington bureaucrat trying to make a name for himself," said Mr. Papadopoulos, whose law firm is alleged to be violating the embargo. "I don't care about these accusations. I don't have anything to explain."
Ivan Mrkic, the charge d'affaires at the Yugoslav Embassy, said about 5,000 Serbs live in Cyprus.
"Most of them are in the offshore industry," he said as he escorted the Mayor of Belgrade on a visit. "They are doing very well. We are thinking of setting up our own offshore industry in Montenegro once the sanctions are lifted."
Many of the Russians and Serbs who have moved their families to Cyprus have bought up numerous villas around Limassol, a major port, as well as luxury cars. They often pay in cash, Cypriot real estate agents say.
"We just built 73 villas in our new Santa Barbara village," said a developer, Demetrakis M. Zavos. "Most of the houses were bought by Russian and Serbian businessmen. These offshore companies give us a lot of clients."
Russian businessmen can often be found in the cabarets that line the coastal strip, many of which feature Russian dancers. Menus are often in Russian, and Cypriot newspapers now have Russian-language sections. A weekly Russian-language newspaper and a Serbo-Croatian newspaper are published on the island.
About 2,000 Russian-owned companies operate in Cyprus. Some of the Russian business executives here are legitimate, fleeing the plunging ruble, rising crime and the faltering Russian banking system.
But Western diplomats say they believe that others are part of Russia's mafia -- including managers of state-run businesses who sell oil and minerals under the table or officials who divert state funds to their foreign bank accounts.
The Serbs seem to keep a lower profile. The companies identified as having direct links to the Yugoslav Government buy trucks, machinery, consumer goods and oil through front operations. The goods are shipped to countries that border Serbia, and are then transported into Serbia.
Several Serbian companies listed as suspect by the United States Treasury have branches in Cyprus, including Yugo-Arab, a firm that diplomats here say has bought arms for the Yugoslav Army.
Cypriot bankers estimate that $50 million in Serbian funds was brought here in the months before Yugoslavia split up in 1991. Beogradska Banka, which set up operations in Cyprus in 1988, is the offshore branch of Beobanka, Serbia's biggest bank. Two smaller Serbian banks, Karic Bank and Beogradska Kreditna Banka, set up offshore branches here three years ago.
Many Serbian business executives and bankers here worked in state-owned enterprises or for the Belgrade Government, but then set up offshore companies after the embargo. Cypriot officials said several hundred million dollars was transferred out of Cyprus to banks in Europe after Cyprus agreed to try to enforce the United Nations sanctions.
"We do several million dollars' worth of business" in violation of the sanctions, said a Cypriot employee of a Serbian company in Limassol, who spoke on condition that neither she nor the company be identified.
"We buy many items, such as pharmaceutical products from Germany and Switzerland, and use a bill of lading for another country near Serbia, usually Greece. It is very efficient, very easy and we don't worry about anyone interfering in our business."

HEADLINE: Administration Proposes Federal Regulation of Health Insurance

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today proposed Federal regulation of private health insurance to make coverage more available and affordable.
But it refused to give any details about the other, more contentious half of the health care policy that President Clinton outlined on Tuesday. Under that policy, the Government would sharply restrict Medicare payments to doctors, hospitals and nursing homes. 
 The proposals are all part of Mr. Clinton's new plan to balance the Federal budget in 10 years. "The key to long-term deficit reduction is controlling health care costs through health care reform," he said, and he described his proposals as "a serious step" toward that goal.
Since the demise last year of his ambitious plan to redesign the nation's health care system, Mr. Clinton has suggested that more modest, incremental changes would be feasible. But until this week, he had not advanced any proposals of his own.
Health insurance is now regulated mainly by the states. But Federal regulation appears likely because Republicans and Democrats in Congress support the idea, much of the health insurance industry accepts it and the Clinton Administration wants it. Administration officials said they could agree with Congress on the shape of legislation, though the details may prove tricky because insurance regulation is technical and complicated.
Under the President's new proposals, insurers could not deny coverage to people with medical problems, and they would have to renew policies regardless of the subscriber's medical condition. Insurers would have to offer coverage to small employers and their workers, and the Federal Government would limit insurers' ability to vary or increase premiums because of the subscribers' claims history.
Mr. Clinton also proposes Federal subsidies to make insurance more affordable for people who lose their jobs. Under current law, employers must offer coverage to employees for at least 18 months after they lose jobs. But the employers are not required to pay premiums for these workers, and the premiums are often more than the jobless workers can afford.
The Health Insurance Association of America, which mobilized opposition to Mr. Clinton's health plan last year with a series of television advertisements, welcomed Mr. Clinton's new proposals, which are much more modest.
Bill Gradison, president of the association, said: "Overall, I have a very positive reaction to what the President proposed. It greatly increases the chances of needed health reform legislation becoming law this year. Many of the President's proposals mirror proposals in our own legislative agenda."
Mr. Clinton left many unanswered questions about his proposals for Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for the elderly, and Medicaid, the program for the poor. His proposed cuts in projected Medicare spending -- totaling $124 billion, or 6.6 percent, over seven years -- are about half as deep as those endorsed by Republicans in Congress.
But the impact on doctors, hospitals and nursing homes might be almost as severe. Most of Mr. Clinton's cuts fall on such providers. He would not increase premiums, deductibles or other charges for beneficiaries. Indeed, he said his plan would impose "no new cost increases on Medicare beneficiaries."
Dr. James S. Todd, president of the American Medical Association, criticized that aspect of Mr. Clinton's plan, saying it did not call for "shared sacrifice."
At a White House briefing today, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, was asked to specify how the Administration would limit the growth of Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals. "I can't do that because we are not going into detail on specific cuts," she said.
Dr. Shalala said Administration officials could lay out details later, in negotiations with Congress. Whether Mr. Clinton will submit a detailed legislative proposal -- a standard test of serious political intent in Washington -- is unclear.
Richard J. Davidson, president of the American Hospital Association, said: "We are terribly disappointed with the President's proposals. He had an opportunity to push for major restructuring of the Medicare program, but he didn't do it. His proposals are not part of overall health care reform, but are used mainly to reduce the deficit."
Mr. Davidson said that 1,500 hospitals derived at least 75 percent of their revenue from Medicare and Medicaid, and he predicted that "some of those hospitals will bleed to death" under the plans advanced by the President and Congress.
Mr. Clinton's proposal for Medicaid is a turning point in the 30-year history of the program. He would impose limits on the annual growth in per capita Medicaid costs.
Governors have long sought some type of ceiling on Medicaid spending; costs have quadrupled in the last decade and are now growing by 10 percent a year.
Mr. Clinton's proposal is much different from the lump-sum payments, or block grants, favored by Republican leaders in Congress. A block grant gives each state a fixed amount of money, with no allowance for population growth. Mr. Clinton's proposal to limit the per capita growth of Medicaid would, by definition, allow for population growth. It would probably save less money than a block grant but would be easier to carry out and less disruptive, state officials said.
In his effort to improve access to private health insurance, Mr. Clinton proposed increasing the Federal income tax deduction for the insurance costs of self-employed people and their dependents. Congress recently increased the allowance so self-employed people can deduct 30 percent of such costs, up from 25 percent. Mr. Clinton would allow self-employed people to deduct 50 percent of health insurance costs.
In addition, Mr. Clinton would allow small businesses to obtain insurance through the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. The program offers scores of private health plans to active and retired Federal workers and their dependents. Mr. Clinton said that proposal would increase the purchasing power of small businesses. But he said the premiums of such businesses would be calculated separately, so they would not affect the premiums of Federal employees.
Dr. Shalala said that the architects of the President's original health plan, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Ira C. Magaziner, helped prepare the new proposals. But other Administration officials said that Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the head of the National Economic Council, had the primary responsibility this year.

LENGTH: 514 words

HEADLINE: Rendezvous in Halifax

 BODY:
Every year the leaders of the seven major industrial countries gather for a summit meeting, whether needed or not, and issue a communique long on vague promises and short on concrete commitments. This year's meeting, which begins today in Halifax, Nova Scotia, may prove a modest exception. A draft of the final statement includes some proposals that deserve support.
The first would enhance the role of the International Monetary Fund in monitoring and responding to economic problems that develop in member countries. The need for more engagement was shown when the fund, along with the United States, bailed out Mexico and prevented financial turbulence from spreading through Latin America. 
 The seven leaders are likely to urge the fund to develop standards for monitoring financial data from member nations that would provide early warning signs of trouble. Monitoring itself is a useful, though limited, step. It would be even better for nations to publish the data, which the leaders will urge, and for the fund to make public its analysis. That way private investors could, by withdrawing funds, discipline countries that pursue imprudent policies. So far the fund's members have rejected public scrutiny. The leaders will also propose giving the monetary fund more money to aid countries under financial siege, a need highlighted by the drain on the fund's reserves from the Mexican bailout.
Beyond these measures, the draft obliquely calls for studying a reform proposed by Prof. Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard. He wants the fund to act more like a bankruptcy judge and less like a lender using taxpayer money. The idea is to give the fund the authority to hold foreign creditors at bay, while issuing guarantees that make it possible for private lenders to provide money to a bankrupt government while it puts economic reforms in place. The idea is attractive, but needs study before it can be translated into a workable plan.
Another useful step the leaders might take is to provide Ukraine additional money to support the impressive market reforms it initiated last year. The leaders pledged $4 billion to Ukraine last year if it adopted fund-approved reforms. Ukraine obliged by freeing prices, bringing down its deficit and lowering inflation. But its Government needs more help to boost the economy.
The final communique, as always, will call on governments to coordinate economic policies. The promise will be abandoned the minute domestic politics dictate otherwise. The leaders will probably duck a proposal to use gold held by the fund to relieve the debt of desperately poor countries. There will also likely be inconclusive talk about Bosnia, and meetings with President Boris Yeltsin of Russia, who wants to join the industrial nations' club. To avoid unpleasantness, President Clinton and Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama of Japan plan to touch only glancingly on Washington's plan to impose trade sanctions on Japan at the end of the month.
Still, these meetings rarely do much harm, and this year the leaders seem headed toward doing some good.

HEADLINE: Journal;
The Longest Year

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
It's hard to believe that this weekend marks the first anniversary of the wild Bronco chase. Doesn't it feel as if we ran to our sets for our first breathless glimpse of A. C. Cowlings at least three years ago?
Time doesn't fly when you're not having fun. Though conventional wisdom now says that the O. J. Simpson case has no redeeming social or intellectual value as a landmark in jurisprudence or anything else, it has nonetheless hijacked our culture. You don't have to follow the trial to be affected by it. You can't escape no matter how hard you try. 
 O. J. permeates the airwaves, journalism, most overheard conversations. O. J. is now the nation's weather, and it's raining all the time.
Taken in sum, the moral lessons to be drawn from O. J. might make for an Antichrist's "Book of Virtues." The defendant has demonstrated that with enough money you can probably buy your way out of any trouble. Lance Ito has proved that even 15 minutes of fame won't satisfy some Americans; the judge won't be happy until his aggregate TV time eclipses Ed Sullivan's. The jury has shown that, given enough rope, ordinary people selected by lot from all walks of life will hang themselves by lapsing into an orgy of greed, racial acrimony and overall pettiness. After which, they run out and hire agents.
But if O. J.'s legacy has been the fomenting of race and class conflict and the undermining of whatever faith Americans still had in the legal system and the press, there is still a bright side. Many people, and not just the lawyers, have gotten very rich. As The Wall Street Journal reported in March, the O. J. industry has long since passed the gross national product of Grenada -- even though the prosecution, whose bill to Los Angeles taxpayers now totals some $5.8 million, has yet to rest its case.
O. J. has been a boon to publishers, with at least 15 books already out or on their way, not counting F. Lee Bailey's fortuitous reissue of his 1972 "The Defense Never Rests." Five have been best sellers, with the latest, the Kato Kaelin reminiscence that Mr. Kaelin himself disowned, already boasting 800,000 copies in print at $20 a pop -- $16 million in potential sales for one title alone. The tomes by O. J.'s mom and Johnnie Cochran's former wife are still to come.
CNN, charging up to $24,000 per half-minute of commercial time, could make more than $45 million on the trial, according to one industry estimate. Rupert Murdoch's Fox was first to cash in with a TV movie, while an officially authorized Simpson statuette has passed $5 million in sales at $3,395 apiece. Trial transcripts can be ordered through an 800 number at $9 per day; Mr. Cowlings's 900 number for recorded apercus charges nearly $3 per minute. "I Killed Nicole" T-shirts ($12.75), pins and bumper stickers are now a thriving industry in L.A. "The Dancing Itos," regulars on Jay Leno, are a hot show-biz act, as are the chattering legal eagles who fill the chairs opposite Ted Koppel and Larry King. An Internet site, the Canonical List of O. J. Simpson Jokes, lists 17 orange juice puns and 13 gags featuring Hertz.
Who is to blame for this circus in which the murder victims have increasingly become forgotten players? Cynical observers might point the finger at a public so ravenous for celebrities that even Faye Resnick will do -- and so infatuated with violence that witnesses' descriptions of off-camera autopsy photos take on their own pornographic allure. Psychiatrists, meanwhile, might theorize that Americans are so eager to avoid confronting their real problems that they would rather fixate on a distant soap opera in which they have no direct stake.
But polls have revealed that 90 percent of the country says it's sick of O. J., so surely that absolves each of us of any responsibility for this ugly national appetite for tawdriness and gore.
Note instead that many of the unsavory O. J. products, from Mr. Simpson's own best-selling apologia, "I Want to Tell You," to the recent cable broadcast of Mr. Kaelin's soft-core porn film "Sand, Surf and Sex," have been forced on an unwitting audience by a single media empire -- just like the violent movies and gangsta rap that destroy our cities. As we reach this first anniversary of our O. J. culture, we can rest assured that it in no way reflects poorly on our national character. It's all Time Warner's fault.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Senate Approves Bill To Regulate the Internet
The Senate voted 84 to 16 for a bill that would impose a maximum fine of $100,000 and prison terms of as much as two years on individuals who transmit sexually explicit material over computer networks.
Advocates of regulation easily overwhelmed objections from a handful of lawmakers who said the measure would violate constitutional rights to free speech and threaten the growth of computer networks. [Page A1.]
 
Hoping to head off legislation that would censor material on the Internet, three software companies proposed a rating system and an electronic filter that could block access to sexually explicit content. [D6.] 

Bidders Seen for Hills Store
Venture Stores and Apollo Advisers, headed by the former co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Leon Black, are said to be potential bidders for control of the Hills Store Company. [D11.]
 
Reports Point to Slowdown
In another sign of weak economic growth but low inflation, inventories rose in April for the 13th straight month, climbing eight-tenths of a percent, and sales fell four-tenths of a percent. The Federal Government also reported that worker productivity increased 2.7 percent in the first quarter. [D24.]
 
Sprint Mulls Cellular Sale
Sprint said its directors were considering options for the company's cellular unit, including a spinoff or a sale. [D5.]
 
Test Results Hurt Cor Shares
Shares in Cor Therapeutics fell $8.50, to $10.25, after the company's flagship heart attack drug, Integrelin, delivered disappointing results in late-stage clinical trials. [D4.]
 
Duff & Phelps in Deal
Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance and Duff & Phelps are merging their investment management businesses. [D5.]
 
Clinton's New Health Plan
The Clinton Administration, as part of its plan to balance the budget, proposed regulating private health insurance to make coverage more available and affordable. [A22.]
 
Bank Derivative Holdings Up
American banks' holdings of derivatives soared to $18 trillion, from $15.8 billion, in the first quarter, but the surge appeared to have come in relatively low-risk investments. [D4.]
 
Age-Bias Awards Taxable
The Supreme Court ruled 6 to 3 that money received from a lawsuit or settlement under the Federal law that bars discrimination on the basis of age is taxable as income. [D2.]
 
Lotus Notes Is No Groupwise
Lotus Notes may be getting all the attention because of I.B.M.'s takeover of Lotus, but Novell's Groupwise dominates the world of network computing. [D4.]
 
Different Game for Olajuwon
Hakeem Olajuwon is one of the top stars in the N.B.A., but his endorsement portfolio isn't as impressive as his scoring. Why? Executives say his name is hard to pronounce, he doesn't play in a major market and that he doesn't "register with youth." Yet his endorsement portfolio is not bare; last year, endorsements yielded $2 million in off-the-court income. Advertising. [D11.]
 
U.A.W. Elects President
The United Automobile Workers elected Stephen P. Yokich as its new president. [A14.]
 A chart with the Business Digest misstated economists' expectations for a Federal Reserve report on industrial production in May. They expected a decline (not an increase) of four-tenths of 1 percent. Yesterday the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production fell two-tenths of 1 percent for the month. Details appear today on page D1.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Glum Unity: The Group of 7 Sees Downhill

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Lurking just off the horizon at the economic summit meeting that opens in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on Thursday is the kind of potential crisis that the Group of Seven was created two decades ago to keep from getting out of hand. Some of the world's biggest economies, in an oddly synchronized fashion, may be headed downhill together.
Japan is caught in a vicious deflationary spiral, its economy shrinking and its banks threatened by losses so enormous that they could shake markets around the world. The United States is struggling to keep a soft landing from becoming a hard one, and Canada is being sucked down in its wake. 
 The Clinton Administration has counted on exports to help keep the economy afloat, but with Canada, Mexico and Japan -- its biggest trading partners -- all reeling, who is about to go on a buying spree?
In the old days, this would have been the moment to announce a grand coordinated effort by the world's seven big industrial democracies. Officials would have deftly laid out a series of precisely timed economic initiatives.
But no one talks seriously about coordination any more. Even the American Secretary of the Treasury, Robert E. Rubin, concedes that "in the old sense of the word -- an agreement for specific action at a specific time -- coordination may be dead."
Mr. Rubin sees plenty of other justifications for the annual gathering of thousands of communique-scribbling bureaucrats, headline-seeking politicians and news-starved reporters, all engaged in a mad competition for a very limited number of hotel rooms and restaurant tables. But many others, particularly those who wonder whether economics still has much to do with the economic summit meeting, are asking the simple question: Why bother?
The end of the cold war has made it seem far less urgent for the Western political allies to put up a common economic front, which was the subtext of the first decade and a half of summit meetings. But that is only one of the reasons, said Robert D. Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, that "it is getting harder and harder to make these summits work."
As Mexico learned the hard way, private markets these days can swamp decisions made by governments that now control far fewer levers to move the world's economy than they once did. And when the moment came earlier this year to save Mexico from collapse, it took unilateral action by the United States -- and then grudging acquiescence from the other allies -- to bring about what, Administration officials, with some presumption, hailed as a "coordinated response."
Then there is the question of whether the right countries are even at the table. Where will the bigger decisions be made in the world economy of 2010, in Rome or Beijing?
"You sometimes get this sinking feeling," one of the sherpas, or bureaucrats, who do the advance work for the summit meeting said a few weeks ago, "that we're talking to the wrong people, often about the wrong subjects."
That helps explain the proliferation of competing meetings, led by the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, the still new annual gathering of Pacific leaders, which at least has the benefit of more equatorial settings.
Most experts agree that there is merit in getting leaders of the Western world together, even if only to talk about the crisis du jour. In the early 1990's the subject was how to save the Russians from economic ruin, while at the same time separating the former Soviet republics from their nuclear weapons. This year it will be Bosnia.
There are annual chestnuts: For years Americans have wanted to turn the meeting into a forum for beating up on Japan over its closed markets. Everyone else has wanted to use it to lean on the United States to cut its budget deficits and entice Americans to save more money. There will probably be a good deal of both this year around the fringes of the meetings, as Washington and Tokyo maneuver for advantage in their dispute over luxury car imports into the United States and access to the market for autos and parts in Japan.
But by any measure, the meeting has wandered a long way from the goals set out by the two former finance ministers who got the Group of Seven started in the midst of the energy crisis in 1975: President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of Germany. The idea was to create an informal, private place for the world's leaders to handle common problems of inflation and economic growth, figuring that together they could do a lot more than they could individually.
For the first decade it worked reasonably well, with joint plans to stimulate economies and curb the use of oil. In 1985, at a separate meeting led by finance ministers and central bankers, the five big industrial powerhouses worked together to rein in the dollar, which at the time was viewed as tremendously overvalued. A decade later, with the dollar regularly hitting record lows, that looks like a problem the Group of Seven solved beyond its wildest imaginings.
But as Mr. Rubin noted in a lengthy conversation in his office this morning, "coordination proved to be like many other things in economics: something that sounds nice and simple and is anything but simple. It ran into the complexities of economic life."
Now, Mr. Rubin sees a new form of coordination, one that is more about long-term strategy than short-term action. It "is much better fitted to the realities of the world," he says. General goals are in; 15-point action plans are out.
"This has its own utility," he said, arguing that a general agreement on exchange rates reached by the finance ministers earlier this year paved the way for an unusually well-coordinated surprise intervention in the currency markets a couple of weeks ago, bolstering the dollar.
Mr. Rubin's big initiative this year is one that is not expected to bear fruit for some time: A revamping of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to prepare for the next Mexico-style crisis.
"The United States cannot be the world's lender of last resort," Mr. Rubin has said time and again in recent weeks.
His plan is to force countries that have artfully covered up their financial books for years to disclose a range of information about their borrowings and their reserves. That, in theory, will permit the markets to enforce fiscal responsibility by refusing to lend to governments that go on spending and borrowing binges.
The crux of the American plan is to create a fund within the I.M.F. to bail out countries on the brink of bankruptcy, preventing what Mr. Rubin calls a "contagion effect" on markets around the world. But even that plan, analysts say, bespeaks the obstacles to coordination.
The draft communique says nothing about how to pay for this special fund, and the European partners have shouted down an American proposal that the I.M.F. sell some portion of its $40 billion in gold reserves to create a fund for the purpose.
Mr. Rubin acknowledges that going to the Republican-controlled Congress for an additional contribution would be "a difficult proposition" that will require "an education process on Capitol Hill."
The Group of Seven already see this as an example of the limits on Mr. Clinton's power in economic matters. That explains why Mr. Rubin and others are suddenly talking about dunning the emerging economies of Asia for the extra money.
That is hardly the only issue on which Mr. Clinton will face difficulty getting cooperation. No one, for example, is counting on Japan's Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama -- whom Mr. Clinton meets separately on Thursday -- to stay in power long enough to engineer a bailout of the Japanese banking system and stimulate its stagnant economy. Nor does he have the power to settle the automobile dispute, the other time bomb for the markets.
That leaves the United States and its big partners to do what they have learned to do so well at economic summit meetings. Count on Mr. Clinton and his best friends in the world for the next three days to schmooze, jawbone and then step in front of the television cameras to argue that the events of Halifax have made the world a better place -- even if a few months later no one can remember exactly how.
 
Where to Go

 However ineffectual it may sometimes seem, don't say that the Group of Seven does not keep up with the times.
This year, its summit meeting enters cyberspace -- both with an official World Wide Web site on the Internet sponsored by the Canadian Government and with two unofficial Web pages, one set up by Dalhousie University in Halifax, the summit site, and the other created by teachers and students of Cornwallis Junior High School there.

Chart/Photos: "Less Glitz, More Talk"

At the top of the agenda are proposals to overhaul the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, two global economic institutions established at the end of World War II, so they are better equipped to deal with any future Mexico-style currency crisis. HEADLINE: Clinton's Budget Doesn't Matter

BYLINE: By James C. Miller 3d 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton's weak effort to get back in the budget ballgame does not alter one big political fact. Whatever he has to say about the budget is of little consequence. Its fate lies with the Republican Congress. Not only will Congress draft a budget that reflects its own philosophy, it wields enormous leverage over the President and will likely get its way in the end.
Unless Congress approves appropriations, most discretionary programs will halt on Oct. 1, when the new fiscal year starts. Only those Government functions essential to health and safety will be up and running. It will be too distasteful for President Clinton to see welfare, road-building, small-business loans, environmental regulations and other programs grind to a tire-smoking halt. 
 What's potentially more troubling for the President is that in November the $4.9 trillion debt ceiling will be reached, and by law cannot be exceeded. Unless Congress acts in a timely fashion, he will have to cut back all discretionary programs and possibly entitlements like Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid, because the Government would have to spend incoming revenues to roll over debt as bonds and notes come due.
The House and Senate have both passed resolutions calling for balanced budgets in the year 2002, and they intend to do this without raising taxes. But the House version is preferable for three important reasons.
First, the House budget, true to the Contract With America, offers a tax cut. The Senate version contemplates action on taxes -- maybe and, if so, in the sweet by and by. The House would accelerate economic growth through an expanded individual retirement account, changes in business depreciation rules and, most important, by reducing the tax rate on capital gains. The Senate offers nothing along these lines.
The House plan would remedy the tax code's discrimination against families. The House wants a $500 nonrefundable tax credit for each dependent, and eliminates the so-called marriage penalty, under which a couple living together pay less in taxes than if they were married.
Second, the House would make up for part of the cut in tax revenues by spending a little less -- $11.9 trillion -- than the Senate's $12 trillion on Federal programs over seven years. The Congressional budget committees have forecast that annual Federal spending and tax revenues at the end of the seven years would be nearly $70 billion less under the House plan than under the Senate's version.
Finally, the House budget is more likely to restrain spending because the House is more willing to pare down the Federal establishment. It would close down three Cabinet departments -- Commerce, Education and Energy -- altogether. The Senate would eliminate only Commerce. The House would terminate hundreds of unnecessary agencies (like the National Endowment for the Arts) and programs (like clean-coal technology). The Senate would reduce the financing of many but leave them intact.
In proposing to balance the budget over 10 years, President Clinton cautioned against reducing the deficit too fast so as not to hurt the economy. This echoes a recent warning by Laura D'Andrea Tyson, President Clinton's chief economic adviser, that rapid reduction of the deficit would drive the economy into a tailspin.
How soon we forget. In the 1987 fiscal year, total Federal spending, adjusted for inflation, fell for the first time in nearly two decades, and the deficit plummeted from $221 billion to $150 billion.
There are no grounds to imagine that the national recession in 1990 had anything to do with the rapid reduction of the deficit in 1987. But there are firm grounds to believe that today's economy will grow stronger under the rigorous Republican approach to deficit reduction.

HEADLINE: Making It Easier to Uncover Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 15

 BODY:
The International Atomic Energy Agency adopted tougher safeguards today that are intended to help its inspectors ferret out clandestine nuclear arms programs.
At the agency's headquarters in Vienna, its board of governors approved an initial set of measures that will allow its inspectors in countries suspected of developing nuclear weapons to gain broader access to suspected nuclear sites, to mount inspections with little or no notice and to sample soil, vegetation, water and air for traces of radioactivity. 
 In early May, countries meeting at the United Nations extended indefinitely the treaty to limit the spread of nuclear arms. The atomic energy agency has the task of monitoring national energy programs to insure that no nuclear materials are siphoned off for use in developing weapons. But disclosures in recent years that Iraq and North Korea -- despite being signers of the treaty -- had been able to pursue clandestine weapons programs had led to calls for a strengthening of inspections.
The broader inspection powers passed today will cover only nuclear sites that were already accessible to the agency. David Kyd, the agency spokesman, said by telephone from Vienna that the agency would press for a "more ambitious racheting up" of the safeguards, to extend them into research facilities and areas where inspectors do not yet have access. It also wants fuller disclosure of nuclear activities from member states.
The Director General of the atomic energy agency, Hans Blix, plans to seek this expanded authority when the board of governors meets in December. The board includes representatives of 35 of the 122 countries belonging to the agency.
The expanded measures approved today are expected to cost $1 million a year beyond the annual safeguards budget of $70 million.
The agency's total annual budget is $211 million, plus $50 million more in voluntary contributions for programs making nuclear technology for peaceful purposes available to member states. Dr. Blix told the board that the increase could be offset by other cost-cutting within three years.
Several critics have said the new measures are still insufficient. Not only is the agency underfinanced, they say, but it also spends too much time and money monitoring unthreatening nations in Western Europe or North America at the expense of suspected violators like Iran and North Korea.
"What's needed is a candid acknowledgment by the agency of what it can do and what it cannot do effectively," said Paul L. Leventhal, president of the Nuclear Control Institute in Washington.
But another analyst, Leonard S. Spector, said he thought the agency's new safeguards would "contribute enormously" to discouraging potential violators. "It's going to enable us to keep some of these countries on the defensive," said Mr. Spector, who directs the nuclear nonproliferation project at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington.
In an interview in Vienna last month Dr. Blix spoke of limits to what his agency can achieve, however many safeguards it devises. Because it is virtually impossible to confirm that a nuclear weapons program does not exist, he said, "in no country do we give a clean bill of health." "We say we have seen no evidence of diversion or misuse," he added.
The agency's mandate does not allow it access to known military nuclear programs. It can only try to insure that nuclear material for peaceful uses is not diverted for weapons. If its inspectors find something suspicious, they can only raise the alarm, leaving it to the Security Council to take action against the violator.
"We happen to live in a world of sovereign states," said Dr. Blix. "We cannot parachute in or shoot our way in, absolutely not."
The agency, authorized at the time only to monitor declared nuclear facilities, was caught off guard when Iraq's secret nuclear weapons program was disclosed after its defeat in the Persian Gulf War in 1991. After the war, agency inspectors descended on Iraq to find and demolish buildings and machinery. In 1992, the agency determined that North Korea was not providing a full accounting of its stocks of plutonium, a possible bomb ingredient, triggering intense diplomatic efforts and a recent agreement under which North Korea has foresworn nuclear weapons. Iran, which is buying Russian nuclear equipment over United States objections, has become the latest candidate for closer scrutiny. So far, Dr. Blix said in the interview, "we are not encountering any lack of cooperation from the Iranians" in getting access to their installations.
While the agency's watchdog responsibilities have increased, its regular budget has been frozen for the last decade, excepting for inflation, by a blanket policy of zero real growth in United Nations spending.
Its technical cooperation programs, which provide the carrot for nonnuclear countries to join, are financed in large part by the United States, which now pays nearly 40 percent of the agency's total expenses, compared with a normal assessment of 25 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Takes A Softer Tone In Auto Battle

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 15

 BODY:
Japan's Prime Minister struck an unexpectedly compromising tone today in talks with President Clinton about American demands to widen access to the Japanese automotive market. But the Administration's top economic officials reacted warily, saying they would not know until negotiations began next week in Geneva whether a last-minute deal might be possible.
In an hourlong meeting here, before the summit talks began among top leaders of the seven largest industrial democracies, Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama repeatedly told Mr. Clinton that he hoped to resolve the issue in the next two weeks, according to American and Japanese officials who sat in on the meeting. 
 But the Japanese trade officials who descended on this seaside city offered no specifics. And they appeared somewhat taken aback at Mr. Clinton's clear warning shot, delivered at a news conference this afternoon with Mr. Murayama. "I will not agree to extend the deadline," Mr. Clinton said, on stiff tariffs on luxury cars scheduled to go into effect on June 28 if the conflict is not resolved.
Mr. Murayama's tone was far different from the tough public Japanese stance thus far in the confrontation over autos. Still, American officials, including some of Mr. Clinton's closest economic advisers, cautioned that there might be less to the shift than appeared.
The Japanese Prime Minister's hold on power is tenuous at best -- experts say he could be forced to resign after parliamentary elections in mid-July -- and so far he has been only a bit player in a trade dispute that all sides agree has far broader implications than a disagreement over auto parts.
The real decision-maker in Tokyo thus far has been Ryutaro Hashimoto, Minister of International Trade and Industry, who sat silently at Mr. Murayama's side today as the Prime Minister met with Mr. Clinton. Mr. Hashimoto engaged in a few jocular exchanges with his American counterpart, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, before the talks began. But he gave no indication whether he was ready to back away from his statement two weeks ago that he had already made "the maximum possible concession" to Washington.
Tokyo's new tone may come from increasing nervousness in among Japanese business executives that Japan's markets are not prepared to withstand a possible shock from the imposition of sanctions at a time when the nation's hard-pressed banks are calling for Government bailouts and the economy has plunged into deflation.
But Mr. Murayama, a genial and grandfatherly figure, may also be playing out a familiar script in trade negotiations, seeking to show the Japanese public that the Government has gone the last mile to compromise with an American Administration that has been widely portrayed in Japan as bullying and unreasonable.
"Maybe it's real, maybe it's not," an American official said today. "We won't know until next Thursday," when trade negotiators from both sides are scheduled to meet in Geneva.
In his one flash of pique today, Mr. Murayama, 71, denounced the American threat to place 100 percent tariffs on $5.9 billion in Japanese luxury car imports, including the Lexus models made by Toyota, the Infiniti line from Nissan and other popular models. At the news conference Mr. Murayama said he had asked Mr. Clinton for "expeditious removal of the unilateral measures since they violate the rules and the spirit of the World Trade Organization," the new international governing body of trade.
But for much of the day, the aging Socialist, who until three years ago was not well known, even in the Japanese Parliament where he has served for seven terms, talked only of compromise. "What is important is that we do not engage in talks with both of our fists raised," he said, "but rather talk to each other in good faith and try to resolve the problem through talks."
"Where we can yield," Mr. Murayama said, "we should yield to each other, so that we should find out the ways that will lead us at the end of the day to a solution."
The chief point of contention between the two countries remains the American demand that Japan agree to some kind of "targets" or "goals" for the purchase of more American-made car parts by Japanese manufacturers. A similar agreement was struck with President Bush in 1991, but Japanese officials say that was a mistake, and that any such accord constitutes managed trade. American officials respond that Japan has managed its trade for years -- especially with Europe -- and that anything short of a concrete agreement would not solve the problem.
The question now is whether Washington and Tokyo can find a way to stitch together an accord that to the Americans looks like an ironclad commitment but that can be dressed up as something less than that by the Japanese.

HEADLINE: Republican Squabble Delays Welfare Debate

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Deep ideological disagreements among Senate Republicans have forced them to delay floor debate on a welfare bill so party leaders can seek a compromise.
The disagreements involve a wide range of issues: formulas for distributing Federal money, work requirements for welfare recipients, proposals to discourage unmarried women from having babies, and the balance of power between the Federal Government and the states. 
 The disagreements are "pretty profound," said Robert Rector, a senior policy analyst at the conservative Heritage Foundation, who has worked closely with Republicans on the welfare bill.
While the disputes do not jeopardize passage of a bill, they have left its shape in doubt. The disagreements have split the Senate Republican caucus into several camps, prompted nasty exchanges between Republican senators, provoked threats of a filibuster and frayed relations between Republican governors and senators.
Democrats, usually split by their own intramural fights, say they are delighted by the spectacle of Republicans squabbling among themselves. The squabbles have touched off a frantic effort by the White House and Senate Democrats to win Republican support for Democratic amendments to the bill.
"We certainly hope we can work together across party lines on this," said Bruce Reed, a White House aide, who drafted the 1991 campaign speech in which Mr. Clinton promised to "end welfare as we know it."
On May 26, the Senate Finance Committee approved a bill that, like a companion measure passed by the House, would freeze Federal welfare spending for five years, cancel the Federal guarantee of a subsistence income for poor children and give each state a lump sum of money to spend on the poor, with no allowance for inflation or population growth.
Some conservative Republican senators like Lauch Faircloth of North Carolina want to use the bill to try to change the behavior of welfare recipients and reduce out-of-wedlock births. "The bill doesn't do anything to reduce illegitimacy," Mr. Faircloth said in an interview today. "I absolutely intend to filibuster it."
Senator Faircloth said the bill should contain provisions like those in the House bill to reward states that reduce out-of-wedlock births and to cut off payments to unmarried teen-age mothers. He and some other conservatives also seek stricter work requirements.
But moderate Republicans say the Federal Government has no business dictating the behavior of welfare recipients and should not impose its policy preferences on states. The Senate bill, like the House measure, would eliminate Federal requirements for states to spend their own money as a condition of getting Federal welfare grants. Democrats want to require states to maintain current spending.
Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, a Republican who is chairman of the Budget Committee, is working with Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana, a Democrat, on an amendment to encourage such "maintenance of effort" by the states. Aides to Senator James M. Jeffords, Republican of Vermont, said he would be a co-sponsor of the amendment, which is opposed by many Republican governors.
Under the proposal, a state could reduce its welfare spending below the 1994 level, but if it did so, it would lose some of its Federal money.
A summary of the proposal prepared by aides to the three Senators says it would "give states a financial stake in welfare reform, making them more accountable to both state and Federal taxpayers." States now contribute 43 percent of the money spent on the main welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children; the states' share amounts to $10 billion of $23 billion this year.
Republican governors say they should not be required to keep spending at that level if they can reduce poverty and put welfare recipients to work with innovative programs.
Under the bill, each state would get the same amount of Federal money it received for cash assistance to poor people in 1994. Republican senators from the South and the West, led by Kay Bailey Hutchison of Texas, are demanding a different formula that would distribute Federal money according to the number of poor children in each state. Fourteen states, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, would lose money under the proposal.
Senator Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, denounced the proposal. "This is not welfare reform," he said. "It's a redistribution of dollars. It shifts money to Texas and Florida. It penalizes states like New York that have met their moral obligation to take care of impoverished children."
The "formula fight" is distressing to some party members. "Republicans should not be fighting with one another over how to divide up the spoils of the welfare state," said a Republican Senate aide.
The campaign for block grants is led by Republican governors. Gov. John Engler of Michigan, one of the chief proponents, attended a Republican caucus on Wednesday and urged senators to create a block grant with no strings attached.
Senator Faircloth objected to Mr. Engler's presence. "I find it most unusual for a Governor to lecture us at a meeting called for senators to talk among themselves," he said.

HEADLINE: Reliving Volunteer Work in the South

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., June 10

 BODY:
In the spring of 1964, Robert Ostrow was the epitome of an establishment lawyer. Living in Scarsdale, N.Y., practicing tax law, never having had a black classmate in 15 years of graduate school, Mr. Ostrow could not have lived a life more removed from the turbulent civil rights struggle being waged in the Deep South.
"I was not involved in any social movement," Mr. Ostrow said in a recent interview. "I didn't know there were problems. I was completely isolated." 
 Then one day he gazed at the scarred face of a friend who had been beaten by a group of whites while providing legal help for civil rights workers in St. Augustine, Fla.
"When he came home, he was bloody and scabbed around his face," Mr. Ostrow said. "I just became outraged that lawyers who went to help young people register people to vote were at risk."
Mr. Ostrow contacted the Lawyers' Constitutional Defense Committee, a group that sent volunteer lawyers south from 1964 to 1971 to provide legal work for civil rights protesters whom Southern white lawyers routinely refused to defend. Initially, he worked in Mississippi, then later provided legal aid to the the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee in Selma, Ala.
Mr. Ostrow was not alone in his desire to serve. About 250 lawyers volunteered for the defense committee's program in the 1960's. And about 75 of them gathered here recently for a reunion, 31 years after the group began its work.
At first, they said, the jobs were mostly technical -- appearing at bail hearings or trying to transfer routine criminal suits against civil rights workers from hostile state courts to the more sympathetic Federal courts.
"I probably did work that was more intellectually challenging later on," said John L. Saltonstall Jr., who took three weeks off from his corporate practice in Boston in 1964 to represent a group of black civil rights workers who were being sued for libel in northern Mississippi. "But I probably never did any work that was more exciting."
These volunteers were sent to the toughest part of the South -- Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana -- where resistance to black progress was most entrenched. And, though there were no instances of lawyers being harmed as had happened in Florida, the environment was terrifying.
Talking to a visitor over breakfast, George R. Hinckley, a lawyer from Manhattan, reached into a file folder full of memories and pulled out a note he wrote to himself in 1964 as he drove from New Orleans into Mississippi and listened to the latest news on the radio. "Goodman, Chaney, Schwerner still missing," the note said, referring to the three civil rights workers who were later found murdered near Philadelphia, Miss.
Veterans of the Lawyers' Constitutional Defense Committee said the real heroes of the civil rights movements were Southern blacks who stood up to segregation, and not the lawyers who volunteered for a typical two- or three-week assignment, then returned north.
Still, the volunteers' contributions were critical, especially in the early days when lawyers were desperately needed to represent civil rights workers who were being locked up on any charge the authorities could fashion. Local white lawyers, fearing economic isolation, refused to represent anyone challenging segregation. And there were few black lawyers in the South. In Mississippi, for example, there were only four black lawyers in the entire state.
Later, the defense committee and other groups like the Lawyers Guild of America moved from bailing civil rights workers out of jail to gathering evidence of harassment of blacks who tried to register to vote.
For many lawyers who volunteered with the defense committee, their work was a watershed, inspiring them to forgo corporate law for careers in areas like civil rights or environmental law, or at least to devote more time to pro bono work.
"I was practicing in a large law firm and I never went back to it," said Mike Nadler who worked in New Orleans and in Mississippi in 1964 and who later ran for Congress from New York. "I don't know if it turned around my life or if it was ready to be turned around anyway. But it did."
The work also contributed to the transformation of the South. In Mississippi now, there are some 300 black lawyers and nearly 900 state, local and Federal elected officials -- the highest number of any state in the nation. One of the panels at the group's reunion was moderated by Fred L. Banks Jr. the first black to sit on the Mississippi Supreme Court, which is elected.
Mr. Ostrow, who since his time in Mississippi has helped set up the National Welfare Rights Organization, said: "We were there for a principle, but I never thought we would be able to change things. At the time I was so depressed that I wouldn't have bet a quarter that we would have prevailed. But we did."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lawyers who worked in the civil rights movement in the South in the 1960's returned to Jackson, Miss., last week for a reunion. Robert Ostrow, right, talked about his work in Mississippi and in Selma, Ala. (Rogelio Solis for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Items Dear to Council Ease Budget Approval

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
On their way to approving New York City's new $31.1 billion budget near dawn yesterday morning, the City Council sat patiently through hours of committee meetings and weighty discussions about finance, debt and bond ratings.
As the hours dragged by, many Council members grew bleary-eyed. Some nodded off. But suddenly, heads snapped up and attention sharpened decidedly when, about 1 A.M., Speaker Peter F. Vallone's staff at last distributed to each Council member a list of so-called Council initiatives, a package of pork-barrel projects, New York City style. Together they cost about $9 million. 
 Mr. Vallone allowed Council members who planned to vote in favor of the budget to apportion $80,000 apiece in any way they choose. Dissenters were allowed to dole out only $50,000, leaving the Speaker to decide how the rest would be spent.
The Council went on to approve the budget by a vote of 45 to 5, with one member absent. But the release of "member items," as they are also called, appeared to be the most spellbinding moment of the long night of budget discussion, far eclipsing any of the talks on the austere city budget, which will cut a wide array of city services.
"The fact is that the largest impact Council members have in the budget is in the small amount of money they give to community groups in their districts," noted Chris Meyer, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group who follows the Council. "It is the thing that resonates the most in their district because it is the biggest barometer in the district of the effectiveness of the member. So it means everything to them."
In some cases the amounts are small, with very few being in six figures. Among the "Council initiatives" were $9,000 for the Staten Island Ice Hockey Association, a group that provides transportation for children to skating rinks; Hellenic Public Radio, an organization that provides Greek news and other programming on radio. The Tibet Museum received $2,500; the N.A.A.C.P. was awarded $1,563 and the New York Junior Tennis League received $185,909.
Council members said each one received $80,000 for his or her district. But those who were expected to support the budget had money allotted to the organizations they requested. For those who opposed the budget, Mr. Vallone's staff controlled the disbursement of $30,000 of the allocation. That practice in itself was a new one. In previous years Mr. Vallone reduced the total allocation for dissenters to $50,000.
Some Council members, however, have received even more than the $80,000 allocation. One was Jerome X. O'Donovan, a Democrat who represents the North Shore of Staten Island. Mr. O'Donovan said that Mr. Vallone made $155,000 in member items available to him this year. He is chairman of the Council's Economic Development Committee. He said that he was merely being rewarded for being loyal to the Speaker and for being a Council leader with 12 years of seniority.
"I got that much because I'm in leadership," Mr. O'Donovan said. "Sometimes there is more money to give to people in leadership positions. That's the way it goes."
Some Council members have speculated that it was Mr. Vallone's way of assisting Mr. O'Donovan, who is considered a likely contender for the position of Staten Island Borough president if the Republican incumbent, Guy V. Molinari, is successful in unseating the current District Attorney, William L. Murphy, a Democrat, in a race in November.
The all-night session included little of the harsh criticism of the budget that had been prevalent at City Hall in the two months after the Mayor unveiled his plan. Instead, one Council member after another praised their legislature, saying that it had been the Council that had made Mr. Giuliani's budget more humane by restoring funds for youth programs, hospitals and capital projects for schools.
"We took a lemon and made it just a little bit sweeter," said Lawrence A. Warden, a Democrat who represents the Baychester section of the Bronx. "It's not perfect, but the Council has improved upon it tremendously."
After the Council passed the budget, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sat in Mr. Vallone's office with a number of mayoral aides, Council leaders and staff members. Both the Mayor and the Speaker praised the budget as a document, rejecting criticism that some of the revenue estimates were based upon unrealistic assumptions.
Feelings about "member items" among the Council members seems to be mixed. Not surprisingly, the major critics are either those who vote against the budget, or who are not considered to be in senior leadership positions.
"A lot of good government groups think it's just pork and to some extent that's true," said Charles Millard, a Republican who represents the Upper East Side of Manhattan. "The fact is that a lot of smaller groups get funded that would not otherwise make it on the radar screen."
But Mr. Millard said "the problem with the system is that, even though everybody is supposed to get a certain amount of money, the reality is that everybody gets a certain amount. But the favored few get more."

1. The papers of former Mayor Edward I. Koch are overseen by LaGuardia Community College in Queens and have fallen into disarray. Mice have chewed away at the edges, said one Council official. HEADLINE: U.S. Factory Output Falls in 3d Straight Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
American industry cut production in May for the third consecutive month, the longest stretch of falling output since the final stages of the recession that ended in early 1991, the Federal Reserve said today.
At the same time, the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities -- a widely followed gauge of inflation risk with a close correlation to short-term interest rates -- retreated for the fourth consecutive month, to a pace now below that of May 1994. 
 Analysts took the figures, together with other data from the Labor Department and the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, as further confirmation of what has become sharp deceleration of the economy from the torrid pace of late 1994.
Indeed, the ranks of those calling for the Fed to cut interest rates continued to swell.
But Alan S. Blinder, vice chairman of the Fed, dampened the expectations of a cut in rates by telling a lunch audience in Minneapolis today that despite some rocky quarters ahead for the economy, a recession was unlikely and that, moreover, the effort by the Fed to fight inflation "cannot be ended at 3 percent."
Mr. Blinder also said the Fed could tolerate higher inflation for a single year as long as it was on a downward path for the longer term. His comments helped send Treasury prices lower.
Despite today's data, many analysts agreed with Mr. Blinder that a recession remained unlikely.
"I think this shows an economy still in the midst of a temporary inventory adjustment," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley. "But the forces of adjustment are both contained and now moderating."
There were signs of that moderation in the figures released today. The decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in industrial production last month was not only less than that of April and half of what was generally anticipated for May, it included sizable advances in business equipment and, a bit surprisingly in light of recent slack consumer demand, in appliances and television sets.
Still, a growing number of economists have urged the Federal Reserve, which is approaching a crucial policy meeting in early July, to cut short-term interest rates to head off a possible downturn.
"There is plenty of evidence that the economy is weak enough to need a boost from an easier Fed," Rosanne M. Cahn, chief economist for equity research at CS First Boston, said in a statement. She said the third consecutive decline in production was "a rare event for nonrecession times."
The decline in industrial output was largely a result of a drop of 3.9 percent in motor vehicles and parts, a sector particularly burdened by slumping sales and rising inventories this spring. Not counting the automotive industry, industrial production would have been unchanged from its April level, the Fed noted.
Vehicle assembly was at an annual pace of 11.4 million in May, down from 12.1 million, with automobiles down the most and the heavy and medium truck category holding steady.
The output of industrial equipment, however, turned up three-tenths of 1 percent, after two consecutive declines, and there was a rise of 2 percent for computers and other office equipment, the fourth consecutive advance at least that large.
Over all, production fell three-tenths of 1 percent at factories and 1 percent at mines, but rose six-tenths of 1 percent at utilities.
The industrial operating rate eased for a fourth consecutive month, to 83.7 percent, from 84.2 percent, leaving it 1.8 points below its recent high of December and January.
Plants turning out cars and light trucks ran at only 79.4 percent of capacity last month, far below the average of slightly less than 91 percent during the first three months of the year, when some workers at the General Motors Corporation struck briefly for being forced to work too much overtime.
In a separate report, the first-time claims for unemployment benefits edged down 5,000 last week, to 371,000, but the claims for the week of June 3 were revised up 4,000. That helped to lift the claims for the latest four weeks, to an average of 376,500, the highest level since October 1992. It was the eighth consecutive rise for the four-week moving average.
Yet another indicator today was the Philadelphia Fed's Business Outlook survey, whose index of general business conditions for the region fell to minus 24.3 in June from minus 16.4, the third consecutive decline and the first such streak since April 1991.
Nearly all its large components remained in negative territory, with significant declines in new orders, shipments and unfilled orders. The "prices paid" subcomponent also continued to fall in in June.
"These data are extremely significant as they offer one of the first indications of how the economy is faring during June -- apparently not well," analysts at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Bagpipes and Bailouts as Leaders Gather

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 15

 BODY:
Leaders of seven major industrial democracies sat down today to their self-appointed task of overhauling the world's financial institutions to better handle crises like the crash of the Mexican peso that shook world financial markets early this year.
To the skirl of Scottish bagpipes and the flag waving of hundreds of cheering onlookers, the leaders arrived in this center of Canada's Atlantic provinces, and after ceremonies under a sunny sky went into a working dinner to discuss financial matters. 
 Before the dinner, President Clinton and Japan's Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, sought to prevent a festering trade dispute over cars and car parts from overshadowing the economic summit meeting in this port city. But it was unclear whether their trade lieutenants would be able to resolve the conflict at another round of talks scheduled June 22-23 in Geneva.
Their discussions shortly after arriving in Halifax for the annual gathering of the Group of Seven left open the possibility of a compromise to forestall trade sanctions President Clinton has ordered to go into effect on June 28.
In the background of the economic discussions is an enormous increase in international financial transactions, which has accentuated the vulnerability of markets to shocks like the one from the peso devaluation. To prevent the collapse of the Mexican economy, the United States and the International Monetary Fund pumped nearly $40 billion into support for the peso.
Over the last decade, bond issues have tripled, securities transactions have increased more than tenfold, and foreign exchange transactions have quadrupled to $1 trillion a day, according to the International Monetary Fund, the Washington-based institution that tries to help countries in financial trouble.
"We cannot simply expect those famous currency speculators to shut off their computer terminals, hang up their red suspenders and get a life," said Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada, the host at the three-day summit meeting. "But what we can do -- what we must do -- is take effective, concrete action to minimize the vulnerability of national economies."
Among measures the leaders will look at are ways to improve the early-warning capabilities of the I.M.F. to respond more quickly to crises and to increase its resources to permit faster such response.
A senior Canadian official said the measures would mean that "various surprises in the market will be much less likely in the future."
Another idea on the front burner, Canadian and American officials said, is the creation of a kind of international bankruptcy court in which the I.M.F. could stop debt payments by insolvent nations, organize new borrowing, and approve a plan to pay off creditors, much as courts now do under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings with private corporations.
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin accompanied the President here, along with Secretary of State Warren Christopher and the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor.
In an attempt to reassure investors that Washington supports a stronger dollar, Mr. Rubin said after a meeting with his Japanese counterpart, Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura, that he and Mr. Takemura had reaffirmed a finance ministers' assessment that exchange rates in Group of Seven countries were "out of sync with the fundamentals."
Japanese officials attribute their country's weakening economic performance this year to the persistent strength of the yen.
At the April meeting of finance ministers and central bankers in Washington, a closing statement spoke of the need for an "orderly reversal of exchange rate movements."
The leaders of the Group of Seven -- the United States, Canada, Japan, Britain, France, Germany and Italy -- arrived at Shearwater, a Canadian Forces base near here. In separate entourages, they sailed across one of the world's deepest harbors into Halifax.
The Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, joins the Group of Seven leaders on Friday for political discussions that are almost certain to include conditions in Bosnia, where more than 15,000 Bosnian Government troops are massed around Sarajevo for what looks like preparation for a major offensive.
President Clinton's party took 20 minutes to cross the harbor aboard a brilliantly orange-colored 300-foot Canadian icebreaker, the Sir William Alexander.
As they neared a wharf in the restored waterfront, a bagpiper pealed out a Scottish ballad from a bluff on nearby St. George's Island. A squad of eight police boats, equipped with twin 150-horsepower engines, flanked the Presidential vessel.
Although security is tight around a downtown square kilometer known as the "red zone," where the meetings are being held, there was an air of festivity and celebration, which had all the trappings of a giant Nova Scotia kitchen party.
Two outdoor rock bands drowned out the bagpipes. Buildings flew the Canadian maple leaf, the Union Jack and the blue cross of St. Andrew, the flag of Nova Scotia.
Canadian authorities have encouraged people to come downtown.

Joining Mr. Clinton were, from right, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin and Secretary of State Warren Christopher. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
In search of global diversity? France may offer new promise.

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado 

 BODY:
INVESTORS in the United States who seek global diversity might do well to consider France, now that the uncertainty surrounding the recent Presidential election there has passed.
Unlike emerging markets like Mexico, which can carry sizable risks, an industrialized country like France offers investors the promise of a stable economy with stable growth. 
 France's economic landscape is viewed as improving despite questions about the newly elected President, Jacques Chirac, and his ambitious plans to tackle the high unemployment rate, which has been hovering around 12 percent. For instance, capital investment is expected to increase 10 percent this year, far faster than 1994's growth of 1 percent. Olivier Davanne, an economist at Goldman, Sachs, expects French inflation of about 1.7 percent this year, the lowest among Western European countries and well below the region's average projected rate of 2.9 percent.
At the same time, gross domestic product is expected to grow by about 3 percent this year and 3.5 percent in 1996, according to a report on the French economy by S. G. Warburg Securities. That should lift French corporate earnings.
Still, Americans seeking to invest in individual French companies may face some difficulty. Only eight stocks in the CAC 40 Index, the 40-stock index that is the Paris exchange's equivalent of the Dow Jones industrial average, trade here, in the form of American depository receipts.
"Some of the higher-quality stocks do not trade on U.S. exchanges -- a clear deterrent for many prospective investors who are unlikely to traverse the unfamiliar terrain of the Paris bourse," said Bruce Watts, a closed-end-fund analyst with S. G. Warburg & Company.
An easier path, Mr. Watts suggested, is the France Growth Fund, the only closed-end country fund exclusively covering French stocks. Like open-end mutual funds, closed-end funds hold a portfolio of securities, but they trade as stocks on exchanges. Their per-share net asset value represents the current value of their securities, such as stocks and bonds. When a fund's quoted stock price exceeds the net asset value, the fund trades at a premium; when it is less than the net asset value, the stock trades at a discount.
From its start in May 1990 through the first quarter of 1995, the France Growth Fund has raised its net asset value by 11.4 percent. That compares to a loss of nearly 9 percent in the same period registered by the Societe de Bourse Francais 120 Index, a broad French market index.
The France Growth Fund is selling well below its net asset value, closing yesterday at $10.25 on the New York Stock Exchange. The closing price equates to a 16.7 percent discount to the net asset value of $12.30. The discount and the outlook for an improving French economy have led some observers to conclude that now is a favorable time to buy the fund.
"The France Growth Fund is an easy way to play the economic progress of the country," said Steven Vannelli, a managing director at the KJMM Investment Management Company in San Francisco. The fund gives investors a diversified selection of French companies, "all of them quality companies," he said. "The fund is fully invested and just in French stocks -- a much, much better deal than, say, a Europe fund."
Mr. Vannelli also said that "the fund is not busy turning over assets." He said the fund was not concerned about adjusting its portfolio each quarter to look as strong as possible and said that its turnover rate had ranged between 40 and 57 percent during the last three years, compared with rates of 100 to 200 percent for open-end funds. The turnover rate measures the volume of buying and selling of securities in a portfolio; high turnover increases transaction costs and can lower a fund's value.
Guy de Froment, chairman of Indosuez International Investment Services, the adviser to the France Growth Fund, expects capital goods companies, commercial banks and companies that provide services to businesses and consumers to be among the industry groups benefiting from French economic growth. The France Growth Fund's stock portfolio, which is now made up of about 70 issues, is skewed to these sectors.
Among specific stocks favored by the fund are Groupe Danone, the maker of Dannon Yogurt; Compagnie Generale des Eaux, a major waterworks and infrastructure developer, and Banque National de Paris.
