HEADLINE: Clinton Plan Keeps Deficit, Study Shows

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
President Clinton's new budget plan would fall short of his stated goal of balancing the budget in 10 years, the Congressional Budget Office has concluded.
A study by the nonpartisan agency completed tonight found that under the Clinton proposals, the deficit would be about $200 billion every year for the next decade and would be $209 billion in 2005, slightly higher than it is this year, Congressional staff assistants said. 
 The discrepancy results from different projections by the Clinton Administration and the budget office about the state of the economy in the next 10 years.
Republican Congressional leaders anticipated the finding. At a news conference this morning, Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said of the President's plan: "It doesn't do the job he claimed it would do. It doesn't come close to balancing the budget in 10 years."
In response, Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, said in an interview that the Administration's forecasts were based on the best available economic information and that the plan the President announced on Tuesday night would indeed lead to a balanced budget.
Last month, the Senate and the House of Representatives approved separate budget plans that are supposed to result in a balanced budget by 2002. These plans were grounded in economic forecasts made last winter by the budget office.
The differences between the estimates of the Administration and the budget office about how well the economy will do in the next decade are tiny. For example, the Administration predicts that the economy will grow by 2.5 percent a year. The budget office puts the figure at 2.3 percent or 2.4 percent a year.
But such small differences compounded year after year result in large gaps several years down the road. As a consequence, the spending cuts needed to predict a balanced budget using Administration figures are much smaller than those needed using the Congressional numbers.
For example, by the Administration's reckoning, the deficit in 2002 without any changes in the law would be $240 billion, and the deficit in 2005 would be $266 billion. The Congressional projections put those figures at $349 billion and $472 billion.
Congress calculates that it will need about $1.5 trillion in total savings to balance the budget in seven years. The Administration estimates that it needs only $1.1 trillion to do it in 10 years. That means the Administration does not have to predict cuts as deep as Congress to reach the same end.
A senior Administration economist explained the discrepancy this way: "This is a world where you take a small difference and you work it through the pipe and everything compounds itself and you wind up with a large difference."
Ms. Rivlin said that the two sides would have to agree on a common set of projections before they could enter serious budget negotiations but that she was not now ready to abandon the ones the Administration was using.
Neither side is accusing the other of cooking the books. "The differences are well within the range of likely outcomes," said Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the budget office who was responsible for preparing the Congressional budget estimates that are now being used.
Moreover, no one can forecast the state of the economy reliably several years in advance. "No one can say with confidence how fast the economy is going to grow in 2000, much less 2005," Ms. Rivlin said.
The forecasts of both the Administration and Congress contend, incidentally, that the country can go 10 more years without a recession, a prospect that no economist would put money on.
The Office of Management and Budget is a political arm of the White House. The Congressional Budget Office, on the other hand, has the reputation of being scrupulously nonpartisan.
In the Reagan and Bush years, wildly optimistic budget forecasts were often issued to attain political goals, and the Congressional forecasts were generally more reliable. President Clinton's budget officials have tried to make realistic projections, but the fact remains that they work for politicians.
In addition to the different assumptions about the state of the economy over the years, the Clinton Administration is more optimistic than Congress about the rate at which Medicare and Medicaid costs will rise. Again, the differences are small in each year. The Administration believes the annual rate of increase in the Government's health costs will be six-tenths of 1 percent slower than Congress calculates. But over seven years, the difference in the predictions of Medicare expenditures alone is $70 billion.
Because of this, some of the material the Administration released in conjunction with the President's speech on Tuesday night was misleading.
The Administration maintained that Mr. Clinton would save $126 billion over seven years in Medicare costs, while the House plan would save $287 billion and the Senate, $256 billion. If a common set of projections had been used, the Clinton figure would surely have been higher or the Congressional ones lower, meaning a smaller difference between the Administration and Congress.
The Administration's Medicare and Medicaid estimates were not made by the Office of Management and Budget but by actuaries at the Health Care Financing Administration, who are career civil servants. These are the same actuaries Republicans keep citing to justify the cuts they want to make in the growth in Medicare spending. The actuaries reported recently that the Medicare system would run out of money by 2002 unless changes were made in the program.

HEADLINE: 2 Sides of a Puerto Rican Coin;
Corporate Tax Breaks Help and Hurt an Economy

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

DATELINE: CULEBRA, P.R.

 BODY:
To hear her tell it, the story of Yolanda Rivera is a heartening tale of private enterprise helping to break the cycle of poverty and dependence. Unlike many unskilled Puerto Ricans, Ms. Rivera has a full-time job at a company that pays a living wage -- $11 an hour, including benefits. "What would I be doing without this job?" she declares. "Nothing."
 Ms. Rivera, a 31-year-old divorced mother of five, works for Baxter International Inc., which employs 5,600 Puerto Ricans in making health care products. Yet that is just the tip of the iceberg. Hundreds of other big American manufacturers, lured to Puerto Rico by a set of much-disputed corporate tax incentives, employ nearly one-fifth of all workers on the island and generate more than half of its economic output. The tax breaks, known as Section 936 for their obscure location in the Federal tax code, allow American corporations to escape Federal taxes on profits earned in Puerto Rico. 
 And that is where the troubles begin.
 Much of the hostility to Section 936 comes from Washington policy makers who are trying to expand the tax base to generate more revenue. After years of controversy and feverish lobbying, the generous tax breaks, which have been particularly lucrative for American pharmaceutical, chemical and electronics manufacturers, were pared in 1993 as part of a broader effort to reduce the Federal deficit.
 The modified Section 936, while safe from budget-cutting efforts this year, remains a prime target for future cuts. That is because it is an area where House Republicans, seeking further savings to balance the budget, might also win favor with a number of Democrats who share their desire to slash what both groups now call "corporate welfare."
 The problem for Puerto Rico is that while it has not been living all that well with Section 936, it probably would not be able to live without it.
 In luring so many factories to Puerto Rico, Section 936 has generated about 170,000 relatively well-paying manufacturing jobs. It has also kept many Puerto Ricans from moving to the mainland to compete for unskilled jobs. But by raising wage levels and expectations far above what unsubsidized companies can meet, it has also prevented Puerto Rico from attracting lower-paying jobs for other residents. The island's unemployment rate -- currently about 14 percent -- remains more than double the national average.
 This quandary is one reason that so many elected officials from Puerto Rico view Section 936 with resigned distaste. Not only has it been a symbol of Puerto Rico's second-class status in the United States, but some also see it as an obstacle to a more direct attack on poverty and underdevelopment.
 "Section 936," says Carlos Romero-Barcelo, the commonwealth's nonvoting delegate in Congress, "is Puerto Rico's greatest obstacle to sound economic development."
 That's not the way it looks to Yolanda Rivera, of course. She is one of 105 Baxter employees in Culebra, a separate island community of about 2,000 people that is 90 minutes by ferry off the eastern tip of the main island. She pieces together the plastic parts of bladder irrigation kits in one of the factory's "clean rooms." It is a tedious task, lightened by chatter along the assembly line and hearty lunches in the company-supported canteen. Her weekly pay of $275 is no fortune, but it beats the alternatives.
 The only other jobs that could sustain a middle-class life in Culebra are civil service positions provided by the government. The Baxter payroll represents one-quarter of the income of Culebra's residents, and is the economic glue that keeps the crime-free little community intact. "If Baxter left the island, our boat would sink," says Anastasio Soto, a former fisherman who has been the Mayor of Culebra for 15 years.
 But the economic stability of Culebra and dozens of other towns with subsidiaries of mainland companies does not come cheap. Big American corporations were lured to Puerto Rico by the promise of Section 936, which saved them $3.3 billion in taxes in 1993, the last year for which figures are available. What made it especially appealing to most of them was the opportunity to write off not only the actual cost of doing business in Puerto Rico but also to transfer billions of dollars of income from patents, trademarks, brand-name loyalty and other intangible assets carried on corporate balance sheets to Puerto Rico, where they would generate extra tax credits without adding much of value to the local economy.
 The biggest gainers have been a host of American pharmaceutical, chemical and electronics manufacturers. The Treasury Department estimated that the tax savings for Section 936 corporations in Puerto Rico averaged $16,835 a worker in 1987 -- essentially paying for 95 percent of their compensation.
 Some of that is changing. Under the 1993 budget accord, the maximum tax credit under the old rules was reduced from 100 percent of profits to 40 percent after 1997. But corporations were given the alternative of deducting 100 percent of just their payroll and capital costs, up to their total profit. That provision gives corporations a big incentive to create jobs and expand operations on the island.
 Supporters of the new tax provisions hope that the expected job losses in the companies that relied excessively on intangible-asset tax breaks will be offset by gains by companies like Baxter, which use a lot of labor.
 As long as the labor subsidy is generous, Baxter has no reason to abandon Puerto Rico. But if the subsidies are slashed further, said Carlos Antoni, a Baxter executive, the company might be tempted to automate much of the work at Culebra or consolidate operations in the Dominican Republic, where wages are much lower.
 Given a lack of politically realistic alternatives, tying Section 936 benefits more closely to job creation and investment was a step in the right direction, many analysts say. They would like to see even more effort to use the tax incentives to attract tangible capital. "Do we want machines or trademarks in Puerto Rico?" asked Joel Slemrod, an economist at the University of Michigan, who specializes in tax policy.
 But it may not be that simple. Jose Berrocal, a former head of the Government Development Bank of Puerto Rico who now works for James D. Wolfensohn Inc., a New York investment bank, said more straightforward tax incentives might do more harm than good. For one thing, he said, wage-based tax credits are already undermining Puerto Rican-owned businesses that have sprung up to serve the heavy concentration of manufacturers on the island. That is because the credits encourage big corporations to use their own employees to perform support services like maintenance, security and catering.
He also argued that subsidies might lead some American companies to close plants elsewhere in the Caribbean and to consolidate operations in Puerto Rico -- hardly Washington's intent in creating the Caribbean Basin Initiative.
 At the heart of the conundrum posed by Section 936 is the hard reality that America's responsibilities to its Caribbean commonwealth conflict with sound development policy. Because Puerto Ricans are American citizens -- and because they have the right to live anywhere in the United States -- there are both moral and practical reasons to maintain high wages and high levels of consumption on the island. Until the local economy is sufficiently productive to meet Puerto Ricans' expectations, however, efforts to sustain living standards will almost inevitably distort development.
 Puerto Rico already generates a higher percentage of its income from manufacturing than any state, a direct consequence of Section 936. By no coincidence, Puerto Rico's tourism industry lags far behind those of other Caribbean islands, partly because the wages it must pay hotel and restaurant workers are much higher than on islands with lower wage scales. And similar wage problems apply to other industries that might absorb Puerto Rico's unemployed.
 "No one is looking at investments in Puerto Rico that depend on competitive labor costs," one investment banker said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
 In some ways, Puerto Rico's quandary resembles the situation facing eastern Germany after the fall of the Berlin wall. German unification, which increased eastern wages much more rapidly than productivity, caused unemployment to soar. But Germany, noted Jeffrey Sachs, director of Harvard University's Institute for International Development, is plowing hundreds of billions of dollars into building roads and factories and training eastern Germany's work force so that its productivity will match western levels. That may not be the most efficient solution to the problem, he said, but it should eventually do the job.
 Puerto Rico, however, cannot count on any comparable government commitment to raise its productivity. And further tinkering to get more development bang from a Section 936 buck may alienate big corporations already in Puerto Rico, leaving the island without effective champions in Washington for an alternative development strategy.
 "I'm afraid we're condemning Puerto Rico to high and chronic unemployment," Mr. Sachs concluded.

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action Should Focus On Poor People, Gingrich Says

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
Speaker Newt Gingrich says that poor people need to "learn new habits" and that women and minorities who rely on affirmative action should instead take advantage of "enormous avenues for opportunity" that ignore race and sex.
Mr. Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, said he would like affirmative action to focus on poor people, provided they were willing to work extra hard, without putting more expectations on the institutions asked to educate or hire them. 
 The Speaker said: "I am prepared to say to the poor, 'You have to learn new habits. The habits of being poor don't work.' "
Mr. Gingrich made the comments on Thursday to 10 black journalists who report on race, school busing and civil rights strategy.
The Speaker said that Republicans were interested in making preference programs work for the poor but that there was "a growing consensus against" helping people solely because of their race or sex.
He said he was skeptical of "a system that says, 'Tell me what your racial makeup is and I'll tell you whether or not you get the next slot.' "
Mr. Gingrich said the flaw with affirmative action was that it was built on lawsuits, a structure encouraged by civil rights advocates who used the courts to break down segregation during the 1960's.
Meanwhile, he said, conservatives "who knew how to create wealth" failed to get involved in the movement. That left the economic experts out of social change that became increasingly economic, Mr. Gingrich said.
"When you create that kind of backward-looking, grievance-looking system, you teach people exactly the wrong habits," he said. "They end up spending their lives waiting for the lawsuit, instead of spending their lives seeking opportunity."
But advocates for affirmative action said they were not willing to heap more expectations on the victims of discrimination while expecting less of those who perpetuate bias.
"Our contract with America is the United States Constitution," said Wade Henderson, a lobbyist for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "We expect the nation to live up to its commitment to all its citizens."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEXT CHANCELLOR SEARCH MAY BE DIVISIVE
Mayor Giuliani insisted that he had the right of "approval" in the selection of a successor to Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines, who announced his resignation on Thursday. But Carol A. Gresser, chairman of the Board of Education, dismissed that idea. The disagreement suggested that the selection process for a new chancellor may be a divisive one. [Page 1.]
 
Mrs. Gresser, the person with the most power to pick the next chancellor, did not get a telephone call yesterday from City Hall, much less from Mayor Giuliani. [24.]
 
Many teachers, parents and schoolchildren were angered and saddened over the loss of a Chancellor many considered to be their leader and ally in educational reform. [24.]
 
Mr. Cortines spoke guardedly with reporters, but to his associates, he appeared to be in high spirits. [25.]
 
Mr. Giuliani's confrontations with the Chancellor have undermined his efforts in Albany to win expanded authority over New York City's schools, Democratic legislators said. [25.]
 
SUBWAY SIGNAL SPACING CAUSES CONCERN
After the fatal crash on the Williamsburg Bridge last week, subway officials acknowledge that there may be many places where the system's signals are too close together to prevent rear-end crashes if a train operator runs a red light at top speed. [1.]

ANOTHER CHALLENGE OVER HOMELESS
The Legal Aid Society again asked a judge to compel New York City to stop housing homeless families with children in a Bronx welfare office. The group requested a civil contempt-of-court ruling against Mayor Giuliani and two city agencies. [23.]

Five days after it was transformed into a drive-in without cars for the premiere of the Walt Disney film "Pocahontas," the Great Lawn in Central Park was reopened clear of the litter and other debris that had angered some park users earlier this week. [23.]

After serving less than two months of a one-year sentence, a former New York State trooper convicted in an evidence-tampering scandal has been granted early release by a Delaware County panel. The decision means that the former trooper, Patrick F. O'Hara, will leave jail six months before he would normally be eligible for parole. [22.]

HEADLINE: As His Critics' Voices Rise, Greenspan Plans an Address

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
With criticism rising that the Federal Reserve has pushed the economy to the brink of recession, its chairman, Alan Greenspan, has scheduled an address in New York for Tuesday that may be his biggest effort of the year to make his thinking clear.
 The speech before the Economic Club of New York will also be his first big attempt to counter the growing chorus of Wall Street analysts and academic economists who contend that while the central bank might have been right to start raising short-term interest rates last year, it was wrong to do so seven times. 
 The plans for Mr. Greenspan's presentation come after two weeks in which he and half a dozen other Federal Reserve officials presented an often inconsistent picture of the economy.
 One of those officials, Alan S. Blinder, the Fed's vice chairman, said in an interview this afternoon that as he watched the flow of economic statistics from various Government agencies, "I think I'm growing slightly more pessimistic week by week."
 The American economy may stop growing and even shrink in either the second quarter or the third, but probably not in both, Mr. Blinder added. Most economists define a recession as two or more consecutive quarters of shrinking economic output, and Mr. Blinder said this was not likely.
 Mr. Blinder's comments were consistent with Mr. Greenspan's brief remarks last Sunday in Basel, Switzerland, that the United States economy might face a mild recession in the near future but not a deep or lengthy downturn. Just four days earlier, in comments in Seattle, Mr. Greenspan raised the possibility of a recession but played it down. The changing tone of the remarks created confusion about where he stood.
 Some of the regional presidents of the Federal Reserve have taken even more optimistic positions, questioning whether the economy is even slowing significantly.
 Mr. Greenspan is scheduled to give a formal speech on Tuesday for up to half an hour and then take questions for up to 45 minutes from Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist, and Martin S. Davis, the managing director of a private investment company and a former chairman of Paramount Communications.
 Mr. Davis and Mr. Kaufman said today that they did not have any strong views on whether the Fed should cut interest rates. Both men declined to say what they planned to ask, but the questions could be tough. Figures in the last month have shown shrinking employment, falling industrial production and stagnant retail sales.
 The statistics have produced calls from some Wall Street analysts for Fed officials to cut interest rates at their next policy meeting on July 5 and 6. Some economists are even saying the Fed has waited too long.
 "I don't think they're going to turn this around with a cut in July," said William Poole, a monetarist at Brown University, who added that the Fed's decision then "will determine how deep the recession is and how long."
 Mr. Greenspan has apparently consulted very little with his colleagues about what to say on Tuesday. But recent interviews with Fed officials, together with Mr. Greenspan's public remarks and Congressional testimony over the last year, suggest that he will emphasize the underlying strength of the economy while expressing growing concern over the current economic slowdown.
 The factors supporting the view that the economy will bounce back after a couple of weak quarters include a weak dollar, which may stimulate exports; lower long-term interest rates, which help the housing markets, and fairly strong personal income and corporate profits, which mean that consumers and businesses have money to spend if they have the confidence to do so.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Try Recovery But Fall Short

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, although they recovered somewhat in the afternoon after a top Federal Reserve official suggested that the economy was weaker than previously thought.
 The comments by Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Fed, rekindled some hope that the Fed would cut short-term interest rates soon. Market prices have seesawed as investors have tried to pin down the size and timing of such a move. 
 Traders said yields rose on short and intermediate securities, which are the most sensitive to rate moves by the central bank, after the University of Michigan released its preliminary consumer sentiment index yesterday morning showing a higher-than-expected number for June. The index rose to 92.3 from 89.8 in May, traders said.
 Mr. Blinder's comments, which came in an interview with Knight-Ridder Financial News, provided fuel for the market's second consecutive day of speculation about an interest rate cut.
 He said that he was concerned about the slowing economic growth during recent months and that in the time since the Fed had last raised overnight bank loan rates in February, economic reports had painted "a very considerably weaker picture than we saw four and a half months ago." These comments yesterday did lift bonds from their lows of the day, but they were in contrast to the comments he made a day before to a Minneapolis group.
 "Ultimately, the mixed signals that we're getting from the Fed are likely to be negative for bonds because the market needs to have a clear view," said Tony Crescenzi, head of fixed-income trading at Miller, Tabak, Hirsch & Company in New York.
 Without a rate cut anytime soon, some managers are saying, bonds are too expensive.
 The 30-year bond slipped 4/32 to a price of 1132/32 for a yield of 6.62 percent, up from 6.61 percent the previous session. Shorter-maturity bills and notes also fell in price, sending the three-month bill rate up a basis point to 5.47 percent and the yield on a 10-year note up 2 basis points to 6.19 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 Christopher A. Low, senior economist at the HSBC Group in New York, said the numbers he saw in the sentiment index suggested to him that confidence was not eroding so quickly as some of the economic statistics might indicate.
 "Bonds lost on concerns that consumer spending might pick up fast enough to allow the economy to rebound before the current slowdown turns into an outright downturn," Mr. Low said. "That would cancel out any hope of a Fed reduction in short-term interest rates."
 "Mr. Blinder's remarks today led to a nice rebound in prices," Mr. Low added "I think Mr. Blinder's comments were probably taken out of context Thursday, so he returned today to clarify his view on the economy. He seemed much more concerned about the risk of a recession and much less concerned about the risk of inflation." And the risk of recession, Mr. Low continued, would allow for the possibility of a Fed easing in short order.
 "We are faced now with a dearth of economic statistics," Mr. Low said, "which means the game of who said what last takes on more importance. There are a few numbers that will be market movers, particularly durable-goods orders next Friday, which will give the market an indication of manufacturers' willingness to bet on a rebound and at the same time give an indication of how far along they are in the inventory correction."
 Until next Friday, there will be little economic data released, Mr. Low noted.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Steady as Group of Seven Reaffirms Intention to Bolster It

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar was steady yesterday after the seven leading industrial nations reaffirmed their pledge to work together to bolster the currency.
 In Halifax, Nova Scotia, leaders of the seven nations -- the United States, Japan, Britain, Germany, France, Canada and Italy -- agreed to "cooperate closely in exchange markets" to secure an "orderly reversal" of the dollar's 15 percent decline against the Japanese yen and 9.6 percent decline against the German mark so far this year. 
 The pledge echoes a statement by Group of Seven finance ministers and central bankers made at the group's last meeting on April 25. For that reason, traders said yesterday's communique did little to influence sentiment toward the dollar one way or the other.
 "The market waited all day with bated breathe for something that didn't materialize," said Jim Raphael, currency trader at NatWest USA Bancorp in Jersey City. "The G-7 is successful in keeping the market very off balance, which is probably exactly what they want."
 In earlier trading in New York, the dollar slipped against the mark as pessimism grew over whether the Group of Seven would produce a specific plan to bolster the dollar, currency dealers said. The dollar settled in New York at 1.4002 marks from 1.4063 marks on Thursday. The dollar rose to 84.76 Japanese yen from 84.52 yen.
 Concern that the Federal Reserve and other central banks could stage another surprise bout of dollar-buying should prevent the dollar from falling too far, dealers said.
 "I think it will be a cat-and-mouse game," said Tom Hoge, vice president of corporate trading at Bank of New York. "The market is concerned about intervention, while central banks are concerned about a failed intervention." That should keep the dollar from moving too far in either direction against major currencies in the days ahead, he said.
 With the Group of Seven meeting out of the way, traders said they would focus on the outlook for interest rates in Germany and the United States. Signs of slowing in both countries have prompted speculation that official rates could soon fall.
 "We'll be looking at the further deterioration in U.S. economic numbers to decide how soon the Fed will ease," Mr. Raphael of NatWest said. "If the Bundesbank eases first, it could be dollar positive." Higher American rates, relative to German rates, often help the dollar against the mark by making deposits in the United States more attractive.

HEADLINE: Slovak Publisher, Facing the West, Checks His Flanks

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia

 BODY:
Immediately after the Communists fell in 1989, the publishing house created by the novelist Martin Simecka carried on smoothly enough. The goal of the house, called Archa, was to reacquaint Slovaks with the European thinkers who had been banned for 50 years. Simple, elegantly designed pocket editions on the meaning of freedom, human rights and conflict in modern societies by such writers as the philosopher Raymond Aron and the sociologist Karl Mannheim sold at the equivalent of a dollar each to an audience eager to learn about the West through means other than cable television.
But now Mr. Simecka, a gregarious 37-year-old author with prizes from the United States, says Archa is in danger from both an increasingly anti-democratic and nationalistic Slovak Government and declining idealism abroad about Eastern Europe. 
 "Sponsors from outside are losing interest," Mr. Simecka said of the modest publishing venture, squeezed into a few rooms above the side entrance of a bland Government building. "I understand when they say you've had five years to stand on your own. But we have only five million people in this country and sometimes when I'm very cynical I say I know every one of our readers personally."
But the most serious menace, he said, lies at home. "In the Government's eyes we are very unpopular," Mr. Simecka said. "One minister said Archa was a cuckoo's egg in Slovak culture, meaning we are foreign." The Government has revoked the license of a Slovak investment fund that had helped finance the publishing house, in part, it seemed to Mr. Simecka, because Archa also backed an independent daily newspaper critical of the Government.
"Now if we ask for help from business people they'll say: 'I'd like to but I don't dare,' " he said.
Small, quality publishing houses all over Eastern Europe are running into economic problems as the initial burst of money from the West and euphoria at home peter out. But the fragility of Archa, the only publisher in Slovakia to concentrate on serious nonfiction, is particularly critical as Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar, a former Communist who was re-elected last year, tries to create an atmosphere of xenophobia.
Mr. Simecka is a second generation writer, the son of a well-known Slovak writer and dissident, Milan Simecka, who was imprisoned and not allowed to publish after the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. Because of his father's opposition to the Communists, Mr. Simecka was denied university admission. Instead of attending class, he took menial jobs: as a hospital orderly in an operating room and as a clerk in a hardware store selling enamel pans. In an autobiographical coming-of-age novel, he wrote about his adventures of maneuvering around the repressive system and his earnest desire to "be moral, to be good" amid all the sloth.
The novel, "The Year of the Frog," was both comic and wistful and appeared in Slovakia in samizdat form before the Communists collapsed. Since then, it has been translated into English and French. In 1993 it won the Pegasus Prize for Literature, awarded in the United States for a first foreign novel, and last November The Los Angeles Times Book Prize for a first published work of fiction in any language. It is to be published by Simon & Schuster in the fall.
Mr. Simecka, a tall, wiry man, is working on a second novel. He won't divulge the subject except to say it is set in contemporary Slovakia. Mr. Simecka said, "The political novel is not a good novel." But to hear him talk passionately about Slovakia, there is little doubt where the manuscript is heading.
"I think it will get worse in Slovakia; what is coming here is an authoritarian regime," he said as he paced the kitchen of the worker's cottage he and his wife, Marla, bought during the Communist days in one of the few Bratislava suburbs not bulldozed for apartment houses.
"It doesn't mean a totalitarian regime. It means what I call the post-modern dictatorship. Meciar has a talent to be a dictator. He is creating this step by step by manipulating the electronic media, the secret police, business. All the methods are old, he uses them in a different period, in new ways to manipulate society."
Mr. Simecka cited the decision by Mr. Meciar's Government to ban three popular television shows, including "An Evening With Milan Markovic," a Saturday night show of satire on the Slovak political system. At the same time, the state-run television news is a dull but laudatory recitation of the Government's doings, not dissimilar to the style of the Communist-era newscast, he said. In another sign of trying to limit dissent, journalists from the opposition newspaper Sme have been banned as interviewers on the televised weekly talk with a Government figure.
"After getting the electronic media, the next step is to get his hands on the press," Mr. Simecka asserted.
This has already started, he said, with the threat to impose a value-added tax on newspapers, most of which irritate the Meciar Government because they are sympathetic to the opposition parties. The Culture Ministry has started to deny money to theaters deemed to be against the interests of the Government.
"That we are not forbidden -- that is a big difference from the Communist times," Mr. Simecka said of writers and publishers. "Indeed, the only thing that has survived from the November 1989 revolution, the only thing with roots from then is the publishing house. Everything else has gone. The regime and the political parties are not from the revolution."
But he is pessimistic. "Before 1989," he said, "I had a desire for two things: a passport and the possibility to publish. I have these two things and in the near future I don't think they will be threatened. But in the future I don't know. It is a race against time."

HEADLINE: Security Council Approves Sending Reinforcements to Bosnia

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 16

 BODY:
In a hastily called session early this morning, the Security Council approved sending up to 12,500 more troops to aid the United Nations military force in Bosnia, but put off for now the issue of how they would be paid for.
Adopted on a 13-0 vote, with Russia and China abstaining, the resolution was needed to accommodate a new rapid-response force being assembled by Britain, France and the Netherlands to reinforce the peacekeeping troops in the field. 
 The resolution, which makes clear that the additional troops are for peacekeeping operations, passed as fighting intensified around Sarajevo, raising the possibility once more that the United Nations troops, whatever their numbers, might have to withdraw if they cannot fulfill their mandate of protecting civilians and delivering relief supplies.
President Clinton, in Halifax, Nova Scotia, for the Group of Seven meeting, said today that if United Nations troops were forced to withdraw from the Balkans he would favor lifting the weapons embargo on the Bosnia Government so that it could better arm itself. Republican leaders in Congress also favor lifting the embargo, and withdrawing the United Nations troops.
The Administration, which earlier favored lifting the embargo by agreement with other nations, stopped pushing the issue last year under pressure from the British and the French, who have the largest contingents of troops in Bosnia. But there is a shared sentiment in Congress and the Administration that the Bosnian Government has been handicapped by the ban since the Bosnian Serbs have had access to the weaponry of the Yugoslav Army.
After a dispute erupted between the Europeans and Americans here on Thursday over who would pay for the new reinforcements in Bosnia, the Security Countil resolution was amended at the last minute to put off determination of financial assessments or contributions until some unspecified future date.
"The wording of the resolution leaves all options open," said Joe Sills, spokesman for Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali. "This is a question of a political decision that will have to be made by the member states most closely involved."
In her speech early this morning, Madeleine K. Albright, the United States delegate, told the Council, "To put the matter simply, in a time of serious budgetary cutbacks, we are not now prepared to pay the lion's share of the cost of expanding this force."
Clinton Administration officials said today that it would conduct a fund-raising drive among the world's wealthier nations to help pay the bill for the rapid-response force for Bosnia. The White House spokesman, Mike McCurry, said that the United States would contribute to the fund, but less than the 31 percent it would normally have been assessed.
The Security Council's unexpected meeting was called by the French after European and American leaders at the economic summit in Halifax agreed to the compromise, which added eight words to a three-page resolution that has been in circulation all week.
The Council had adjourned Thursday evening without agreement, expecting to return to the issue this morning. The call for a midnight session brought diplomats, interpreters and many staff members scurrying in from their homes to pass a resolution at a meeting that lasted until 3 A.M.
France and its new President, Jacques Chirac, had staked a great deal of prestige on getting the resolution passed while Mr. Chirac was in the United States. He met President Clinton on Wednesday and Mr. Boutros-Ghali on Thursday, after which he confidently predicted to reporters here that the resolution would pass the same day.
But it was Washington that caused nearly a week of delay in acting on the resolution, irritating both the French and the British. The Clinton Administration, which supported a resolution that would have automatically led to the United States being assessed nearly a third of the cost of the operation, was challenged twice by Republican leaders in Congress who opposed the financial obligation.
Congressional leaders also said that the Administration had created its own problems by failing to consult fully with lawmakers as the resolution was being drawn up in New York.
On Tuesday, the chairman of the House Committee on International Relations and two other Representatives wrote to President Clinton saying that they were "dumbfounded" to learn that the United States would pay for a rapid-response force that began as a strictly European project with limited American backing. The Administration responded by stalling further debate here.
On Thursday, a day after meeting with President Chirac, Speaker of the House Newt Gingrich and Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, wrote another letter asking that the rapid-response force be paid for by voluntary contributions. Mr. Chirac had left the impression that France would be willing to have Europeans or others pay for the new force, a position contrary to that of Britain, which always wanted the costs divided by normal United Nations assessments.
Mr. Gingrich and Mr. Dole also said that they had been led to believe by Mr. Chirac that the force would not fall under United Nations civilian control, an assertion that ran contrary to documents circulating here since last week. It is unclear who misunderstood whom.
The effect of the Gingrich-Dole letter was to derail the Clinton Administration's support for the resolution, creating havoc in the Security Council Thursday.
By Thursday night, all the parties involved had bucked the issue up to Halifax for a decision, which was not made until late in the evening. Then the French, to make a point, brought the whole slumbering organization to life at an even later hour.

HEADLINE: A Fair Farm Bill

 BODY:
The House should get behind a bipartisan farm bill proposed this week that would bring down food costs and the deficit by wiping out Federal farm price supports. A less obvious, but important, virtue is that the bill could also save the food stamp and child nutrition programs.
The farm bill -- sponsored by Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, and Richard Zimmer, Republican of New Jersey -- would phase out commodity support programs. These set target prices for rice, cotton, wheat and several other crops. If market prices fall below the targets, the Government pays farmers cash to make up the difference. The bill would also eliminate subsidies to farmers who earn more than $100,000 in non-farm income. The Schumer-Zimmer bill would save about $30 billion over seven years. 
 Farm subsidies are inequitable -- transferring money from consumers, some of whom are poor, to owners of farms, many of whom are wealthy. The average net worth of the farms that collect 70 percent of the Federal payouts -- those with annual sales over $100,000 -- is nearly $1 million. About 40 percent of the subsidies go to non-farm landlords. Another flaw is that the commodity subsidies make no economic sense. American farms are the productive envy of the world and require no handout from Washington. Indeed, farm products that are not subsidized, like potatoes and tomatoes, do perfectly well.
Besides raising food prices and the deficit, farm price supports threaten the Federal food stamp and nutrition programs, like subsidized school breakfasts and lunches. Budget resolutions will require Congressional committees to make cuts of about $40 billion in food stamps, nutrition and farm programs. The committees currently plan to take only about $10 billion out of farm programs. But under the Schumer-Zimmer bill, farm programs would be cut an additional $20 billion, leaving that much more for food stamps and nutrition.
President Clinton in his latest proposed budget chose not to take on the farm lobby -- proposing a meager cut in farm programs of $4 billion over seven years. More courage is needed. At a time when the Republicans are dismantling the welfare safety net for the poor, Congress ought to do no less for farmers, phasing out their safety net. The poor deserve low-cost food more than millionaire farmers deserve Federal handouts.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Hotel Franchise Company Looks to Century 21

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Harry R. Silverman is the biggest hotel magnate in the nation, but nobody knows his name. Maybe that's because he does not actually own any hotels.
 Mr. Silverman is no Conrad Hilton or J. Willard Marriott. But in less than five years, he has quietly put together a hotel empire that exceeds anything they ever dreamed of. As chairman and chief executive of Hospitality Franchise Systems, Mr. Silverman owns the franchise operations that control 4,200 mostly low- to mid-price hotels that go under the Ramada, Howard Johnson, Super 8, Days Inn, Park Inn and Villager Lodge names. Hospitality, in return for some nice fees, provides nationwide marketing services and centralized reservations systems to the chains. 
 And, while Mr. Silverman would not mind being better known, he is not about to change a winning formula. He is taking that same idea on the road.
 Last week, Hospitality Franchise agreed to pay up to $230 million for Century 21, the nation's largest residential real estate chain, with 6,000 franchised offices. That follows closely on the heels of Mr. Silverman's decision last year to create a gambling subsidiary to provide marketing services to 10 casinos in six states.
 Strange alliances? Not as Mr. Silverman sees it. "We're not in the hotel business; our customers are," he said in a recent interview in his 41st-floor office in midtown Manhattan. "We're a service provider to franchises." And franchising, as Mr. Silverman points out, "is a cash machine, and its assets are all tax-deductible."
 Wall Street seems to agree. Since Hospitality, which is based in Parsippany, N.J., announced its plans to acquire Century 21, its stock has risen from $28.75 to $31.75 yesterday.
 Hospitality makes most of its money by collecting a set percentage of annual gross room revenues for the services it provides to hotels affiliated with its six brands. Fees from those room revenues produced $132.7 million of Hospitality Franchise's $312.5 million in total revenues last year. But the operation was so profitable that it accounted for more than 80 percent of the company's $53.5 million in earnings.
 Hospitality's success has made Mr. Silverman a very rich man. He owns about 10 percent of the company, which makes him worth roughly $180 million today. Apart from Mr. Silverman, the managers of the company own a collective 15 percent. Each of the 12 members of the senior management committee, which includes Mr. Silverman, has at least $1 million in equity.
 But can Mr. Silverman duplicate that success elsewhere? Some analysts think so.
 "He'll do something similar for the domestic residential real estate market to what he did for lodging," said Michael G. Mueller of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "It's a different business, but it has been undermanaged and Henry has been very adept at figuring out what to do to increase value. That will encourage more people to sign up with the system."
With only limited opportunities to expand the reach of his hotel empire, Mr. Silverman sees Century 21 -- whose revenues last year were just 40 percent of Hospitality Franchise's -- as opening the door to what could be a much bigger business in the future.
 "If you add up all the revenues of all the hotels in the United States, including food and beverage, it's about a $30 -billion-a-year business," he said. "Single-family residences are a trillion-dollar business. Obviously, profit opportunities are significantly larger with Century 21 than with hotels."
 To begin the transformation of Century 21, formerly owned by Metropolitan Life, into a more efficient cash machine, Mr. Silverman is talking to a publisher about putting out a series of real estate books under the Century 21 imprimatur.
 The next step would be to adapt a preferred-vendor program to the housing market. Hospitality's hotels now sign exclusive contracts with a range of suppliers from AT&T to Alamo Rent-a-Car to provide certain goods and services in return for the best possible price. The same concept, Mr. Silverman says, should work in real estate, allowing Hospitality to grab an extra piece of the action on tens of thousands of deals. Each slice might be thin, but they should add up.
 "Every housing transaction has many elements, including property and casualty insurance, mortgage insurance," he said. "You could designate an insurance company or a series of mortgage lenders, and make them your preferred vendor."
 Despite a poor track record by many other companies in combining disparate units, Mr. Silverman also believes there are economies of scale to be achieved by integrating some operations. "There are important synergies in the back office, the part of the business involved in containing costs," he said. These include marketing, risk management, training, human resources, the legal department and accounting. "We bought six companies," he said, "and our back office is essentially the same as when we started."
 Mr. Silverman has a reputation as a stern, somewhat aloof boss, who pays his top executives well, but expects them to deliver good results -- or else. "We have a policy that you're entitled to a raise each year or you're out," he said. "The theory of a marginal performer doesn't exist in our company."
 For all his interest in exploring new territories, however, Mr. Silverman still looks forward to some remaining conquests on the hotel front. "It's no secret that we are very covetous of the Hilton name," he said. "We have every hotel segment covered except the four- and five-star level, so it would be advantageous to have another arrow in our quiver."
 Hospitality has made an offer, through Goldman, Sachs, to buy Hilton Hotels, probably with a partner that would acquire the real estate ("bricks and sticks," Mr. Silverman calls it). That would leave Hospitality free to own the name alone, which it would license to Hilton hotels and casinos.
 "They're considering it," he said. But, after a pause and a fleeting smile that suggested a rare moment of uncertainty, he added: "They're undoubtedly considering other proposals as well."

HEADLINE: The Case For No Helmets

BYLINE: By Dick Teresi; Dick Teresi is editor of VQ, a magazine about Harley-Davidson motorcycles.

DATELINE: AMHERST, Mass.

 BODY:
It's time for the nation's oldest bike festival. This weekend, 150,000 motorcycle enthusiasts have converged on Laconia, N.H., for the Laconia Motorcycle Rally. Ah, the joys of motorcycling! The throaty roar of your V-twin engine, the call of the open road, the wind in your hair . . . .
Wait. Forget about that last part. The riders en route to Laconia won't feel any wind in their hair. They'll just feel the rush of air over their plastic helmets -- at least until they cross into New Hampshire, which doesn't require riders over 18 to wear them. 
 Forty-seven states have some helmet requirements. At the rally, plenty of T-shirts will deride motorcycle helmet laws. They'll sell well. In a survey of 2,500 bikers at the 1993 rally, 98 percent of the respondents said they opposed such laws. This opposition is often dismissed by nonriders as evidence of bikers' rebelliousness. But we oppose the laws for reasons other than personal freedom. Helmets are not necessarily the life-savers some people think they are. In some cases, they may be killers.
Deep in the plush recesses of any helmet approved by the Department of Transportation is a tiny warning label: "Some reasonably foreseeable impacts may exceed this helmet's capability to protect against severe injury or death." The unspecified "reasonably foreseeable impacts" are any collisions at speeds greater than 15 miles per hour. The department tests the protection provided by helmets by dropping them on an anvil from a height of six feet. This is equivalent to an impact at 14.4 miles per hour. So if you're riding to Laconia, keep your speedometer below 15 miles per hour.
But what about all those statistics purporting to prove that helmets save lives? Some studies indicate that there are fewer motorcycle deaths per one million residents in states with helmet laws than in states where helmets are not mandatory. (The study most cited was made by the Center for Disease Control and covers 1979 to 1986.) But this is largely because there are more riders per capita in states that did not require helmets.
If you take those same statistics and count motorcycle fatality rates per 10,000 registered motorcycles rather than per general population -- a more sensible approach -- you find that nine states without helmet laws had a lower fatality rate (3.05 deaths per 10,000 motorcycles) than those that mandated helmets (3.38).
What about claims that helmet laws reduce deaths caused by head trauma? Jonathan Goldstein, a professor of economics at Bowdoin College, studied crash and injury statistics and found that while helmets might prevent head injuries at very low speeds, they can increase the possibility of neck injuries at high speeds.
This makes sense. The body, like any object under impact, breaks at its weakest point. If a biker wearing a four-pound helmet is thrown to the pavement, the head might be saved but the neck is more likely to snap.
Helmets, especially full-face models, suppress the normal sensations of wind and speed and thus can give riders a false sense of invulnerability and can lead to excessive risk-taking and dangerous riding habits.
The real problem is not uncovered heads. It's that too many bikers don't ride well and too many automobile drivers don't look out for motorcycles. To make motorcycling safer, the nation needs better driver and rider education. A 1988 study by the American Motorcyclist Association, showed that states with good motorcycle education programs and no helmet laws had an average fatality rate of 2.56 deaths per 100 motorcycle accidents while states with helmet laws but no training had a death rate of 3.09 per 100 accidents.
Is there a place for helmets? Sure. Anyone who rides in a car should wear one. Head injuries make up only 20 percent of serious injuries to motorcyclists but are far more common in car accidents. If the state legislators who have passed helmet laws are serious, they ought to prove it by always wearing one in the car. Meanwhile, let motorcyclists feel the wind in their hair.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Filipinos Splurge on Resorts to Woo Tourists

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: CEBU, the Philippines

 BODY:
After decades of a downward-spiraling economy and tumultuous politics, the Philippines has steadied itself. The economy is beginning to boom. Politics has settled down to a more genial level of boisterousness. And finally the door to tourism has been opened with enthusiasm.
Tourist arrivals in the Philippines, especially from other Asian countries and Hong Kong, have climbed rapidly in the last three years. From just over 900,000 visitors in 1990, the Philippines saw a record 1.6 million last year. High quality, Governmentapproved hotel rooms, which numbered only 9,000 in 1990, have mushroomed to 11,000. 
 Even as older, run-down Government-owned resorts are closing or are being taken over by private owners, a stream of new hotels and resorts are being built or have recently opened throughout the country. Many of these resorts boast facilities rivaling those elsewhere in Southeast Asia: impeccable, spacious cabanas huddled around glistening pools overlooking pearl-white beaches. And there are, as well, lower-key, more rustic sites scattered across the archipelago.
Some resorts occupy entire tiny islands. The Amanpulo, for one, rambles across the island of Pamalican, about 125 miles northeast of Northern Palawan. Like other Aman resorts throughout Southeast Asia, the Amanpulo is expensive; rooms start at $350 during the high, winter season. The palm-fringed shard of sand and jungle is surrounded by a huge reef for divers and snorkelers. A golf cart comes with each of the 40 air-conditioned hillside casitas, or bungalows.
The island of Palawan, which the country's tourism officials refer to as the Philippines' last frontier because of its brilliantly clear waters, untouched reefs and blindingly white beaches, has a few resorts as well. Not new, but a favorite of Asian travelers, is El Nido on Miniloc Island, one of hundreds of islands that sprinkle the western coast of Palawan. With peak season prices of $190, it is a bargain for Asia, and offers everything from diving to cave exploration.
Among the newest of the Philippine resorts is the 359-room Mactan Island Resort, run by the Shangri-La group of hotels here on Cebu Island, about an hour south of Manila by air. Cebu Island, with a proliferation of dive sites, beaches and jungle, has struggled to attract Western tourists until recently. A disheveled Government-owned resort called Argao, a frequent destination for Asian visitors, closed last year, so the recent opening of the Shangri-La resort has been a boon for the island.
Cebu, unlike smaller islands, has direct service to Hong Kong, usually the central destination for visitors to Southeast Asia from Europe and North America.
At the former American naval base at Subic Bay, a three-hour drive from Manila over sometimes hair-raising roads, or 30 minutes by helicopter, the Subic Bay Resort and Casino has just opened for business. Owned by Malaysian investors, the hotel is a former officers' barracks which has been transformed into a nautically themed luxury hotel.
The hotel offers a range of gambling, from blackjack to slot machines and poker. Rooms are aligned along corridors designed like those on a 1940's cruise ship and range in price from $128 for a double to about $220 for a two-room suite.
Around the old naval base, parts of which have been turned into light industrial parks, are swimming pools, a golf course, bowling, bungee jumping from an old Navy crane and, for the hardy, a jungle survival course taught by Negritos, the area's indigenous people, who live in the jungle.
The biggest obstacle for tourists coming to Asia for the first time is Manila's ramshackle and chaotic Ninoy Aquino International Airport, which suffers from passenger overcrowding. Entire families, neighborhoods or villages will descend on the airport to see friends off or welcome them home. With more than four million Filipinos working abroad, mini-festivals surrounding arrivals and departures are a constant occurrence. Baggage delivery is slow, and shuttling to the domestic airport is not always trouble free. The Philippine Government hopes to build a new airport, but at the moment, it is a long way off.

HEADLINE: Spring Housing-Sales Climate Is Chilly

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
SPRING is the time of year when residential real estate markets often blossom. This spring, though, the market's climate in most of the New York metropolitan region has been cool.
House closing figures -- which typically reflect contracts signed one to three months earlier -- have been below those of a year ago in most areas and sale prices have been somewhat lower for many types of houses. 
 Not even near-record-low interest rates have sparked a rise in home buying activity, though some local brokers have reported an increase in recent weeks. Because closings often take up to 90 days, though, sales figures from May and early June will not become public until late summer.
"Consumers may be a little overcautious today, considering that home prices have stabilized and where interest rates are at," said Robert Sperte, president of Century 21 of the Northeast, which is based in Manhattan. "We think it is a healthy, normal market now in most of the region, and the boom-and-bust cycle is over."
Economic uncertainty, particularly about future layoffs, continues to hold back potential home buyers in the New York metropolitan area, however. There also appears to be a lingering hesitation because of heavy losses suffered by property owners in the late 80's and early 90's.
Other factors are at play, as well, like less favorable demographics, specifically a declining pool of young first-time home buyers. And median home prices in many parts of the region, even after the drop off a few years ago, are still high compared with local median income levels.
Rents, however, are at record highs throughout the suburbs as well as in the city, prompting some tenants to put pencil to paper and consider buying a home, regardless of their qualms about potential lack of liquidity or the prospects for appreciation of residential real estate these days.
Thus, at best, the overall market in the region this spring appears flat at least compared with last year, with small pockets of strength, such as high-end properties in Manhattan's better neighborhoods and some single-family homes in affluent suburban towns, such as New Canaan and Westport, Conn., with outstanding public-school systems.
"Over the last few weeks, the upper end of the market in Manhattan has been hot as a pistol," said Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group, a Manhattan real estate firm. "It is characterized by lots of buyers with cash, a short supply of large apartments and multiple overbidding.
"More foreigners bought condominiums this spring than ever before," she added. "With rising rents and the drop in the dollar, foreign investors snapped up whatever remaining inventory was available."
Rick O'Neil, a regional director of Century 21 in Westbury L.I., added: "Queens right now is the hottest market in the five boroughs. I have a feeling it is because there are a lot of homes available for first-time buyers, and there are immigrants that either come here with money or save up enough for a down payment."
Overall, though, the decline in sales volume was almost universal in the region in March and April.
IN Westchester County, for example, where there were a record number of sales in 1994, there were 53 fewer homes sold in April than in March, when there were 288, and 106 fewer this April than in April 1994, when there were 341, according to statistics compiled by the New York State Association of Realtors. That's a drop of 18 percent over one month and 31 percent over a year earlier. In Rockland County, there were 135 April sales this year compared with 138 the month before and 160 in April 1994.
On Long Island and in Queens, the number of home sales fell to 1,176 in April from 1,338 in March, a 12 percent decrease, and from 1,349 a year earlier -- a 13 percent drop. On Staten Island, the number of homes sold in April dropped to 52 from 83 in March and from 72 in April 1994. (No reliable statistics exist for Brooklyn or the Bronx.)
In Fairfield County, Conn., the number of homes sold fell to 1,012 in April from 1,136 12 months earlier, a 10.9 percent decline, according to The Commercial Record, a weekly newspaper in Hartford that tracks real estate transactions.
The April figure was also a 13.9 percent decline from March, when 1,176 homes were sold.
"There continues to be concern about the economy -- even in Fairfield County," said Vincent Valvo, editor and publisher of The Commercial Record. "Fairfield County is doing better than the rest of the state, but it is not immune to problems. Wall Street isn't doing well right now, and there have been problems at Sikorsky, the helicopter-maker in Stratford."
In New Jersey, there are no statistics available yet for April, but the figures for the first quarter of the year showed a decline in sales for Northern New Jersey to 52,200 in the first quarter of 1995 from 63,500 in the first quarter of 1994 -- a drop of 18.1 percent.
In New York City, the trend downward in sales was not as sharp. Condominium sales, for example, steadily declined from January through April. But the 182 sold in April are still a tad more than the 177 sold in April 1994.
As for the co-op market in Manhattan, comprehensive statistics on sales really don't exist, and the broadest set of figures available, which are produced by the Real Estate Board of New York, only cover the first quarter of 1995 and only about 25 percent of the sales in the city, according to the board.
Those statistics show that there were 368 sales in the first quarter of 1995 compared with 358 in the first quarter of 1994, a slight improvement.
"SALES have definitely been on the upswing in May and June, particularly in the studio and one-bedroom category," said Deborah Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York. "This may be due, in part, to the extreme tightness of the rental market. With fewer units available for lease, a lot of renters are suddenly becoming buyers."
When digesting all these sales figures from various areas, it is important to keep in mind that sales for the first quarter -- and even for April -- are not truly an accurate reflection of much of the activity this spring.
This is because closings on single-family-home sales routinely take two to three months, and the process can be even longer for co-ops because of the need for board approval. So, a true statistical picture of the spring market won't be visible until late summer or even early fall.
"The decline in actual home sales across the country and the Northeast this spring is really a reflection of a drop in activity that took place in the later part of 1994 when the Fed pushed rates higher," said Mr. Sperte of Century 21 of the Northeast.
The decline over the first quarter of last year also reflects how well the market was doing a year ago, as much as a downturn in 1995. Last spring was a banner year in many places because of pent-up demand among Baby Boomers who didn't or couldn't buy during the late 80's and early 90's. Many home buyers also took the plunge last spring after the Federal Reserve starting raising interest rates, fearing that they would only go higher in the next few months or years.
"Over the last year, rates had not gone up enough to create a pent-up demand across the board, but they did slow sales of low-to-mid-priced properties," said Clark Halstead, managing partner of the Halstead Property Company, a residential real estate brokerage firm in Manhattan.
"With rents at astronomical levels for small apartments now, I think this current rate drop is going to push a lot of buyers into the market for studios, and one- and two-bedroom apartments," he added. "There is a lot of well-priced property out there, and there is a feeling that rates can't go much lower. When buyers start to think that rates have bottomed, there is almost a rush to buy. I think we are going to see that this summer."
There are pockets of strength already in Manhattan. They tend, though, to be in the town-house market, which usually starts at around $1 million, and in co-ops in the $750,000-and-up range. The number of such homes, however, is minuscule compared with the thousands of studio and one-bedroom apartments in the city.
"There is a perception that because the market is strong at the top it is strong throughout and that is not true," said Alan Rogers, managing partner with Douglas Elliman, the Manhattan real estate broker and management company. "It's a seller's market at the top and at the bottom it's a buyer's market."
Mr. Halstead added: "It's an orderly market, not frenetic like it was in the 80's. This time last year, people on Wall Street got bonus checks, and this year it's unemployment checks."
SALES prices have mirrored the flat trend in sales volume, for the most part, though measuring changes using median prices is imprecise. And it is generally considered by economists and statisticians to be of limited use in a real estate market because its results can be skewed by a lack of market activity or a pattern of dissimilar sales in different years.
The median price per room of studio and one-bedroom apartments in Manhattan, according to the Real Estate Board, fell to $50,000 from $56,000, but rose for two-bedroom units to $83,500 from $75,833.
Ellen Bitton , co-founder of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, a mortgage broker, said that her firm has seen an increase in sales this spring, spurred by falling interest rates.
"Once fixed-rates dipped in May to their lowest level in the last 15 months, the sales dam seemed to burst," she said. "From February 1995 to May 1995 there was a 45 percent increase in new mortgage applications here, and I would venture to say that only about 20 to 25 percent of that was refinancing.
"We are not in the midst of a recession and the low rates today don't mean the same thing they did 18 months ago," she added. "People want to take out loans today. They are very interested in buying and getting what they see are low-rate loans. They are very interested in buying and getting low mortgage rate deals."
The average interest rate on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages in the New York metropolitan area has plunged in the last few months, dropping more than 1.5 percentage points to 7.84 as of last Wednesday from its recent high of 9.39 percent on Dec. 16, according to HSH Associates, a mortgage research company in Butler, N.J.
That means that anyone who simply waited five months to buy a home with a fixed-rate mortgage may have saved, before taxes, $110 a month on a $100,000 mortgage; the payments would have dropped to $723 from $833.
Rates on adjustable-rate mortgages also have dropped -- but not as much. The average interest rate on a one-year A.R.M. in the New York metropolitan area fell to 6.02 as of last Wednesday from its recent high of 6.54 percent on Jan. 13, according to HSH Associates. That means the average monthly payment for a new A.R.M. fell $34 on a $100,000 loan, to $601 from $635.
Mr. Sperte of Century 21 added that people shopping for houses had become increasingly sophisticated about different types of mortgages and rate structures. "They are surfing the rates and seem to be waiting for the right time to strike," he said. "This leads us to expect a slowly improving residential market for the remainder of the year."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Housing Sales Just a Bit Off Record 1994 Pace

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
LAST MONDAY Uta and Bob Hershey closed on a 60-year-old English Regency-style house in the Village of Bronxville. For more than six months, they had been looking in the suburbs closest to New York City for a house with "an excellent school system," Ms. Hershey said.
There was a sense of urgency, she added, since they wanted to be ensconced in their new surroundings by the time their son, Bo, started kindergarten in September. 
 Such reasoning makes the Hersheys the prototypical spring buyer who storms real estate offices from March to June so as to be settled in a new home by the start of summer vacations and well before the beginning of the school year.
The spring selling season has traditionally been the busiest time of year for real estate agents who count on it for the bulk of the their annual revenues. The Westchester County Board of Realtors said that first-quarter sales were 10 percent off from the first quarter of 1994, but nevertheless the second busiest first quarter ever after last year's record comparable period. The year as a whole was also a record for the county, the board added.
"Buyers are being cautious right now," said Nancy Seaman, chairwoman of Houlihan/Lawrence, the largest residential real estate company in the county. "For us, we've been a little bit off from last year, but only marginally down. And in the last month or so, things have definitely picked up."
Ms. Seaman, who noted that 1994 was her agency's best year, said that a few of her company's offices were having banner years. "Katonah is hot," she said, "so is Bronxville and Rye has really taken off."
Sometimes, real estate brokers say, it's hard to determine exactly why some communities are doing better than others. For instance, Audrey Rapaport, regional manager of south Westchester for Houlihan/ Lawrence, said that her agents had been working around the clock in the company's Rye office.
"When a house comes on the market in the Rye and Harrison area, it's immediately getting mulitiple offers," she said.
At the beginning of the year, Ms. Rapaport said, her office had the buyers but was waiting for listings.
"We've gotten more listings in the last month, and there's tremendous pent-up demand, especially in the $500,000 to $800,000 price range. We're much busier than this time last year."
APRIL and May were two of the best months ever for Coldwell Banker Schlott in White Plains, according to Joseph Monaco, the office's branch manager. "It's tied to the slide in interest rates," he said. "We've seen activity in all categories. There's been a 50 percent increase in sales volume so far this year."
Communities such as Bronxville, which is known for its school system, have been the traditional sites of a spring selling spurt. While sales this year are steady, "it's not as hectic as last year," said Vera Blendermann, the office manager for Houlihan/ Lawrence.
"We're about 10 percent off from this time last year," she said. "But we planned to be off."
The houses that are selling best now in Bronxville are in the $700,000 to $800,000 price range.
"Last year, it was the $800,000 to $900,000 range," Ms. Blendermann said. "I can't really account for the difference except that people are being extremely careful, due to job uncertainty. They're waiting for interest rates to bottom out. Historically if they go up a quarter point, there's frantic activity."
In some areas, the pace of spring sales has ranged from sporadic to desultory. "It's not last year," said Mary Grimm, partner in C.S. McClellan Real Estate, of Pelham. "We've been seeing spotty activity."
Ms. Grimm said she did not feel that spring lived up to its billing anymore. "You can't judge it like you used to," she said. "We had a wonderful January, February and March when young professionals were getting their Wall Street bonuses. And we're looking to blossom in June and July."
This year, all the brokerage offices in Pelham posted 49 sales from Jan. 1 through June 5 -- 8 more than last year, said Ms. Grimm.
Ms. Grimm said that her office had also benefited from corporate relocations. "They've really helped us to maintain good market activity throughout the year," she said.
It just so happened that Irene and Tony Hutchings closed on their 100-year-old Victorian home in Pelham during the spring season. The couple moved from Boston because of a job change and Pelham was the first place they looked. "It had the Old World charm we were looking for," Ms. Hutchings said. The quality of the school system didn't figure in, since the Hutchings have grown children.
For a while the spring season was hampered by a shortage of inventory, according to Savo Fries, president of the Westchester Multiple Listing Service. "A lot more has come on the market in the last month or so," she said. "There's plenty of inventory now. It's a very diversified market. There are houses from $150,000 to $1 million. Anything in the $300,000's is selling immediately. And the $500,000 to $600,000 houses in the right locations are also moving."
Ms. Fries said she had also noted a return of the second-home buyer in the more rural northern part of the county, people from New York City and other areas. "I guess they figured they've waited long enough and now is the time to buy," she said.
HOUSE prices have been declining, Ms. Fries added. "It couldn't be a better time to buy," she said. In the first quarter of this year, the median price including all four housing categories -- single-family houses, condominiums, co-ops and 2- to 5-family houses -- dropped 4 percent, from $239,000 in the 1994 quarter to $229,900.
Some people who, in previous years, might have looked in Northern Westchester are now zeroing in on Putnam County, according to Natalie Pugliese, owner of a real estate agency in Mahopac that bears her name. "The phones started ringing a few weeks ago as interest rates inched down," she said. "We're getting people with money who are interested in new construction. They're buyers who work on Wall Street. They come here because of the lower taxes and expenses. Distance to Manhattan is not that big an issue."
Ms. Pugliese said that her customers were "getting more conservative, especially if they work for a company."
If they have their own business, she said, they are a little more confident."
Across the river, in Rockland County, news couldn't be better, according to Paul McKearnin, manager of Weichert Realtors, in Pomona. "Our office is up 101 percent in sales from last year," he said. He attributes the increase to his office hiring 11 more sales people. "We now have 46 people," he said. "And there's been good buyer flow."
Another change from last year, Mr. McKearnin said, is a greater interest in high-end properties. "We've been selling well in the $600,000's, which is our high-end," he said. "Of course, the bulk of sales is still in the $175,000 to $230,000 category. We do 50 percent of our business with first-time buyers."
