HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Dual Agency;
When a Brokerage Represents Both Sides in a Deal

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT has become a common sales pitch: Hire our firm to handle your building's leasing, and not only will our brokers funnel the hundreds of tenants they represent to your property, but you will save money when they do.
After all, if the tenant's representative and the leasing agent are from different firms, you would have to pay the tenant's rep a full commission, and the leasing agent a smaller one, usually called an "override." If both those people work for us, the sales pitch goes, you'll pay only one full commission, and we'll worry about how it gets split. 
 The surface logic is irrefutable, and almost irresistible. But it poses one problem: If the landlord is paying less in commission, that means the brokers are earning less. And that, in turn, gives brokers a financial incentive to avoid in-house -- known as "dual agency" -- situations.
"In an in-house deal, everyone takes a bit of a haircut," said Michael E. Gochman, a managing director at the Peter R. Friedman brokerage.
Real estate regulations require that firms inform tenants and landlords of dual-agency situations. And few landlords simply shrug off the potential problems.
"This is one of the great debates," said Kevin R. Wang, a senior vice president of the Mendik Organization, which usually handles its own leasing but recently hired Newmark to lease up its 18-story building at 330 West 34th Street, which is about 25 percent vacant. "Sure, good brokers won't steer a tenant to a building where they make more money, but there's a potential problem nonetheless. It has to do with human nature."
It is a sensitive subject among brokerage firms, particularly those with so many tenants and buildings in their stable that dual-agency situations are unavoidable. The top executives at the Edward S. Gordon Company, one of New York's largest real estate service firms and thus very likely to run into potential conflicts, will not even discuss their dual-agency policies, preferring to say through a spokesman that the firm's commission policies are confidential.
The brokers who will talk generally deny there is any problem. They insist their only concern is matching the right tenant with the right space.
"This is a professional business, and that means you represent your client's interests," said Barry Gosin, Newmark's chief executive. "Otherwise you're a used-car salesman, nothing more."
OTHERS note that even a broker who wanted to follow mercenary motives would be afraid to take the chance.
"It has nothing to do with morals or ethics, but with long-term business sense," said Benjamin Fox, a partner in the New Spectrum store-leasing firm. "What are you going to say if your tenant finds out? It was a great space for you, Joe, but I didn't show it to you because I'd get paid badly?"
And there is probably little doubt that the tenant would find out. Mr. Gochman recently put a tenant into some sublet space that brokers from his firm were handling at 666 Fifth Avenue, at 53d Street. He knew his commission would be smaller than it might have been in another building, but he saw no other choice. Mr. Gochman's firm had the exclusive right to lease the building, but the tenant could have gone with whatever broker came through with the best space.
"You can be sure that if I had not shown them this space, another broker would have," he said.
But despite the disclaimers, many real estate firms have grown uncomfortable enough with the financial disincentives inherent in dual agency deals to do something about them. Cushman & Wakefield was in the vanguard. For more than a decade, it has made up part of the tenant broker's commission shortfall in dual-agency deals, by cutting the amount the firm takes out. And unlike some other agencies, it refuses to ask landlords to help defray the expense.
"You can't tell landlords to pay a premium to deal with your people," said David M. Gialanella, a senior managing director at the firm. "But you also can't disincent the person who procures the tenants."
Other brokerages are reaching the same conclusion. Last year, when Colliers ABR rose from the ashes of a failed merger between Koeppel Tener Riguardi and Abrams Benisch Riker, the new firm set up a commission schedule to tackle the conflict head-on. Normally, the firm takes 45 percent of its brokers' commissions. In a dual-agency deal, it only takes 20 percent; the tenant representative keeps 55 percent, the leasing agent gets 25 percent.
"It makes our brokers totally neutral, and that is an excellent selling point to landlords," said Peter G. Riguardi, the firm's executive vice president.
For now, Williams Real Estate is holding the line on commission splits, instead asking landlords to kick in extra commission money in a dual-agency situation, or promising to reward brokers who take smaller commissions with a lucrative leasing agency assignment down the road. But that policy is not set in stone. "In theory, a broker will always do what's best for the client, but in the real world everyone wants to make a full commission," said Andrew H. Roos, executive vice president of Williams. "We are taking a second look at our policy because no firm wants to think that it is doing anything that can demotivate a broker in any way."
Landlords, meanwhile, are reacting with a combination of trust and practicality. The World Trade Center recently hired the Gordon company to lease some 550,000 square feet in the Twin Towers. Charles E. Maikish, the center's director, doubts there will be any conflicts -- and if there are, he says, they are Gordon's problem as much as his.
"This is a high-profile property, and Gordon wants to demonstrate it can lease it up quickly and effectively," he said. "They know that if I ever suspect a personal economic bias at play, I will consider them in violation of the agency agreement." In other words, the firm would endure a highly publicized dismissal.
Still, Mr. Maikish will pay a small override even if a tenant comes through a Gordon broker, just in case. "Both brokers do have to take a commission reduction in a dual-agency deal, but at least this way they don't take as big a hit," he said.
The dual-agency question is less pressing among retail brokers, in that retailers are less flexible about space and locations than are office tenants. "If a retailer wants to be on 57th and Fifth, you can't talk to him about 48th and Park," said Mr. Fox.
Still, New Spectrum has started distributing 10 percent of its own piece of the commission back to its brokers in dual-agency deals. Garrick-Aug, another store leasing firm, recently started allocating 10 percent of the house take to the leasing agents in dual-agency deals. "We talked about this a long time," said Faith H. Consolo, the firm's managing director. "We finally realized we had to do this so that agents would really promote their space in-house."
Actually, many brokers say that the non-monetary compensations in dual agency deals make up for slimmer commissions. They say the deals go more quickly and are less acrimonious, since neither party wants to humiliate a member of his or her own firm. They say that brokers dealing with their own colleagues are more likely to offer a true rendition of what points are negotiable, and of what rent the building will not go below -- or the tenant will not go above.
"You can go down the hall and say, 'Look, this is what I need to achieve in this deal,' and find out right away if it's doable," said Robert A. B. Baraf, a Gordon managing director who recently put Montgomery Securities into 590 Madison Avenue, at 57th Street, where the Gordon firm handles the leasing. "You don't waste anyone's time by bringing a $20 tenant to a $40 building."
BUT brokers have to walk a somewhat fine line here, too. Telling a tenant's representative that the landlord will take, say, $30 a square foot per year for a space can cut days out of a negotiation, but it certainly lessens that landlord's chances of getting $35. The converse is also true: Admitting that a tenant will go as high as $35 makes it less likely that the tenant will get the space for $30.
"You've got to put up a wall, to make sure that no information is revealed that shouldn't be revealed," said Kenneth Singleton, Cushman & Wakefield's managing counsel.
Most brokers report that, while in theory there may be a problem with breaches in the wall, in actuality both sides to a negotiation are so conversant with going market rents and concession packages that no one can be tricked into giving away the store. All that happens, they say, is that they can dispense with uncertainty.
"What brokers fear most is what they don't know," said Mr. Gochman. "Did another tenant offer a better deal, or does an existing tenant want to expand into the space? The quicker you know about that, the quicker you can look for a backup deal for your tenant. And someone who works for your firm is more likely to tell you."

HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
Faith in Education: A Church Prep School in Newark

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
There are many images associated with this city, but "prep school" is not one of them.
If anything, the thought of education in Newark brings to mind decrepit classrooms and low test scores. The State Department of Education is so unhappy with the city's public schools that it is assuming control of them next year. But even if Newark's schools become the best in New Jersey, the Rev. William D. Watley wants to offer another option. 
 That is why Mr. Watley's congregation at St. James African Methodist Episcopal Church is raising money for a preparatory high school. Although some members of his congregation are unhappy with Newark public schools, he said, the project was not conceived out of anger.
"We simply want to provide a viable alternative for people who want something different," he said. "The idea for our school was not born out of frustration with the system."
The 3,000-member congregation has already collected about $5 million for the project, which is expected to cost about $11 million. An architectural firm in Princeton has designed a building, and Mr. Watley hopes construction will begin late this year.
He said he seized upon the idea of a prep school in the late 1980's, when he was pondering how his church could better serve Newark residents. Although the city has several other private schools, including St. Benedict's Grammar School and St. Vincent Academy, all have extensive waiting lists, he said.
The new school, called St. James Preparatory School, will be open to anyone in grades 9 through 12. It is expected to begin with 250 students and eventually expand to 500.
Mr. Watley said he had decided on a high school because several other Newark churches are planning elementary schools.
"Because of who we are and where we are, the school will probably be mostly African-American," he said. "But we want it to be an option for anyone who wants something different."
The school's board of directors, which includes congregation members and business leaders, has hired educational consultants to help set up a curriculum. It will emphasize foreign languages, international studies and technology, Mr. Watley said. The school will include a Family Development Center that will offer such things as job training and counseling to students and their families.
Tuition has been set at $5,500 for the 1996-97 school year, but Mr. Watley said scholarships would be available. The school will accept not only the brightest students, but also those who receive B's and C's.
"I believe a lot of students fall through the cracks because they're not academic superstars," Mr. Watley said. "If they have the motivation, they can still be productive members of society."
The 55,000-square-foot school will be built next to St. James Church, a 103-year-old stone building on the corner of Martin Luther King Boulevard and Court Street. The lower half will match the exterior of the church, but the rest will be a mix of brick, glass and metal, symbolizing the school's emphasis on technology. The Hillier Group, an architectural firm in Princeton, designed the building.
"We wanted it to embody both the tradition we stand upon and the forward thinking of where we're going," Mr. Watley said. "They put our vision into the bricks and mortar."
Many businesses and foundations have contributed to the cause, but half the donations have come from individuals and families. Elderly members of the St. James congregation have offered cans full of pennies, and children have surrendered their allowances, Mr. Watley said.
Despite the city's depressed economy, he said, he is confident that the millions of dollars still needed will materialize because so many residents are devoted to the project.
"It's a matter of when we do this, not if," he said. "We have to believe our faith and hard work will be justified."

HEADLINE: UP FRONT: CHATTER;
Cutting Taxes: Cost or Benefit?

BYLINE: JEAN RUTTER

 BODY:
Supporters of Governor Whitman's plan to cut the state income tax by another 15 percent say it will distribute the tax burden more fairly and stimulate the economy. Opponents say her timing is unwise, given the possibility of large cuts in Federal aid or a recession, and they claim it will lead to higher property taxes. What do you think?
 
Not Worth the Stress 
 The small amount saved for each individual is not worth the stress that will be placed on municipalities and school systems. This is not responsible government. Governor Whitman will be long gone and will have achieved her political ends before the effects of her shell game are realized.
ED FISCELLA
Blackwood
 
Passing Costs Along
I agree. Those of us who work in municipal government or closely observe the effect of state and even county handoffs like this are not fooled. Much as I appreciate some of Governor's Whitman's measures, I can't condone this "tax cut." It's not a cut. The costs are simply passed along to lower levels of government. She gets away with her shell game because so many school boards and municipal governments are separate legal entities. When schools come in with higher budgetary needs, guess who gets blamed?
KAREN LYNCH
Bloomfield
 
Unfair Impact
When taxes were cut last time, my property tax went up more than my income tax went down. Now, as a result of these tax cuts, the D.M.V. offices will be returned to the patronage mills that they were in the 80's. Our highways are darker and dirtier, essential services are being cut and burdens are being shifted. The income tax is a fair tax because it's progressive. The increased taxes and fees that the income tax cut produced have disproportionately hit people with lower incomes.
JOSH DUBNICK
Hopatcong
 
Paying for Services
Tax cuts are gimmicks to appease voters and supporters. I want services, and I know they cost money. I look to government officials to cut costs and minimize waste, not line their families' and friends' pockets with handouts, and to be honest with the public. I have yet to see it. Governor Whitman is wasting her time. She should really try and lead. She'll be able to eat after her two terms are through.
JOHN N. HAHN
Glen Rock
 
Paying for Stability
Services cannot be reduced much more without instability among the population. The money must come from somewhere. I'll pay the taxes for the well-being of the state.
MARK QUINN
Somerset
 
A Flawed Assumption
To those who insist on believing that a tax cut at the state level must cause a tax increase at the local level: That is true only if it is assumed that the level of services must remain the same. Closed equations are only as good as the assumptions upon which they are based. It is not lower taxes that really bother those who are in favor of higher taxes, it is the lower level of government spending that the lower taxes requires. EDWARD J. ZOHN
Scotch Plains
 
Thanks Anyway
What the income tax cut does is boost Whitman's popularity while sending more of the responsibility for services to the municipalities, meaning higher property taxes. Thanks anyway, Christie, but the extra $50 a year isn't really helping me that much.
JEFFREY COHEN
Highland Park
 
Filling the Gap

SECTION: Section 13NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2441 words

HEADLINE: Perfect Game

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
WELL before the baseball game, the purple sky and the wind-whipped ripples on the Delaware River told of a storm coming. Some of the fans streaming into Waterfront Park to watch the Trenton Thunder play the Binghamton Mets cast anxious glances upward.
If a minor league game means less than, say, the cost of living or the fate of the blue whale, it still means a lot to those who fill the Thunder's idyllic playground, where enthusiasm for the summer game burns as fiercely as the midday sun. 
 A baseball game is fun for Glenn Carter too, but it is much more than that. It is his self-image, his dream. Never mind that at 27, he was the oldest player on the Thunder. On this Saturday night, the relief pitcher was optimistic that his 90-mile-an-hour fastball could carry him to the Boston Red Sox, the Thunder's major league parent, before his arm died.
"I'm never going to give up," he said in his Kentucky drawl. "It might come this year."
Nearly five hours later, he got a chance to show his stuff with a game on the line. Thanks to a 76-minute rain delay in the sixth inning, it was getting on toward midnight by the time the Thunder scored four runs in the eighth to go ahead, 8-7. With the Mets coming to bat in the ninth, Carter was summoned from the bullpen. As he walked to the mound in the late-night chill, the sound-effects man in the press box played "Wild Thing" -- that's Carter's nickname -- on the public-address system.
The sound effects (and accompanying images on the electronic scoreboard) are just part of what draws sellout crowds of 7,000-plus to see Class AA Eastern League baseball -- two steps below the major leagues -- at Mercer County Waterfront Park. There are also dinner prizes for some lucky seat-holders, a free wash for the dirtiest car in the parking lot, and base-running contests between innings pitting children against Boomer, the Thunder's bird-costumed mascot. Somehow, Boomer always trips over his own feet or gets distracted, because he never wins. He is so popular that there is a Boomer fan club for younger children.
If much of this sounds and looks like low-camp, cornball tinsel . . . well, it is. It provides nothing more useful than fun and laughter. And in embracing such frills, minor league clubs like the Thunder -- and the state's other pro baseball franchise, the Class A New Jersey Cardinals in Augusta, Sussex County -- are clearly on to something.
After decades of decline, minor league baseball has suddenly become a viable industry -- an economic-development tool and a source of pride for downtrodden cities like Trenton, a magnet for commerce in the hinterlands of Sussex County. Nationwide, attendance has more than doubled since 1980 -- to 33 million in 1994 -- and demand for franchises has increased 27 percent, acccording to the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, which governs the minor leagues. There is even talk that the minors, with 214 teams, may soon draw nearly as many fans as they did in their golden age -- the late 1940's -- when there were more than twice as many teams.
And just last week, organizers of a brand-new league -- the Atlantic League of Professional Baseball Clubs -- announced plans to put two of its six franchises in New Jersey: in a new stadium in Atlantic City and a renovated one in Newark. That would give the state more minor league teams than at any time in nearly a century.
Though the Atlantic League is a long way from playing its first game, local politicians are exuberant at the prospect and have promised to find ways to raise the necessary capital, at public expense if they have to. "We'll find the money," said Mayor Sharpe James of Newark.
For those who love the intimacy and hometown spirit of minor league ball, it has been a long wait. At their height, in 1949, the minor leagues drew 39 million fans to 448 ball parks. But that fan base soon withered, and as with so many other things that go wrong in baseball, it is easy in retrospect to see why. Many ball parks were allowed to grow shabby, and the prevailing philosophy among team owners seemed to be that the game was the thing, that the prospect of seeing major league players of the future ought to be enough.
It wasn't. For one thing, television allowed the fans to see the major league players of the present in the free comfort of their homes. And more and more people with leisure time and money discovered the joys of pizza parlors, shopping malls, video-rental movies and other post-World War II adornments of American life.
But in the late 1980's and early 90's -- a time when nostalgia for the small-town, Sunday-social America of "Field of Dreams" was sweeping the country -- baseball-loving entrepreneurs began moving into the minor league establishment and making some radical suggestions. The game is supposed to be fun, they said. And the setting should be made a lot more fun.
Trenton's Waterfront Park, with its diversions, sound effects and a special picnic area, is certainly a pleasant (and inexpensive) place to spend a few hours. What is truly splendid about games in the year-old ball park next to the river is that they are played with abandon by young men -- boys, really -- who may still harbor dreams of the big money in the big leagues but have not yet lost their sense of fun.
It has become almost a cliche that some major league players, taking their inflated salaries for granted and sometimes distracted by off-the-field legal problems, have lost touch with everything but their own egos and incentive clauses. It may be unfair to generalize, but cliches have some foundation in truth. There are big league players who are gracious to their adoring fans, and there are others who sulk while earning as much in a season for batting .243 as Joe DiMaggio or Ted Williams did in a career.
At Waterfront Park, there is a smiling rapport between players and autograph hunters who line the rail at the playing field's edge. And the fans have paid no more than $7 for the privilege.
UP in the press box, Bart Mix selects the computer-generated sounds, or "click effects," as he calls them. Often, he confers with Les Trinity, who sits a few feet away and operates the scoreboard.
Mix, a 35-year-old math teacher and wrestling coach at Matawan High School, and Trinity, who is 20 and graduated from Mercer County College, have a wide variety of sights and sounds with which to entertain the fans and taunt the opposition.
The noises and images, some from the barnyard and a few that sound suspiciously like belching and flatulence, occasionally walk the line between foul and fair. When the opposing team's manager and pitching coach go to the mound to confer with the pitcher, Trinity is apt to flash an image of the Three Stooges on the board. Depending on his meanness of the moment, Mix may select the Mickey Mouse Club song or the theme from "Psycho."
"When we're winning, we can do a lot more because the visitors go to the pitcher's mound a lot," Mix said.
During the rain delay, Mix played a medley of songs, including (of course) "Who'll Stop the Rain?"
Just before the game, Glenn Carter had talked of how a reliever had to stay cool and not let mistakes get him down. "Mentally, I'm perfect for the bullpen," he said.
Now, in the top of the ninth, he took his warm-up throws, and the sounds of "Wild Thing" died away.
His first pitch was not wild at all. It was right over the plate, and Binghamton's shortstop, Kevin Morgan, hit it for a clean single. Carter got the Binghamton center-fielder, Jay Payton, to pop up on the next pitch.
Carter threw nine pitches to the third man he faced, Jeff Barry, the Binghamton center fielder, walking him. Then came his worst throw of the night, not toward home plate but to first base, a pick-off attempt that sailed high, letting Morgan race to third. (Straining the boundaries of good-natured ribbing, Mix chose that moment to play "Wild Thing" again.)
Carter struck out the next batter, third baseman Chris Saunders, on six pitches, but then left fielder Jay Davis smacked a single, and Morgan scored. Though the next batter flied out to end the inning, Carter had let the Mets tie the game.
He was far more effective in the 10th, 11th and 12th (the outing was his longest of the season), finding the plate more often, throwing his fastball with the pop he had boasted of earlier and holding the Mets scoreless.
Carter left in the 13th. The Mets scored off his replacement, Scott Bakkum, and Trenton lost, 9-8.
Three fans who stayed to the end were Vanessa Falcone, Kimberly Dale and Valerie Lauer, all 10th graders at nearby Ewing Township High School. Weren't they taking this loyalty thing a bit far?
Not at all, they replied: the players are approachable, courteous "and good-looking." (Their favorite is Jeff Suppan, a tall right-handed pitcher from California who, at 20, is not much older than they are.)
Would the girls return the next day? Silly question. They have season tickets.
In the quiet locker room afterward, Glenn Carter was courteous despite his pain. "I feel bad about losing the lead," he said. "I threw the ball well, but . . ."
BASEBALL Is Life," read the T-shirt of one of the first fans into the park the next day.
If it is life, it is also redemption. In the Sunday sunshine, with the stadium sprinklers watering the grass and the river sparkling like molten silver in the background, the previous night's loss seemed a distant memory.
Stadium crews wiped off the seats, now and then stopping to chat with the players; food vendors began preparing mountains of pizza, hot dogs, cheeseburgers and (yes) peanuts and Cracker Jacks, and one could hear the sounds of chopped ice being nestled around bins of soft drinks and beer.
These happy sounds have been heard along the Delaware since the spring of 1994, when minor league baseball returned to Trenton for the first time in 44 years and to New Jersey for the first time since 1978 -- when the Oakland A's pulled their Jersey City farm team out of the dilapidated Roosevelt Stadium.
The Thunder is owned by Garden State Baseball Limited Partnership, whose principals include Samuel Plumeri. His father was a part-owner of a minor league team of yesteryear, the Trenton Giants, who had a player thought to have some big league potential. (His name was Willie Mays.)
Before 1994, the Thunder played in Ontario as the London Tigers and was affiliated with the Detroit Tigers. It was still part of the Detroit organization when the new owners brought the team to Trenton, but the franchise became affiliated with the Boston Red Sox for this season.
Despite finishing last in the Eastern League's Southern Division in 1994, the Thunder was third in overall attendance. This year, the team has been playing around .500. It leads the league in attendance, having drawn 156,591 fans to its first 29 games.
Down on the field, Glenn Carter confessed to a few aches in his 6-foot, 170 pound frame. Had he shaken off the disappointment?
"Got to," he said. "It's part of baseball." And Carter, a plain-spoken man with a crewcut, loves baseball, likes the fringe benefits ("I've had a lot of free meals in Trenton"), thinks it would help him provide a good life for himself and his girlfriend, even though he was playing at the moment for about $1,500 a month, paid only during the season.
And wasn't he going the wrong way? Last year, Carter pitched for Boston's Triple-A affiliate in Pawtucket, R.I. This year, he was a rung lower. "They're making me into a closer," he explained. "That's why I'm here."
As a starter in Pawtucket, he had an 8-7 record with a 4.79 earned run average in 1994. "But I was 8-2 at one point," he said. Then he got sick, and hits started dropping for the batters he faced.
Now, on this baseball Sunday, his optimism was flowering again. In a dugout chat with coach Rico Petrocelli (the first shortstop to hit two home runs in a World Series game, a feat he accomplished for Boston in 1967, the year Glenn Carter was born), Carter said he could go a couple innings this day if he had to.
"Sure," Petrocelli deadpanned. Then, seeing Carter rubbing a sore muscle, he said, "You should run; get that lactic acid out."
"Want to run a few laps with me?" Carter said.
"I don't have any lactic acid," Petrocelli said, aiming at a spitoon that wasn't there.
And off went Carter and his teammates in a coltish, laughing trot around the perimeter of the stadium.
The Thunder took an early lead and was ahead by 9-2 at the end of six innings, and the crowd was happy indeed.
Ron Martin, an affable Tennessean, watched with more interest than most fans. He is the father of the Thunder catcher, Jeff Martin, who was a month short of 25 and a strapping 6-4 and 220 pounds. What did he think of his son's chances of making it to The Show, -- the big leagues?
"Oh, he's a big, strong kid, and they like that. He's on the right track. With a break here and there. . ."
Of course, the catcher's father agreed, a good break for his son might mean that someone else had had a bad break. Such is life in the world of professional sports. No, the father said. It would not destroy his son if the breaks did not go his way. (But so far, they are. In a bit of a slump lately, Martin was still batting .246 last week, with 2 home runs and 20 runs batted in. And his strong frame is supported by what Tom McCarthy called "the biggest legs I've ever seen.")
The Mets narrowed the margin to 9-7 at the end of eight. The indefatigible McCarthy, who is also the the Thunder's radio announcer, reminded his audience how "last night's game got away."
On came another Trenton reliever, Joe Hudson. He yielded a hit, but he didn't let the game get away. The Thunder won, 9-7, and the fans went home to savor the rest of a sunny day.
GLENN CARTER went home too, to Kentucky the next day, after the Thunder released him. The Red Sox reached the decision after conferring with the Trenton manager, Ken Macha, and the pitching coach, Al Nipper. There was a collective feeling, McCarthy said, that Joe Hudson -- almost three years younger than Carter -- had a better future.
(The Red Sox thought so too. Hudson was called up to the big club just over a week ago, and performed creditably in his first appearance, allowing one hit and getting a strikeout in an inning and two-thirds against Oakland.)
It may be small consolation to Glenn Carter, but he took with him the Trenton record for saves by a pitcher: eight.
"He may latch on with someone else," said Tom McCarthy. "But with his age, it's going to be difficult. I think he knows that."

LENGTH: 1154 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT: OFF THE RACK;
How to Sell Your House in a Hurry

BYLINE: By BRETT BRUNE 

 BODY:
WITH a company transfer in hand, you take the plunge and move up to a more expensive home in a new city. But while you unpack those hundreds of boxes, butterflies crowd your stomach. And they're not just anxieties about a new job in a new place. You still haven't sold your old house. And you're ready to try anything to unload it.
For you and other would-be home sellers, the July issue of Smart Money describes a do-it-yourself home auction in an article titled "Going Once . . . Going Twice . . ." It focuses on one family's intensely trying, though ultimately successful, experience. 
 After a year of getting nowhere with conventional home-selling methods, the family took the advice of William G. Effros, a computer consultant who wrote "How to Sell Your Home in Five Days." The family had one "out" -- the sale could be canceled if the price was disappointing -- but it was still a gamble.
The article makes it clear that Mr. Effros's book could have been called "How to Test the Limits of Your Primary Relationship for Five Days." Because this family succeeds, albeit after summoning Mr. Effros himself to the scene, the magazine plants an idea: Five head-spinning days of playing auctioneer may be better than months of angst trying to sell a home -- for some people.
Also in Smart Money, an update on last year's list of the best and worst discount brokers. Among the 19 brokers ranked by the magazine, Jack White came out on top. The firm was cited for relatively low commissions and a wide array of services.
In the category of broker expertise, K. Aufhauser and Lombard received top marks, and Pacific Brokerage came in last. Steven Wallace, Pacific's president, is quoted as saying that to get up to speed, new hires "just sit next to someone who has been doing it for longer." K. Aufhauser and Lombard, the magazine reports, "train even their brokers licensed by the National Association of Securities Dealers for one and a half and three months, respectively, before they are allowed to handle orders, and then insist brokers take one or two weeks of refresher courses each year."
 
LAND RUSH Office buildings. These two words can clear a room of investors nearly as quickly as yelling "derivatives" can. But after years of problems, commercial real estate is once again being promoted as an attractive investment. In its July cover story, "Timely Picks for Your Portfolio," Kiplinger's quotes a financial analyst from Prudential Securities who calls Highwoods Properties in North Carolina the firm's "single best idea."
The company owns 2 retail properties, 36 industrial properties and 64 office properties, and it recently bought several more, including Forsyth Properties, the biggest owner and developer of office and industrial properties in the Winston-Salem, High Point and Greensboro areas of the state.
The recovery in real estate, now in its early stages, is expected to last beyond 2000, Kiplinger's reports. Beware though, investing in real estate can be dangerous, as both big and small investors learned in the 1980's.
On the insurance front, Kiplinger's suggests that condominium owners; parents of teen-age drivers; people who own pools, boats and large dogs, and families who employ child-care givers and cleaning people consider buying an umbrella policy with $1 million in personal liability coverage.
Phooey, you say? Kiplinger's describes a home owner who had to pay a window washer $1.2 million after he broke his heel in a fall and another who had to pay $1.5 million after a teen-ager struck his head on the swimming pool and became a quadriplegic.
The umbrella policy, generally very inexpensive, doesn't cover all types of claims, like those arising from a position on the board of a nonprofit group, the article notes.
 
A FEE FOR ALL Floridians in particular will want to take note of "Fees from hell: How fiendish is your bank?" in the latest issue of Money. Five of the nation's 10 "most fee-frenzied banks" are in Florida, the magazine concludes in its Your Money Monitor.
In the category of obnoxious corporate behavior, Money had no trouble finding examples. The highly publicized account of a Chicago bank that charges customers for consulting a real person for a transaction is just one.
Another Chicago bank charges its clients a 1 percent commission to deposit their coins. A Colorado bank charges its customers $25 an hour for help solving problems with their accounts.
From a survey of 1,137 banks, the magazine produces a list of the "fee-fattest" banks in each state. Winners of this dubious achievement award include the First Interstate Bancorporation in Washington state, Signet Bank in Washington, D.C., State Bank & Trust in Oklahoma and First Union National in Tennessee.
Also worth reading is the magazine's cover story on getting emotions under control when it comes to money matters. While its approach is far from fresh -- eight things not to do with your money -- the article is an enjoyable overview for people learning the ropes of personal finance.
Among some of the more interesting points made by Money is that people fear a loss more than they should. Along with loss aversion, Money describes the sunk-cost fallacy, which means that once you have paid for an item or service, you can be overly reluctant to waste that service -- another tendency that can lead to poor decisions. And it offers advice. "Evaluate investments solely on their potential for future loss and future gain," it suggests. "Your best bet is to ignore all your feelings about what you paid and calculate only on the basis of current value."
 
DIE AND LET DIE For everyone who believes that life is no dress rehearsal, Worth's cover story is right on track. "Die Broke" stands out in the July/August issue for its thoughtfulness on how to coordinate the end of one's physical and fiscal lives.
It starts off by painting Americans as a pack of fanged beasts obsessed with their parents' money ever since two Cornell University economists "primed U.S. baby boomers to expect the largest collective inheritance in world history." In the end, "Die Broke" states the obvious: it may be more satisfying to give away money while you're alive than after you're gone.
After someone 60-plus deals with long-term care and buys annuities to guarantee a decent income for life, the money left over can be considered free game. Each person is allowed to give another person $10,000 a year free of gift taxes. Bigger gifts can be made without taxes if the money is applied against a $600,000 lifetime exclusion from estate and gift tax. And payments to educational institutions or medical facilities for someone else's current or future bills are also gift-tax exempt.
Worth does not spare the ink to make its case. But for details on the seven financial tools mentioned in "How to use it all up -- safely," readers will need to look elsewhere.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

THE BUDGET
Clinton's Balancing Act
To balance or not to balance, that used to be the question, with Bill Clinton clearly favoring a lopsided budget over the pain of a balanced one. But the slings and arrows of outrageous Republicans proved too painful, and last week the President hummed a radically new tune. O.K., balance it, he said, but do it in 10 years, not 7. His formula: save on Medicare, but not as drastically as the Republicans want; cut taxes for the middle class, not the wealthy; cut welfare, but protect children. But the question remains: Will any of the grand formulas being tossed out in the current political frenzy actually stick for 7 or 10 long years? As one lawmaker put it: if you don't like the President's stance on a given issue, just "wait a few weeks."
 
AUTOS
Fiery Voice at the U.A.W.
When Stephen Yokich first picketed G.M., he was in a stroller. He was, after all, just 22 months old; his mother, a G.M. worker, was pushing. That was in the late 30's, a hot time for union battles. Cut to the 90's: automation, Japanese cars, an economy manically reinventing itself, fading memories of union power. United Auto Workers membership has slumped from 1.5 million in 1979 to perhaps 800,000 today. Mr. Yokich, now 59, wants to change that -- and he just might. Last week he was elected U.A.W. president, and hopes are high that he can bring vigor -- and members -- to the struggling union. He's got a fiery resume -- he was, for one, behind last fall's strike in Flint, Mich., which rippled through plants nationwide. But he's also known as a realist, one who can cooperate with management when the handwriting's on the assembly line.
 
SOFT DRINKS
A Cola With Snob Appeal
It's a time-honored marketing tactic: put some bows and ribbons on it, call it "premium" or "luxury," and double the price. Look at "gold" cards, which quack pretty much like humbler pieces of plastic. Look at Lexuses, which look a lot like Camrys with gold earrings. And now comes -- take a deep breath -- "Royal Crown Draft Premium Cola." It's "rich and smooth," the company says, "with a long-lasting head." It comes in beer-style bottles. "We're inventing a whole new category," Royal Crown's president said. And, yes, a whole new price: up to $4.99 a six-pack. Actually, given the huffing and puffing of the great "cola wars," it's a wonder no one has thought up the "premium" angle before.
 
DRUGS
The Menopause Market
Menopause has clearly arrived as a hot topic. Why? Because all those baby boomers are hitting the relevant age, of course; out of sight, out of mind. And, yes, it's a hot business topic too, as drug makers hover hungrily at the gates to this life passage. So when news came last week -- from The New England Journal of Medicine, of course -- that estrogen therapy lifts the breast-cancer risk by at least 30 percent, drug makers watched carefully. Many experts say the cancer risk is more than offset by estrogen's protection against osteoporosis and heart disease -- a view sure to be embraced by American Home Products, which last year sold nearly $1 billion worth of Premarin, the leading estrogen. It gets complicated, though, for Merck is nearing the market -- a market that will bulge in a few years -- with a drug that treats osteoporosis without hormones. For women caught in this vise, this means the added assault of marketers confusing them even more.
 
MEN AT WORK
Father? What's a Father?
At the risk of sounding like a greeting card: What is a father? (This being His Day, you were naturally wondering this, weren't you?) Don't get soppy or philosophical, though; we're talking statistics, just statistics -- offered by Catalyst, a research group aimed at helping women in business. Does Dad bring home the bacon to two children and stay-at-home, slipper-bearing Mom? A mere 3.1 percent of families fit this cuddly mold in 1993. Fully 10 percent of American husbands are "designated homemakers" (no relation, presumably, to designated hitters), up from 2 percent in 1986. And among households with working parents, those headed by single fathers are increasing fastest. Still, Child magazine, which tracked "father-friendly" companies in 1992, stopped the next year because so few qualified -- or even cared. O.K., back to the football game (or whatever season it is).
 
CYBERSPACE
Between Consenting Computers
On the Senate floor last week, Jim Exon of Nebraska waved a blue binder with a red label reading "Caution." Mr. Exon was shocked to find this "disgusting material" on the Internet, and he and most of the rest of the Senate don't want your children to see it. (Don't ask how many senators sneaked a peek.) So they did what lawmakers tend to do -- voted to impose fines and prison terms on those who distribute "filthy" material over computer networks. A worthy sentiment, surely -- and the lopsided 84-16 vote reflects a distinct fear of being seen as "pro-filth" -- but the whole free-speech issue lurks awfully close by. Cyberspace has created an odd new mix of public and private, and private communication between adults has always been sacred territory. Even Orrin Hatch, that pillar of conservatism, denounced the measure, saying, "It's a political exercise, and I'm against it."
 
THE MILITARY
Let Them Eat Missiles
Starting in the early 80's -- you remember, when we didn't worry about spending money we didn't have -- this nation spent more than $35 billion on a "Star Wars" missile defense, with little to show for it. So you'd think those Republicans hell-bent on balancing the Federal checkbook would apply their austerity here, too -- especially with the cold war over. But no -- even while slashing everywhere else, the House last week added $628 million to the anti-missile allotment. The rationale: the cold war's end means greater risks of missiles from rogue nations, and thus more need for that fabled "missile shield." If, that is, it works.
 
POSTAL SERVICE
Moving New York's Mail
Good news, New Yorkers: those 17 catalogues and 14 credit-card offers that are jammed daily into your mailbox are arriving a bit faster this year. (Oh, yes, the real mail is, too -- when you can find it amid the junk.) The Postal Service said last week that New York no longer languishes at the bottom of the nation's big-city mailbag in on-time delivery -- with 83 percent of mail arriving punctually, up from 62 percent last year. Westchester is another matter, though -- the county's mail service ranks second from the bottom nationally, with only San Juan, P.R., below it.
 
MERGERS
I.B.M.-Lotus: Teamwork?
So I.B.M. buys Lotus. What does it get for its $3.5 billion? Clearly, what it hopes to create, with Lotus's Notes software, is a team powerful enough to play in Microsoft's league. But that will be a disjointed team indeed if, as promised, Lotus remains a private enclave within Giant Blue. Louis Gerstner, I.B.M. chairman, is all for a big, solid front. But with separate sales forces and software teams, "there is simply no way," one business professor said, that I.B.M. can "make this deal pay off." So the surprising independence granted Lotus managers may soon be in name only. . . . Microsoft, meanwhile, got some good news. An antitrust deal it cut with the Justice Department had been tossed out in court, but a Federal appeals court reinstated it -- and took the judge who'd rejected it off the case.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Helping the Renaissance Ballroom Live Up to Its Name

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
On a recent gray morning at 138th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard, the Renaissance Ballroom looked like a ghostly reminder of its former glittering self -- the only remaining evidence of its heyday a sagging marquee and a faded sign for the Chinese restaurant that used to be one floor up.
Just down the block, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts was halfway through a glazed doughnut in his office at the Abyssinian Baptist Church, waxing lyrical about what the ballroom will be like once the church's development corporation is through restoring it. 
 "With all of this development, there's no place for a young girl to have a sweet 16, for a young couple to get married, for old-timers to do the Lindy Hop," Mr. Butts said between bites. "A community is more than housing, it's more than business. It's culture. People have got to have a place to laugh, sing and dance."
The Abyssinian Development Corporation has already raised close to $1 million from public and private sources for the ballroom's renovation, which is expected to start by year's end and cost $9 million.
Built in 1921, the Renaissance Ballroom -- known affectionately as "the Rennie" -- was the dance hall that popularized black music and drew Lindy-lovers from all over the world. It was the stage for the big band sounds of jazz giants like Cab Calloway, Count Basie and Duke Ellington. And the home court for the all-black New York Rens basketball team (named after the ballroom) before African-Americans were allowed into the National Basketball Association. It was also where former Mayor David N. Dinkins and his wife held their wedding reception, more than 30 years ago.
The adjacent Renaissance Theater offered plays featuring Paul Robeson and movies by film makers like Oscar Micheaux.
And, of course, there was the China House above, which Mr. Butts would like to see re-emerge as a Red Lobster. "Black people love seafood," he said. "It's a great family restaurant."
After the Ensign Bank, the savings and loan association that owned the ballroom, went bankrupt, the Abyssinian group bought the 40,000-square-foot property for about $300,000 from the Federal Resolution Trust Corporation. It has been vacant since 1979.
On Friday, the Abyssinian group hosted its Harlem Renaissance Day of Commitment, a day of corporate networking and cultural events on West 138th Street that organizers expected to generate $250,000. Although money from the day's festivities were intended to support and celebrate the development corporation's work in general, organizers and participants clearly had the Rennie in mind as a goal.
"It's the symbol of what the Renaissance Ballroom stands for, as far as our community is concerned," said George Weldon, who heads the Harlem Business Alliance, runs a funeral home and has contributed toward the Rennie's renewal. "We need not only to leave our children a legacy of love, but a legacy of economic empowerment, and we can't do that if we don't own anything."
 ROBIN POGREBIN

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Warrior for the Bodega Owners

BYLINE: By ADAM NOSSITER 

 BODY:
SEATED AT A PLAIN table in a boxy, bare-walled storefront office in a nondescript section of Bellerose, Queens, Richard Lipsky is the picture of modesty. Soft-spoken and professionally self-effacing, he describes himself merely as someone "paid to make arguments," an idealist engaged in nothing more subversive than a "cheering-up process."
Shift the scene to municipal buildings and executive suites, and the picture of Mr. Lipsky cast by city planners, nutrition advocates and supermarket executives turns dour. He is an obstructionist extraordinaire, they say, a kind of Luddite hired-gun opponent of progress and big stores who stirs baseless fears among the small merchants he organizes and represents. 
 "He's a very capable and articulate lobbyist whose mission is to prevent the opening of retail stores in New York City," Joseph Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, said.
As the executive director and sole staff member of the Neighborhood Small Business Association, Mr. Lipsky fancies himself the David battling the Goliath of the supermarket chains. His role representing Hispanic owners of bodegas and small supermarkets in the recent cacophonous fight over a Pathmark supermarket in East Harlem gained him his greatest visibility yet. Even though Mr. Lipsky lost a major battle in that fight when the Manhattan Borough Board approved the project, his supporters -- whose stores are generally in the 3,000- to 6,000-square-foot range -- still credit him with being thorough in his facts and lean and mean on the attack.
Among New York lobbyists Mr. Lipsky is a small fish, not even coming close to the city's top 10 for 1993, the last year for which comparative statistics are available. Last year, he earned $96,000 from clients like the grocers, the Empire State Beer Distributors and the Uniformed Firefighters Association. Still, to his opponents, Mr. Lipsky, 48, seems ubiquitous, and indeed he can be found at the center of many fights over big supermarkets these days, all over the city -- Springfield Gardens, Astoria, the Bronx.
The Giuliani Administration finds Mr. Lipsky a particularly frustrating adversary. Mr. Giuliani -- who must still grant final approval to the East Harlem Pathmark project and could be Mr. Lipsky's last hope in that fight -- has proposed zoning changes that would make it easier for big stores to locate in New York, and Mr. Lipsky has fought them every step of the way. Since the early 1980's, when he got started, Mr. Lipsky has been involved in about eight supermarket fights, he says, winning over half -- a tally difficult to guess listening to his riled but respectful opponents.
His detractors accuse him of exaggerating the effect of big markets on small ones and, by insisting that Hispanic merchants would be harmed in a project led by blacks, of injecting race into the struggle. "He framed it, he invented it," said one city official, who insisted on anonymity. "Lipsky's signal contribution to the East Harlem Pathmark fight was to make it a racial issue."
The critics offer no solid proof for the charge, and Mr. Lipsky and his supporters deny it vigorously. For his part, Mr. Lipsky, who holds a doctorate in political science from the City University of New York, said the charges stem from being vocally "concerned that you have a successful minority business class, and people didn't give a damn about that." But he insists he is not a blind obstructionist.
"We don't want to be in opposition to everything that comes down the pike," he said. "We want a seat at the table."
With pained smiles, the lobbyist's foes acknowledge with grudging respect that, at the very least, he has succeeded in gaining one. Not surprisingly, the critics accuse him of cynicism; they say he is hindering efforts to ease the burdens of poor New Yorkers forced to pay more in cramped stores for lower-quality groceries. Mr. Lipsky will come back with emotionally compelling counterarguments about the need to nurture immigrant entrepreneurs and preserve neighborhood stores. Whatever the case, Mr. Lipsky manages to promote enough concern among the small supermarket owners that any big merchant wanting to do business in the city needs to take care.
Some of his technique was on display at the City Club in April, when Mr. Lipsky faced off against Mr. Rose and Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter. Like a hunter bragging about the big game he has bagged, Mr. Lipsky began by citing one of his trophies: a proposed Pathmark on Zerega Avenue in the Bronx he shot down in the early 1980's.
To the officials' cool recitations of the economic benefits to be derived from big stores, Mr. Lipsky countered in a relentless monotone with fearful talk of crime, traffic and transiency. But some city officials say Mr. Lipsky is needlessly stirring up such fears. "When someone proposes to open a store, he goes and organizes the local merchants and sows panic among them," one official said.
Mr. Lipsky acknowledges that most of the time he contacts merchants when a proposed store looms, rather than the other way around. "These projects are not advertised," he said. "If you're going to stop them, you need lead time."
Then comes the work of getting the merchants organized, cheering them up and informing them. He meets with his "guys," as he calls them, once a month, "when I get paid." Good organization is essential. "If I'm going to be successful, I have to get my own guys in cohesion and then look for allies in the community."
Alfredo Rodriguez, a Harlem small supermarket owner who is president of the Neighborhood Small Business Association, said Mr. Lipsky "analyzed every single store" in the area before the East Harlem Pathmark vote. But as the fight heated up, Mr. Lipsky met with his clients less and less, Mr. Rodriguez said, because the lobbyist's race became a liability. "Why are you letting this white man represent you?" Mr. Rodriguez said Pathmark supporters would ask.
Mr. Lipsky's defeat in that battle rankles him, but it hasn't shaken Mr. Rodriguez's faith. "He believes in our survival," Mr. Rodriguez said.
 
STORE WARS
A Lobbyist's Ups and Downs

 Early 1980's Long-planned Pathmark on Zerega Ave. in Unionport, the Bronx, is not built.

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
In the Age of Megalopolis

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS 

 BODY:
THE ARCHITECT Robert A. M. Stern has written a chronicle of New York City's changing face that fills three hefty volumes, weighs more than 15 pounds and has five times as many pages as the Manhattan phone book. And he hasn't even finished with the 20th century, much less started the 19th.
"New York is not tidy and neat," says Mr. Stern, who just turned 56 and lives on the Upper East Side. 
 Nor static. The first three volumes of what he now envisions as a five-volume project graphically capture the controlled chaos that passes for planning in New York. By analyzing architecture, the art of public space and the people who use it, the books also chart what may be an inevitable, if disturbing, metamorphosis of New York's from its gilded age as the nation's dominant city to its new status as merely one component -- if, surely, the primary one -- of a still-emerging megalopolis that goes well beyond the tri-state region.
"It's the dominant place," Mr. Stern says. "It still sets the agenda, but its actual economic clout? That's the question. To answer whether it's waning, wait for my next book."
The genesis of the project was an essay Mr. Stern wrote in 1980 for the centennial of Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture, Planning and Preservation, where he is a professor.
"I thought, well, there's a book here," he recalled. "There had been a number of books of modest size but considerable interest to me on London in 1900. I started to write more and it just came out. But it's not as if this developed according to a divine plan. My buildings are organized in a premeditated way. My life is not."
He wrote "New York 1900: Metropolitan Architecture and Urbanism 1890-1915" with Gregory Gilmartin and John Massengale. "New York 1930: Architecture and Urbanism Between the World Wars," was written with Mr. Gilmartin and Thomas Mellins. (Both were published by Rizzoli.) The latest volume, "New York 1960: Architecture and Urbanism Between the Second World War and the Bicentennial," was written with Mr. Mellins and David Fishman and was published earlier this year by Monacelli Press.
Why 1960? That year, Mr. Stern says, signaled a turning point in the city's architectural evolution, a shift from waning Classicism hastened by a new zoning ordinance that, he wrote, "virtually legislated Modernist urbanism" with its bonuses for setbacks and plazas.
Then in 1961, Mr. Stern recalls, Jane Jacobs published her "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," a celebration of the "ballet of the street" and a manifesto against "the pseudoscience of planning" -- the impact of which will be reflected more in a future book, "New York 2000."
Indeed, Mr. Stern says, one consequence of that doctrine is the difficulty in getting anything big built, and today, "New York needs a large project."In rebuilding the West Side highway, he says, "all solutions are being trashed in the Balkanization of communities." Mr. Stern says that Ms. Jacobs and Robert Moses were both power brokers. And their struggle endures, a struggle that the authors describe as between "New York as the grandest metropolis in the world on the one hand and as the world's biggest village on the other."
In the politics of the 1960's, he says, community participation in planning "was seen as a way to break the stranglehold of a moribund city government."
"But the consequences have not been completely sanguine. In terms of architecture and urbanism, we've gone so far that it's difficult to imagine building a large-scale project. Look at Westway -- every community along the way feels that that portion of the waterfront belongs to it, instead of to all of us."
Mr. Stern's studies are more than coffee table books to be strategically placed as intellectual props or as an elevated perch for canapes. For one thing, they are sturdy enough to be a coffee table. The latest has 1,213 pages of text and pictures, 134 pages of scholarly notes and a 26-page index.
The book offers a composite history of New York's streetscape, not just in midtown and lower Manhattan, but encompassing a range of architecture, from urban renewal in Harlem to airport terminals in Queens.
"Amazingly enough, I thought there aren't that many interesting buildings," Mr. Stern said, in reflecting on the research for "New York 1960." But in surveying the city he and his collaborators found plenty of examples of notable architecture since 1945 -- some of them, unhappily, structures that replaced the very buildings that had been featured in his earlier two books.
They devoted an entire chapter in "New York 1960," to preservation, as a warning.
"We've lost an awful lot even with preservation," he says, referring to the city's landmarks law. (He would confer official landmark status on the stretch of Park Avenue that is graced by, among other buildings, Gordon Bunshaft's Lever House and Ludwig Mies van der Rohe's Seagram Building and might even include the over-sized old Pan Am (now Met Life)Building "as a kind of wagging finger at New York: 'Let not greed take over.' ")
Mr. Stern largely made his mark as a post-Modernist residential architect and has never designed a major project in Manhattan, although his firm has a number of commercial buildings in design.
"I don't have a favorite building," he says diplomatically. His least favorites, though, are the Modernist office towers, which his book dismisses as bland and banal.
Meanwhile, Mr. Stern is engaged in assessing the 19th century and the city's development after the Civil War for "New York 1876" before going back to the future to finish "New York 2000." He usually works on the books up to five hours each weekend day, drawing on his knowledge and research by his collaborators to write a first draft, then polishing it with his co-authors.
"The nice thing about writing history," Mr. Stern says, "is you don't have to solve the problems."
 
 
 
MID-CENRURY SNAPSHOTS: Bits and Pieces From 'New York 1960'
In the 50's and 60's the city's office buildings, restaurants and neighborhoods change swiftly. Here are some examples:
 
* An office building boom is fueled in part by the need for more sophisticatedoffice space, a result of the new dependence on complex and changing electronic technology.
 
* Lever House, 53d St. and Park Ave. (1952) announces a transformation of American corporate architecture, which becomes a play of light and shadow on glass.
 
* CBS Building (1965) sets the shape and standard for building in the city with its reinforced concrete tower sheathed in black granite rising without setbacks from a plaza.
 
* By the 1950's, with the notable exception of Chock Full o' Nuts, most fast-food restaurants had beguin taking on a warmer look, using naturally finished wood and replacing bar stools with chairs.
 
* In the 50's and early 1960's, a new Upper West Side emerges -- less desirable to the upwardly mobile middle class but a viable location for the Puerto Ricans pouring into the city.

HEADLINE: The New Gulf War: Man Your Computers

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
TWO feet of rain had fallen around New Orleans at the height of last month's fierce Gulf storm, shutting down regular air service into the city, and still the oil executives kept coming. One group hired a private jet and then a helicopter. Others had to abandon their car to wade through water up to their necks, holding their briefcases high to keep them dry.
The Government was selling oil and gas leases in the Gulf of Mexico and a little derring-do to get to the auction site was a small price to pay for a piece of the action. When the bidding was over at the Interior Department's Minerals Management Service office in the flooded suburb of Metairie, the executives had forked over $307 million for drilling rights -- nearly triple what the Government had expected. 
 The Great Oil Rush of the mid-1990's is on, and in a most unexpected setting.
As recently as three years ago, many oil executives described the Gulf of Mexico as a dead sea, a played-out place where production could only fall and drilling for new reserves would be futile. Now there is a growing conviction that the gulf holds reserves even larger than those in Alaska's Prudhoe Bay, the last huge domestic discovery. And no one wants to be left behind.
"There's a lot of money to be made out there," said John H. Miers, vice president of the Amoco Worldwide Exploration Business Group.
The intense bidding last month by Amoco and other industry giants like Shell, Mobil and British Petroleum shows just how much money is at stake -- and how alive the gulf has suddenly become.
Starting to dot the horizon are billion-dollar rigs that can bring oil up in waters that are thousands of feet deep. Shell is the acknowledged leader on that front. Meanwhile, exploration ships like the New Venture ply the shallower waters, searching for overlooked pockets of oil and gas in older fields and new treasures long hidden under thick layers of salt that cover some parts of the gulf's bottom. A joint venture involving Amoco, Phillips Petroleum and Anadarko Petroleum has scored big in that area.
Behind the rebirth are broad technological advances in rig construction and prospecting techniques. One day recently, for example, the New Venture was trolling for oil 50 miles off the coast of Galveston, Tex., by using a pair of on-board supercomputers to turn seismic readings into three-dimensional models of deposits buried 15,000 feet beneath the gulf's floor.
Also pushing the turnaround has been the industry's slow progress in developing the huge reserves of the politically unstable former Soviet Union -- where today's oil rush was supposed to have taken place.
Having taken another look at prospects closer to home, industry executives are now smiling. Below all the layers of salt on the gulf's continental shelf and the inky mile-deep waters further out lie fields far exceeding the 12 billion barrels at Prudhoe Bay, according to some projections. The gulf's deep-water reserves alone have been estimated as high as 15 billion barrels. Billions of barrels more are thought to be in the shallower waters.
"It will be the biggest thing since Prudhoe Bay -- there is no question about it," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the New York-based Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
Oil production in the gulf will increase from about 900,000 barrels a day this year, or 17 percent of total domestic output, to about 1.6 million barrels a day by 2000, or about 28 percent of the country's output, according to Mr. Lichtblau's projections.
With the United States dependent on foreign sources for about half of its oil, a surge in gulf output would give the country some help against any moves by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to cut production and raise oil prices, now hovering at around $19 a barrel.
It should also give the oil companies more time in which to nail down the kind of contractual and legal protections that they would need before investing heavily in Russia and other former Soviet republics, where proven reserves already total about 57 billion barrels.
The industry will also profit from exporting the technological tricks that it is learning to play in the gulf. They may eventually be put to use in deep-water fields in the North Sea, parts of the Pacific and off the coast of West Africa, among other places.
Another likely beneficiary is the gulf's regional economy, long heavily dependent on the energy industry, which suffered in the 1980's as domestic oil production tumbled in the face of low prices and dwindling production. The industry's domestic work force has been sliced in half -- to about 450,000, from 920,000 in 1982 -- while hundreds of small companies in the region have gone under or been forced to merge.
Now, things are going the other way, with struggling companies starting to revive and new ones sprouting up, like Petroleum Geo-Services, which operates the New Venture and 12 other high-tech ships like it.
The company was founded in 1991 by eight partners who worked out of an office in Houston that they borrowed from another company at night. P.G.S. now has a workforce of 1,100, mostly deployed in the gulf but also in the North Sea. Its revenues have surged, reaching $258 million last year. Its stock price has also soared, from $11.75 when the company went public in 1993 to the high 20's. On the Nasdaq exchange, it closed Friday at $29.375, up 25 cents.
Still, the Gulf of Mexico will never be America's answer to the Persian Gulf, around which are countries with about 663 billion barrels. The United States' dependence on imported oil is expected to continue to grow, even with the Gulf of Mexico producing more, just not as quickly. Rosy projections about the size of reserves here could fade. And further technological refinements will be needed to add to the reach of the current generation of deep-water rigs.
But none of that is taking away any of the gulf's glow in industry eyes.
"You don't have to worry that the U.S. Government will expropriate your fields or that war is going to break out," said James Stone, the oil industry analyst for Wertheim Schroder & Company.
Reidar Michaelsen, chairman of Petroleum Geo-Services, added, "The companies went to Russia and little has happened. Now they're coming back to the gulf because this is the cheapest oil they can produce. It's in their backyard and they have most of the infrastructure in place."
The shallow waters of the gulf are dotted with scores of production platforms and crisscrossed with hundreds of miles of pipelines. Except for exploration and drilling costs, companies generally have to make little added investment to get more production out of equipment that has long been paid for.
"You have the platforms, you have the pipelines," said Amoco's Mr. Miers. "If you can find some oil, it's very cheap to produce it."
So, who is finding it, or is likely to?
In deep-water drilling, to some extent everybody is playing catch-up to Shell. The company operates the current deep-water record holder, the Auger platform, which is tethered to the gulf floor in water half a mile deep. The $1.2 billion rig went into production more than a year ago, and several of its wells are true gushers, yielding oil in record daily volumes for the gulf. Shell is set to launch another deep-water rig next year and is joining Exxon and Amoco to build a third, at a cost of nearly $1 billion.
Some companies are behind in building the deep-water platforms, which are floating hulls tethered by steel tendons to barn-size anchors.
Still others, like Mobil, are even further behind because their exploration sites are few in number or from the second tier, shortcomings that came about in part because until recently they did not seem to matter. But Mobil, for one, has been moving to catch up, bidding aggressively to win leases on some choice blocks at last month's Government sale.
"We didn't have as good a position in the deep water as we would have liked," said Robert White, president of Mobil Exploration and Producing U.S. Inc.
Mobil has also teamed up with Enserch Exploration Partners Ltd., a smaller independent oil company that has been active in the gulf's deep water, buying a 40 percent interest in one of its prospects. The two companies will sink six exploration wells this year in fields 2,800 feet below the surface.
In shallower waters, Amoco, Phillips and Anadarko are the stars because they scored the first commercial success in finding oil under layers of salt. Such finds, called sub salt deposits, had been impenetrable to seismic surveys until ways were found to harness computers to decipher the soundings.
In fact, whether searching in older fields or in new sub salt areas, high-tech gear and knowledge are essential.
"The industry is now being driven by technology," said David Simon, the group chief executive of British Petroleum.
The new approach is a far cry from the industry's colorful past, when wildcatters would jump for joy when they hit a gusher in the field. Now the excitement often comes in offices full of computer screens and printouts where the silence is broken only by the sound of hands tapping keyboards.
Similarly, the current surge is being led by executives who are spending less time in the field and more time with laptops analyzing data.
Bennett Z. Spevack, Amoco's exploration manager for Europe and the United States, has spent the past five years with a 15-member team analyzing parts of a sub salt section of the gulf that covers about 9,000 square miles. Much of the section is 80 to 100 miles off the coast of Texas and Louisiana, where the water is only about 150 to 400 feet deep.
For years these areas remained a mystery because the sound waves sent by exploration equipment were severely distorted by the salt layers, preventing geologists from getting a clear picture of what was below.
Then along came the new technology. Now, extensive seismic surveys take individual "pictures" of small slices of terrain. These are then run through supercomputers, which use programs supplied by geologists to adjust the images to compensate for the distortion of the sound waves. Ultimately, the geologists create a three-dimensional model of the survey area that they interpret based on past experience.
"Basically, it has given us a much clearer picture of what's down there," said Mr. Spevack, looking at a survey image on a computer screen at Amoco's headquarters in Houston.
Nevertheless, he cautioned, the models are partly based on inferences made by his staff and are far from foolproof.
In spite of the uncertainty, there has already been a payoff, in the Mahogany section of the exploration area. In that section, about 80 miles off the Louisiana coast, intense surveying led a team from Amoco, Anadarko and Phillips to drill in the fall of 1993, finding a field 15,000 feet beneath the gulf floor that could have reserves of 100 million barrels or more.
A second well, sunk last fall to a depth of 19,100 feet, also hit oil and gas deposits that are being brought to the surface in commercial amounts. The three companies, as well as others in the industry, are becoming convinced that the $200 million being spent on the project can be recovered and a hefty profit can be made.
The approach being used to explore at Mahogany is far different from what was typically employed in the past, when a well was simply drilled if some formations looked promising. Costs were not as high as today because the drilling didn't have to go as deep. That approach led to thousands of dry wells in the 1980's.
"We were dreamers," Mr. Spevack recalled. "Now we're more focused and constrained by the data." With sub salt wells costing from $13 million to $15 million each, a company can't afford to come up with too many dry ones.
"This is the most significant discovery in shallow water in the gulf in the last decade," said John W. Laird, an Amoco geologist who helped put together the Mahogany find. "The risk was very high and it worked."
There have been big payoffs as well for others who have been betting on the gulf, especially those who jumped in when the odds were long.
That is the case for the partners at Petroleum Geo-Services, who have been successful in using the new technology to greatly drive down the cost of surveying.
One of them, Bjarte Bruheim, gave up a high-paying position as vice president of marine operations at Schlumberger Ltd. to join the new venture. As president and chief operating officer of P.G.S., Mr. Bruheim, who is Norwegian, got stock options in the new company. He now owns about 250,000 shares, a stake that is worth more than $7 million.
The secret to the partners' success, he said, was that they did not listen to the common wisdom that the gulf was dying. "No banks would lend us money, no one would listen to us in Houston," he recalled. "But you can still make it if you stick together and stick to your idea."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Orange County Gets A Message

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
What would you do if someone owed you a lot of money and showed no intention of paying it back? Would you lend more money?
That's what municipal bond investors did last week, as they lent $295 million to bankrupt Orange County, Calif., which shows every intention of stiffing its previous lenders. Orange County, as you no doubt recall, went broke by speculating on interest rates and is in bankruptcy court trying to weasel out of its obligations. 
 Looked at in isolation, the buyers last week got a pretty good deal. Orange County's latest bond issue was insured by MBIA, the nation's largest municipal bond insurer, and locks up some revenue streams that might otherwise have gone to pay the creditors that the county wants to avoid paying. The county paid a premium of about one-quarter percentage point over normal rates.
But the lending also sent a message to the county, that money will be available to it in the future no matter what it does about its past debts. Next week the county's voters are expected to turn down a proposal to raise sales taxes by one-half of a percent. Without that, default looms.
That message should surprise no one. To be sure, the bond industry has been talking tough, threatening not to lend any more money to Orange County, and maybe not to anyone in California, unless the state and the county live up to their responsibilities. But this market's history is one of a total inability to act tough when confronted with the most outrageous conduct. Never forget the Washington Public Power Supply System, a group of local utilities that was able to borrow again only shortly after walking away from its obligations and getting the State Supreme Court to approve the repudiation.
Still, it is breathtaking to see MBIA, a company that has the most to lose from a widespread repudiation of obligations by municipalities, stepping up to guarantee the bonds of a deadbeat that is certainly wealthy enough to pay but whose elected leaders see no reason why it should do so.
The money from this bond issue will go to pay off the local agencies, like school districts, whose money was gambled away by the county. Neil Budnick, the MBIA man on the deal, explains that without the bond issue, a lot of school districts would have defaulted, bringing "chaos that is in no one's interest." Mr. Budnick adds that MBIA got four times its usual fee for insuring the Orange County deal, and says other bond insurers were bidding for the business. Of course, Orange County has done wonders for MBIA's stock price, which has soared on the theory that more bond buyers will want insured bonds.
Joe Mysak, the editor of Grant's Municipal Bond Observer, thinks this could lead to a historic reversal in which revenue bonds, those backed by a project like a toll bridge, yield less than comparably rated general obligation bonds. After all, those bonds have something that may be seized by angry creditors.
California tax-free muni bond mutual funds have seen some money flow out this year. But a lot is left, and it will be invested. Some funds may, for a time, refuse to buy new Orange County paper, which will have to carry a small extra yield, but then they will lag in the yield sweepstakes to those that do, and the money will go to the buyers. If Orange County finds a way to stiff holders, it will not be punished by the markets.
When it comes to forgiving, only an indulgent mother can match the muni bond market.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Barbara B. Hauptman, Jonathan Falk

 BODY:
Barbara Barbat Hauptman, the executive director of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation in New York, was married yesterday to Jonathan Slotin Falk, a senior consultant at National Economic Research Associates in New York. Jack Gilpin, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Yale Club in New York.
Ms. Hauptman, who is keeping her name, graduated from the University of Texas at Austin and received a master's degree in arts administration from Yale University. She is the daughter of Ruth Patterson Barbat of Dallas and the late George Washington Barbat. Her father was a salesman for Tussy/Dorothy Gray cosmetics in Houston. Her mother, who is retired, was an independent employment counselor in Dallas. The bride's first marriage ended in divorce. 
 Mr. Falk graduated from Yale, from which he also received a master's degree in economics. He is a son of Charlotte Falk of Reno and Washington Falk 3d of Atlanta. His father is a real estate investor in Atlanta.
